DOC.HEAD: Plane Crashes Near Stapleton Airport
DOC.TEXT: A Federal Express airplane crashed and burned Tuesday evening in a residential area near Stapleton International Airport, killing the pilot, officials said. There were no reports of injuries on the ground. The aircraft, which had been en route from Aspen to Denver, went down several blocks from the southeast end of the airport. The plane crashed into a back yard near an alley, and did not hit any buildings. The pilot was the only person aboard the single-engine Cessna 208 Caravan, said airport spokesman Jack McGuire. A city firefighter said the pilot was killed. At the time of the crash, the temperature was just below freezing and the weather included a combination of sleet, rain and snow grains, the National Weather Service said. Laura DeMorrow, who lives near the crash site, said she saw the plane sputtering and spiraling slowly towards the ground. DeMorrow said she then saw a large fireball. ``I saw flames and smoke,'' then ran inside to call police, she said. DeMorrow said it sounded like the plane was stalling as it plunged to the ground. Police erected barricades, and put up yellow rope to keep back hundreds of curious spectators. Federal Express spokesman Armand Schneider said the plane had been flying from Aspen to Denver, and was operated under lease by PM Air of Phoenix. A Federal Express single-engine plane operated under lease by PM Air crashed Jan. 17 into a mountain while flying packages from Denver to Montrose, killing the pilot.

DOC.HEAD: Northrop Pleads Guilty to Falsifying Tests on Harrier Jet, Missile Parts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with company statement, comment from government attorney and details of indictment and resolution of charges against other defendants. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Northrop Corp. pleaded guilty Tuesday to nearly three dozen federal counts related to falsified testing of parts for the AV-8B Harrier jet and cruise missile components, and agreed to a $17 million fine. In a plea bargain, the defense contractor entered guilty pleas through attorney Richard Sauber to 34 counts of making false statements to the government. Assistant U.S. Attorney William Fahey called the resolution of the case ``a very significant victory in our efforts to combat defense contractor fraud and mismanagement.'' Prosecutors said charges would be dropped against Joseph Yamron, 62, vice president and general manager of Northrop's Norwood, Mass.-based Precision Products Division, and Leopold Engler, 60, vice president of instrument operations there. Earlier in the day, Charles Gonsalves, a former Northrop Corp. plant manager, pleaded guilty in U.S. District Court to charges of falsifying test data on components of cruise missile guidance systems. ``The U.S. government and Northrop Corp. reached a complex compromise today under which the government agreed to withdraw various charges the company had been contesting for over a year, and Northrop in turn agreed to pay a $17 million dollar fine for charges arising out of actions by some employees it subsequently fired in 1987 from its now closed Western Services Department,'' Northrop said in a statement issued from its headquarters. Northrop asserted that, according to the military services that use the Harrier and the cruise missile, ``both systems have performed satisfactorily in flight operations.'' Regarding the Western Services Department and Precision Products Division, the company said the government dropped 139 counts of making false statements and two counts of conspiracy, and Northrop agreed to plead guilty to 34 false statements that had been made by the former employees at the department. Gonsalves entered the plea under an agreement with prosecutors under which he would be sentenced to no more than three years in prison and be fined a maximum of $1.2 million. Gonsalves, once supervisor of the Western Services Department, pleaded guilty to one conspiracy count and seven counts of making false statements to the government from 1984 to 1987. Sentencing was set for May 1 before Judge Pamela Ann Rymer. Northrop Corp. and five current and former employees were indicted April 11, 1989, on charges of conspiring to defraud the government through the cruise missile and the Navy's AV-8B Harrier jump jet program. Gonsalves entered his plea pertaining to the cruise missile systems as a jury was about to hear the case against him, quality assurance supervisor Cheryl Hannan and Northrop on charges related to the Harrier parts. Prosecutors agreed to a diversion program for Hannan, who was charged in both the Harrier and missile aspects of the case, and charges will be dropped if she completes the program to the satisfaction of probation officials. Howard Hyde, chief engineer at Western Services, pleaded guilty last May to charges involving falsifying tests on the jet parts. The 167-count indictment charged that the company and five others conspired between the 1970s and 1989 to install parts for the cruise missile's flight data transmitter that failed to meet government specifications. It also said the transmitter required extensive reliability testing that was not performed. Instead, the indictment said, three of the defendants supervised false testing and falsification of test results. Concerning the Harrier jet program, the indictment accused the defendants of failing between 1981 and 1986 to conduct vibration tests of the jet's rate sensor assemblies at levels required by contract. The assemblies are part of the flight stabilization system of the attack jet. Yamron and Engler, who have been on administrative leave to prepare their defense, will return to their former duties, Northrop said. ``From the time last April when the government filed its charges against the division, Mr. Yamron and Mr. Engler, Northrop has stated the charges were unwarranted and strongly disputed any allegations of criminal behaviour by the Precision Products Division or by those individuals,'' Northrop said.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer: No Settlement in AIDS Doctor Case
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers for a physician who contends she contracted AIDS from a contaminated needle said Monday there would be no settlement with the city hospital agency and her negligence lawsuit would go to the jury. ``We are committed to get this case through to a verdict as quickly as possible so that Veronica Prego can go on with whatever remains of her life,'' one of Prego's lawyers, Diane S. Wilner, said outside the courtroom. The end of the two-month-long trial had appeared to be at hand on Friday as testimony was interrupted for several hours while the opposing sides conferred in the chambers of Justice Aaron D. Bernstein of Brooklyn state Supreme Court. However, the negotiations collapsed and Prego's lawyers said the jury would decide the lawsuit's outcome. The trial was postponed Monday because a juror became ill over the weekend. Testimony was scheduled to resume Tuesday. Prego, 32, contends she developed the fatal disease after she accidently pricked her finger on a needle that had been used to draw blood from an AIDS patient at Kings County Hospital on the night of Jan. 12, 1983. Prego is suing the city Health and Hospitals Corp. and two physicians, charging negligence.

DOC.HEAD: Fate of Millions May Hang on Ethiopian Port Battle
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: The Ethiopian army and rebels are locked in battle for a small, steamy Red Sea port that represents a door of life for starving millions. President Mengistu Haile Mariam of Ethiopia has called the struggle for the port of Massawa a ``fight to the death'' to prevent the collapse of one third of his army and the secession of Eritrea province. But the outcome of the battle also may determine the fate of an estimated 4 million people in northern Ethiopia in peril of starving to death in the next few months. ``It's grim,'' said one Western relief worker. ``We're looking at a catastrophe in the making.'' Crops have failed, emergency food stocks are running low and the fighting has closed avenues for relief supplies. The United Nations had hoped to ship most of 1.1 million tons of donor food through Massawa to feed drought victims in Eritrea and neighboring Tigre, Wollo and Gondor provinces. But with each day of fighting between government forces and the Eritrean People's Liberation Front, that hope fades. The Eritrean rebels attacked Mengistu's 2nd Army along a 200-mile front on Feb. 8 in what the rebels described as a massive assault. Within two days, the rebels claimed the capture of Massawa. Without specifically denying the claim, the government in Addis Ababa said fighting for the port was continuing. The rebels later accused the government of subjecting Massawa to attacks by heavy artillery, bombs and napalm. The rebels contended as recently as last week that they still controlled the port, but both sides have had little to say about the fighting for more than a week. Since each side normally trumpets its victories, diplomats and other observers in Addis Ababa take the absence of battlefield reports to mean the battle for the port continues. On Feb. 17, in an unprecedented burst of candor, Mengistu said his 2nd Army faced collapse and Eritrea would secede if the rebels gained control of Massawa. ``We have no alternative but to fight to the death,'' Mengistu told his armed forces in a radio and television broadcast. ``He is throwing everything he has into the battle,'' said an African diplomat in a telephone interview from Addis Ababa. ``He is reinforcing it (Eritrea) in every way possible,'' said another envoy. The diplomats spoke on condition they not be identified. ``What we don't know is whether the port is going to be usable, no matter whose hands it winds up in,'' said the Western relief worker. ``It presumably has been badly damaged.'' None of the diplomats or aid officials interviewed by telephone from Nairobi would speak for attribution, saying they must deal with Mengistu's government. Ethiopia has Africa's largest army, an estimated 315,000 men, most of them ill-trained and poorly motivated peasant conscripts. Between 120,000 and 130,000 are assigned to the 2nd Army, which has borne the brunt of a 28-year-old secessionist war by the Eritrean rebels. The International Institute for Strategic Studies in London puts the strength of the Eritrean rebels at about 30,000, but they are known to be well armed, mostly with captured weapons, and highly disciplined. In the first few days of fighting for Massawa and the road that connects it with the provincial capital of Asmara, the rebels claim to have killed, captured or wounded 12,000 government soldiers and seized 72 Soviet-made tanks, 22 artillery pieces and tons of small arms. They also say they sank 12 Ethiopian navy craft in or near the port. As ports go, Massawa isn't much _ a cluster of whitewashed stone buildings, narrow streets and a population of 19,400. But it is one of only two ports on Ethiopia's Red Sea coast, has two deep-water berths and, until the rebels began their offensive, was the main northern gateway to mostly arid and mountainous Eritrea. The country's only other port is at Assab, also in Eritrea near its border with Djibouti. But it has no deep-water berths. Beyond Massawa, there are few alternative routes for emergency food aid. Another rebel group, the Tigre People's Liberation Front, cut the only highway from the capital north to Asmara a year ago. Some food could be trucked in from neighboring Sudan, but few vehicles are available, the roads are terrible and, at least for now, all movements must be at night for fear of Ethiopian air attacks. This year's harvest failed in large parts of Eritrea and Tigre provinces and, to a lesser extent, in Wollo and Gondor. What food stocks remain from a year ago are rapidly running out. Some 25,000 refugees already have fled Tigre into Sudan and United Nations and other aid officials expect their number to grow as fighting halts food deliveries in northern Ethiopia. Those officials foresee a repeat of Ethiopia's great famine of 1984-85, in which as many as 1 million people may have died. Their grim scenario has hundreds of thousands of desperate refugees crowding into makeshift camps where, weakened by hunger and long treks in search of food, more die of disease than from meager rations. No end to the fighting is in sight.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Company Announces Programming and Commercial Deal With Polish TV
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmits to avoid duplicate numbering.
DOC.TEXT: ``The Wonder Years'' and steamy ``Santa Barbara'' are among the television shows headed for Polish audiences under an agreement announced Monday between Polish TV officials and an American outlet. The two-year agreement between Polish Television Channel 2 and Annapolis-based Conduit Internationale Films calls for provision of programming and selling of advertising for the station. Formerly one of Poland's two government-operated channels offering a slim variety of news, current affairs and regional programs, Channel 2 has been converted into a commercial operation under Poland's new, non-communist government. In a statement released with the announcement, C.I. said it has reached an agreement with the New World International production company to provide ``The Wonder Years'' for Channel 2. Other New World features heading for Poland include the daytime soap opera ``Santa Barbara'' and the crime-adventure show ``Wise Guy.'' Poland has a population estimated at 38 million and about 10 million households with televisions, according to C.I. The only other Eastern European country with a commercial station is Hungary, with a population of about 10 million. Conduit Internationale is a subsidiary of NL Technologies, which has been involved over the past dozen years with several non-entertainment businesses in Poland, including clothing marketing and production and aircraft marketing.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Singer Marian Anderson, whose concert before Eleanor Roosevelt in 1939 was a landmark in the fight against segregation, is asking black Americans to stand up and be counted in the 1990 census. At a ceremony at the Apollo Theater in Harlem, the Census Bureau on Monday unveiled a campaign to reach as many blacks as possible after roughly 5 percent were missed in 1980. ``If they don't know now, they'll learn a little bit later that it really pays to stand up and be counted,'' said Ms. Anderson, who retired 25 years ago. On April 9, 1939, the 88-year-old Ms. Anderson sang in Washington before an illustrious audience, including Mrs. Roosevelt, at the Lincoln Memorial after she was barred from appearing in Constitution Hall by the Daughters of the American Revolution. The Census Bureau issued a poster Monday showing Ms. Anderson performing on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial. The poster urges blacks to ``Lift Up Your Voice. Stand up for who you are. Answer the census on April 1, 1990.''

Grammy winners Mac Rebennack and Art, Aaron and Charles Neville say the world is finally waking up to the New Orleans sound. ``I don't think we're doing anything differently. I think the world is just catching up to us,'' said Rebennack, better known as Dr. John, at a city awards ceremony honoring the prize-winning artists. Rebennack won a Grammy last week with Rickie Lee Jones for a jazz duet version of ``Makin' Whoopee.'' Art Neville of the Neville Brothers, winners for best pop instrumental with the song ``Healing Chant,'' said national and world recognition of New Orleans music, with its jazz, Caribbean and African influences, was long overdue. Charles Neville said the awards were bound to help the city's musicians. ``I think the big thing it did, though, was give more credibility to New Orleans music,'' he said. ``We'll probably get regular air play now. Before this, programmers said New Orleans music was too regional. Well, it's true it is regional. But the region is the world.''

Ronald Reagan received an honorary degree from Israel's largest institute of higher learning, Tel Aviv University, one of several Jewish honors given the former president so far this year. The presentation Sunday at a star-studded dinner at the Century Plaza Hotel cited Reagan's ``steadfast friendship for the Jewish people and vehement rejection of anti-Semitism.'' In recent weeks, Reagan has been honored by the American Jewish Committee and Hebrew University. In a few weeks, he will be feted by the United Jewish Appeal Drive. Reagan joked to the appreciative black-tie audience that his receipt of the honorary doctor of philosophy degree ``cannot be based on any academic achievements.'' He went on to explain that his alma mater, Eureka College in Illinois, once gave him an honorary degree 25 years after his graduation. ``That only aggravated a sense of guilt that I nursed for 25 years,'' Reagan said. ``I always suspected the first degree was honorary.''

Producer Saul Zaentz owes his ex-wife a $300,000 share of the proceeds from the Oscar-winning movie ``Amadeus,'' a state appeals court ruled. The decision, released Monday, upheld a ruling by the judge at the couple's divorce trial that Zaentz made $600,000 in unstated income from the 1984 film, which won an Academy Award as best picture. Half that amount belongs to his former wife, Lynda, under California's community property law. The couple married in 1978 and separated in 1983, a year in which Mrs. Zaentz worked as a production assistant on ``Amadeus.''

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Valdez Chronology
With PM-Exxon-Valdez, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of the Exxon Valdez oil spill, its cleanup and related developments. March 24, 1989: The 987-foot tanker Exxon Valdez runs aground on Bligh Reef 25 miles south of Valdez, Alaska, spilling nearly 11 million gallons of North Slope crude oil into Prince William Sound. March 26: Alaska fishermen's union spokeswoman Riki Ott says the group wants full compensation for damages from the spill.'' More than 250 lawsuits will be filed against Exxon in the months that follow. March 30: Exxon fires tanker captain Joseph Hazelwood after tests reveal he was legally drunk 10 hours after the accident. April 4: U.S. Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan calls the spill the oil industry's ``Three Mile Island.'' Oil now covers 1,000 square miles, leaking out of the sound to foul beaches along the Gulf of Alaska and Cook Inlet. June 19: Exxon and other big oil companies announce plans for a voluntary network of response teams capable of handling big spills anywhere in U.S. coastal waters. Estimated cost: $250 million. Sept. 15: Exxon suspends its beach cleanup for the winter, claiming it has left 1,100 miles of oiled beaches ``environmentally stable'' and saying its 25-week cleanup involving more than 10,000 workers was a job well done. Alaska officials disagree and announce their own $21 million winter cleanup plan. Oct. 10: State officials warn people not to consume shellfish in areas affected by oil. Oct. 27: The National Wildlife Federation says Exxon has resigned from its corporate advisory board. Exxon calls the conservation group unfair in its criticism of the oil spill; the group calls Exxon ``a corporate pariah.'' Nov. 8: The U.S. House of Representatives passes a bill preserving states' ability to adopt stricter oil spill liability laws than the federal government. The Senate also is working on a bill, but agreement is put off until 1990. Dec. 4: U.S. Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner says Exxon's cleanup has cost the company $1.9 billion, and praises Exxon for ``a very substantial, good-faith effort.'' Dec. 31: Wildlife officials report that more than 1,000 sea otters, 140 bald eagles and nearly 36,500 seabirds have been found dead in the spill area. Jan. 5, 1990: The Alaska Oil Spill Commission issues a report calling for an overhaul of the nation's oil transportation system. It blames the Valdez spill in part on the Coast Guard's ``unduly friendly relationship with industry,'' and a reckless rush to profits by the oil industry. Jan. 22: Hazelwood goes on trial in Anchorage, facing three felony charges of criminal mischief and misdemeanor charges of reckless endangerment, negligent discharge of oil, and operating a vessel while intoxicated. Feb. 20: The Coast Guard orders Exxon to resume its cleanup May 1 and to submit a plan by March 15. Tuesday, Feb. 27: A federal grand jury indicts Exxon and its shipping subsidiary on five criminal counts. Officials say that if convicted, the company could be fined up to $1.6 million if convicted on all counts and could be assessed an additional $700 million in penalties.

DOC.HEAD: Dukakis Regrets Missing `Great Time' to be President
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: ``It's a great time to be president,'' said Michael Dukakis, who isn't. The Massachusetts governor visited his would-be home for an East Room reception with President Bush on Monday and afterward said he knows he's missing out on a spate of good news. ``I don't stay up nights on the subject,'' Dukakis said. ``I must say that this would be a great time to be president of the United States.'' Dukakis, who has had no such luck with affairs in Massachusetts over the past year, reflected on how events have smiled on his political nemesis. ``We're living through history here. This is unprecedented. The Cold War has defined everything about our lives about our country, about the world, and all of a sudden, nobody predicted it, it seems to be sliding away.'' The question, Dukakis said, is what Bush can make of the opportunities that have fallen into his lap. ``It seems to me that this is a very good time for the country, providing we take advantage of what is an extraordinary opportunity to provide international leadership. ... If the administration does a good job of that, then they're going to be successful, and if they don't, then somebody else is going to be president.'' Sporting a cast on his left hand because he broke two fingers on Saturday trying to push a car out of snow, Dukakis made his second trip to the White House since losing to Bush in the November 1988 presidential election. He is in town to take part in the annual National Governors' Association meeting. As one with direct experience in the field of changing political fortunes, Dukakis warned Bush not to grow over-confident, especially now that a favorite Republican enemy _ communism _ appears to be waning as a major issue. ``The Republicans have always had this defense thing and, you know, Bush used it against me and in retrospect, who was the most accurate forecaster? It was the Democratic nominee,'' Dukakis said. ``You never know. Things change in this business.'' The successful elections Sunday in Nicaragua, Dukakis said, are an example of the bankruptcy of the Reagan-Bush policy of military aid to the Nicaraguan Contra rebels. It was a diplomatic approach that opened the door to free elections, he said. ``What's the record? There was no progress toward genuinely open, free, internationally supervised elections until the Contra effort effectively was killed,'' Dukakis said. ``What does that tell you?'' Acting the part of a reporter, Dukakis quoted Bush as saying in the closed-door luncheon with the governors that the defense budget may be cut further. The governors were asking Bush whom the country should fear as an enemy with the sudden turn of events in Eastern Europe. ``He said, `The enemy is instability.' OK, fine. But then he said, `Look, we've already cut the defense budget substantially below projected levels,' and he said, `it's probably going to be cut even further.''' Dukakis said he has been too busy digging Massachusetts out of a fiscal hole lately to think about his post-gubernatorial career. He said he wants to remain involved in public affairs. As for future runs for political office, he said: ``I don't think you ever say never to anything. Who knows.''

DOC.HEAD: One in Four Young Blacks in Criminal Justice System, Report Says
DOC.TEXT: The ``get tough'' approach is failing to deter criminal activity by young black males, 23 percent of whom are behind bars or on probation or parole, a non-profit group says. ``We now risk the possibility of writing off an entire generation of black men from leading productive lives,'' said Marc Mauer, assistant director of The Sentencing Project, which promotes alternative punishments and sentencing reform. In a report issued Monday, the group said 609,690 black men age 20 through 29 _ nearly one in every four _ were in prison or jail or on probation or parole in mid-1989. In contrast, only 436,000 black men in the same age group were enrolled in college in 1986, the latest year for which figures were available. ``These are shocking, disturbing numbers,'' said Rep. John Conyers, D-Mich., chairman of the House Government Operations Committee. Conyers said he would hold hearings but first wanted the General Accounting Office, a congressional investigative agency, to conduct a separate investigation. The past decade was ``an experiment in the get-tough approach to crime,'' as the federal and state governments built more prisons, imposed mandatory sentences and embraced capital punishment, the report said. ``We will never build enough cells to house everyone that can be brought into the prisons,'' Conyers said. ``Also, there's no showing that increased incarceration has any deterrent effect whatsoever.'' For white men in the 20 to 29 age group, 1,054,508, or 6.2 percent, were incarcerated or on probation or parole. A total of 238,255 Hispanic males, or 10.4 percent, were in the criminal justice system. Although fewer young women than men were in the system, there were racial disparities: 164,249 whites, or 1 percent; 78,417 blacks, or 2.7 percent; and 37,093 Hispanics, or 1.8 percent. Stu Smith, a spokesman for the Justice Department, said the report's numbers were accurate but declined further comment. The report blames social ills, including high unemployment rates, for the disproportionate number of black men in the prison system. Conyers agreed, noting that black men as a group are less educated and in poorer health than their white counterparts. He also said the criminal justice system was ``racist in impact if not by intention,'' with blacks more likely than whites to receive lengthy sentences or capital punishment. To reverse the trend for blacks, governments should prescribe counseling and other alternatives to prison for young, first-time offenders, the study said. For others, mandatory sentencing guidelines should be loosened so judges can tailor each criminal's punishment to his particular situation, it said. Prison should be a last resort after alternative punishments have failed, the report said, urging governments to make greater use of restitution to victims, community service, intensive probation and employment and education programs.

DOC.HEAD: Jackson Won't Run for DC Mayor; Revives Predictions of Presidential Bid
Laserphoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson's political future is beginning to resemble his past. His announcement Monday that he will not run for mayor of the nation's capital revived the assumption that when the 1992 presidential campaign gets rolling, Jackson will make his third bid for the White House. ``I want to continue to serve, but not as mayor,'' Jackson told a news conference, ending speculation that he might run to succeed the troubled Marion Barry as mayor of the District of Columbia, a city without a state. Serve as what, was the next natural question. ``It is premature to talk about the next level of activity,'' he replied to such queries. ``The push is for statehood.'' Jackson established residence in Washington last spring, a move that touched off speculation he would run for mayor. The talk intensified after Barry was arrested on a misdemeanor cocaine possession charge and later indicted on perjury charges. Many people were advising Jackson to run. They included some union and business leaders who regarded him as the best possibility for lifting the city out of a cycle of drugs and murder that has brought unwelcome headlines across the nation. The advice also came from some of the veteran politicians who worked on the late stages of Jackson's 1988 campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination. ``I thought he ought to run,'' said John White, a former Democratic national party chairman. ``It would give him a chance to develop some credibility on big-time issues.'' ``I thought he ought to do it,'' said Georgian Bert Lance, who served as budget director for President Jimmy Carter. ``I thought he could show his skill.'' White and Lance speculated that Jackson's detractors would try to turn his reluctance to take on the challenges of mayor against him in the future. ``I don't know how much bypassing this kind of challenge in a future race, how much negative impact that would have,'' White said. ``But certainly he chose to pass it by.'' The D.C. Council is considering authorizing the election of two ``shadow senators'' to lobby Congress for statehood. Jackson often is mentioned as a shoo-in for election to such a post. ``I don't understand that shadow senator stuff,'' White said. ``I don't know whether he (Jackson) has a real interest in it. I've never heard him discuss it. ``But for a real politician, I don't see much interest in it. Politics is about power.'' Massachusetts Gov. Michael Dukakis, the man who defeated Jackson in the race for the 1988 presidential nomination, reacted to Jackson's announcement by saying: ``I'm sorry about that. He would have been a good candidate. The job of mayor of the district is a national office in every sense of the word. I wish he would have given it a whirl.'' ``It's not good for the city, what's been happening,'' said Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas. ``And we need to look at the city with pride again. He could have made a contribution.'' ``At present I believe that I may best serve by continuing my work on a national level to change the direction of this country. I want to serve, but not as mayor,'' Jackson said. White said, ``You have to almost predict a rerun of '88.''

DOC.HEAD: Wife, Sister of Two U.S. Hostages Optimistic About Releases
DOC.TEXT: Relatives of two Americans held captive in Lebanon by pro-Iranian factions say they are more optimistic than ever that all the Western hostages in that country will soon be freed. ``I feel much better than I've ever felt. ... I feel very confident that the hostages will be released,'' said Ferial Polhill. Her husband Robert, who taught at Beirut University College, was kidnapped on Jan. 24, 1987. Peggy Say, sister of Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, said: ``I feel something's going to happen.'' Anderson, 42, is the longest held of the 18 Westerners kidnapped in Lebanon. He was abducted on March 16, 1985. ``There seems to be some kind of major impact looking at the five-year anniversary of Terry Anderson,'' said Mrs. Say, who is winding up a ``humanitarian pilgrimage'' with an AP delegation to seek international support for the release of Anderson and the other hostages. ``I think it outrages people that for five years he and the other hostages have been held under such unspeakable conditions,'' said Mrs. Say, who has tirelessly lobbied for her brother's release. The other Western hostages are six Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Irishman and an Italian. Most are believed held by pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem factions linked to Hezbollah, or Party of God, an anti-Western fundamentalist faction. Mrs. Say, of Cadiz, Ky., has met with Pope John Paul II, United Nations Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar and Palestine Liberation Organization chairman Yasser Arafat. At the United Nations Monday, Kit and Joan Sutherland, daughters of U.S. hostage Thomas Sutherland, presented Perez de Cuellar with a petition containing 18,000 signatures from Colorado appealing for help in seeking their father's release. Sutherland, on leave from Colorado State University at Fort Collins, was abducted June 9, 1985, while serving as acting dean of agriculture at the American University of Beirut. Mrs. Say flew to Cyprus from Damascus, Syria, where she had met with Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa and Information Minister Mohammed Salman. Syria is the main power broker in Lebanon. Mrs. Polhill, a Lebanese, had come from Beirut. The two women, sitting side by side in a Nicosia hotel, said they were greatly encouraged by recent statements in Tehran and Beirut about the hostages. ``I feel this way particularly after the statements by Iranian officials and by Sheik Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah,'' said Mrs. Polhill. Fadlallah, Hezbollah's spiritual guide and the most influential Shiite cleric in Lebanon, said Friday that ways had to be found to free the hostages. Iran's Chief Justice, Mohammad Yazdi, declared Sunday that Islam opposed hostage-taking and there was no need for diplomatic maneuvering to free the hostages in Lebanon. ``This feeling is also prevalent in Beirut after the latest statements. ... It appears the hostages will be released unconditionally,'' Mrs. Polhill added. Mrs. Say said her increased optimism resulted ``from all the people that I've seen.'' Yazdi's statement came amid other indications that the Iranian government was moving to distance itself from the hostages. The Tehran Times said in an editorial last week that the American hostages held in Lebanon have become a tool to be used against Iran and should be released. The English-language newspaper generally reflects the thinking of President Hashemi Rafsanjani, leader of Iran's so-called pragmatists. He is seeking to improve relations with the West to secure badly needed investment and technology to revitalize Iran's moribund economy. But he is opposed by radical fundamentalists who charge he is deviating from the teachings of the Islamic republic's late founder, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, who died June 3. The Tehran Times report was followed Sunday by an editorial in Tehran's Ettela'at daily that said the groups holding the foreigners should release them.

DOC.HEAD: Government Doesn't Want AIDS Experts in Court
DOC.TEXT: The government is refusing to send its AIDS researchers into court to shed light on allegations that drug companies failed to move swiftly enough to prevent their blood products from transmitting the virus to children with hemophilia. The Centers for Disease Control contends AIDS researchers' time is better spent in the laboratory. Lawyers for families of the AIDS victims say they believe both justice and science can be served by having the experts testify. ``Parents whose hemophiliac children have gotten AIDS from AIDS-contaminated blood are shocked that the federal government is refusing access to the truth about what information was given to people in the blood business in the early 1980s about the transmissibility of AIDS,'' said Laura Anderson, a Miami attorney for families who are suing Armour Pharmaceutical of Bradley, Ill., and Cutter Laboratories of Berkeley, Calif. The government has won the first legal skirmishes, most recently a ruling by a federal judge in Atlanta that CDC experts can't be forced to testify in AIDS-related lawsuits. Senior U.S. District Judge Charles A. Moye Jr. said he was concerned that compelling the experts to testify would subject the CDC to ``an onslaught of subpoenas'' for testimony on AIDS. Lawyers for families of the AIDS victims hope to win reconsideration of that ruling and a similar one in California. The lawyers want to question AIDS experts Bruce Evatt and Donald Francis about their dealings with companies that make clotting products from donated blood. According to documents filed in the case, CDC researchers sent to at least one drug company a 1982 draft report saying hemophiliacs ``should be advised of this risk'' _ a suggestion missing from the CDC's subsequent official report. The documents also say that Francis advised a CDC colleague in a January 1983 memo that he feared ``it might be too late'' to prevent AIDS from spreading to hemophiliacs. But he urged that the CDC recommend using only a very small pool of screened blood donors for manufacturing such products, even though ``there will be objections by industry and blood bankers.'' The Atlanta ruling, quashing a subpoena issued in Florida, means Evatt does not have to testify. But a larger issue remains _ when, if ever, CDC researchers should be compelled to testify in AIDS lawsuits. The CDC has fielded about 50 requests in the last seven years for testimony from three top AIDS specialists. The agency also has responded to more than 200 inquiries from lawyers concerned with such cases, according to the CDC. Moye, in his Feb. 6 order, said the plaintiffs have a reasonable explanation for why they need Evatt's testimony, but ``their interest in getting the deposition simply cannot compare to the government's interest in maximizing the use of its limited resources in dealing with a national health crisis.'' The government contends research should take precedence. ``We've taken a fairly hard-nosed position on this,'' said CDC legal adviser Gene Matthews. ``We simply can't let our doctors and researchers, who are spread thin as it is ... peel off time and go testifying.'' A subpoena issued to Francis, a CDC expert in California, was quashed by a federal magistrate there last year. Ms. Anderson suggested that if Evatt were allowed to testify in her case, his testimony could be videotaped and saved for use in other AIDS lawsuits. She raised the possibility that the government won't allow the researchers to testify because of the possibility of embarrassing material coming out. ``Nothing was ever articulated specifically, but that is sort of by implication what is going on,'' Ms. Anderson said. CDC spokeswoman Gail Lloyd said the agency is not worried about anything embarrassing coming out in court. Already, Ms. Lloyd said, ``we have supplied voluminous documents. Everything we've ever had has been supplied. It is not an effort to withhold information.'' Francis and Evatt have refused to comment on the lawsuits, Ms. Lloyd said. ``They're scientists, and they'd just as soon do science. The issue here is a legal issue, not a scientific issue. On this issue, they just don't feel it's their subject,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: `Driving Miss Daisy' Dominates Box Office Business
DOC.TEXT: ``Driving Miss Daisy'' grossed $6.1 million at the nation's theaters last weekend, its nine Oscar nominations helping it hold the No. 1 position at the box office. Warner Bros. estimated the Academy Award nominations ``Miss Daisy'' collected Feb. 14 would boost the film's revenues by $20 million, and so far the prediction is holding true, according to figures from Exhibitor Relations Co. ``Miss Daisy,'' which grossed $10.8 million the previous weekend, has now sold more than $53 million worth of tickets, with the bulk of the income coming in the last several weeks. The movie starring Jessica Tandy and Morgan Freeman as a Southern widow and her black chauffeur opened in December. But ``Miss Daisy'' could be knocked from the No. 1 spot next weekend by the much-anticipated ``The Hunt for Red October,'' starring Sean Connery. Another surprise hit, ``Hard to Kill,'' finished in second place with receipts of $5.4 million, making $27.5 million in three weeks. The poorly reviewed film stars Steven Seagal as a policeman with a bad attitude. His wife, Kelly Le Brock, plays a supporting role. ``Madhouse,'' with John Larroquette and Kirstie Alley as a couple entertaining impossible house guests, landed in third place with a gate of $3.4 million. Fourth was the Kevin Costner film ``Revenge,'' which made $2.9 million and is fading. ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' in fifth, has not enjoyed a great boost from its eight Oscar nominations. The film collected $2.5 million, but its per-screen average has weakened to $1,755. Here are the top movie ticket sales for Friday through Monday as tallied by Exhibitor Relations, with distributor, weekend gross, number of theater screens, average per screen, total gross and number of weeks in release. Figures are based on a combination of actual box-office receipts and studio projections where actual figures are not immediately available. 1. ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' Warner Bros., $6.1 million, 1,432 screens, $4,265 per screen, $53.3 million, 11 weeks. 2. ``Hard to Kill,'' Warner Bros., $5.4 million, 1,508 screens, $3,600 per screen, $27.5 million, three weeks. 3. ``Madhouse,'' Orion, $3.4 million, 1,554 screens, $2,205 per screen, $9.6 million, two weeks. 4. ``Revenge,'' Columbia, $2.9 million, 1,379 screens, $2,080 per screen, $10 million, two weeks. 5. ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' Universal, $2.5 million, 1,432 screens, $1,755 per screen, $56.8 million, 10 weeks. 6. ``Men Don't Leave,'' Warner Bros., $2 million, 802 screens, $2,503 per screen, $2.3 million, four weeks. 7. ``Nightbreed,'' 20th Century Fox, $1.8 million, 1,488 screens, $1,235 per screen, $6.2 million, two weeks. 8. ``Glory,'' Tri-Star, $1.68 million, 809 screens, $2,080 per screen, $18.4 million, 11 weeks. 9. ``Stella,'' Disney, $1.67 million, 1,291 screens, $1,293 per screen, $15.6 million, four weeks. 10. ``Steel Magnolias,'' Tri-Star, $1.2 million, 1,214 screens, $995 per screen, $72.8 million, 15 weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Nebraskans Kerrey, Yeutter at Odds Over Surplus Grain
DOC.TEXT: The Agriculture Department is likely to continue a policy of releasing government-owned surplus grain into the commercial market despite the objections of Sen. Bob Kerrey, D-Neb. Kerrey had asked Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter, a Nebraskan on the opposite side of the political fence, to reverse a decision to dump on the market 55 million to 60 million bushels of corn owned by the Commodity Credit Corp. Kerrey, a member of the Senate Agriculture Committee, said last week that Yeutter's decision to issue new CCC ``catalogs,'' or lists of grain inventories available to buyers, was ``a clear signal to farmers'' that the Agriculture Department believes current corn prices of $2.25 per bushel are too high. Yeutter, in a letter released Monday by USDA, told Kerrey that the catalogs ``help to move grain out of more expensive commercial storage and into the market to satisfy domestic and export demand.'' Kerrey said last week that the Bush administration ``has been lecturing farmers to become more `market-oriented' and rely less on the government for their income, but its decision to sell still more corn undermines the ability of farmers to heed that directive.'' Farmers who developed a thoughtful marketing plan have been told by USDA ``that the government stands ready to erase any opportunity for better prices,'' he said. Yeutter said he was troubled by Kerrey's request to keep the corn in CCC storage because ``most Nebraska farmers know that, in the long run, American agriculture is far better off moving grain to market.'' ``The early 1980s taught us that we can't store our way to prosperity,'' Yeutter said. ``The grain recently cataloged had already been in storage for at least two to three years.'' According to recent USDA reports, corn exports are expected to rise 12 percent this year, to around 2.275 billion bushels, and domestic use may be up 9 percent, to more than 5.7 billion bushels. Thus, total corn use in the 1989-90 marketing year _ 7.98 billion bushels _ will exceed last fall's harvest of less than 7.53 billion bushels. As a result, U.S. corn stockpiles are expected to drop to 1.48 billion bushels by the start of the next marketing year Sept. 1, the first time since 1983-84 that the carryover has been below 1.5 billion bushels. ``The tight stocks mean that corn prices will be sensitive to weather conditions that may affect the planting and development of the 1990 corn crop,'' one USDA analysis said. Projections by the department's Economic Research Service put corn prices in the range of $2.20 to $2.40 per bushel, on the average, over the 1989-90 marketing year, compared with $2.54 estimated for 1988-89 when drought reduced the supply and forced up prices.

Agriculture Department economists say brisk exports and heavy domestic use are draining off U.S. cotton inventories and boosting prices. Domestic mills used 7.8 million bales in 1988-89, the department's Economic Research Service said Monday in a preliminary report. ``This season, strong denim demand and apparel sales are expected to push consumption to 8.2 million bales, the highest in nearly two decades,'' the report said. ``Mill use for the first six months of the season average about 8.4 million bales on a seasonally adjusted annual rate.'' Cotton exports are forecast at 7.7 million bales this season, up 25 percent from 6.15 million bales in 1988-89. As of mid-February, outstanding sales and shipments totaled nearly 7 million bales, compared with 4.7 million at this time last season. The U.S. cotton inventory by Aug. 1 is expected to be about 3.5 million bales, about half the 7.09 million on hand last Aug. 1. ``During the 1989-90 marketing year, both U.S. and world prices for cotton have exceeded those of the past season by substantial margins,'' the report said. ``The adjusted world price for August to mid-November averaged 67 cents per pound this season, about 23 cents ahead of the comparable-period average last season.'' World cotton production was projected at about 79 million bales in 1989-90, down 6 percent from last year. Foreign production, at around 67 million bales is down 3 percent. The U.S. harvest is estimated at 12.2 million bales, down 21 percent.

China is looking for foreign partners to set up a joint dairy venture, says an Agriculture Department dispatch from Beijing. Edwin A. Bauer, U.S. agricultural counselor reports that Chinese dairy authorities are interested in foreign partners supplying livestock, equipment and technical expertise. ``The main problem for U.S. firms wishing to enter such an arrangement will be recouping the investment in exportable dairy products or hard currency due to a shortage of both,'' he said. Bauer's report, included in the March issue of AgExporter magazine, said China wants to boost national per capita milk consumption from the current 3 kilograms to 5.4 kilos by 1992. One kilogram is about 2.2 pounds.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Union Refusing Visas to US Members of Congress
DOC.TEXT: For the second time in a week, the Soviet Union is planning to deny visas to members of Congress seeking to watch local elections in that country, according to lawmakers and the State Department. Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., chairman of the U.S. Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe, on Monday criticized the Soviets' failure to provide visas to a group of House members who want to observe the elections in the Ukraine on Sunday. ``We don't understand why Moscow would want to keep U.S. congressmen from observing the process of democratization in the U.S.S.R.,'' DeConcini said in a statement. The commission monitors the human rights aspects of the Helsinki accords. ``Moscow's clear unwillingness to permit U.S. legislators to observe the political processes and elections runs counter to the trend of improved U.S.-Soviet relations and parliamentary contacts,'' he said. The group had planned to leave Thursday, but has yet to receive entry permits. The Soviets have told the lawmakers they do not have proper invitations to warrant visas, said Orest Deychak, a commission staff member. House members were told invitations must be issued by the Ukrainian Supreme Soviet. A State Department official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Soviet officials have given ``signals'' that visas would be denied to Reps. Don Ritter, R-Pa., a commission member; John Edward Porter, R-Ill.; David Drier, R-Calif.; Dennis Hertel, D-Mich.; Bob McEwen, R-Ohio; and Dan Schaefer, R-Colo. The congressmen have not been officially notified that they will not get visas. A telephone number provided by the Soviet Embassy to ask questions about visas rang unanswered Monday. Last week, four House members flew to Berlin, intending to get visas to watch elections in Lithuania on Saturday, the first multiparty contest in the Soviet Union since after the Bolshevik Revolution. The group arrived Wednesday in Berlin, where they remained until after the elections. They were not permitted to enter Lithuania until Sunday night, and they will return Tuesday. Last Friday, 11 senators wrote a letter of protest to Yuri Dubinin, the Soviet ambassador to the United States, calling for approval of the visas. In addition, Secretary of State James A. Baker III contacted Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze about the matter, a State Department official said. Although the congressmen _ Reps. Richard Durbin, D-Ill.; Christopher Cox, R-Calif.; John Miller, R-Wash.; and Bill Sarpalius, D-Texas _ only managed one day in Lithuania, the trip was worthwhile, said Durbin's spokeswoman, Melissa Batty. ``They met with people,'' she said, adding that Durbin, who is of Lithuanian descent, also planned to visit his mother's hometown. She said the group went to Berlin because they had not expected to have trouble obtaining their visas.

DOC.HEAD: Private School President Refuses to Testify About Loans
DOC.TEXT: The president of a private trade school is refusing to answer Senate investigators' allegations that documents were altered to fatten profits from federal guaranteed student loans. ``On advice of counsel, I respectfully decline to answer the question,'' Joseph A. Calareso, president of American Career Training Corp., replied when asked whether he had instructed anyone to doctor records. Staff members of the Senate Permanent Investigations Subcommittee testified Monday that they found evidence suggesting ``intentional abuse of the guaranteed student loan system'' by the corporation and its two arms: A.C.T. Travel School and Hart School for Professional Secretaries, both in Pompano Beach, Fla. Investigators allege that from 1986 through 1989, $150 million in loans were guaranteed for 60,000 students of the A.C.T. schools, which combine home study with on-campus courses. Calareso and his brother, James, who own the school, paid themselves $12 million in salary and stock dividends during that time, the investigators said. Joseph Calareso earns $1.5 million a year as president. ``I'm afraid they are just scratching the surface'' of deep problems in the program, said Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the subcommittee. The system, added Sen. William Roth, R-Del., ``seems to invite fraud and abuse.'' Subcommittee investigators David B. Buckley and Grace T. McPhearson targeted the A.C.T. operations as part of a broader probe of abuses in the student loan programs. A.C.T. was chosen because of its heavy reliance on student loans. Brenda Ann Brandon said that when she was the organization's financial-aid officer, the school was receiving 200 to 250 student-loan checks averaging $2,000 to $2,500 a week. Although federal regulations limit guaranteed loans to those who have completed high school or who are obtaining an equivalency diploma, ``some of the students literally could not read or write, some could not speak the English language,'' Mrs. Brandon said. She said she had seen Joseph Calareso alter records of students who had no high school diploma. In addition, Mrs. Brandon said, employees were instructed by Joseph Calareso ``to contact every new student, even cash students, and try and get them to finance their education through a guaranteed student loan.'' ``This way, the school was guaranteed to receive the full tuition up front,'' she said. ``If a cash student is on a payment plan, there is a lower probability that the school will receive all of the tuition, because the majority of the students enrolled never complete the course.'' Senate investigators contend that: _In 1986 through 1989, 90 percent of A.C.T. students _ including some who did not meet federal requirements _ received federal aid but only 16 percent completed their courses. _The schools list only 23 instructors but 109 sales representatives trying to recruit students. In 1989, from each $1,000 of revenue, the schools spent $4 on classroom materials, $14 on instructors' salaries and $338 on advertising. _In 1985, the first year it was eligible to participate in federal student-loan programs, A.C.T. revenues increased by 800 percent, to $5.5 million, investigators testified. Revenues reached $34.5 million in 1989. Andrea Lynn Merritts-West of New Smyrna Beach, Fla., told the subcommittee that within a week after enrolling in the travel school, she received a filled-in form that _ she learned months later _ was an application for a guaranteed student loan. She said she received a $2,650 check from A.C.T. and, following instructions, endorsed it and returned it to the school. She dropped out a few months later and eventually was notified by a private lender that she was about to default on a government loan. ``This is the first time that I had ever been told that I had received a government student loan,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: `Fatsats,' `Lightsats' May Reduce Cost of Space Program
DOC.TEXT: Increasing the payload on a spacecraft can make it more economical, but so can sending up a series of smaller satellites, a congressional study says. The Office of Technology Assessment proposes ``fatsats,'' ``lightsats,'' and ``microspacecraft'' as possible solutions in the quest for a cheaper space program. With payloads costing up to $800,000 a pound, the congressional office has been looking at offbeat technologies that can reduce costs. One idea in the study released Monday proposes to launch 10,000 small projectiles a year for as little as $500 a pound for the payload and $20 a pound for the launcher. ``Unless spacecraft costs are reduced, even dramatic reductions in launch costs will have only a small effect on total spacecraft program costs,'' said the report ``Affordable Spacecraft: Design and Launch Alternatives.'' The study follows OTA's ``Buyer's Guide'' to launch options, its ``Big, Dumb Booster: A Low-Cost Space Transportation Option,'' and its study of human spaceflight. A summary report on space transportation will be published in the spring. Reducing the cost of launchers will have only a small impact on overall costs and new strategies are needed to cut the cost of payloads, the report concludes. The report proposes: _Requiring payload designers to include a margin for weight overruns to avoid the long delays and high cost of redesigning spacecraft that tend to grow in size and weight during production and ``gross out'' their intended launchers. _Allowing ``fatsats,'' or spacecraft that are built larger, with less-expensive materials to keep costs down. The money saved can far exceed the increased cost of a larger launcher. _Making more ``lightsats'' that weigh less but have fewer capabilities. The idea is that for some applications, launching an array of small and simple satellites instead of one large sophisticated vehicle could cut costs. _Building small instruments for small, rugged satellites that can be launched by laser-powered or cannon-like launchers. The study suggests several options for Congress, including legislation that would require two design contracts for a selected new spacecraft: a conventional one and one that would consider unconventional approaches. OTA proposes that Congress require the National Aeronautics Space Administration to include 15 percent weight margins in its new designs. The study also suggests funding of programs to build larger launchers that could carry ``fatsats'' and continued funding for military development of launch vehicles for ``lightsats.''

DOC.HEAD: Mexico City Mayor Announces Tougher Actions Combat Pollution
DOC.TEXT: After getting residents to cut back on driving, officials of this smog-choked metropolis are expanding anti-pollution measures to move steel works out of town and encourage buses and trucks to use propane. In addition, all vehicles will now be required to submit to emissions inspections. The new measures Mayor Manuel Camacho Solis announced Monday step up the battle to cut some of the 4.8 million tons of pollutants spewed every year into the air breathed by the capital's 18 million residents. ``We are determined, and we have the overwhelming support of an equally determined citizenry, to go ahead and make next winter even less contaminated than this winter was,'' the mayor told a news conference. An experimental program that started Nov. 20 _ its main feature being to force people not to drive one day a week _ had been scheduled to end Wednesday but was extended for at least two months. The period corresponded to the winter season's thermal inversions, when cold air traps huge quantities of toxic gases during the early hours of the morning in the Valley of Mexico. Camacho said the program was so successful that, when city authorities conducted a series of public opinion polls, 70 to 90 percent of those questioned said they favored extending it. While the measure only was intended to cut pollution by 23 percent, the reduction was only about half that. Still, Camacho said, you can see the results: ``On many days you could even see the volcanoes surrounding the city very clearly.'' Similarly, Camacho announced that the sale of oxygenated gasoline and the substitution of natural gas for fuel oil in Mexico City two huge power plants _ part of the experimental program _ would continue. Adding the oxygen-compound additive to gasoline raises combustion levels and sharply reduces pollutants, especially in Mexico where emission control devices are not mandatory, experts say. Petroleos Mexicanos S.A., the goverment's oil monopoly, will continue providing 109 million cubic feet of natural gas to replace the 16,000 barrels of fuel oil the capital's two power plants had burned daily, he said. By the time winter sets in again next November, Camacho said, all metal foundries will be forced to resettle outside the valley under an agreement the city recently negotiated with the state of Mexico. The rest of the area's industries will be gradually forced to install anti-pollution devices or move out, Camacho said. Camacho said Pemex will also start marketing low-cost liquid propane gas to encourage bus lines and delivery trucks to convert their gasoline engines to the less polluting fuel. Also for next winter, all taxis, trucks and buses will be forced to undergo periodic emission control testing. Testing was required only for private automobiles this winter.

DOC.HEAD: Activists Say They'll Continue Fight Against Military Ban on Gays
DOC.TEXT: Gay rights activists say a Supreme Court rebuff will not deter their continuing fight to overturn a general ban on homosexuals in the armed forces. ``There are other remedies for us to take care of this deeply irrational policy,'' said Peri Jude Radecic of the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force. ``We've had a great deal of congressional interest in this. Within the next year, you'll see some good things coming from Congress.'' The court Monday refused to disturb Pentagon policy, which says ``homosexuality is incompatible with military service.'' The court rejected appeals by Miriam Ben-Shalom, denied re-enlistment in the Army Reserve in Wisconsin because she is a lesbian, and James M. Woodward of Spring Valley, Calif., released from active Navy duty because he is gay. ``The refusal to allow lesbian and gay Americans to enlist in the military constitutes what is probably the most blatant example of official discrimination by the federal government today,'' said Nan Hunter of the American Civil Liberties Union. Ms. Ben-Shalom said after the court's announcement that she may leave the United States. ``I've considered Holland because they consider people like me as legitimate political refugees,'' she said. Army spokesman Joe Padilla said the service was ``pleased that this longstanding litigation ... is finally terminated and that our position has been upheld.'' Ms. Ben-Shalom, who joined the Army Reserve in 1974 and rose to rank of sergeant, served out an enlistment that ended in August 1988. The Army bars ``persons who engage in homosexual conduct or who by their statements demonstrate a propensity to engage in homosexual conduct.'' The 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the policy in August, but noted that there never was a complaint about Ms. Ben-Shalom's military record. Woodward was allowed to enlist in 1972 for a six-year hitch in the Naval Flight Officer Candidate Program even though he answered ``yes'' to a questionnaire asking whether he was sexually attracted to men or desired sex with men. Woodward wrote ``no'' when asked whether he ever had engaged in homosexual conduct. The Navy has allowed some homosexuals to serve despite its general policy. Ensign Woodward was serving in the Philippines in 1974 when he was seen in the Subic Bay Officers' Club sitting with a sailor who was to be discharged for homosexual conduct. Questioned by his commanding officer, Woodward acknowledged his homosexual tendencies but said, ``For the good of both the Navy and myself, I respectfully request the chance to contribute to the defense of the United States as an honest, open, `gay' officer.'' The Navy released him from active duty and assigned him to the Naval Air Reserve staff in San Diego, where he served until his discharge in 1978. In other action Monday, the Supreme Court: _Heard arguments over a federal regulation putting Postal Service property off-limits to solicitors of contributions. A ruling is expected by July. _Said it will decide in a West Virginia case whether a federal law that requires some losers of lawsuits to pay the winners' lawyer fees also covers fees for expert witnesses. _Refused to force the CIA to release documents on the 1985 sinking of the Greenpeace ship Rainbow Warrior by French government agents. _Let stand a 15-year prison sentence and a $6.6 million fine imposed on California businessman Edward Elkins for selling two airplanes with a potential military use to Libya.

DOC.HEAD: Waste Crisis Said Averted at Rocky Flats Weapons Plant
DOC.TEXT: Energy Secretary James D. Watkins says a waste storage problem that threatened the future of the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant has been resolved, at least until late 1991. That's a rare piece of welcome news for Rocky Flats, which is shut down for safety and management improvements. The plant, 16 miles northwest of Denver, also is under FBI investigation for possible criminal violation of environmental laws. Rocky Flats is the nation's sole source of plutonium triggers for nuclear weapons. Watkins told a meeting of the National Governors Association on Monday that a program of ``waste minimization'' at Rocky Flats will keep the plant within its limits of plutonium waste storage until August. By then, he said, the department expects to begin operating a special waste compactor that will enable Rocky Flats to handle all its own waste until late 1991. No specific date was mentioned. It was thought that Rocky Flats would reach its waste limit this spring. Rocky Flats had been sending its excess waste to a weapons facility in Idaho, but when Idaho Gov. Cecil Andrus blocked further shipments last year, Watkins launched an ill-fated effort to persuade seven states _ Colorado, Washington, Idaho, Nevada, New Mexico, Tennessee and South Carolina _ to take equal amounts of Rocky Flats waste. Watkins pleaded on national security grounds, but all seven states turned him down. The Watkins seven-state plan was based on the assumption that Rocky Flats would reach its waste storage limit of 1,600 cubic yards by March or April 1990. The department recently indicated that the crunch might be delayed slightly, but Watkins' statement Monday was the first word of a major change in circumstances. Eventually, the Rocky Flats waste is supposed to go to a permanent underground storage site in the New Mexico desert, but efforts to open that facility _ originally scheduled for 1988 _ have been plagued by delay. Watkins has said the New Mexico dump could be available late this year, but new delays are possible and the facility is unlikely to be in full operation until 1992 or later. In his remarks to the governors meeting, Watkins said the key to relieving the waste-storage pressure at Rocky Flats was a program undertaken by the department and its Rocky Flats contractor to ``segregate and minimize'' the generation of plutonium wastes. ``This effort has been effective in reducing the generation rate from 130 cubic yards per month in March 1989 to 70 cubic yards per month,'' Watkins said. Calls to Watkins' aides seeking additional details on how waste generation was minimized were not returned. In a related development, the department issued a report critical of Rockwell International Corp., which operated Rocky Flats until the end of last year. The company agreed to withdraw from its contract early because of a dispute with Watkins over its approach to Rocky Flats' environmental and safety problems. The department said it was paying Rockwell $2 million for running Rocky Flats from April through September 1989, a cut from the $8.2 million it could have earned. The department said Rockwell's handling of environmental, safety and health programs was unsatisfactory and that management was ``not totally responsive'' to the department's requirements. Rockwell insisted it put a high priority on environmental and safety issues.

DOC.HEAD: Special Session Looks at Discrimination in School Funding, Judge Elections
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Session set to begin 3 p.m. EST, may stand.
DOC.TEXT: The Legislature is opening a special session with its work cut out for it by the courts, which found Texas discriminates in the way it funds schools and elects judges. Gov. Bill Clements called the 30-day session beginning today after the state Supreme Court found ``glaring disparities'' in funding available to rich and poor districts and after a federal court ruled that judicial elections in nine urban counties discriminated against minorities. The state court gave lawmakers until May 1 to overhaul financing for the nation's second-largest school system, with 3.3 million students in 1,100 districts. Only California's school system is larger. Texas schools are funded with local property taxes and state aid; funding totals more than $13 billion a year. The court found that because of disparities in property values, annual spending per student among Texas districts ranges from $2,112 to $19,333. In a 9-0 ruling in October, the court said it would not tell the Legislature how to correct the inequities or order it to increase taxes, but warned: ``A Band-Aid will not suffice; the system itself must be changed.'' At least six major funding proposals, including one costing more than $1 billion, are before legislators. But state Comptroller Bob Bullock warned lawmakers there is no money available for school funding reform. ``If they do spend additional money they need to raise it ... or forever hold their peace,'' he said Monday. The superintendent of San Antonio's Edgewood school district _ the lead plaintiff in the lawsuit challenging the current school funding system _ said it's time the system was made fairer. ``It's been too long that thousands of children in this state, over the last 20 years, have had to go through systems of education that did not provide them the quality of education because of a lack of basic equity in the school finance system,'' James Vasquez said. The Legislature was forced to take up election reform after a federal judge found that countywide elections for district judges in nine counties violated the Voting Rights Act of 1965 by watering down black and Hispanic voting strength. At the time of U.S. District Judge Lucius Bunton's ruling in November, non-Hispanic whites held 155 of the 172 district judgeships in the nine counties, while blacks and Hispanics make up about one-third of the state's poulation. Bunton began dividing the counties into judicial districts in line and in January he ordered special elections in May for 115 judgeships in the counties _ nearly one-third of the state's 375 district judges. But a federal appeals court halted the elections, saying lawmakers should be allowed to draw up the judicial districts.

DOC.HEAD: Police Tailing Foreign Journalists More Since Martial Law Lifted
DOC.TEXT: Foreign journalists say plainclothes police have been tailing them more often _ even while they jog or shop _ in the month since the government lifted martial law in the Chinese capital. Reporters said Monday that as a result they have been more cautious about talking to Chinese, not wanting to get them in trouble with authorities. ``Several (Chinese) contacts have been hauled before the leaders in their (work) units and told, `We know you had contact with a foreign journalist and this must stop,''' said a British reporter. Like the other journalists, he spoke on condition of anonymity for fear of provoking official retaliation against his Chinese friends. Correspondents from nearly a dozen news organizations, including those from the United States, Soviet Union and Europe, said they have been tailed at least once by plainclothes police in recent weeks. Since June, when the government crushed student-led protests for democracy, official access has been more limited, and even many ordinary factories and offices are afraid to let reporters visit for interviews. Under martial law imposed in Beijing during the protests, foreign reporters were required to get military approval for all interviews. The requirement lapsed with the Jan. 11 lifting of martial law, but the police surveillance appeared to be a substitute measure. The British reporter said he had been tailed each of the past three days, and that on one occasion plainclothes police tried to photograph him meeting a Chinese friend in a park. The next day, police followed him to a hotel where he met a Chinese acquaintance, and three motorcycles and a van followed his car from the hotel, keeping pace when he accelerated and drove in circles. After he dropped off the Chinese man, police pursued the man on foot, the reporter said. An American reporter who noticed she was being tailed by a man on a bicycle said it made her decide not to visit Chinese friends, ``so I guess it's working.'' She and several other reporters believe the surveillance, which in many cases has been obvious, is intended to discourage them from normal contacts with Chinese friends or news sources. ``What we're all terribly concerned about is getting a Chinese in trouble,'' said another American reporter who said he and his wife were followed even when they went jogging. In the past, Chinese have been accused of giving state secrets to foreigners with whom they were friendly, and in some instances have been jailed. Others have been denied promotions or the chance to study abroad because of friendship with a foreigner. Without Chinese friends, foreigners find themselves cut off entirely from Chinese society, isolated in their separate apartment compounds and with little access to officials. China does not censor the writings of foreign reporters. However, it censors foreign news entering the country. Authorities tear out articles they consider objectionable before allowing newspapers and magazines to go on sale in hotels. Chinese-language broadcasts of the U.S.-run radio station, the Voice of America, have been jammed since June.

DOC.HEAD: Government Could Save Billion Dollars a Year on Foreign Loans
DOC.TEXT: The Congressional Budget Office says the federal government could save $5.45 billion over five years by ending subsidized loans that help sell U.S. products abroad. Outlays of $4.3 billion are foreseen from 1991 to 1995 under the ``Food for Peace'' program, which provides loans to Third World countries to buy surplus U.S. farm products. Loans can be extended to 40 years at interest rates averaging 2 percent to 3 percent a year, a much longer term and much lower rate than any bank would provide. The detailed report by the bipartisan agency, which presents pros and cons but does not make recommendations to Congress, recently became available. Typically, according to the report on possible changes in revenue and spending, the subsidies average 70 percent of the market price. Governments that buy the food sell it on their home markets and use the proceeds for development projects or other official spending. ``The marketing of some food commodities, most notably wheat and wheat flour, still relies significantly on food-aid programs,'' it said. Some recipient countries, according to the report, complain that the loans are not really aid because most must eventually be repaid. The report said the money from sales is being used increasingly for development projects and that the loans remain one of the few international policy tools in U.S. government hands. To sell American industrial products, subsidized loans are made by the government's Export-Import Bank, largely in the Third World. Savings from abolishing it are estimated at $1.15 billion over five years. The loans are defended on the ground they create jobs, counter similar subsidies from U.S. competitors such as France and Japan, and help U.S. high-technology companies keep up high rates of output. However, the report said, much of the aid is given to exports that don't face foreign competition. ``Direct subsidies to U.S. manufacturing would be more cost-effective,'' the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Kaifu Re-Elected Prime Minster With New-Found Muscle
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with upper house approval. Picks up 5th pvs, `Both houses ...' ^By TETSUO JIMBO
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu was re-elected to Japan's highest government post Tuesday, and immediately began efforts to form a Cabinet that will reflect his new-found political muscle. Kaifu bowed as his formal re-election was proclaimed after a vote in the lower house of Parliament and hailed by a round of rousing applause and scattered cheers. Of 508 valid votes cast in the 512-seat chamber, Kaifu won 286. His closest rival, Socialist Party Chairwoman Takako Doi, received 146 votes. Kaifu needed 255 votes for a majority. Immediately after the lower house vote, Kaifu rushed off without comment to meet party leaders to work out a Cabinet lineup. In the 252-seat upper house, which is controlled by the opposition, Kaifu failed to win a clear majority in the first round of voting, but won in a run-off with 111 of the 246 votes cast. Ms. Doi garnered 91 votes, and 44 ballots were left blank. The decision of the lower house is final, as the chamber by law can name a prime minister without upper house assent. A lack of consensus is rare, however. When Kaifu first assumed office six months ago, he was the first prime minister in 41 years not nominated by both houses. Both houses convened Tuesday for a special 120-day session, the first since Kaifu steered his Liberal Democratic Party through difficult elections for the lower house Feb. 18. Kaifu has strengthened his hand since the elections but powerful party leaders have challenged his move to keep scandal-tainted politicians from the new Cabinet, officials said Monday. Kaifu and party elders agreed Monday to reappoint Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto and Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama, party officials said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The ministers were to continue work on issues such as an unpopular sales tax and trade friction with the United States. The tax and an influence-peddling scandal, which tainted many party elders, stirred doubts over whether the Liberal Democrats could keep their 34-year-old hold on power. Kaifu, who has a clean image but weak power base, assumed the party leadership in August after the influence-peddling and a sex scandal forced two predecessors to step down, and the party lost upper house elections in July. Kaifu, 59, formed an unusually young Cabinet and, for the first time, gave two important ministerial posts to women. But his image suffered from a public perception of him as manipulated by elders, who assumed low profiles because of links to the Recruit scandal. The Feb. 18 voting left the Liberal Democrats with a comfortable lower house majority, however, and Kaifu suggested the results should strengthen his leadership position. Last week, Kaifu strongly opposed recommendations to name two lawmakers linked to the Recruit scandal to top party posts, party officials said. After lengthy negotiations, Kaifu appointed only one. But two major factions within the governing party have suggested Kaifu include in the new Cabinet at least two senior politicians linked to bribery scandals, despite the prime minister's efforts to protect his administration's image, news reports said. The faction led by former Foreign Minister Shintaro Abe insisted that former Education Minister Yoshiro Mori, who was one of 16 politicians linked to the Recruit stock scandal, should be given one of the most prestigious posts, party officials said. Kaifu, however, took an unusually strong stance and told party Secretary General Ichiro Ozawa he would not include politicians tainted by the Recruit scandal. Ozawa eventually convinced Abe to withdraw his request, and, by late Monday, Mori announced he would not seek a post in the Cabinet. One party official said it would have been ``unthinkable for Mr. Kaifu to exert such a strong initiative'' before the election. Another powerful faction led by former Finance Minister Michio Watanabe has been insisting that Takayuki Sato, who was given a suspended sentence in the Lockheed bribery scandal in the 1970s, be included in the Cabinet, officials said. The Liberal Democratic Party, which has governed Japan since it was formed in 1955, comprises four major factions and two smaller groups, including Kaifu's. It is considered one of the prime minister's most important tasks to form a Cabinet based on his own desires without upsetting the factional balance. In the 1988 scandal surrounding the Recruit Co., key politicians acknowledged they received large donations from the information conglomerate in return for political favors.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Ruling Devastates Lesbian Soldier
With PM-Scotus-Checkpoints, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Miriam Ben-Shalom said she has lost faith in the country she wants to serve after the U.S. Supreme Court left intact a military policy that keeps her out of the Army Reserve because she is a lesbian. ``I keep wondering if there is a place out there that will accept me for the human being that I am,'' Ms. Ben-Shalom, who fought the ban on homosexuals for 16 years, said Monday night. ``I feel devastated, I am angry, I am hurt, I am outraged,'' she said. ``I also have lost faith in America. I still love America, but will somebody please tell me what I need to do to be fit? For the rest of my life will appear the words `unfit to serve her country.''' Ms. Ben-Shalom, 41, joined the Reserve in 1974 and was discharged in 1976 after she acknowledged being a lesbian. Army policy at the time barred anyone who ``evidenced homosexual tendencies, desire or interest.'' A federal judge ordered Ms. Ben-Shalom reinstated, and she served out an enlistment that ended in August 1988. But she was barred from re-enlisting under amended Army policy that calls homosexuality ``incompatible with military service.'' The 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in August upheld the policy.
