Although acknowledging there never was any complaint about Ms. Ben-Shalom's performance of her military duties, the court said the Army acted to protect ``morale, discipline and the effectiveness of our fighting forces.'' On Monday, the Supreme Court, without comment, refused to hear Ms. Ben-Shalom's appeal. ``We are pleased that this longstanding litigation brought by Ms. Miriam Ben-Shalom against the U.S. Army is finally terminated and that our position has been upheld,'' Army spokesman Joe Padilla said. The court also summarily rejected an appeal by James M. Woodward of Spring Valley, Calif., who sued in 1976 after he was released from active duty in the Navy because he is gay. In both cases, the Supreme Court did not rule on the legality of the ban. ``My record and the record of all the other gay veterans speak for themselves,'' Woodward said Monday. ``I wasn't on the fast track for an admiralty or anything, but I was a competent officer and did my job.'' Both former soldiers promised to continue their fight through other channels, including Congress and veterans' groups. Ms. Ben-Shalom said the ban on homosexuals persecutes people for being honest. ``Right now, there are a class of people who _ if they tell the truth about themselves _ they are considered to be felons. I think that stinks,'' she said. Ms. Ben-Shalom, who teaches at a high school and a technical college in Milwaukee, said she fears an unfavorable discharge could affect her teaching career. But she said the Army will have to acknowlege that she has ``an impeccable service record.'' ``The fact of the matter is that they can't pretend that I was never there,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Dinkins Declares Death of Far Right; Ascent of Progressivism
DOC.TEXT: If progressive ideas were a stock, now would be the time to buy because conservatism is dead, says Democratic New York Mayor David N. Dinkins. ``The crest of the conservative flood has passed,'' Dinkins, a Democrat, told the National Press Club on Monday. ``The Republicans still occupy the White House, but the conservative coalition has lost its way.'' He said the revolutions in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union herald the death of communism. That, in turn, mean the end of the influence of U.S. conservatives, he said. ``Without communism, they have no enemy, and without an enemy, they have no energy,'' he said. He also predicted that the political right will not be able to win office by running as anti-abortionists, citing as proof his election and alluding to the elections of New Jersey Gov. James Florio and Virginia Gov. Douglas Wilder. ``Who would have thought a year ago that even the chairman of the Republican National Committee would claim to be agnostic on abortion?'' he asked. ``The effort to make God a partisan political being has failed. She will judge our performance later.''
DOC.HEAD: Teachers Want States to Require Geography
DOC.TEXT: A new survey shows high school teachers want students to get closer to geography in order to graduate. The nationwide survey of 852 elementary and secondary school social studies and geography teachers found 86 percent favored changing requirements to require that high school students pass a geography course in order to graduate. Eighty-seven percent want state governments to increase geography requirements. The Rand McNally Report on Geography Education in America, conducted by Ketchum Communications Research and Measurement, was released Monday on the heels of the first study of geography education by the National Assessment of Educational Progress. That report said high school seniors have a gap in their knowledge of geography, with only 37 percent able to find Southeast Asia on a world map. The average student could answer just 57 percent of the questions and the best score among more than 3,000 students tested was 59 percent, the report showed.
DOC.HEAD: Extra MH-47E Boeing Helicopters Unneeded
DOC.TEXT: The Defense Department doesn't have a ``sound mission-based justification'' to spend an estimated $532 million to buy 34 additional helicopters for commando missions, a congressional report says. But the Defense Department said plans to cancel the new V-22 Osprey vertical takeoff airplane make the additional helicopters necessary. The General Accounting Office said Monday the Army based its decision to buy 34 MH-47E helicopters from The Boeing Co.'s Philadelphia-based Helicopters Division, in addition to its own needs of 17, on a May 1984 agreement between the Army and the Air Force. The accord said the Air Force would transfer the responsibility for providing helicopter support for commando operations to the Army. But in June 1987, the Defense Department told Congress that it had revised its requirements and only needed 17 MH-47E helicopters, and 41 MH-53J helicopters, to fly these missions of about 265 to 520 miles. ``The Army's reason for procuring an additional 34 MH-47E aircraft is based on an earlier memorandum of agreement between the Air Force and the Army, which has been superseded by the 1987 report,'' the GAO said.

DOC.HEAD: Idealistic Sandinistas Profoundly Changed Their Land
DOC.TEXT: They were full of vigor and revolutionary fervor, fresh from the mountains and battles and ready to spread the gospel of Marx. As their 10{ years in power came to an end, they could list among their accomplishments improved educational and health systems and, in a final irony that could only be confirmed by accepting defeat, democracy. They were the Sandinistas, young guerrillas who looked to Cuba's socialist society as a model after they smashed the corrupt capitalist system of dictator Anastasio Somoza's regime. In recent years, dismayed by the disparity between economic theory and practice, they denied they were Marxists and became believers in private property and a mixed economy. They sought improved relations with a Roman Catholic Church they had attacked and vilified in the person of Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo. But they were booted on Sunday by an electorate fed up with economic crisis, the eight-year war with U.S.-backed Contra rebels, internal political polarization and a confrontation with Washington that led to regional isolation. ``I don't think we were ever real Marxists,'' said a high-ranking official on condition of anonymity. ``We read mostly bad translations in Mexico. We will probably end up as social democrats.'' But whether Marxists or social democrats, the Sandinistas with their black-and-red bandannas, their youthfully dogmatic policies, anti-U.S. rhetoric and social reforms left an imprint on the soul of Nicaragua. ``There is no question that there was a revolution here and it cannot be reversed whether you agree with it or not,'' said the Rev. Bismarck Carballo, a bitter critic of the Sandinistas. Even critics acknowledge that the Sandinistas changed Nicaragua and like to speculate on how things might have been different had the Sandinistas not been so bitterly anti-American. The United States, which provided nearly $100 million in aid in the months following the Somoza overthrow, turned against them, accusing them of domestic repression and of going back on pledges they would found a politically pluralistic and democratic society. Eventually, the United States financed the Contra rebels that tied up tens of thousands of Sandinista soldiers and drained more than 40 per cent of the country's budget. The Sandinistas' first accomplishment was a massive literacy campaign in which they involved young idealistic youths who went into the mountains to suffer with peasants while teaching them to read and write along with the basic tenets of Sandinismo, a nationalist mixture of populism and Marxism. As they pulled away from their Central American neighbors and from the United States, they brought in Cuban and Eastern European technicians to build schools and hospitals. Their concern for social needs made them popular among the so-called ``internationalist set'' that attached itself to anti-U.S. causes. They confiscated banks and controlled foreign trade. They established free higher education, eliminated polio and reduced infant mortality, established price controls and gave away tens of thousands of lots for housing. Brigades of volunteers from Europe and the United States came to Nicaragua to help pick coffee in the daytime and sing revolutionary songs at night. The Sandinistas confiscated tens of thousands of acres, giving it to thousands of landless peasants whom they organized into cooperatives. But that and the draft drove thousands into the arms of the Contras and created hostility across broad swaths of the countryside. They antagonized a powerful business class, confiscating property, and irritated the establishment church in this staunchley Roman Catholic land with their support of the so-called popular church. Many companies became property of the state and began losing money under the guidance of inexperienced and dogmatic managers who sacrificed efficiency in the name of worker control or egalitarianism. The Sandinistas also irritated their regional neighbors with open support of the leftist rebels of neighboring El Salvador, who found a haven in Nicaragua and a steady supply of weapons. Eventually bureaucracy, rigid state planning and a U.S. economic embargo sent the Sandinista economy into a dive. ``They defeated the Contra militarily, but they could not defeat the economic crisis,'' said Mauricio Diaz, leader of the Social Christian Party. Their economy became closely tied to that of Eastern European countries and Cuba. For years practically every local product was rationed, gasoline was limited to 20 gallons a month per car and most imported items were expensive and of low quality. ``We were not just committed to economic growth, but to social and economic equality,'' wrote governnent official Edmundo Jarquin in a recent article. In recent years, under pressure from European countries and as their East bloc allies abandoned centrally planned socialism, the Sandinistas began seeking closer ties with the United States. Their biggest accomplishment, ironically, caused their undoing. They promised and carried out a clean, fair election, and when the electorate turned against them they promised to respect the voters' decision. ``We are proud, regardless of the results, to give Nicaragua and the underdeveloped countries of America a bit of dignity, a bit of democracy and a bit of social justice,'' Ortega said with painful pride as he acknowledged defeat.

DOC.HEAD: One Debut in Met's `Abduction'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs Planned
DOC.TEXT: A fine cast, which included a performer making his Metropolitan Opera debut, made ``Abduction from the Seraglio'' a musical and visual treat. James Levine conducted the Mozart comedy with dash on Monday night. Lars Magnusson, a principal lyric tenor with the Royal Opera in Stockholm, was making his U.S. opera debut as Pedrillo, servant of Belmonte, a Spanish nobleman. It's the role he sang for his 1987 debut at Covent Garden and will sing for his San Francisco Opera debut next season. He has an unusual light tenor voice. It doesn't get heavy but it does have character. It's as though it has been given a light layer of wood-grained baritone tonal quality, the way colored varnish might be brushed onto a light wood. It sounds right for David in ``Die Meistersinger,'' which was Magnusson's Paris Opera debut role. Stanford Olsen of Salt Lake City provided a good tenor contrast as Belmonte. Olsen sounded serious, his voice focused and seemingly ready to sing oratorio. Mariella Devia of Imperia, Italy, sang Konstanze, the young woman who has been captured by pirates and sold to the Pasha for his harem. Her maid, Blondchen, and Pedrillo are captives in the Pasha's residence _ seraglio _ with her. Miss Devia's singing was like a string of pearls, her tone sweet, each note carefully rounded and clear. Both she and Barbara Kilduff as Blonchen had coloratura passages and both sang them beautifully. Miss Kilduff's acting was more understated and less relentlessly pert than some who sing Blonchen. But Magnusson was more nimble than most who sing Pedrillo, so the balance of that pair of sweethearts was maintained. Bass Kurt Moll of Buir, Germany, was Osmin, the Pasha's overseer. He was the only one in the cast who sang his part when this production was introduced in 1979. Moll has a voice of depth and richness and he has added some effective bits of comedy to a portrayal that already was very funny. Nico Castel took the speaking part of the Pasha. He creates the happy ending after Osmin discovers the abduction attempt by wandering around and sticking his arm through the plotters' ladder.

DOC.HEAD: Family Bids Private Farewell to Forbes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to fix typo in `horsemen.'
DOC.TEXT: Publisher Malcolm Forbes, who once threw himself a Gatsby-like birthday party attended by nearly 1,000 guests, was carried from a church in a pine coffin after a funeral attended only by immediate family. The funeral Monday at the tiny Church of St. John on the Mountain included a bagpiper playing a mournful ``Scotland the Brave.'' Forbes, the balloonist, motorcyclist, lavish party-thrower and owner of the business magazine that bears his family name, died of a heart attack in his sleep Saturday at his 40-acre estate in nearby Far Hills. He was 70. A public memorial service is planned for Thursday at a church in New York City. Monday's service took place in the church his family had attended since the late 1950s. His son Malcolm ``Steve'' Jr., who will succeed him as head of the publishing empire, delivered the eulogy, said the Rev. Alfred Niese, pastor of the Episcopal church. Also attending were Forbes' former wife, Roberta; daughter Moira Mumma; his other sons, Robert, Christopher and Timothy, and eight grandchildren. Following the 1\-hour ceremony, Forbes' flag-draped coffin was carried to a hearse. His body is to be cremated and the ashes are to be placed on the Fiji island of Lucala, owned by the Forbes family. Forbes, whose worth has been estimated at $400 million to $1 billion, had made his last birthday, in August, his biggest. He spent $2 million on the party in Morocco. It featured 600 belly dancers, 200 Berber horsemen, pigeon pie served under tents, and a guest list that included Elizabeth Taylor, Henry Kissinger, Barbara Walters and Lee Iacocca.

DOC.HEAD: Boy in Coma After Drinking Bourbon
DOC.TEXT: A 5-year-old lapsed into a coma after a friend of his mother's handed him a bottle of bourbon and told him to ``drink it like a man,'' police said. Anthony Jimerson, 21, of Forest Hills was jailed on $100,000 bail on charges of causing injury to a child. Police in suburban Everman said Raymond Griffin was given the alcohol at a party Friday night. ``The guy took the lid off the bottle, gave it to the kid and he took a big swallow,'' said Sgt. Mark Bigler. Raymond, who weighs about 60 pounds, drank about 10 ounces of bourbon _ roughly the equivalent of a fifth of alcohol for an average adult, Bigler said. The boy was in critical condition Monday in a coma at Cook-Fort Worth Children's Medical Center, where he was taken Saturday after he went into convulsions, authorities said. At one point, the boy's blood-alcohol level was about .55 percent _ more than five times the legal limit for driving in many states _ and he probably will suffer brain damage, the officer said. Jimerson had been invited to play dominoes at the home of Raymond's mother, Patricia Griffin, 31, police said.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: University of Texas groundskeepers launched a pyrotechnic assault that finally chased hundreds of cackling grackles from the campus. But they ruffled some gubernatorial feathers in the process. University officials had tried for five years to chase away the grackles, small blackbirds that taunted students with their cackling and soiled sidewalks with their plentiful droppings. For four straight nights this month, groundskeepers armed with exploding Roman candle-type devices waged an all-out artillery offensive, finally succeeding in shooing the birds off-campus. The birds headed south _ straight for the governor's mansion, less than a mile away. They converged on the lawn in one big, mad squawking flock, as if demanding an audience with Gov. Bill Clements himself. He was not home. The staff immediately knew where the birds came from, and called university officials, said Anne DeBois, the mansion's administrator. ``We don't want the grackles here,'' she said. ``They are unwelcome tourists.'' So the university sent their bird-bombers to the mansion to drive the flock away. ``We're waiting to see whether they come back,'' said Howard Wilson, university maintenance chief. ``But for the time being, it's now a much nicer place.''

Natalie Tennant says her school spirit, not a desire to be a 20th century pioneer, prompted her to try to become the West Virginia University Mountaineers' mascot _ an 18th century frontiersman. ``I think when people first hear of a lady Mountaineer, they think, `Oh, no.' But the reason I applied was not to prove any point, but to show my enthusiasm,'' Tennant, the first woman finalist for the position, said Monday. Tennant, 22, a broadcast journalism student from Fairview, is competing against junior business student Doug McClung, 21, of Waynesboro, Va. Mountain Honorary, a group of student leaders, on Thursday night will announce which of the two will don the buckskin and carry the muzzleloading rifle. Marilyn McClure, president of Mountain Honorary, said several people called a radio talk show during the weekend to oppose a frontierswoman mascot. But women's groups on campus have said it's a step forward that a woman even felt she could apply for the job, McClure said. Gordon Thorn, adviser for Mountain Honorary, said the mascot's gender makes no difference. ``The spirit is the thing. I'm sure the women had just as much pioneer spirit as the men did to get through those days,'' Thorn said.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Sets its Sights on Wednesday Morning Shuttle Launch
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf pvs, `Atlantis' commander ...' to CORRECT that only three astronauts returned to Houston for tuneup training.
DOC.TEXT: NASA set its sights on a sixth attempt early Wednesday to launch space shuttle Atlantis on a secret military mission, but the weather forecast still looked dim. Air Force forecasters said there was only a 40 percent chance the weather would allow liftoff at 12:45 a.m. High winds and clouds are expected to move into the launch area, and the outlook for Thursday is about the same. The five delays in as many days have so far have cost NASA $2.75 million in fuel, labor and materials. Atlantis' mission is classified, but sources who spoke on condition of anonymity said the shuttle is on a 4{-day mission to put in orbit a $500 million satellite capable of taking detailed photos and listening in on electronic communications over much of the world. The latest postponement came early Monday. NASA kept the spacecraft and crew poised for favorable conditions, but good weather never developed, and the space agency decided to hold off for 48 hours before trying again. ``It's going to give us all a chance to get some rest,'' said NASA spokesman Bruce Buckingham. Atlantis' commander, John O. Creighton, a Navy captain, led two members of his five-man, all-military crew back to Houston on Monday for tuneup training at the Johnson Space Center. They were to return to the Kennedy Space Center today. Atlantis was delayed twice because of weather and Creighton's sore throat and nasal congestion. Weather alone caused two other delays and a failed computer was blamed for another. The first attempt was last Thursday. A sixth delay will tie Atlantis for the number of launch postponements experienced by two earlier missions. Columbia lifted off Jan. 12, 1986 after six delays caused by weather and mechanical problems. Challenger's ill-fated launch on Jan. 28, 1986 came after six delays, three as a result of the Columbia postponements and three that came during actual countdowns. With Creighton on the mission are Air Force Col. John H. Casper, the pilot, and mission specialists Marine Lt. Col. David C. Hilmers, Air Force Col. Richard M. Mullane and Navy Cmdr. Pierre J. Thuot. Atlantis' flight will be the 34th shuttle mission and the sixth classified military flight.

DOC.HEAD: Rocky Statue Loses Art Museum Battle
DOC.TEXT: Rocky Balboa is down but not out. A crew worked two hours with a diamond-tipped circular saw and jackhammer to free the 8{-foot bronze likeness of the movie boxing champ from the steps of the Philadelphia Museum of Art before returning it to the Spectrum sports arena. But fans of the South Philadelphia palooka played by Sylvester Stallone said Monday they will fight to return the 800-pound statue to the stone stairway made famous in the original ``Rocky.'' Museum President Robert Montgomery Scott has said the statue is a movie prop, not art, and he doesn't want it in front of the classical building. Among those working to keep the statue there is James Binns, a lawyer and former boxing commissioner hired by Stallone. In Binns' corner is Mayor W. Wilson Goode, who has come out in favor of the statue as a tourist attraction. The city Art Commission said it will wait 60 days before determining whether the statue of Rocky in boxing trunks, arms raised in triumph, will be returned to the steps. The statue, which first appeared at the museum during the shooting of ``Rocky III'' in 1981, was brought back from the Spectrum for filming of ``Rocky V.'' Filming ended Friday, clearing the way for the producers to honor their contract to move the statue. ``I feel kind of bad,'' said Bret Carpin, one of the workers who cut the figure from its concrete base. ``I hope he doesn't hold it against us.'' The museum was closed Monday as usual, but a crowd of TV camera crews, photographers and curious museum employees circled the statue. Before the movers arrived, more than 30 members of a high school swim team from Jacksonville, Fla., came to see the statue while in town for a swim meet. It was the first tourist site they saw, even before the Liberty Bell. In the original ``Rocky,'' which won the Oscar for best picture in 1976, Rocky runs up the stone steps in triumph while training for a fight. The Los Angeles publicist for ``Rocky V,'' Dave Fulton, said of the statue's fate, ``It's pretty much up to the people of Philadelphia. It's out of our hands.''

DOC.HEAD: Canceled Meeting Jeopardizes Season Openers
DOC.TEXT: A canceled meeting between club owners and the baseball players' union sent the spring training lockout into its 13th day today and dimmed the prospects of the season opening on time. Union chief Donald Fehr canceled negotiations Monday with the owners, who he said offered nothing new in a dispute that is mostly over what year in their careers players can enter into salary arbitration. Players want that right after two years instead of three. Owners and players say a minimum of three weeks of spring training and several days for players to travel to camps are needed before the season can begin on time April 2. No new talks were scheduled. ``The season is in very heavy jeopardy,'' Baseball Commissioner Fay Vincent said Monday. He said he sympathized with fans who endured a 50-day strike in 1981, and he called the standoff ``tragic to the point of absurdity.'' Fourteen of the nation's governors sent a letter to Vincent on Monday, calling the labor dispute ``a national disgrace.'' ``Baseball is too important to our country _ both economically and culturally _ to allow this to drag on,'' the letter said. Minimum salary, player benefits and team roster size are also at issue.

DOC.HEAD: Ortega Makes Gesture of Peace With Victorious Rival; Transition Talks Begin
LaserPhotos MGA2,3
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Supporters of his victorious rival cheered President Daniel Ortega at length as he entered the home of Violeta Barrios de Chamorro and embraced her, offering his help in national reconciliation. ``There are neither winners nor losers here, Daniel,'' Mrs. Chamorro told the man she defeated in a stunning electoral upset the previous day. The short congratulatory visit was another statesmanlike gesture from the 44-year-old revolutionary leader of this country torn by civil war and partisan bitterness. Earlier Monday, Ortega conceded defeat in an eloquent, impassioned television speech. He said his Sandinistas would honor the voters' wishes and, after 10 years of one-party rule, surrender power to the fractious 6-month-old United Nationalist Opposition (UNO) alliance Mrs. Chamorro led to victory. When Ortega visited Mrs. Chamorro accompanied by key international observers including former President Jimmy Carter, she greeted him warmly. ``Come here, my darling,'' she told Ortega. ``I love you very much.'' The post-election holiday was mostly quiet and transition talks began between Sandinista and Uno leaders. There were, however, brief clashes in the capital between inebriated Sandinista and opposition militants. Ortega may have lost Sunday's peaceful election, but his Sandinistas remain the country's largest party and control the military as they go into transition talks with Mrs. Chamorro's U.S.-backed coalition. He has promised to relinquish power to Mrs. Chamorro on April 25, when the 60-year-old publisher of the country's only opposition newspaper is to be inaugurated for a six-year term. But he will become a member of the National Assembly, where Sunday's elections put the Sandinistas in opposition. For a year after the 1979 revolution that toppled the corrupt Somoza regime, Ortega had shared podiums with Mrs. Chamorro, whose husband's assassination a year earlier helped ignite the Sandinista revolution. But she became disillusioned with the leftist Sandinistas as they turned repressive and dogmatic, and left the revolutionary leadership. In 1981, with former President Reagan's blessing and support, the Contra rebel insurgency was launched. U.S. trade sanctions followed and before long the centrally planned, poorly managed economy was in decline. Mrs. Chamorro, then, inherits a country wracked by inflation with a huge trade imbalance and will surely be seeking substantial U.S. aid. In Washington, there was elation and Bush adminstration officials said lifting the U.S. economic embargo was under discussion. President Bush called on both the Sandinistas and Contras to exercise restraint: ``Given the clear mandate for peace and democracy, there is no reason at all for further military activity from any quarter.'' With 82 per cent of the vote counted, Mrs. Chamorro was leading Ortega by 633,357 votes, or 55.2 per cent, to 468,040 votes, or 40.8 per cent. The breakdown of 90 directly elected National Assembly seats had not been announced, but Ortega was certain to receive one of the special seats reserved for losing presidential candidates who win more than 1 percent of the vote. On Monday, Sandinista and UNO leaders met with each other, with Carter and other key international observers. ``We want to make sure there is a smooth transition of power,'' Foreign Minister Miguel d'Escoto said in an interview. Carter said that he, representatives of the United Nations and the Organization of American States had agreed to stay and help both parties during the transition period. One of the main points of the transition discussions is the role of the army, closely identified with the Sandinistas and now a strong, well-trained organization following years of warfare. The opposition coalition wants to reduce military spending and abolish the draft, while the Sandinistas are opposed to a quick, drastic reduction. In Managua on Monday night, several dozen drunken supporters of both sides traded insults and clashed briefly in the streets. And in the provincial capital of Leon, Sandinista activists occupied opposition party headquarters for a time but left peacefully. The Managua confrontation developed into a drunken rock- and bottle-throwing fracas that was broken up by riot police using tear gas. Afterward, Mrs. Chamorro's campaign manager, Antonio Lacayo, went into the street later told UNO supporters: ``I have a message from Violeta, and it's that you should go home right now, and peacefully.'' All but a few of the more inebriated celebrants dispersed. One man was cut in the head during the clash, reporters on the scene said. For most international observers it was getaway day, and senators, congressmen and other dignitaries hustled into buses to head for the airport. At the Olof Palme Convention Center, saddened members of international pro-Sandinista groups gathered in front of video monitors to watch taped replays of Ortega's concession speech. In the crowd in front of one monitor stood actor Ed Asner and singer Jackson Browne. On Radio Sandino, the party station, callers expressed anger, sorrow and determination to continue as a party. While one caller said Ortega shouldn't step down because the election was fraudulent, most were far more poignant. ``Daniel, Daniel, we are still with you,'' said one tearful girl from the nearby city of Masaya, the cradle of the Sandinista revolution. Ortega had called the election and invited the international observers that made Sunday's the freest balloting in Nicaraguan history and perhaps the most closely monitored anywhere. After overthrowing dictator Anastasio Somoza, the Sandinistas transformed the country into a revolutionary state, redistributing wealth to poor peasants, improving the literacy rate and nationalizing major industries. The Ortega government won strong support from the Soviet Union and Cuba and was accused by the United States of trying to foment a Communist revolution in neighboring El Salvador. But the embattled Sandinistas recently abandoned strident socialism and, with economic support from the Soviet bloc decreasing, sought closer ties with the United States. Their loss at the polls follows by just a few months the restoration of democracy in much of the East bloc and moves toward democratization in the Soviet Union itself.

DOC.HEAD: Key Dates in Decade of Sandinismo
With PM-Nicaragua, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Important events in the decade the Sandinistas have ruled Nicaragua: _ July 19, 1979: The Sandinista National Liberation Front enters Managua, two days after dictator Anastasio Somoza had fled in secret and begins its rule. _ April 1980: Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, whose husband was assassinated in a killing that helped bring the Sandinistas to power, quits the governing junta, claiming health problems. Mrs. Chamorro, who succeeded her husband as publisher of the newspaper La Prensa, would soon start criticizing the Sandinistas. _ November: First attacks by anti-Sandinistas who became known as Contras, short for the Spanish word for counterrevolutionary. _ February 1981: The Reagan administration announces suspension of aid to Nicaragua and accuses the Sandinista Front of aiding leftist guerrillas in El Salvador. _ April 9, 1984: Nicaragua asks the World Court to order the United States to stop helping the Contras. The Reagan administration announces it won't accept the court's jurisdiction. _ Jan. 10, 1985: Daniel Ortega is inaugurated as president following national elections. _ May 1: Reagan announces a trade embargo against Nicaragua. _ June 27: The World Court says U.S. support of the Contras violates the U.N. charter's ban on use of force. _ Aug. 13: The U.S. Senate approves Reagan's request for a military aid package for the Contras. _ Oct. 5, 1986: An American-manned cargo plane is shot down over Nicaragua. Surviving crew member Eugene Hasenfus is captured and implicates the CIA in Contra-supply operations. Hasenfus is subsequently freed. _ Nov. 25: U.S. Attorney General Edwin Meese says some of the profits from the sale of American arms to Iran were secretly diverted to the Contras in an operation under U.S. Marine Lt. Col. Oliver North. _ Aug. 7, 1987: Five Central American presidents sign a regional peace plan sponsored by Costa Rican President Oscar Arias. He would subsequently receive the Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts. The plan called for amnesties for political prisoners, democratic reforms, an end to foreign aid for irregular forces, and prohibiting one country from allowing its territory to be used by guerrillas to attack another country. _ Feb. 3, 1988: Congress cuts off military aid to the Contras but continues non-lethal aid. _ March: Sandinistas and Contras meet for the first time in face-to-face peace talks in the Nicaraguan border post of Sapoa. _ April 1: A formal 60-day truce begins. _ May 31: The Sandinistas decide to extend the cease-fire on a month-to-month basis; the Contras say they consider the truce indefinite. Fighting slackens. _ July 11: U.S. Ambassador Richard Melton is expelled from Nicaragua along with eight other U.S. diplomats, accused of trying to destabilize the Sandinista government. Washington retaliates by expelling the Nicaraguan ambassador, Carlos Tunnerman, and eight other diplomats. _ September: Contra-Sandinista talks break down, but thousands of Contra guerrilla fighters are moving out of the Nicaraguan hinterland into base camps in Honduras. _ Jan. 30, 1989: Ortega announces a tough austerity program to combat world-record inflation that surpassed 33,600 percent in 1988. _ Feb. 14: Five Central American presidents sign an accord in El Salvador. Ortega promises early elections in exchange for dismantling the Contras, based in Honduran jungle camps. _ April 28: President Bush signs a $49 million non-lethal aid package for the Contras. The package runs out Feb. 28, 1990. _ Aug. 7: Five Central American presidents meeting in Tela, Honduras, sign an agreement to dismantle the Contras' bases in Honduras by Dec. 8, 1989. They ask help from the United Nations and the Organization of American States. The rebels are not signatories to that pact, which says their demobilization must be ``voluntary.'' The Bush administration wants the Contras to remain intact to guarantee that elections set for Feb. 25, 1990, are free and fair. _ Aug. 26: Contra Commander Israel Galeano says the rebels will ignore the Tela accord and U.S. advice and starts moving his troops back to Nicaragua. _ Nov. 1: Ortega announces the lifting of the 19-month-old cease-fire after several attacks and the infiltration of thousands of Contra troops. Fighting surges briefly, but returns to the low level it had reached earlier, after the U.S. cut off lethal aid. _ Nov. 27: Ortega refuses to deny Nicaragua's role in a shipment of missiles found when a small plane crashes in El Salvador. The United States and El Salvador accuse the Sandinistas of continuing to help the Salvadoran guerrillas, who had launched their biggest offensive Nov. 11. _ Dec. 12: Ortega and four Central American presidents issue a communique calling for the demobilization of both the Salvadoran guerrillas and the Contras. _ Sunday: Elections are held and Mrs. Chamorro's coalition defeats Ortega. _ Monday: Ortega concedes, visits Mrs. Chamorro at her home and promises to promote national reconciliation. Transition talks begin.

DOC.HEAD: Sheriff Reaches Three Centuries Back for Legal Argument
DOC.TEXT: A sheriff who seized a National Guard armory to ease jail overcrowding is relying in part on a 300-year-old statute that compels others to help him keep the peace _ or face four hours in the stocks. ``It sounds funny, people laugh about it now,'' county attorney Edward McDonough said Monday. ``But I think people realize that the emergency we faced in 1990 in Hampden County was something that was unprecedented.'' The issue arose Feb. 16 when Sheriff Michael Ashe seized the armory, telling surprised guardsmen that lack of jail space posed an imminent danger of a breach of the peace. On Friday, Ashe won the right to keep inmates at the armory while county and state officials try to work out a compromise location. A hearing on the matter was set March 12. Assistant Attorney General Lawrence Fletcher-Hill argued the sheriff is a county official with no authority to take state property. Ashe cited a law dating from the Massachusetts Bay Colony that allows a sheriff to require assistance in carrying out his duties with regard to criminals. Anyone refusing to help, if convicted before ``one or more of his majestie's justices of the peace, such offender or offenders shall be fined, to the use of the poor of the town where the offence shall be committed, not exceeding forty shillings, at the discretion of such justice or justices, acording to the circumstances aggravating or lessening such offence,'' reads the statute in the Acts and Resolves, Public and Private of the Province of the Massachusetts Bay. Those unwilling to come up with the 40 shillings could spend 48 hours in prison or four hours in the stocks. McDonough said in addition to the old statute, the county also is arguing that the sheriff's duty is to house convicted prisoners, something his overcrowded jail wouldn't allow.

DOC.HEAD: Coasters Lead Singer Slain in Car
DOC.TEXT: Cornell Gunter, lead singer of The Coasters, the comic do-wop group that had hits in the late '50s with ``Yakety Yak'' and ``Charlie Brown,'' was shot to death while driving, police said today. He was 53. Gunter was shot twice in the chest at an intersection at midday Monday was found slumped over the steering wheel of the car, police said. ``It appears he was shot through the windshield and he was dead on the scene. We don't have a motive at this time,'' said Lt. Gary Rainey. Gunter and The Coasters had been scheduled to perform at the Lady Luck Hotel this weekend, said Janice Mazuroski, a spokeswoman at the hotel. A tenor, Gunter joined The Coasters in 1957, two years after the group was formed in Los Angeles. With a flurry of hits that included ``Yakety Yak'' in 1957 and ``Charlie Brown,'' ``Along Came Jones'' and ``Poison Ivy'' in 1959, The Coasters were the nation's most popular black rock 'n roll group at the end of the decade. Other hits included ``Framed,'' ``Idol with the Golden Head'' and ``Shoppin' for Clothes.'' Their last chart appearance was in 1971 with ``Love Potion No.9.'' ``Yakety Yak'' contained the refrain, ``Yakety yak, don't talk back,'' while ``Charlie Brown'' was known for line, ``Why's everybody always pickin' on me?'' With changes in personnel, Gunter kept the group on the concert circuit, with the current ensemble known as Cornell Gunter and His Coasters. Various band members headed separate groups in recent years billed as The Coasters. Gunter was a native of Los Angeles. In 1987, he was inducted into the Rock n' Roll Hall of Fame.

DOC.HEAD: Snow Falls Over Midwest; Freeze Grips Northeast
DOC.TEXT: The Northeast shivered in temperatures lower than those in much of Alaska early today, while snow fell over northern Michigan. Temperatures dropped to 0 at Albany, N.Y., minus 1 in Portland, Maine., and the 20s in Philadelphia and New York, which on Friday had highs in the 60s. It was a relatively balmy 31 degrees in Anchorage, Alaska, where the temperature climbed to 43 on Monday. The high for the nation Monday was 85 degrees at Borrego Springs and Palm Springs, Calif., Buckeye, Coolidge, Gila Bend and Yuma, Ariz., and Laughlin, Nev. Elsewhere, snow fell on Sault Ste. Marie in upper Michigan early today, and rain dampened Indianapolis. Most of the rest of the nation enjoyed fair weather. On Monday evening, snow fell over eastern North Dakota, northern Minnesota, and northern Wisconsin. Snow also fell over eastern Kentucky, while rain mixed with snow over southeast Minnesota. DOC.HEAD: Salvadoran Leaders Hope For Domestic Peace After Chamorro Victory
With PM-Nicaragua, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: This country's rightist government says it hopes the opposition victory in Nicaragua will have a ripple effect in El Salvador and improve chances of ending a leftist insurgency backed by Managua. ``I believe that now is when the Salvadoran democratic process should open political spaces for the incorporation of the guerrillas and seek social harmony,'' Armando Calderon Sol, head of the governing Nationalist Republican Alliance Party, known as Arena, said Monday. In Nicaragua, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro of the United National Opposition alliance on Sunday defeated President Daniel Ortega of the Sandinistas, who have ruled since coming to power in a 1979 revolution and backed the Salvadoran rebels. ``With the upset of the Sandinistas, democracy in the region is taking hold. There's no call to go on killing in El Salvador, and we should facilitate dialogue,'' Calderon said. There was no immediate comment from the rebels, fighting the right-wing Salvadoran government in a 10-year-old civil war that has claimed 72,000 lives. The government, which broke diplomatic and commercial ties with Nicaragua in November over arms shipments to the rebels, congratulated Mrs. Chamorro in a statement issued by Deputy Foreign Minister Ricardo Valdivieso. Chamorro's triumph ``opens broad hopes for Nicaragua's social and economic development process and that of the whole Central American region,'' Valdivieso said. Salvadoran opposition party spokesman Ruben Zamora also praised Ortega's government for holding clean and free elections. The elections ``are an example of democracy,'' said Zamora, head of the Popular Social Christian Movement party and the Democratic Revolutionary Front. Zamora's party and the Democratic Revolutionary Front are politically aligned with the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front (FMLN) guerrillas. Calderon, referring to rumors that Nicaragua has sent weapons to the Salvadoran rebels, said the fall of Sandinista government means ``the FMLN is historically cut off.'' Col. Mauricio Ernesto Vargas, military commander in four eastern provinces of El Salvador, said, ``This means the FMLN will have to change. They're going to lose the suupport they had from Nicaragua for damaging the political economic and social system in El Salvador,'' he said. ``Peace is closer with the change in Nicaragua,'' Vargas said in a telephone interview with The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Death Sentence For Man Who Traffcked in 1.61 Million Dollars Of Heroin
DOC.TEXT: A court has sentenced to death a 46-year-old gambling den operator after convicting him on charges of trafficking in $1.61 million worth of heroin, news media reported today. Tan Boon Tat was found guilty of transporting 2{ pounds of heroin on May 10 1987, the Singapore Broadcasting Corporation reported. Trial judges Yong Pung How and L.P. Thean, in sentencing Tan on Monday, rejected his defense that he did not know the drug was in the trunk of his car, the Straits Times daily reported. The court was told narcotics officers trailed him from his gambling den to a coffee shop, from which he emerged with a plastic bag. He was then trailed back to near his gambling den, stopped at the entrance to a parking lot and arrested. Tan claimed the bag was left in his car by a friend a few days before his arrest. Thirty-eight people have now been sentenced to death in Singapore on drug trafficking charges under a 1975 law that allows the death penalty in such case, the Central Narcotics Bureau said. Of them, 26 have been hanged.

DOC.HEAD: New McMartin Judge Picked
DOC.TEXT: A judge known for running an efficient court has been picked to hear charges left over from the nation's longest and costliest criminal trial, the McMartin preschool molestation case. Superior Court Judge Stanley Weisberg replaces Judge William Pounders, who presided over the trial of Peggy McMartin Buckey, 63, and her son, Raymond, 31. The nearly three-year trial cost more than $15 million. A jury in January acquitted the Buckeys on 53 child molestation charges but deadlocked on 13 counts against the son. His retrial is set for March 9. Gary Klausner, supervising judge of the Los Angeles Superior Court's central criminal division, announced Weisberg's assignment Monday. Klausner removed Pounders on the recommendation of Superior Court Judge Michael Hoff, who ruled last week that Pounders' post-trial TV appearances could hamper selection of a new jury. Weisberg, 47, spent 18 years as a Los Angeles County prosecutor. He won a murder conviction in the slaying of Vicky Morgan, mistress of business tycoon Alfred Bloomingdale. Weisberg, appointed to the bench two years ago by Gov. George Deukmejian, has a reputation for moving cases along efficiently. He will meet with prosecutors and defense lawyers in a pretrial hearing Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Iphigene Ochs Sulzberger Dead at 97
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf pvs, `Ochs appointed ...' to fix style on `20s'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY10
DOC.TEXT: Newspaper heiress Iphigene Ochs Sulzberger, whose powerful acquaintances included every president from Coolidge to Kennedy and whose subtle but firm influence shaped The New York Times, has died at age 97. Trustee of the family fortune and the daughter, wife, mother-in-law and mother of Times publishers, Mrs. Sulzberger died in her sleep of respiratory failure Monday at her home in Stamford, Conn. She played an important role in selecting publishers of the Times after her father, Adolph S. Ochs, acquired it in 1896, and she worked to expand the paper's coverage of women's affairs and its circulation in schools. ``You cannot think of Iphigene Ochs Sulzberger without thinking of The New York Times. And it is impossible to imagine the Times without Iphigene Sulzberger,'' wrote former Times editor Harrison E. Salisbury in the introduction of her memoirs, ``Iphigene: My Life and The New York Times.'' She recalled meeting ``many interesting people'' as a child: Mark Twain, Andrew Carnegie, President William Howard Taft, Adm. Richard Byrd. As an adult, Mrs. Sulzberger traveled and rubbed elbows with the famous: she met Eleanor Roosevelt, dined with Chiang Kai-shek and sipped coffee with Golda Meir. She was a White House guest of every president from Calvin Coolidge to John F. Kennedy and was acquainted with many heads of state, including Japanese Emperor Hirohito, the Shah of Iran and Winston Churchill. In ``The Kingdom and the Power,'' Gay Talese suggested that if her father had permitted it, Mrs. Sulzberger ``might have become a journalist, a crusading sort urging reform.'' But she disagreed, saying a single course at the Columbia School of Journalism represented ``the first and only time I aspired to become a journalist.'' ``People often think that I must have reached some profound conclusions about life and that what I have to say is to be taken very seriously,'' she said in her memoirs. Ochs appointed her to the Times board of directors in her 20s. After he died in 1935, she was one of three trustees _ along with her husband and then her son _ of the Ochs estate, which owns the controlling interest in the paper. To perpetuate her father's dream, Mrs. Sulzberger's four children and her grandchildren entered into agreements that will continue family control of the Times indefinitely. Newspapers were the birthright of Iphigene Bertha Ochs, the granddaughter of Rabbi Isaac M. Wise, founder of Judaism's Reform movement. On Sept. 19, 1892 _ the night she was born in Cincinnati _ her father, then publisher of The Chattanooga Times, was in New York fighting to get smaller papers accepted in The Associated Press. In 1904, young Iphigene helped lay the cornerstone for the Times' building at Times Square. Sometime later, her father, dismayed by Iphigene's fascination with ``vulgar'' comics in competitor papers, started the Times' first and last comic strip, ``The Roosevelt Bears.'' Young Iphigene judged their adventures ``wordy and uninteresting,'' and the bears became extinct after a year and a half. Salisbury said her impish nature emerged in childhood and she remained irrepressible as an adult. At age 9, she signed a thank-you note to President Theodore Roosevelt ``love and kisses''; at 12, she was expelled for ``impertinence'' from Dr. Sachs' School for Girls; at 16, she enjoyed the rides at Coney Island with Guglielmo Marconi, inventor of the wireless. An economics major, she graduated from Barnard College an A student despite having dyslexia, a learning disability unknown at the time. She became engaged to Arthur Hays Sulzberger at a romantic-looking park in Spartanburg, S.C., which ``turned out to be the grounds of the local lunatic asylum,'' according to her memoirs. They were married in 1917, completing their Washington honeymoon with a White House meeting with President Woodrow Wilson. Her husband retired in 1961. Their son-in-law, Orvil E. Dryfoos, held the publisher's post until his death in 1963. Their son, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, known as ``Punch,'' has been publisher since then; their grandson Arthur Ochs Sulzberger Jr. is deputy publisher. Mrs. Sulzberger's other children are Marian Sulzberger Heiskell, the widow of Orvil Dryfoos and wife of Andrew Heiskell, retired chairman of Time Inc.; Ruth Sulzberger Holmberg, publisher of the Chattanooga Times, and Dr. Judith P. Sulzberger, a New York doctor. She had 13 grandchildren and 24 great-grandchildren. Funeral services were scheduled for Wednesday at Temple Emanu-El.

DOC.HEAD: Witness to Drug Killing Slain Before Trial
DOC.TEXT: A man who was to testify against a drug gang accused of murdering his live-in companion was himself slain this month, apparently to keep him from taking the stand, it was reported today. Unidentified investigators said a man in a ski mask killed John Shelton in Queens with a rifle Feb. 7, The New York Times said. Shelton, 43, had witnessed the slayin in 1988 of Maxine Peterson, 43, who was hit by one of more than 20 bullets fired as she stood holding their baby in the kitchen of their home. He called 911 for an ambulance. The baby was not hurt. Shelton was a potential witness in the trial of the alleged killers, although prosecutors would not say whether they had planned to put him on the stand. Officials would not say whether he had identified any of the four defendants, whose trial opened on Monday. Michael Bethea, 18, was charged with murdering Sheldon. Officials would say whom they suspect of having hired the killer, the Times said. Ms. Peterson, a nurse, was killed in what officials said was a drug-related dispute between the defendants and a group that included a member of Ms. Peterson's family or a friend of someone in the family. Two other witnesses in Queens have been murdered or menaced in recent years. A 61-year-old woman was shot to death in 1987 after testifying before a grand jury about a gun battle that took place outside the car service where she worked. In another case, a man's home was firebombed twice after he complained about drug dealers, and a rookie policeman was shot to death in his patrol car while guarding the house.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Call For Defense Minister's Removal Over Death Squads
By BARRY RENFREW
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: The opposition called today for the suspension of the defense minister while the government investigates charges a secret military unit murdered anti-apartheid activists. The Democratic Party said Gen. Magnus Malan must be suspended until a probe into the military's Civil Cooperation Bureau is concluded. Justice would almost certainly be obstructed if Malan remains in power during the investigation, the liberal party said in a statement. ``The black reaction is going to be one of anger because blacks see this as a case of government manipulating the truth,'' party co-leader Denis Worrall said. Malan, defense mnister since 1981, has denied ordering any killings or other criminal activity. There have been more than 60 unsolved killings of anti-apartheid activists in the past decade. In other developments, police said today that two black men were killed in continued fighting between rival black factions near Durban in Natal province. Scores of people have been killed in recent weeks in fighting in the province and black leader Nelson Mandela, released this month after 27 years in prison, appealed for peace at a rally in Natal on Sunday. Police said violence was nevertheless continuing in the province, with 18 people killed in clashes in the past three days. They said about 200 people had been left homeless after scores of homes were burned in black townships near Durban in the fighting between the United Democratic Front and the more conservative Inkatha movement of the Zulu tribe,. Also today, Lawyers representing more than 300 political prisoners on Robben Island near Cape Town said their clients would stay on a hunger strike until the government releases them. The prisoners, who began the strike Monday, are protesting a government decision not to release political prisoners convicted of violent crimes. ``They want to be unconditionally released. They are extremely unhappy,'' lawyer Willie Hofmeyr told a news conference in Cape Town. President F.W. de Klerk released some political prisoners earlier this month as part of his effort to try and clear the way for talks on ending white rule and sharing power with the black majority. De Klerk has refused to release hundreds of anti-apartheid activists convicted of violent offenses. The incoming black goverment in neighboring Namibia, a former South African territory becoming independent at month's end, denounced Malan today for claiming a slain white activist was an agent of South Africa's military. Theo-Ben Gurirab, the new foreign minister, said Malan's statement about Anton Lubowski was ``tantamount to an act of cowardice ... to make these kind of allegations which cannot be rebutted by Anton Lubowski.'' Malan told parliament in Cape Town on Monday that all activities of the Civilian Cooperation Bureau were being suspended pending a government probe into charges it was involved in political killings. Malan also claimed Lubowski, a leading figure in the South-West African Peoples Organization (SWAPO) that fought a 23-bush war for Namibian independence, was a South African intelligence operative. South African police Brig. Floris Mostert has alleged in court documents that he suspects the bureau was involved in the Sept. 12 killing of Lubowski, the highest-ranking white member of SWAPO.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Gold Down
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mostly higher in early European trading today. Gold prices fell. Traders said the dollar was likely to stay within a narrow range in Europe until U.S. markets opened. Trading was thinned by carnival celebrations in much of West Germany, dealers said. Banks in Duesseldorf were closed Monday, and Frankfurt banks were scheduled to finish business around 8 a.m. EST for a semi-official afternoon holiday. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 0.38 yen to a closing 149.03 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 148.78 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Monday: _1.6903 West German marks, unchanged _1.4903 Swiss francs, up from 1.4865 _5.7233 French francs, up from 5.7205 _1.9058 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9023 _1,250.50 Italian lire, up from 1,250.25 _1.1955 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1975 In London, the dollar rose against the British pound, and was quoted at $1.6871, compared with $1.6927 late Monday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $408.45 a troy ounce, down from $411.75 bid late Monday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $408.80. In Zurich, the bid price was $408.75, down from $411.25 late Monday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $4.30 to close at a bid $407.85. Bullion dealers said gold prices were wedded to dollar prices, with any rally in the U.S. currency expected to put downward pressure on gold. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $5.18 a troy ounce, from Monday's $5.23.

DOC.HEAD: Cancer Patient who Delivered Healthy Baby Hopes to Beat Cancer
DOC.TEXT: A woman cancer patient who refused chemical and radiation treatment because she was pregnant, delivered an apparently healthy baby and now plans to beat the odds again with her own diet program. ``I believe I don't have cancer any more,'' Linda Babcock said Monday from her bed at St. Joseph Medical Center in this central Illinois city. ``I feel so much better. I can breathe. I could tell it was there before. It felt like something cutting off my air, taking my life,'' she said. Mrs. Babcock gave birth Friday to a 5-pound 6-ounce boy, Jesse Warren Babcock. ``She has defied the statistics so far and provided a very viable child,'' her physician, Dr. Larry Webster, said Monday night. ``Basically, the cancer stayed pretty much the same since last summer,'' Webster said. ``That's good.'' Diagnosed in August with a type of inoperable lung cancer called oat cell carcinoma, Mrs. Babcock lived on a diet of carrot juice, organically grown vegetables and fruits, lots of purified water and vitamin pills. She also relied on her strong faith in God, she said. ``Give God the credit,'' said Mrs. Babcock, who described herself as in the 30s. ``He guided me, through people I met, books I read.'' Statistically, her condition is ``certainly guarded,'' said Webster. ``The cancer is very malignant and carries a very low survivability rate.'' Although X-rays show the tumor and fluid caused by the disease remain in her right lung, the possibility exists the disease is in remission, he said. ``You certainly would have to think so on the history of the disease in other people. Normally at the stage it was in her, it would be fatal.'' Webster said he will not try to talk her into a more traditional therapy. ``We mention chemotherapy and radiation to her, but that's her choice,'' he said. ``I'd have to say that I would leave it up to her.'' ``I'm confident of living, of beating the cancer,'' Mrs. Babcock said. ``The baby saved me from death _ as I saved him.''

DOC.HEAD: Witness to Drug Killing Slain Before Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf `Michael Bethea... to ADD dropped word officials would not say whom they suspect
DOC.TEXT: A man who was to testify against a drug gang accused of murdering his live-in companion was himself slain this month, apparently to keep him from taking the stand, it was reported today. Unidentified investigators said a man in a ski mask killed John Shelton in Queens with a rifle Feb. 7, The New York Times said. Shelton, 43, had witnessed the slaying in 1988 of Maxine Peterson, 43, who was hit by one of more than 20 bullets fired as she stood holding their baby in the kitchen of their home. He called 911 for an ambulance. The baby was not hurt. Shelton was a potential witness in the trial of the alleged killers, although prosecutors would not say whether they had planned to put him on the stand. Officials would not say whether he had identified any of the four defendants, whose trial opened on Monday. Michael Bethea, 18, was charged with murdering Sheldon. Officials would not say whom they suspect of having hired the killer, the Times said. Ms. Peterson, a nurse, was killed in what officials said was a drug-related dispute between the defendants and a group that included a member of Ms. Peterson's family or a friend of someone in the family. Two other witnesses in Queens have been murdered or menaced in recent years. A 61-year-old woman was shot to death in 1987 after testifying before a grand jury about a gun battle that took place outside the car service where she worked. In another case, a man's home was firebombed twice after he complained about drug dealers, and a rookie policeman was shot to death in his patrol car while guarding the house.

DOC.HEAD: Nude Celebrants On TV; Gov't Asks Broadcasters To Be More Discreet
DOC.TEXT: Parade floats and scantily clad samba dancers revved up the city's marathon carnival, while the government urged TV stations to be a bit more discreet about broadcasting nude revelers. Justice Minister Saulo Ramos asked TV executives Monday not to broadcast flagrant examples of nudity, but the more prevailing attitude was expressed by Roberto Costa, an advertising agency employee in Belo Horizonte. ``This helps us forget inflation, the foreign debt and all of Brazil's problems,'' said Costa, who wore a glistening purple wig and was dancing in the four-day pre-Lent festivities. In Rio, unofficial capital of carnival, 16 samba ``schools'' _ neighborhood groups from poor, predominantly black districts _ take part in the marathon two-night parade that ends today, the last day of carnival. The schools, each with as many as 5,000 costumed members and up to 20 floats, sing and dance to a bone-shaking beat in the ``sambadrome,'' a parade ground surrounded by a 75,000-seat grandstand that covers six city blocks in downtown Rio. Dancers clad in rhinestone bikinis shimmy and gyrate to the pulsing beat. Two television networks carry the parade live, focusing on nudity and rolling pelvises. In Brasilia, Justice Minister Ramos noted that the 1988 constitution abolished censorship but asked broadcasters to use self-restraint. ``Censorship has ended and we don't have a law that punishes abuses,'' he said. ``We appeal to the conscience of the networks to respect the ethical values of the Brazilian family.'' Revelers with money packed the popular private-club balls, where clothing and inhibitions are shed as the night goes on. The steamy scenes are too much even for the television networks, which stop live coverage in the wee hours. Rich and poor packed the sambadrome side-by-side Monay, singing along as each group passed. When the popular Portela school went by at 7 a.m., thousands of spectators climbed down from the grandstands and joined the procession. The only somber note came when a float struck a high-voltage wire outside the parade ground and a man was killed. Each school writes its own samba for the parade and is awarded points for lyrics, costumes, dancing and music. The themes this year ranged from the discovery of Brazil to last December's election, the first free, popular election of a president in 29 years. This year also brought a revival of street carnival in Rio, with pickup samba bands and improvised costumes. In the downtown financial district, a ``beermobile'' passed out free suds. Police reported 33 killings Saturday and Sunday in greater Rio, fewer than the 57 of the previous weekend. Banks, stores and government offices are closed until Wednesday, when Brazilians will begin straggling back to work.

DOC.HEAD: Marian Anderson Poster Aimed at Black Turnout in Census Drive
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Census Bureau hopes the memory of contralto Marian Anderson's 1939 Washington concert, a civil rights landmark, inspires record numbers of blacks to turn out in this year's census. ``If they don't know now, they'll learn a little bit later that it really pays to stand up and be counted,'' Miss Anderson said Monday at a ceremony at the Apollo Theater in Harlem. She was presented with a birthday cake as the Census Bureau's poster and television campaign was unveiled. Miss Anderson turns 88 today. ``You are the first living American ever in our 200 years to become a symbol of the United States census,'' Census Director Barbara Everitt Bryant told Miss Anderson, who retired 25 years ago. The poster shows Miss Anderson performing on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial urging blacks to ``Lift Up Your Voice. Stand up for who you are. Answer the census on April 1, 1990.'' Considered a historic performance, Miss Anderson sang before a crowd that included Eleanor Roosevelt at the Lincoln Memorial on April 9, 1939, after she was barred from Constitution Hall by the Daughters of the American Revolution. The organization later said the hall was already reserved. The incident became a landmark in the fight against segregation. The census, taken every decade since 1790, determines distribution of seats in the House of Representatives, how seats are divided in state legislatures and how billions of dollars in federal funds are spent. Bryant said in 1790 the U.S. Census counted 750,000 blacks, or 19 percent of the 3.9 million populace. Each black then was counted as only three-fifths of a person, she said. Roland H. Moore, associate director of the U.S. Census, said the 1980 census skipped 6 percent of the black population. This year, the bureau expects to count 31 million blacks from about 250 million Americans.

DOC.HEAD: Sen. Enrile Arrested For Alleged Role In Coup Attempt
DOC.BYLINE: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with Enrile booked, vice president charging attempt to stifle opposition. Picks up 12th pvs, `She thanked ...' ^By EILEEN GUERRERO
DOC.TEXT: Opposition Sen. Juan Ponce Enrile surrendered to police after he and six others were indicted today on rebellion charges for alleged roles in December's failed bid to oust President Corazon Aquino. The former defense minister _ one of Mrs. Aquino's most vocal critics _ has denied any role in the bloody Dec. 1-9 coup attempt and accused the government of fabricating charges to silence the opposition. Enrile left the Senate chamber with agents of the National Bureau of Investigation, who served him an arrest warrant charging him harboring fugitives and with ``rebellion with murder'' _ for which there is normally no bail. He was taken to bureau headquarters where he was booked and fingerprinted. Enrile told reporters he would probably remain there overnight then ask the Supreme Court to allow bail. Before surrendering, Enrile said: ``I know that those who are accusing me will surely have their day, as I have my day today.'' The others indicted today were former Lt. Col. Gregorio ``Gringo'' Honasan, Cagayan provincial Gov. Rodolfo Aguinaldo, retired Brig. Gen. Felix Brawner, retired Lt. Col. Billy Bibit, businessman Rebecco Panlilio and his wife. Enrile was the most well-known figure charged so far in the failed coup, the sixth and bloodiest attempt to unseat Mrs. Aquino since she took office in the 1986 uprising that toppled the late President Ferdinand Marcos. Enrile led the February 1986 military mutiny that triggered the ``people power'' uprising Mrs. Aquino rode to power. But Mrs. Aquino fired Enrile as defense minister in November of that year after a failed coup by his followers. Charges against Enrile stem from statements by witnesses who claimed they saw Honasan and about 100 rebels at the senator's home on the first day of the coup attempt. Enrile claims he has not seen Honasan since 1987. Hours after his indictment was announced, Enrile appeared at the Senate and in a speech to his colleagues said: ``The regime of President Corazon C. Aquino has marshaled all its forces in fabricating charges against me in order to silence the voice of the opposition in this chamber.'' ``As I leave you today, I pledge to you that no jail or prison shall stop me from trying my best to voice the grievances of the Filipino people,'' he added. Supporters of the failed coup have charged the Aquino goverment with mismanagement and corruption. Vice President Salvador Laurel arrived later at the bureau headquarters and told reporters that if Enrile's arrest was an attempt ``to stifle the opposition, this is not going to work.'' ``The arrest of Sen. Juan Ponce Enrile, the lone opposition member of the Senate, is the heighth of intolerance of political dissent which is the essence of a functioning democracy,'' Laurel said. ``The attempt to simulate compliance with legal processes merely heightens the hypocrisy of the act.'' Laurel broke with Mrs. Aquino in 1987 and later organized the opposition Nacionalista Party along with Enrile. In a speech Sunday marking her fourth anniversary in office, Mrs. Aquino repeatedly denounced Enrile, who as Marcos' defense minister ordered the arrest of thousands, including her assassinated husband Benigno Jr., during martial law from 1972 until 1981. She thanked the public for ``protecting'' her from him. Aguinaldo, a former lieutenant colonel, was suspended as governor for 60 days after telling a Manila radio station that he was sending tanks and artillery to the capital to support the coup attempt. Honasan, who has been dropped from the military rolls, led the August 1987 mutiny against Mrs. Aquino and played a leading role in last December's putsch. He was arrested in December 1987 but escaped the following April. Brawner, former military commander for northern Luzon, had been serving as a consultant to the Senate defense committee after he retired from the armed forces last year. He was accused of giving advice to the rebels during the coup attempt. Bibit, the security chief of the customs bureau, was accused of ransacking the customs armory to get weapons and food for the mutineers. He was arrested last month. Panlilio and his wife were reportedly seen at Enrile's house with Honasan on the first day of the Decmeber coup attempt.

DOC.HEAD: Marines Won't Retry Woman Accused of Being A Lesbian
DOC.TEXT: A Marine corporal who won a reversal of her court-martial on charges she was a lesbian won't be retried, officials said. Barbara J. Baum will be given back pay and an honorable discharge, the Marine Corps said in a statement Monday. She served more than seven months in the brig after her 1988 conviction. Maj. Gen. J.D. Lynch Jr. decided that ``in view of the time that had elapsed ... and the additional expense to the government,'' Baum won't be retried, the statement said. Ms. Baum, 25, of Lakewood, Fla., will be paid until she is discharged _ probably in early March, Marine spokesman Capt. J.R. Mill said. ``Obviously we're pleased,'' said Brendan Collins, an attorney for Ms. Baum. ``We see it as a vindication.'' Baum's conviction was overturned Feb. 15 by the Court of Military Review in Washington, which ruled that two of jurors at Ms. Baum's court-martial were biased and that the military judge allowed uncorroborated testimony. One of the jurors had shown an interest in the case before the court-martial and the other had outside knowledge of the case. Ms. Baum was the first of five women charged in a 1988 crackdown on lesbians at the Parris Island Recruit Depot. She was convicted of conspiracy to obstruct justice, obstruction of justice, indecent acts and sodomy. She also received a dishonorable discharge, had her rank reduced to private and lost all pay and allowances. Lance Cpl. Diana Maldonado _ the woman accused of having sex with Ms. Baum _testified against her at the court-martial. The appeals panel found the lack of independent corroboration rendered Ms. Maldonado's testimony ``insufficient as a matter of law.'' The Defense Department's official policy says ``homosexuality is incompatible with military service.''

DOC.HEAD: Israel and Poland Resume Diplomatic Relations
DOC.TEXT: Poland and Israel resumed full diplomatic ties today after a 23-year break, making this country once a vibrant center of Jewish life the third Warsaw Pact nation to resume relations with Israel in the past year. Relations were sealed with the signing of a protocal by Foreign Ministers Moshe Arens of Israel and Krzysztof Skubiszewski of Poland. Poland, like the entire Soviet bloc except Romania, followed Moscow's lead and broke with Israel in 1967 to support the Arab side in the Middle East War. It joins Hungary and Czechoslovakia in renewing ties with the Jewish state. Poland has had low-level ties with Israel since 1987 and the Solidarity-led government that came to power in August is hoping the restoration of a formal embassy will lead to closer economic and cultural cooperation. Poland's Jewish community was 3.5 million strong before World War II, the Holocaust and massive emigration including a wave prompted by a 1968 purge. Today, it numbers just 10,000. From 350,000 to 500,000 Israelis were born in Poland, including the first Israeli prime minister, David Ben Gurion, and the present one, Yitzhak Shamir. Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki looked on during the protocol signing at a government palace, and the Polish and Israeli delegations sipped champagne afterward to celebrate the long-awaited event. Arens said Israel hopes for Polish support for Israeli positions in the Middle East peace process and for ``very extensive economic relations. ... That will be of benefit to both countries.'' The first day of Aren's visit Monday was spent in emotional visits. He went to a Jewish cemetery and paid homage at the monument to the Warsaw Ghetto uprising of 1943, when Jews, held in a walled-in section of the city and facing starvation, murder and deportation, rose up against the Nazi occupiers. Polish press coverage of the Arens visit has focused on the government's acknowledging the error of the decision to sever ties and that act's consequences, including an anti-Semitic purge in 1968. ``Poland Apologizes to Israel'' and ``Return to Normalcy'' were among newspaper headlines Monday. Skubiszewski said he agrees with the need for an apology and said that Jews who left Poland after the 1968 purge are free to come back and recover Polish citizenship. In addition, those harmed can seek damages, he said. Arens is to go Wednesday to the Auschwitz death camp in southern Poland, where the presence of a Roman Catholic convent in a former Nazi warehouse strained Jewish-Polish relations and stirred international controversy. Skubiszewski said the topic of the convent was discussed with Arens on today, with Poland underlining support for the construction of an alternate home for the nuns. Ground was broken last week on an interfaith prayer center that is to include a new convent for the nuns.

DOC.HEAD: 38 Dead As Second Big Storm This Year Hits Europe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to CORRECT that 120 mph winds were on Monday. Pickup 5th graf `Fourteen deaths...'
DOC.TEXT: Europe's second big storm of the year raged on with high winds today after leaving roads and railways blocked, power out and homes flooded in seven countries. Police said 38 people were killed. In Ireland, residents had more than wild weather to worry about during the storm Monday, when winds gusted to as high as 120 mph. Four circus tigers escaped when their cage was blown over near Drogheda, and they roamed free until they were rounded up. For a second day, shipping in the English Channel and the Irish Sea was badly disrupted by the strong winds. The Meteorological Office reported winds of more than 120 mph over Belfast on Monday, the highest ever recorded in Northern Ireland. Wind speeds neared or topped 100 mph in northern England and southern Scotland, the office said. Fourteen deaths were reported in Britain, eight in France, seven in West Germany, five in Belgium, two in East Germany and one each in Ireland and the Netherlands. A storm that hit the northern continent on Jan. 25, packing 106 mph winds, claimed the lives of 95 people. In Britain, Monday's victims included a driver whose bus hit a fallen tree, a man killed by a collapsing chimney and a woman hit by a roof slate. In the North Wales neighboring seaside towns of Towyn and Kinmel Bay, police and rescue workers evacuated 2,000 people from their homes after waves opened up a hole 200 yards wide in the sea wall. Water 5 feet deep in places poured through streets, flooded homes and cut power and telephone links. The Assistant Chief Constable of North Wales, John Owen, said high tides during the rest of this week mean those staying in emergency shelters should prepare for a stay of several days. Homes bordering the Bristol Channel in western England were flooded, many roads and railroad tracks were blocked by fallen trees, and more than 125,000 homes in the Thames Valley near London, in South Wales, in east and southwest England and in Northern Ireland were without power today. In West Germany's northern port city of Hamburg, a woman was killed when a gust pushed her in front of a car, a woman and her two children were injured when a large billboard fell on them, and a crane was blown over, damaging dock buildings. Another crane was blown over at Neu Isenburg near Frankfurt in central Hesse state, killing the operator. The storm spoiled West Germany's Rose Monday pre-Lent carnival, when crowds traditionally parade through city streets in fancy dress accompanied by decorated floats. Strong winds wrecked 12 floats in Duesseldorf, Bonn's parade was canceled and in Mainz 250,000 peole _ 100,000 fewer than expected _ paraded in rain-soaked carnival costumes. The dead in France included a 3-year-old girl killed by a falling branch in Avesnes-sur-Helpes in the north of the country. In Paris, a man was killed by a falling wall and a 17-year-old was killed by a slamming door. In the Belgian port of Antwerp, a boat sank after a 15-ton crane dropped onto the vessel, injuring several people. All ships remained in port in Belgium's North Sea harbors on Monday and train traffic to the Netherlands was interrupted. At Amsterdam's Schiphol airport, the Netherlands' flag carrier KLM said it suspended 15 international flights on Monday. Seven people were hurt at a pre-Lent carnival in the southern town of Beek when a big tent blew down. Storm damage to overhead power lines halted Netherlands' rail traffic on three local lines and the international link with Belgium, the government-owned railroad company said. Two bridges linking the southern and northern parts of the country were closed because of storm danger, police said. The British government's Meteorological Office responsible for weather forecasting said there was nothing abnormal about the storms. ``There have been 10 comparable periods of destructive gales recorded over the past 38 years,'' it said in a statement. It said Monday's storm originated off the eastern seaboard of the United States when cold air from the Arctic collided with warmer moist air from the south.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Offers Help In Economic Reconstruction
DOC.TEXT: Japan said today it welcomed Nicaragua's first free elections and offered to help the country rebuild its shattered economy. The Foreign Ministry did not say how much money Japan was prepared to spend but said it is ``determined to make as much contribution as possible in this regard.'' A ministry statement said Japan hopes all factions in Nicaragua will accept the results of Sunday's election, in which opposition leader Violeta Barrios de Chamorro defeated Sandinista President Daniel Ortega. The statement said it hopes Nicaragua's new president, who takes office April 25, will work for democratization and improved living standards. Ten years of Sandinista rule in Nicaragua has left an economy wracked by inflation and mismanagement. A war with the U.S.-backed Contra rebels and a U.S. embargo also took their toll. The ministry statement said it hopes the international community ``will join in rehabilitating the economy of Nicaragua and the other countries in the region and solving refugee problems.'' Japan has the world's largest budget for non-military foreign aid, about $10 billion a year.

DOC.HEAD: Nicaraguan Exiles Jubilant But Cautious About Elections
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CLARIFY that Sweetwater a town, not a neighborhood. SUBS 12th graf, `More than...', with 5 grafs to ADD comments from Nicaraguans at shelter in Texas. Picks up 13th graf pvs, `Adolfo Calero...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MH2
With PM-Nicaragua, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Nicaraguan exiles clogged the main street of the community nicknamed Little Managua to celebrate the upset defeat of their homeland's Sandinista regime, proclaiming ``miracles do happen.'' But their jubilation was tempered by concern about how victor Violeta Barrios de Chamorra will cope with daunting problems facing Nicaragua.
