Police estimated 8,000 Nicaraguans and other Hispanics converged Monday on Sweetwater, a town west of Miami that is home to southern Florida's largest Nicaraguan community, after the defeat of President Daniel Ortega in Nicaragua's national elections. ``We never dreamed about it,'' said an exultant Francisco Ortega, president of the Nicaraguan American Chamber of Commerce in Dade County. ``We thought it was impossible. But see, miracles do happen.'' Nicaraguan exiles, many of whom had not slept since voting began Sunday morning, jammed busy Flagler Street. Some waved flags, danced and sang patriotic songs. Others sat in cars and blared horns. The crowd swelled in the evening as the work day ended, and police closed a five-block stretch to traffic. While many exiles talked of returning to Nicaragua, they said they wanted to see the new U.S.-backed government in action first. ``Democracy is on its way back,'' said Inez de Gutierrez, a 31-year-old grocery store cashier who has been in the United States for a year with her husband and young daughter. But she said she would not return immediately. ``We'll just wait a while and see how things go in Nicaragua, politically and economically. The country is in ruins. It's in great poverty, now.'' Renato Salazar said he will not be ready to return until the Sandinistas, the left-wing revolutionaries who took power in 1979, relinquish control of the military and police. ``Democracy means total democracy, not the government being in charge of one part and the opposition in control of the army,'' he said. At a shelter for Central Americans near the border city of Brownsville, Texas, Edgar Toruno Raudales expressed the same reservations. ``What good is it to have Violeta in power if the army controls the country?'' he said. ``There could be a coup at any time.'' ``This is what all the Nicaraguans wanted, the victory of Violeta,'' said Jose Alfredo Velasquez. But Rosaria Baldeoceda, a 23-year-old student from Managua, was more skeptical. ``No matter who is selected, we will have the same mess,'' she said at the shelter in Texas. More than 100,000 Nicaraguans have settled in southern Florida since the Sandinista revolution, and Sweetwater Mayor Jose A. Rivero said many of them may have to return because they lack permanent status in the United States. Adolfo Calero, former director of the U.S.-backed Contra rebels who fought the Sandinistas, predicted that ``slowly, the Nicaraguan exiles will go back to the country.'' ``I'm going back as soon as I get a passport from the country,'' Calero said. ``I think the armed struggle is over. The armed struggle was never an end in itself, it was always a means to force the Sandinistas into a political contest which the people won, headed by Violeta Chamorro.'' Luis Munoz, who joined in the celebration, said he hoped the government also changes in his homeland of Cuba, which he left as a teen-ager. ``I know it's going to happen one of these days,'' said the 27-year-old. He said he wanted to return to Cuba because ``I belong there.''

DOC.HEAD: 12th Group of Boat People Repatriated Voluntarily
DOC.TEXT: A group of Vietnamese boat people returned voluntarily to their Communist homeland today, the 12th group to do so since the program began early last year. The group of 115 Vietnamese brought to 1,284 the number who have returned under the U.N. program. Nearly 1,600 more have asked to leave the overcrowded detention centers of Hong Kong and go home. About 44,000 Vietnamese have arrived in this British colony since June 1988, when the government decided to classify arriving boat people as illegal immigrants unless they can prove they fled persecution. Only about 10 percent will be granted refugee status. The rest face repatriation against their will, unless they volunteer to go home. The United Nations provides Vietnamese who return voluntarily with up to $50 in cash and a monthly allowance of $30 for one year. The voluntary repatriation program is expected to speed up now that Hanoi has agreed to accept 1,000 returning boat people each month. The repatriation of boat people against their will remains on hold after an initial departure of 51 Vietnamese in December. Hanoi has expressed reservations about the program because of criticism from the United States and human rights organizations.

DOC.HEAD: Stormie Regaining Strength, Doctors Say
DOC.TEXT: Doctors say 12-year-old Stormie Jones, the world's first heart-liver transplant recipient, is regaining her strength quickly after undergoing a second liver transplant. Stormie was moved from the intensive care unit at Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh to a regular room after being upgraded from critical but stable condition to serious condition Monday afternoon. She remained in serious condition early today. Stormie, who lives in the Fort Worth, Texas, suburb of White Settlement, received her second liver transplant Feb. 20 in a 10-hour operation. She returned to the operating room the next day, when doctors operated for nine hours to halt internal bleeding. Stormie's first transplant, in 1984 at Children's, was needed to control effects of a rare disease that left her cholesterol levels 10 times greater than normal. The second operation resulted from permanent liver damage caused by hepatitis. Despite her liver problems, Stormie's donor heart has remained healthy, doctors said.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Durable Goods Orders in Record Plunge
DOC.TEXT: Orders to U.S. factories for durable goods plunged 10.5 percent in January, the biggest decline since orders first were tracked 32 years ago, the government reported today. A drop in aircraft orders led the way. The Commerce Department said orders for durable goods _ big-ticket items expected to last more than three years _ totaled a seasonally adjusted $118.2 billion last month after increasing a revised 1.4 percent in December. That figure originally was reported to be up 2.5 percent. The steepest decline until January's record was a 9.2 percent fall in February 1982. `Most of the decline was in transportation equipment,'' the department said. ``Aircraft and parts, which had been unusually high in the last several months, accounted for nearly half of the January decline in transportation, although motor vehicles and parts and shipbuilding and tanks were both down sharply.'' Aircraft orders represented one-third of the overall decline. Auto production also fell in January as tens of thousands of auto workers were laid off to help the industry shrink swollen inventories. The department considers car orders and production to be the same. The drop helped pull overall transportation orders down 27.6 percent to $27.9 billion. Much of the economy's recent weakness has been concentrated in durable goods as the Federal Reserve sought for more than a year to drive down inflation by keeping a tight rein on credit. The result has been higher interest rates, which adversely affect durable goods orders because they often are financed by loans. Excluding the transportation industry, orders fell 3.4 percent. The closely watched non-defense capital goods sector, often a barometer of business investment plans, fell 13.7 percent, reversing December's 14.2 percent gain. The sector also posted gains in October and November. Electrical machinery orders dropped 17.6 percent to $18.8 billion after rising 5.6 percent in December and 7.3 percent in November. Virtually all of the decrease was in communications equipment, the Commerce Department said. Orders for non-electrical machinery, including computers and a wide variety of industrial equipment, rose 2.6 percent to $22.3 billion after falling 3.9 percent in December. Primary metals orders were up 1.5 percent to $11.1 billion following a 2.8 percent decline in December. New orders for defense capital goods, a highly volatile sector, plummeted 36 percent to $6.3 billion for the lowest one-month volume of orders since January 1987. Defense orders had slipped 12.9 percent in December after rising 17.7 percent in November. Excluding defense, orders would have been off 3.4 percent. Shipments of durable goods in January dropped 3.7 percent to $117.7 billion after falling 0.8 percent a month earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Fire in Los Angeles Hotel Linen Closet Forces 350 to Evacuate
DOC.TEXT: A fire in a linen closet sent smoke through three floors of the high-rise Wilshire Hyatt Hotel, forcing 350 people to evacuate before firefighters doused the smoldering blaze. There were no injuries in the Monday evening fire, said fire department spokesman Greg Acevedo. The entire 12-story hotel was evacuated, but the guests allowed to return within an hour, he said. The fire filled the seventh floor with smoke and, through a duct, the 11th and 12th floors as well, officials said. Damage was estimated at $6,000. The cause of the fire was under investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Fancy Building's Rent Strike Leader Accused Of Absconding With Loot
DOC.TEXT: Tenants in a luxury apartment building who waged a rent strike over balky elevators and cockroaches may have a bigger problem. Authorities say their leader has disappeared, along with $1.7 million of their money. A warrant is out for the arrest of Steven Nelson Delit, 45, an accountant and president of the tenants association at the 45-story, tinted-glass apartment building on the fashionable east side of Manhattan. Delit used money from the account to pay his rent and gambling debts, Manhattan District Attorney Robert Morgenthau said Monday. A pizza parlor he owns also may have been bought with the money, the prosecutor said. Delit organized a rent strike among some of the tenants who, while paying rents of $1,750 to $5,000 a month, complained of problems with the building's elevators and air-conditioning, cockroach infestations and water leaks. ``When you live in a building and you pay 100 percent rent, you expect 100 percent services,'' he said two years ago. The tenants won a court order in September 1988 allowing them to pay rents into an bank escrow account set up by Delit, instead of to the landlord, until the building's alleged problems were fixed. But the escrow account never was opened, investigators now say. The money paid by 40 to 60 tenants was deposited instead into an account over which Delit had sole authority. Morgenthau said the tenants probably still have to pay the 27 months of rent. The bill could reach tens of thousands of dollars for some tenants. Delit has been charged with first-degree grand larceny on charges of stealing $1.71 million, Morgenthau said. If convicted, he faces up to 25 years in prison. He left $213,000 in the account, which held more than $1.9 million, Morgenthau said. An additional $573,000 has been found in a brokerage account, and $400,000 has been frozen in other accounts, Morgenthau said. Dominick Franklin, a doorman at the building, did have something nice to say about Delit. ``As a tipper, he was one of the best,'' Franklin said.

DOC.HEAD: Cinematographers Honor their Own, Cite `Blaze'
DOC.TEXT: ``Blaze,'' the Paul Newman movie about Louisiana Gov. Earl Long's affair with a stripper, took honors from the American Society of Cinematographers for best cinematography in a feature film. ``Single Women, Married Men,'' received the award in the television special category and the ``Night of the Tarantula,'' an episode of ``Murder She Wrote,'' captured the prize for a TV series at the fourth annual awards ceremony Sunday. A lifetime achievement award was given to Stanley Cortez, who filmed ``The Magnificent Ambersons'' and ``Night of the Hunter,'' both of which brought him Academy Award nominations. Linwood Dunn, special effects cameraman for ``Citizen Kane'' and ``Gunga Din,'' was given the ASC honorary award.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Will Respect the Results of Nicaraguan Elections
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Conforms spelling of Bourliai throughout. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union recognizes the results of the Nicaraguan elections as legitimate and is prepared to negotiate with the government of Violeta Barrios de Chamorro about future relations, a Foreign Ministry official said today. ``The Soviet Union has more than once expressed its willingness to respect the results of just and free elections in Nicaragua,'' said Ion Bourliai, the Foreign Ministry's deputy chief for Latin America. ``Today, we are confirming this position.'' In voting Sunday, Mrs. Chamorro defeated leftist President Daniel Ortega, whose Sandinista party has ruled Nicaragua for a decade. Bourliai told a news conference the Soviet Union would continue to give non-military aid to Nicaragua if the new government wants it, and also was prepared to negotiate future trade and military cooperation. ``The two sides have concrete obligations,'' he said. ``The Soviet Union is prepared to meet its obligations if the Nicaraguan side will follow suit.'' ``We are ready to discuss with the Nicaraguan government the question of cooperation in the military field if necessary,'' Bourliai said. The Soviet Union cut off military supplies to Nicaragua after 1988, but still provides over $324 million in goods, Bourliai said. An additional 25 tons of wheat and rice are given to Nicaragua annually, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Blacks, Whites Clash Over Paving Selma, Ala.'s Martin Luther King Street
DOC.TEXT: Blacks disrupted a City Council meeting and forced a recess after the white-majority council voted 5-4 along racial lines not to repave Martin Luther King Jr. Street. Councilman Lorenzo Harrison asked council to spend $17,000 to pave the street in his district for this weekend's 25th anniversary celebration of the 1965 Selma-to-Montgomery voting rights march. Councilman Bill King said repaving the street would be a conciliatory gesture by the white councilmen to the black community. ``We've spent millions of dollars illogically, so we might as well spend $17,000 on this,'' he said. White councilman argued that other streets in the city were in worse shape. At Monday night's meeting, some of the blacks in the audience exchanged words with city leaders, including Mayor Joe Smitherman, telling them to ``shut up'' and ``sit down.'' Council President Carl Morgan ordered a recess because, he said, the crowd became too unruly for the council to conduct business. The city has been the scene of racial turmoil since December when the six whites on the 11-member school board voted against renewing the contract of Norward Roussell, the city's first black school superintendent. Demonstrators staged sit-ins at the high school and city hall before the school board agreed to allow the superintendent to remain in his job until his contract expires in June.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Hails Chamorro Win, But Worries About Foreign Aid Cost
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 7th graf, Rep. Mickey, to CORRECT Edwards' party to R sted D
DOC.TEXT: The victory of Violeta Chamorro in Nicaragua adds a new country to the world lineup of democracies, but also adds to the U.S. dilemma as it tries to squeeze more eligible nations into a limited foreign aid budget. ``Nobody said democracy was cheap,'' said Rep. Dante Fascell, D-Fla., chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. Fascell declined to say how much the United States must spend to get Mrs. Chamorro's new government, to take office in April, a running start despite an economy in shambles and a shaky political coalition. But Rep. Stephen Solarz, D-N.Y., said the United States should contribute up to $300 million to an international fund that would raise $1 billion to help restore the nation's economic health. ``It will take big bucks,'' agreed Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan. ``She needs our help and she deserves it.'' Others cautioned, however, that with a growing line of potential new foreign aid recipients _ Poland, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, Panama and others _ it would be difficult to promise new money when the budget already is falling short. Rep. Mickey Edwards, R-Okla., said his reaction to the news of Chamorro's win over leftist Sandinista President Daniel Ortega was ``astonishment. ... It's happening from one end of the world to the other, the tyrants are being swept out.'' But any euphoria was dampened by financial reality, he said. No attempt to pour more money into foreign aid will find many supporters because voters tend to see it as ``building roads over there instead of building roads here,'' Edwards said. ``It's not realistic to expect the result of all this is going to be a tripling of foreign aid,'' he said. ``The American people aren't going to support it.'' This year, the United States will send about $9.8 billion in military, economic and development aid to several dozen friendly countries around the globe. The lion's share, $5.1 billion, goes to Israel and Egypt as a reward for entering into the Camp David peace process. The Bush administration has asked for a slight increase, to $10.1 billion, for 1991. Those amounts do not include a new three-year assistance program approved last year for Poland and Hungary. Lawmakers already are talking about adding more money to that program to include countries like Czechoslovakia, East Germany and Romania. In addition, President Bush is asking Congress for $500 million in new cash to help repair economic damage done to Panama by U.S. trade sanctions, and physical damage done by December's invasion. The aid squeeze prompted one U.S. foreign aid official to joke that he was ``a closet Sandinista'' because a Chamorro win would put even greater strains on the aid program. Solarz and others, mostly Democrats, believe the money for new democracies should be taken out of the Defense Department's $300 billion annual budget, reasoning that in a time of diminishing communist threat it would be better spent to shore up potential new allies. Dole took a different approach, using Chamorro's win over Ortega to renew his proposal to alter the nation's foreign aid priorities, beginning with the two largest recipients, Israel and Egypt. ``The only way we're going to pay for new aid to Nicaragua, Panama, Czechoslovakia _ is to look to the foreign aid budget that now exists, and make some tough calls,'' he said in a Senate floor speech. Dole so far has found few supporters for his idea, and House Speaker Thomas S. Foley cautioned that Nicaragua should not automatically be given priority over current recipients of U.S. aid. Foley singled out Jamaica, a country that saw its 1990 overall aid check cut from $46 million to $19 million, despite close cooperation in the U.S. war on drugs. But the consensus was that the money will have to be found somewhere. ``We spent a great deal of money on military aid'' to the anti-Sandinista Contra rebels, Foley said. ``We now should support democracy ... We need to understand that the United States should not be withdrawing from international affairs.''

DOC.HEAD: Clean Air Bill Headed to Senate Floor This Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 2nd graf pvs to update with talks recessing at 3 a.m. and plans for resuming them today; Picks up 3rd graf pvs, Sources close...
DOC.TEXT: Senate and White House negotiators moved closer to accord on a clean air bill today, but Majority Leader George Mitchell says Senate floor debate will begin later this week whether an agreement is reached or not. ``We are making progress,'' Mitchell said as closed-door discussions resumed Monday and continued past midnight. But he added, ``We started the talks three weeks ago and at some point we need to reach a conclusion.'' The talks in a crowded room adjacent to Mitchell's office in the Capitol did not break until past 3 a.m. with no overall agreement reached. Discussions were to resume today, according to Senate sources. Sources close to the talks said early today that Democrats and the Bush adminstration agreed on tougher controls on toxic chemicals and smog-causing pollutants from industrial plants but remained divided on acid rain curbs. The talks also moved closer to agreement on reducing automobile emissions with the Bush administration for the first time agreeing to a second round of tougher emission controls after the turn of the century under some circumstances. The two sides agreed a so-called second stage of tailpipe controls would go into effect nationwide if a certain number of cities with the worst smog problems failed to achieve federal air quality standards by a specific year, according to sources. The White House had argued earlier that a second round of auto emission controls would be too expensive. Mitchell met Monday with White House chief of staff John Sununu and William Reilly, head of the Environmental Protection Agency. Sununu agreed progress was being made, but he expressed concern that bringing the measure to the Senate floor without agreement with the administration might threaten key parts of the bill, including the tough provisions on acid rain. The legislation would be the first revision of the federal clean air law in 13 years. It would require tougher controls on acid rain pollutants from electric power plants, curbs on toxic chemical releases by industry and reductions in smog-causing emissions from automobiles. Among the sticking points were how to ease some of the concerns, especially from a group of Midwest senators, over controls of acid rain pollutants from coal-fired electric power plants. Mitchell, who has made the clean air bill one of his top priorities, told participants he intends to bring the measure to the Senate floor Thursday whether or not there was an agreement with the White House. The Senate bill and administration proposals agree on a call for cutting sulfur dioxide emissions by 10 million tons a year by the end of the decade. More than a dozen senators, primarily from the Midwest, have threatened to filibuster unless some sort of cost-sharing provision is included to blunt the expenses many Midwest utilities will face from having to install new acid rain control equipment. Mitchell bristled at Sununu's suggestion that bringing the measure to the Senate floor might cause it to be weakened. ``It is the administration that has insisted on changing the bill,'' Mitchell said. ``Every single (weakening) concession that has been made ... has been made at the insistence of the administration, every single one.''

DOC.HEAD: Shuttle Needs Near-Perfect Weather to Soar into Orbit or Return to Earth
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to UPDATE with prospects for good weather Wednesday improving.
DOC.TEXT: A shuttle in orbit is a rugged, durable spaceship, but a shuttle on the ground is a weather wimp that demands clear, dry, mild and still air before leaving its Florida nest. When NASA abandoned an attempt to launch Atlantis early Monday, it marked the 13th time in 34 missions that space shuttles had to stay home because of weather. The failed attempt Monday was the fifth postponement in five days for Atlantis; weather was a factor in all but one case. Weather played a role, too, in the worst U.S. space disaster, the Challenger explosion on Jan. 28, 1986 that killed seven astronauts. The shuttle is finicky about the weather because it has to be. Weather forces that might be only minor problems for conventional aircraft can tear the shuttle apart. Winds as light as 23 mph _ just a spirited breeze for a sailboat _ can smash a shuttle against its launch tower during takeoff. This was one of the weather threats that blocked Monday's attempt to launch Atlantis. Bumpy air aloft that might cause an airline pilot to turn on the seatbelt sign can be enough to tear off the wing of a shuttle rising through the atmosphere at three times the speed of sound. High-altitude winds of about 100 mph from the wrong direction can threaten the shuttle but would be nothing of significance for an airliner. Clouds that are only mildly annoying to even small planes can be killers for the shuttle. Because the spacecraft returns to Earth as a powerless glider, astronauts on the shuttle have only one chance to make a runway landing. Thus, even before the shuttle is launched, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has to make sure clouds don't obscure the visibility at emergency landing sites. This was another of the problems that stopped Atlantis' launch Monday. A bank of clouds at 5,000 feet blocked a clear shot at the Kennedy Space Center emergency landing strip. Space shuttles are also supersensitive to water. Raindrops that patter meekly against the window of a house become like buckshot against a shuttle traveling at hyperspeeds. Thus, any precipitation at the launch pad or in the flight path is enough to keep the craft grounded. Even the mild temperatures of Florida can stop the shuttle's show. If temperatures average less than 41 degrees for 24 hours before a launch, NASA must wait for warmer weather. Once the shuttle fuel tank is filled with a half-million gallons of propellant, a temperature rise above 99 degrees or a drop below 37 is enough to call off a launch. Challenger was exposed to hours of freezing temperatures before its ill-fated launch in 1986. An investigation said the cold caused the failure of a rubber O-ring in a solid rocket joint. The shuttles' finicky-weather rules fill a thick volume and are enforced by an army of forecasters and observers who monitor every gust of wind and drop of rain for miles around the launch pad and the emergency landing sites. NASA tries again to launch Atlantis on Wednesday, and forecasters said today that prospects for good weather by that time were looking up. On Monday, they pegged the odds that the weather would be acceptable at 40 percent; this morning, that figure rose to 60 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Revelers Celebrate Mardi Gras
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with first parade, other detail, and correct style on `Tuesday night' to `tonight.' Picks up 7th graf pvs, `Remember, this...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto covering
DOC.TEXT: Costumed revelers danced from bar to bar at the break of dawn today and parade clubs set out in an early kickoff of Mardi Gras, the bawdy, boozy blowout of pre-Lent parades, street parties and carousing. ``I think we're going to make it,'' grinned jazz clarinetist Pete Fountain as his Half-Fast Marching Club strutted toward the French Quarter to the tune of ``Way Down Yonder In New Orleans.'' ``This is our 29th year,'' Fountain said. ``Last year it was so cold, I got to Bourbon Street and quit.'' The weather was glorious this year _ 58 degrees at 8 a.m. and warming, with not a cloud in sight. Long before the Rex and Zulu parades rolled, crowds jammed the uptown parade routes and staked out their positions with ladders and lawn chairs. Non-stop partying began over the weekend with the arrival of thousands of visitors for the first of dozens of parades throughout metropolitan New Orleans. On the side streets, neighborhood marching clubs hopped from bar to bar. ``It's party time!'' shouted Jerry Peterson of the Lyons Carnival Club as he led about 50 beer-swizzling maskers into the streets outside Norby's bar. ``We'll make about 30 bars.'' Dozens of parades draw the focus to the Carnival season, and the club called Zulu, with its painted coconut giveaways, set out this morning, one of 15 organizations planning to parade all day uptown and downtown. Comus, New Orleans' oldest krewe, or parade club, brings it to a close at night. Deputy Police Chief Arnesta Taylor said the crowd appeared bigger this year than the 24 other Carnival seasons he has seen. He said more than 1 million locals and tourists were expected for the daylong partying. Rex, the masked king of Carnival who leads one of Mardi Gras' biggest and richest parades, kicked off celebrations Monday night, sailing into the city on the Mississippi aboard the Eagle, a Coast Guard tall ship. Mayor Sidney Barthelemy welcomed Rex with the keys to the city and read a proclamation ordering the suspension of laws and the symbolic shutdown of the city until midnight tonight, when Lent begins. ``Remember, this is the pre-celebration. The key is to pace yourself,'' Barthelemy told the crowd on Canal Street, a backdrop for a fireworks display over the Mississippi and a free concert by the Neville Brothers. Mild temperatures and sunny skies helped unloosen numerous ``tourist participation'' flesh shows along the narrow streets of the French Quarter, where police officers' tolerance level rises markedly during Carnival. On Bourbon Street, tourists gaped and locals shouted ``Show 'em!'' as partyers tossed plastic beads at a woman who bared her breasts in a hotel window. A police officer at a corner lifted a camera. ``You're taking pictures, too?'' Sue Smith, 55, of Grosse Pointe Park, Mich., asked incredulously. ``Sure,'' said the officer, who said he was aiming his camera at a fellow policeman on another balcony. ``I'm a tourist,'' he told the disbelieving woman. ``I just rented this suit.'' Mardi Gras, French for fat Tuesday, is the last day of the Carnival season, which ends with the start of Ash Wednesday at midnight. Celebrations in heavily Catholic Louisiana begin Jan. 6 and crank up more than a week before today's climax. Three men were hospitalized after a Sunday night shooting during a parade, police said. No arrests were made. Late last week, a teen-ager fatally shot a man he saw with his former girlfriend along a parade route, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Winter's Return Has Farmers Concerned
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 2 grafs to UPDATE with some of this morning's lows, recast lead to move up that damage probably not as bad as feared. Picks up 3rd graf pvs, `Experts said...'.
DOC.TEXT: Farmers from Delaware to Georgia fretted as winter returned after weeks of unusually warm weather that had peach and apple trees blooming early, but experts said the damage from the cold would probably be limited. Temperatures moderated today after Monday's severe cold attack, with Atlanta dipping only to 32 degrees and Macon, Ga., hitting a low of 33. But while the mass of cold air was sliding slowly out to sea, it held on in the Northeast, where Windor Locks, Conn., hit a record low of 2 below zero. Experts said crops throughout the Middle Atlantic region appeared to have been spared serious damage so far since cold moved back in Sunday and Monday. ``Some of the peach trees were in full bloom and some had just turned pink,'' Jim Olson of the North Carolina Department of Agriculture said Monday. ``They (growers) are concerned, but it was not as bad as they had anticipated.'' ``Although temperatures plummeted to near freezing and below throughout the state, they did not drop as low as earlier predicted,'' Georgia Agriculture Commissioner Tommy Irvin said. ``We were certainly fortunate to have survived without significant damage to our peach, wheat and Vidalia onion crops.'' Temperatures dipped into the teens in the Carolinas and as low as 10 in Delaware early Monday, but peach and apple growers said no severe damage was apparent. ``At this stage in their growth, it would have had to have dropped to 7 degrees to really hurt,'' said Charles Smith, co-owner of T.S. Smith & Sons in Bridgeville, Del. ``We might have had some damage. But we can't tell much. I don't think it was disastrous.'' Smith said growers are concerned about temperatures in the next few weeks because the unusual warm spell during much of January and February _ when temperatures often reached into the 60s _ had fruit trees blooming three weeks earlier than normal. Kitty Washburne, president of a mail-order flowering bulb business in Garrison, Md., saw a good side to the chill _ it reminded spring bulbs that it's only February. ``My immediate reaction was that I was kind of glad that we had something to stop them a little bit in their zeal to come up,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: High Court Says Some Patients at Mental Hospitals May Sue
DOC.TEXT: People held against their will at state mental hospitals without receiving legally required hearings may sue officials in federal court for monetary damages, the Supreme Court ruled by a 5-4 vote today. The justices, reversing lower court rulings, said a Florida man may sue in federal court over being held in a Florida state hospital for five months without a hearing that state law requires within 48 hours. Writing for the court, Justice Harry A. Blackmun said people raising such claims are not limited to suing for damages in state courts. Darrell Burch was found wandering along a Florida highway Dec. 7, 1981. He was taken to a Tallahassee community health services center where he was held for three days. During that time, Burch was hallucinating. He believed he was in heaven. After his stay at the center, Burch was transferred to the Florida State Hospital, where he remained until May 7, 1982. his lawsuit alleges that he was heavily medicated and disoriented when arriving at the state hospital. Despite a state law that entitled him to a hearing within 48 hours of his admission to challenge his detention and treatment, Burch did not receive a hearing. His federal lawsuit alleged that 11 officials and employees of the Florida State Hospital acted ``with willful, wanton and reckless disregard of and indifference to'' his due-process rights. The suit invoked a much-used civil rights law. A federal judge threw out the suit, ruling that Burch was barred from filing it because he could win adequate relief in state court. A three-judge panel of the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the dismissal, but the entire appeals court voted 8-5 to reinstate the suit. Today's decision upheld the 11th Circuit court's ruling, and Burch's lawsuit can now proceed. Blackmun wrote that previous high court decisions limiting access to federal courts if adequate state court remedies exist do not apply to Burch's case because ``the deprivation of Burch's liberty'' was not unpredictable. ``Under Florida's statutory scheme, only a person competent to give informed consent may be admitted as a voluntary patient,'' Blackmun said. ``There is, however, no specified way of determining, before a patient is asked to sign admission forms, whether he is competent.'' Therefore, Blackmun said, ``It is hardly unforeseeable that a person requesting treatment for mental illness might be incapable of informed consent, and that state officials with the power to admit patients might take their apparent willingness to be admitted at face value.'' Blackmun was joined by Justices William J. Brennan, Byron R. White, Thurgood Marshall and John Paul Stevens. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Sandra Day O'Connor, Antonin Scalia and Anthony M. Kennedy dissented. The case is Zinermon vs. Burch, 87-1965.

DOC.HEAD: Havel Vists Sakharov Grave, Meets Soviet Legislators
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel today paid homage to the late human rights activist Andrei Sakharov, one of the few Soviets who openly welcomed the 1968 ``Prague Spring'' reforms and denounced the Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia. Havel, Czechoslovakia's first non-Communist leader in 41 years, also met with Soviet legislators and suggested an exchange of parliamentary delegations, with the Czechoslovak side led by Alexander Dubcek, the former Communist Party chief who authored the 1968 reforms. Dubcek's last two official visits to Moscow were humiliating. In the first, days after the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact invasion, he was under arrest. In the second, two months later, he signed an agreement allowing Soviet troops to stay on Czechoslovak soil indefinitely and promising the country would return to Soviet-style, hard-line rule. Dubcek was ousted as party chief in 1969 and returned to a position of power only late last year, as head of Parliament following that country's peaceful revolution. In sharp contrast to Dubcek's experience, Havel met with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev Monday and announced an accord to withdraw the 73,500 Soviet troops from Czechoslovakia by July 1, 1991. ``We perfectly understood each other on various problems,'' Havel in an interview with Soviet television. He also agreed to help pay for the Soviet troops to leave his country, provide free transport back home and help build housing for the troops in the Soviet Union. Sakharov, who died in December, became a fierce campaigner for human rights and reform after the Prague Spring reforms were crushed by Soviet troops. He lived to see the Soviet government condemn its invasion, but he did not see the election of Havel, a former political prisoner, as Czechoslovak president. Havel visited the grave with Sakharov's widow, Yelena Bonner, and Czechoslovak Foreign Minister Jiri Dienstbier. They placed flowers among the many bouquets which are constantly replenished by mourners. The Czechoslovak leader also met today with members of the Soviet parliament's Foreign Affairs Committee, then walked across Red Square to his car surrounded by security guards. Havel and the legislators discussed the parliaments of the two countries and future exchanges, Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov said. Havel arrived in Moscow for talks with Gorbachev on Monday, just three days after returning from the United States, where he met with President Bush. At a news conference Monday, Havel said he signed a joint declaration with Gorbachev that opens the way for new cooperation between the two countries. It suggested relations be developed ``on the basis of equality and complete mutual respect for each other's state sovereignty,'' according to Tass. The Czechovslovak delegation included Defense Minister Miroslav Vacek and Interior Minister Richard Sacher, who wants to reduce links between officials of his ministry and those of the Soviet KGB operating on Czechoslovak soil. Havel, a playwright, spent five years in prison for his political activities against the Czechoslovak government.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Gets Hero's Welcome On First Foreign Trip
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela received a hero's welcome today as he set foot on foreign soil for the first time in 28 years. The black nationalist leader embraced exiled members of his African National Congress and seven African presidents in an emotional ceremony on the tarmac at the Lusaka airport. President Kenneth Kaunda of Zambia, whose Southern African nation has hosted the ANC's exile headquarters for almost two decades, was the first to greet Mandela and his wife, Winnie. To drumbeats, Mandela was draped with garlands of red and white flowers by the children of ANC exiles. Dozens of young ANC guerrillas wearing black berets, ANC T-shirts and military fatigues looked on. In his six-day visit, Mandela will meet African and Commonwealth leaders, as well as with exiled ANC leaders from the organization's 35-member national executive committee and military wing. No agenda for the ANC meetings has been released but officials indicated ANC strategy and Mandela's role within the group would be discussed. Zambian officials said the talks with regional leaders will have the most impact on political life in Southern Africa since the 1979 Lusaka Commonwealth summit. That meeting cleared the way for the end of white minority rule in the former British colony of Rhodesia, now independent Zimbabwe. About 10,000 people, including many South African exiles, cheered, waving the ANC's distinctive black, green and gold colors, when Mandela left the plane and raised a clenched-fist salute. He told the crowd he was happy to be visiting the second home of exiled ANC leaders who molded the organization into a powerful political and military force. ``They have led and directed our people to the point where we are on the verge of a breathrough in our struggle for freedom,'' Mandela said. He praised Kaunda as a peacemaker who tried to persuade successive governments in Pretoria to open dialogue with the ANC. But ``if we are compelled to resort to arms...the responsibility for this lies firmly on the shoulders of the government,'' he said. Tens of thousands of well-wishers, exhorted by full-page advertisements in government newspapers, lined the 15-mile route from Lusaka airport to Kuanda's official residence, where Mandela will stay. People waited in sweltering tropical temperatures for several hours to catch a glimpse of the ANC leader, who was released from prison in South Africa on Feb. 11. The crowds waved green branches, a traditional African symbol of rejoicing, in the biggest public turnout since Pope John Paul II's visit last May. Kaunda declared today a national holiday and Nelson Mandela Day. Factories, offices and shops were closed in Lusaka, a city of 1 million. City authorities temporarily lifted a ban on public gatherings imposed last month to curb an outbreak of cholera that has killed more than 80 people. Mandela, leading a 20-member delegation of ANC leaders from South Africa, was taken by a high-speed motorcade of limousines to Lusaka's main conference complex, where he was to meet visiting foreign dignitaries. During his stay in Zambia, Mandela will meet with leaders from Angola, Botswana, Mozambique, Tanzania, Zambia and Zimbabwe, as well as from the 49-nation Commonwealth of former British territories. ``We will obviously be examining how to proceed with the political struggle and the armed struggle,'' a senior ANC official said on condition of anonymity. He said the meeting will also select a 10-member ANC delegation for preliminary talks with South African President F.W. de Klerk. The talks will clear the way for negotiations on full participation in South Africa by the 28 million disenfranchised blacks. The ANC says reforms announced by de Klerk, including the lifting of a 30-year ban on the ANC on Feb. 2 and Mandela's release, do not go far enough. But on Feb. 16, the group said it was willing to hold its first direct talks with Pretoria.

DOC.HEAD: Excommunicated Priest Condemns `Racist' Church
DOC.TEXT: A Roman Catholic priest excommunicated after he formed a black congregation received applause at a Jesuit college when he condemned the church as racist, and ordered guards to throw out a heckler. The Rev. George Stallings, who was excommunicated after forming the African-American Catholic Congregation in Washington, D.C., last summer, addressed an audience of about 1,300 people Monday at Le Moyne College. He was applauded when he said the Catholic Church ``remains primarily a white, racist institution in the United States,'' and that he would both expose the racism of the church and provide an alternative. But Stallings received some opposition when he strayed from the issue of racism. Stallings, who claims a following of about 2,200 people, began listing his congregation's support for birth control, female priests, married priests, and permission for Catholic couples to divorce. ``What right do they (church leaders) have to say that I ... should not have the right to break that relationship and move into a wholesome, healthy and protective relationship?'' Stallings asked. A man in the audience yelled ``Jesus said it!'' and began moving toward Stallings. ``That's who said it.'' Stallings, quickly surrounded by guards and supporters, ordered guards to throw the man out. ``I am the one who is giving the lecture, sir, not you,'' he said. ``Get him out and put him out.'' Two other dissenters stood outside of the building with posters protesting abortion and Stallings' appearance. Stallings does not support Catholic Church opposition to abortion, saying he supports free choice in the matter. Stallings said his church will allow priests to marry. But he said he wouldn't marry a nun, as some ex-priests have. ``When I get married it won't be to a nun. I can tell you that,'' he said. ``Because she might have more hangups than I do.''

DOC.HEAD: Legislators Approve Presidency
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 grafs after 7th graf pvs, `Pro-democracy demonstrators...' to ADD quote from Gorbachev, others. Pick up 8th graf pvs, `The Supreme...' Minor editing to trim.
DOC.TEXT: A determined Mikhail S. Gorbachev today pushed through the legislature his proposal for a Western-style presidency despite vigorous objections that the new post would concentrate too much power in one man's hands. Amid shouts of protest from lawmakers who warned of the dangers of dictatorship, Gorbachev called the vote for his proposal ``a great political event in the history of our state.'' The vote in the Supreme Soviet was 347-24, with 43 abstentions, in favor of the bill that approves creation of the presidency in principle. The bill now goes to committees, who will consider numerous amendments proposed during a day of heated debate. Then, the Congress of People's Deputies, the Supreme Soviet's parent body, will meet March 12-13 to elect a president. The bill would give the president sweeping powers to declare war, veto legislation, impose a state of emergency and call a referendum on legislative decisions he doesn't approve of. During the debate today, liberals said the creation of a presidency is premature, and they accused the leadership of trying to rush the issue through. But Gorbachev angrily rejected critics, saying they had engaged in ``cheap demagoguery.'' Legislators shouted in protest from the floor. ``Everything I believe necessary to say I'll say,'' the 58-year-old Kremlin chief shouted back. One legislator, a taxi driver from the Ukraine who last year compared Gorbachev to Napoleon on national television, said he saw a bad omen in the voting. ``The way the voting went from the floor today is the same way presidential power will be,'' shouted Leonid Sukhov in an obvious reference to Gorbachev's pressure. Pro-democracy demonstrators in several Soviet cities over the weekend said the president would become a dictator, and one sign at a Leningrad rally warned the new post could lead to fascism. The Supreme Soviet refused Feb. 14 to be stampeded into setting a timetable for approving a presidency modeled after the American and French systems. Gorbachev has said a strong president is needed as part of his blueprint for transferring power from the Communist Party to the government. It is a radical departure from Soviet political practice stretching back to the days of Stalin, when the party leader was supreme ruler. Before the vote, liberals led by Sergei Stankevich, a student of American politics and spokesman for the Inter-Regional Deputies Group, and Anatoly Sobchak, a Leningrad legislator, said the presidency as proposed would be subject to abuse. ``All our decisions can be crossed out by the president,'' Sobchak told the 542-member legislature. He and Stankevich said the proposed presidency would tilt the balance of power toward the chief executive and away from the legislature. Many Soviets today see the need for an iron hand to solve the country's problems. ``We're tired from social tension. When are you going to put the country in order?'' legislator Rano Ubaidullaeva said her constituents are saying. ``We need a person who can have real power ... the quicker the better.'' The draft bill released today says the president must be a Soviet citizen and be at least 35 years old. He would be elected to a five-year term directly by universal suffrage. The official who introduced the bill, however, said the procedure would be different the first time. Vladimir Kudryavtsev, a vice president of the Academy of Sciences, said the first president would be elected by the Congress of People's Deputies to a four-year term. He said it would take too long to prepare direct elections now. Other provisions would give the president power to declare a state of emergency or war, to serve as commander-in-chief of the armed forces, and to veto legislation. The Supreme Soviet could override the veto by a majority vote but the president could then appeal to the congress or call a referendum on the issue. The president could also ask the legislature to hold a vote of no confidence in the country's premier and Council of Ministers, the nominal Cabinet. A new body of advisers would be created, called a ``presidential council.'' For the first time, the law specifies a detailed procedure of succession if the president is unable to fulfill his duties. The chairman of the Supreme Soviet or premier would rule until presidential elections are held within three months. In another first, the bill provides for impeachment of the president if he violates the constitution. A majority of Baltic legislators announced they will not participate in the debate or vote on the proposed presidency because they believe it inappropriate to do so before the structure between the republics and central government is decided. Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania are fighting to restore the independence they had between the two world wars. Georgian lawmakers also announced they would not participate, because they said it was unclear how the office would be used. It is widely assumed Gorbachev will seek the post, but he has refused to commit himself as a candidate.

DOC.HEAD: Foley Says Bush Needs to Back Edcuation Rhetoric With Dollars
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 12 grafs new with Foley speech; picks up at pvs 6th graf, Gov. Richard
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is failing to back up his rhetoric about educational excellence with federal money, and the administration's proposed 2 percent spending increase for schools is ``meager'' and ``tepid,'' House Speaker Thomas S. Foley said today. ``While I commend the president for his desire to be known as `the education president,' I question whether he can achieve that goal by proposing a meager 2 percent increase in the federal spending on education,'' Foley told the nation's governors. ``The simple fact is we don't have a 2 percent education problem in this country,'' he said. ``The education gap is much more daunting.'' Foley spoke to the bipartisan National Governors' Association as it concluded its annual winter meeting. Speaking to the state executives on Monday, Bush praised their education goals but left some Democratic governors grumbling that the administration wasn't recommending additional money to help the states pay for implementing them. Foley said Bush's proposed education spending amounted to ``tepid incrementalism.'' He said the United States lags behind much of the industrial world in per capita spending on kindergarten through 12th grade education. ``We need bolder action,'' he said. Foley also said the lessening in world tensions would result in budget savings for the United States _ the ``peace dividend'' anticipated from reduced demands for military spending. Answering questions from the governors, Foley predicted an actual cut in military spending, not just in its rate of growth. But he said the ``absolute reduction'' would probably take about five years to appear. He also complained that the administration was not releasing for spending on highways and airports money accumulated from excise taxes in trust funds _ a frequent complaint of the governors. Foley said that amounted to $17 billion for highways and $14 billion for airports _ money he said was being retained to make the federal deficit look smaller. The governors' main accomplishments at their meeting came Sunday with approval of a set of goals for improving education, and Monday's meeting with Bush at the White House. Gov. Richard Celeste of Ohio, chairman of the Democratic governors, said he asked Bush in their private meeting about putting more money into education. Celeste said the money was needed ``to translate what is ambitious rhetoric into action.'' ``He seemed unaccountably reluctant to make any commitments,'' Celeste said. ``He steered away from anything that would smack of additional resources.'' The group's education goals follow closely the proposals Bush made last month in his State of the Union speech. Bush praised the governors for their work on education and said he would try to keep it ``in the forefront of America's agenda.'' ``We are launching a new era in education reform,'' Bush said. ``Its focus, high expectations; its hallmark, results.'' Republican Gov. Terry Branstad of Iowa, chairman of the National Governors' Association, said governors were ``committed over the next decade to holding ourselves accountable'' on meeting the goals. But Democratic Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia said the goals may not be reachable if the federal government doesn't propose more funds. Republican Gov. Carroll Campbell of South Carolina, who was co-chairman of the governors' education task force, noted that the federal government pays only about 7 percent of the cost of public schools. ``We're going to have to carry the bulk of this, we and the local communities,'' he said. The governors were voting today on several policy resolutions, including one recommending a clean-air act requiring up to 1 million vehicles be produced annually that make use of an alternative fuel. Celeste, a two-term governor barred by Ohio state law from seeking re-election this year, gave voice to Democrats' frustration with Bush's sky-high approval rating in the polls. ``A president with an 80 percent popularity rating _ he could take on any tough issue. What is the tough issue he's going to take on? I don't see any. He's sort of suspended out there, as I say, in his own medium, at a distance from all of us,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: All Drug Use is Immoral, 61 Percent Say in Survey
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 6th graf pvs bgng, `Americans want,' with 1 graf of new quotes; INSERTS 2 grafs after 14th graf pvs bgng, `Seventy percent,' to UPDATE with Trebach reaction to Americans choosing taking any steps to curb drug use over protection of civil liberties
DOC.TEXT: Fewer than 2 percent of Americans questioned in a new survey say they might try cocaine if it were legal _ but 60 percent say they think someone else would. Three-fifths of those questioned in the poll released today by the Drug Policy Foundation said all drug use is immoral and should be illegal, while 35 percent disagreed. And 55 percent said they believe the Bush administration's war on drugs is likely to reduce the drug problem, while 36 percent favored legalization of less serious drugs along with an increase in drug treatment and education. When given the choice between providing treatment and counseling for drug users or punishing drug users with fines and-or imprisonment, 68 percent favored treatment and 21 percent favored punishment. ``In rejecting the war on drug users and in choosing not to use drugs even if drugs were legal, Americans are saying, `Make health, not war,''' foundation President Arnold S. Trebach said in a statement released with the survey. Trebach said today that he interpreted the survey to mean, ``In general, the American people say, `We would like a compromise. We would like to see that we treat this problem within the health system, not the criminal justice system.' If they see no option, they might go for the criminal justice system. ... I think it's a call for enlightened leadership.'' The Drug Policy Foundation advocates treating drug abuse as a health problem, not a criminal justice issue, and has encouraged drug decriminalization efforts. Despite the 61 percent who said all drug use is immoral and should be illegal, foundation Vice President Kevin Zeese said, ``There is significant support for outright legalization of drugs. Americans are realizing that more jails, more arrests and more seizures will never solve the drug problem.'' National drug control policy director William J. Bennett has called legalization advocacy ``stupid and morally atrocious.'' Bennett, speaking briefly to reporters at the White House today, brushed off the report and said some progress has been made. ``Now that we're starting to see some encouraging signs, why put up the white flag?'' he said. The poll of 1,401 adult Americans in a random, digital-dial telephone sample done Jan. 24-Feb. 4 by Targeting Systems Inc. of Arlington, Va., has a margin of error of 3 percentage points, said company President Charles Welsh. Richard J. Dennis of Chicago, chairman of the Drug Policy Foundation Advisory Board, paid for the survey. The survey revealed some mixed messages. While 36 percent said they favored legalization of less dangerous drugs combined with more treatment and education over the Bush administration plan, 75 percent said they wanted more federal law enforcement efforts. Seventy percent said they wanted more federal drug treatment and education, and 71 percent said it was more important to take ``any step necessary'' to stop drug use than to protect civil rights and civil liberties. Trebach said today that the response to that latter question made him ``very nervous.'' ``My interpretation of that is ... the American people are annoyed enough about this drug problem, worried enough about it, that if their leaders suggest an invasion of a little country in South America ... if they suggest a search of cars and all kinds of other invasions of civil rights, it is possible the American people will support it. That is an enormous danger,'' he said. Of those polled, 11 percent said they had tried cocaine hydrochloride _ cocaine powder _ while 89 percent said they had not. Asked the likelihood of their trying cocaine if that drug were legalized, 1.7 percent said they were very likely or somewhat likely to do so, while 96.9 percent said they were unlikely to try it. However, 60 percent said they believe cocaine use would increase if it were no longer a crime. Ten percent said cocaine use would decrease while 27 percent said it would stay the same. Of those who had never tried cocaine, 0.9 percent said they might try it if it were legalized, while 9 percent of those who had used it before said they were at least somewhat likely to try it again. For marijuana, 35 percent of those polled said they had tried it, 65 percent had not. Overall, 88.8 percent said they were not very likely or not at all likely to try it if it were legalized, while 9.6 percent said they might. But 50 percent said marijuana use would increase if it were legalized, while 12 percent said it would decrease and 37 percent said it would stay the same. Regarding medical use of some prohibited drugs, 76 percent said physicians should be allowed to prescribe heroin as a painkiller for terminally ill cancer patients, and 69 percent said they should be allowed to prescribe marijuana as a treatment for glaucoma. One question was prefaced with the statement: ``The current law enforcement efforts to curb drug use cost taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars per year, with an ever-increasing prison population reaching 1 million people in the U.S.'' Respondents then were asked whether tax dollars are best used for ``imprisoning all drug users'' or whether ``other less expensive methods such as treatment programs and drug education should be allocated more of the tax dollars.'' In response, 74 percent selected treatment and education, 13 percent chose imprisonment for all drug users, 7 percent volunteered that both were good choices.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Rebound In Tokyo, Dollar Continues To Gain
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after the 4th graf, `On Monday,' to UPDATE with New York, London trading; Picks up 5th graf, `There was'.
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index rebounded strongly today from its second-steepest one-day plunge ever as investors took comfort from advances on major overseas markets, analysts said. The dollar continued its gain against the Japanese yen for the sixth consecutive trading day, reaching an eight-month high despite heavy dollar-selling by Japan's central bank in support of the yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues climbed 576.08 points, or 1.73 percent, closing at 33,897.95. On Monday, it had fallen 4.5 percent, or 1,569.10 points, second only to the 3,836.48-point plunge on Oct. 20, 1987, following Wall Street's ``Black Monday.'' The gain in Tokyo helped boost prices in New York and London today. On Wall Street, the Dow Jones industrial average was up 6.98 to 2,609.46 at 11 a.m. EST. Traders said the U.S. market was reassured by the improvement on the Tokyo exchange. In London, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-stock index, the major barometer of the British equities market, was up 7.1 points, or 0.3 percent, at 2,256.4 at midday. There was disagreement on whether the Tokyo market had hit bottom, but Shiro Suzuki, an analyst at Nikko Securities Co., said, ``Especially individual investors gained confidence since Monday's plunge did not have negative effects on the New York and London markets overnight.'' Suzuki said there would be no major buying by institutional investors, now awaiting account settlements at the end of Japan's fiscal year on March 31. The recent fall of Tokyo stock prices has been blamed on stock, bond and yen prices all driving each other down in a vicious cycle, and on computer-guided trading by foreign brokerages taking advantage of different prices for the same issue on different markets, for instance the spot and futures markets. Late Monday, the Tokyo Stock Exchange asked major securities companies to restrict this arbitrage selling. Also Monday, the Finance Ministry bought some $671 million worth of 10-year government bonds in an attempt to stop bond prices from falling and to push long-term interest rates down. In this morning's session, arbitrage selling by some securities firms for profit-taking amounted to some $201 million, said Kazuyuki Suzuki, a dealer with Daiwa Securities Co. He said this brought a moderate decline in the index, which later climbed again. Hironobu Takahashi, a spokesman of the Tokyo Stock Exchange, said, ``It is rather difficult to evaluate the market reaction from just one day of trading, but I believe our member firms understood what we asked yesterday and tried to be cooperative.'' On Monday, when the Finance Ministry was buying bonds, the yield for the benchmark No. 119 10-year government bond fell to 6.875 percent from a high of 7.015 percent. The ministry stayed out of the market today, however, and the yield rose to 6.910 percent. The Nikkei index's rise today was not steady. After a gain of some 700 points, it lost more than 170 before heading up again. ``It will take some time for the index to make a steady recovery,'' Nikko's Suzuki said. Volume traded on the first section reached 550 million shares, up from 400 million shares Monday. In the currency market, the dollar closed at 149.03 yen, up 0.38 yen from Monday's close of 148.65 yen and its highest close since 151.30 yen on June 15. It opened at 148.30 yen and ranged between 148.10 yen and 149.50 yen. The dollar now has gained 4.51 yen in the last six trading days. Currency dealers said the Bank of Japan sold some $2 billion dollars in support of the yen. The bank does not comment on its exchange market activity.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Acquits Social Worker In Child-Abuse Death
DOC.TEXT: A judge today ordered the acquittal of a state social worker accused of failing to report suspected child abuse prior to the potty-training death of a toddler. After the state called three witnesses, Polk County Judge Jesse Barber said that prosecutors simply didn't prove the charge and issued the directed verdict. ``No reasonable jury could reach any other verdict than for acquittal,'' the judge said after two key state witnesses testified the social worker acted appropriately. Kenneth Houk was the first of three state Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services workers to face trial in connection with the death of 2-year-old Bradley McGee. The toddler died July 28 of head injuries after he was dunked repeatedly headfirst into a toilet for soiling his pants and beaten with pillows, prosecutors said. The trial marks the first time in Florida that a child-care worker has been prosecuted for his handling of a case. The misdemeanor carried a maximum penalty of up to 60 days in jail. Bradley's mother and stepfather _ Sheryl McGee Coe, 21, and Thomas Coe, 22, of Lakeland _ face trial this summer on first-degree murder and aggravated child abuse charges. Houk, 39, was accused of twice failing to call the HRS abuse hotline when he received calls about Bradley. Prosecutors said Houk got a call in December 1988 claiming the mother was unfit because she was drinking and using cocaine; and only weeks before Bradley's death, he received another call that the baby's mother had forced him to eat feces as punishment for violating potty training. A key state witness, Theresa Jacobs, who originally reported the feces complaint, told the jury that Houk had urged her numerous times to telephone the child abuse registry when she had a complaint to report. She said she didn't follow his advice. ``He had told me before to call the registry, but I never got any satisfaction from the registry,'' Ms. Jacobs testified. ``I didn't see him eat feces. I didn't see the bruises.'' Houk's attorneys claim he acted in good faith by telling Ms. Jacobs the first time to notify the toddler's assigned caseworker. ``He did not just not do anything,'' Wilkins said, ``They're saying he did the wrong thing.'' A jury was chosen Monday. Attorneys found all of the prospective jurors were familiar with the Bradley McGee case _ with some saying they had read every news article about it. Caseworkers Margaret Barber and Shirley Duboise are also charged with failing to report child abuse in the case. Ms. Barber faces an additional charge of felony child abuse.

DOC.HEAD: DWI Checkpoints vs. Privacy Right Argued Before Court
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 11 grafs new with arguments; picks up at pvs 4th graf, At issue
DOC.TEXT: Authorities today defended police checkpoints as an effective weapon against drunken driving, but an attorney for a group of Michigan motorists told the Supreme Court the stops violate privacy and do not work. ``We think they are very effective,'' said Thomas L. Casey, assistant state solicitor general in Michigan. ``They do result in arrests of drunk drivers. They do have a deterrent effect. They do have an educational effect.'' Mark Granzotto, a Detroit lawyer representing the motorists, argued, however, ``As a means of acting against drunken driving, sobriety roadblocks are worthless.'' ``They don't work,'' Granzotto said when challenged by Chief Justice William Rehnquist to explain why they were ineffective. Justice Byron White asked Granzotto why, if the roadbocks are ineffective, many states have adopted them. ``They are a very visible means of showing that something is being done,'' the lawyer replied. Casey argued that the intrusion into people's privacy has been kept to a minimum under the Michigan procedure. He said people have to be willing to be ``a little bit inconvenienced'' because of the seriousness of the drunken-driving problem. Granzotto said he did not disagree that the problem is serious. However, he said, ``We have an intrusion that may be minimal in some respects, but it is an intrusion that does not accomplish anything.'' The court's decision is expected by July. Lower courts have split on the issue. Some have upheld the use of checkpoints. Others, like the Michigan courts, have ruled that such police tactics violate privacy rights. President Bush called on state and local governments in December to step up the fight against drunken driving. ``It's as crippling as crack, as random gang violence, and it's killing more kids than both combined,'' he said. The president noted that state and local governments are receiving federal aid to operate sobriety checkpoints. Michigan state police first used sobriety checkpoints, which they modeled after a program used in Maryland, in 1986. At a checkpoint site, police directed all traffic headed in one direction to a roadside area where officers checked motorists for signs of intoxication. If there was no immediate evidence of intoxication, the motorist was given a traffic safety brochure and allowed to drive away. The average delay was about a half-minute. If some signs of intoxication were detected, a driver was directed to another area for further questioning and perhaps a breath test. At one such checkpoint, Michigan state police troopers checked 126 vehicles in less than an hour and detained two drivers for sobriety field tests. One driver was arrested on drunken driving charges. Seven Michigan residents sued the state police soon after the checkpoint program began. Their lawsuit alleged that the checkpoints violated the Fourth Amendment's ban on unreasonable police searches and arrests. State courts struck down the practice, citing ``the potential for an unreasonable subjective intrusion on individual liberty interests.'' Michigan's appeal is being supported in ``friend of the court'' briefs by 27 states and groups including the National Governors' Association, the National League of Cities, Mothers Against Drunk Driving and the Alliance of American Insurers. The Supreme Court in 1979 barred police from randomly stopping vehicles to check registration papers. In that Delaware case, officers had total discretion over which vehicles were stopped. But the 1979 decision did not rule out spot checks in which an officer's discretion was not so unconstrained. ``Questioning of all oncoming traffic at roadblock-type stops is one possible alternative,'' the decision said. At issue in a separate case from Pennsylvania also being heard today was whether motorists must be given so-called Miranda warnings before police videotape their taking sobriety field tests. The court will decide by July whether police violated a motorist's rights when they videotaped his answers to questions about his height, weight and eye color before telling him he could remain silent and was entitled to have a lawyer present. The cases are Michigan State Police vs. Sitz, 88-1897, and Pennsylvania vs. Muniz, 89-213.

DOC.HEAD: Kaifu, Re-Elected, Forms New Cabinet
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with new Cabinet. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Newly re-elected Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu today formed a new Cabinet after hours of factional wrangling and succeeded in keeping out scandal-tainted politicians. The backstage maneuvering followed Parliament's vote earlier tday to leave the prime minister's post with Kaifu, who led his Liberal Democratic Party to victory in crucial elections Feb. 18 for Parliament's powerful lower house. Kaifu completed the delicate task of distributing Cabinet portfolios among party factions just three days before leaving for a summit meeting with President Bush. In a major test of his political muscle, Kaifu was able to resist a senior faction leader who pushed strongly for the inclusion of Koko Sato. Sato had been given a suspended sentence in a 1970s scandal in which Lockheed Aircraft Corp. paid bribes to politicians to influence sales of its aircraft in Japan. As expected, Kaifu retained Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama and Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto to preserve continuity in dealing with an unpopular new sales tax and trade frictions with the United States. Kaifu became prime minister last August after two predecessors resigned over the more Recruit influence-buying scandal and the governing party's loss of its upper house majority for the first time in 34 years. With his clean image, Kaifu got the nod despite his weak power base in the party. Senior leaders stayed on the sidelines because of their links to the Recruit scandal. But with the party's unexpectedly comfortable majority in the Feb. 18 elections, Kaifu felt his position strengthened, while party elders insisted the result also meant public exoneration for scandal-tainted politicians who retained their seats in parliament. Kaifu insisted on keeping a ``clean'' Cabinet. Former Finance Minister Michio Watanabe stalled negotiations for several hours by insisting on a post for Sato, a close ally who has been elected to the lower house nine times but never served as a Cabinet minister. Former Agriculture Minister Kabun Muto was named minister of international trade and industry, another sensitive post as Washington steps up demands that Japan restructure its economy to eradicate its $49 billion trade surplus with the United States. Trade will be a main topic taken up by Kaifu and Bush in their two-day meeting Friday and Saturday. Other lawmakers who were appointed Cabinet ministers included Justice Minister Shin Hasegawa, Labor Minister Shunpei Tsukahara, Construction Minister Tamisuke Watanuki, Education Minister Kosuke Hori and Defense Agency Director General Yozo Ishikawa. Dropped from the Cabinet were both women from Kaifu's first Cabinet. One of them, Mayumi Moriyama, a member of the upper house, had been chief Cabinet secretary, the top government spokeswoman. She was reported angered at being replaced by Misoji Sakamoto, another top Kaifu aide, despite her tireless campaigning in the election. Women voters have been getting increased attention, especially after their strong objections to a new 3 percent sales tax were seen as a key factor in the governing party's upper house losses in last July's elections. Economic Planning Agency Director General Sumiko Takahara, also was replaced by a man, Hideyuki Aizawa. The Cabinet resigned en masse earlier today, paving the way for Kaifu to reorganize his administration after a flurry of meetings with the party's various faction heads. Former Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita, ex-Foreign Minister Shintaro Abe and ex-Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa _ all linked to the Recruit scandal _ control the three largest factions. Kaifu, 59, belongs to a minor faction led by former state minister Toshio Komoto and needs the support of the larger factions to maintain the party presidency and thus the prime minister's position. In Parliament, Kaifu won 286 of 508 valid votes cast in the powerful lower house, which formally chooses the prime minister. He needed a majority of 255 to win. Socialist Party Chairwoman Takako Doi, his nearest rival, won 146. Kaifu bowed as his formal re-election was proclaimed. He was greeted by a round of rousing applause and scattered cheers. In the opposition-controlled, 252-seat upper house, Kaifu failed to win a clear majority in the first round of balloting, but won in a run-off with Ms. Doi 111-91. Forty-four ballots were left blank. The lower house decision is binding with or without the assent of the upper house, but the lack of consensus is rare. When Kaifu first assumed office six months ago, he was the first prime minister in 41 years who was not nominated by both houses.

DOC.HEAD: Sentenced for Robberies
DOC.TEXT: A man dubbed the ``gentleman bandit'' for promising to send roses to bank tellers after robbing them has been sentenced to 37 months in prison. Kevin Lee Newby on Monday also was ordered to pay $8,972 in restitution _ the amount taken in five 1989 savings and loan robberies. Newby used a toy pistol in the robberies and told some of the tellers to ``have a nice day'' and promised to send them roses. He pleaded guilty in November to robbing the First Federal Savings and Loan Association in Grandview, Mo., on April 24, and the World Savings & Loan Association in Lenexa on Aug. 9. Charges in three other robberies were dismissed. Newby told police he had been out of work and was trying to find a way to support his wife and son.

DOC.HEAD: Champs-Elysees to Become `Wheatfield'
DOC.TEXT: Farmers will turn the famed Champs-Elysees into a gigantic field of golden wheat that they will harvest in June to celebrate French agriculture. The 4{-acre field will stretch halfway down the avenue, which will be closed to traffic, starting from the Arc de Triomphe. ``The Big Harvest,'' to take place on June 24 at the cost of $4.7 million, is sponsored by the National Center For Young Farmers to focus attention on the positive aspects of farming. ``When farming adopts a friendly, convivial tone, the rest of the world is interested,'' said Henry Jouve, president of the center. The 24-hour extravaganza will culminate with a show by 500 farmers, including agricultural displays and musical performances. The wheat already has been planted in special greenhouses outside Paris. It is expected to be ripe for picking by June 23, when 1,000 young farmers will truck it into the capital and install it on the Champs-Elysees.

DOC.HEAD: Mount Everest Cleanup Will Be a New Kind of Superpower Summitry
DOC.TEXT: Chinese, American and Soviet mountaineers plan to scale Mount Everest and clean up some of the 2 tons of discarded tents, oxygen bottles and other garbage left by generations of climbers on the world's highest peak. The expedition _ a new kind of superpower summitry _ is China's biggest joint cultural undertaking with any foreign country since June, when its violent crackdown on protesters strained ties with many countries. Jim Whittaker of Port Townsend, Wash., who organized what he is calling the Everest Peace Climb, tried to emphasize the political implications at a U.S. Embassy reception Tuesday on the eve of the team's flight to Tibet. Will the friendly climb affect tense Chinese-American relations? ``We hope it will, we hope there's peace,'' Whittaker answered quickly. ``One Chinese, one Soviet and one American will stand on the summit with our arms around each other, demonstrating that with cooperation, high goals can be reached.'' But U.S. Ambassador James Lilley, to whom the question had been directed, smiled uncomfortably and said, ``I believe it stands on its own: normal people-to-people relations.'' For several hours, Chinese, American and Soviet officials mingled at Lilley's residence and heard speeches about friendship and cooperation _ a scene that was common in Beijing before June but has become rare since. China has accused the United States of seeking to undermine its socialist system, and privately has labeled the Soviets ``revisionist'' for political reforms that have weakened the role of the Communist Party. All three countries appeared in agreement, however, on the need to clean up Mount Everest. The team of 17 Americans, 17 Chinese and 12 Soviets plans to bring down as much as it can of the estimated 2 tons of garbage left at camp sites on the Himalayan peak on the Nepal-Tibet border. ``We're going to take duffle bags and load them up,'' said Whittaker, 61. ``In places we can drop (the garbage), let it free-fall, and then we'll pick it up at the bottom, burn what will burn and bury the rest. ``We want to leave no trace of humans on the mountain.'' The 29,028-foot mountain was first scaled in 1953 by Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay. Since then, dozens of teams have swarmed over its lower reaches each year, although fewer than 250 climbers have reached the top. Whittaker, who in 1963 became the first American to reach Mount Everest's summit, said he saw no sign at the top of those who went before him, but that his own team left empty oxygen bottles and other debris. ``We thought differently in those days. We weren't as concerned about the environment because there weren't so many people going into the hills,'' he said. The expedition plans to send only three people to the summit, one from each country. Their target date is April 22, Earth Day. Whittaker said the summiteers will use a satellite hook-up to converse from the peak with President Bush, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and a Chinese leader. Chinese sports officials said that probably will be Premier Li Peng. Teams from the three countries made practice climbs together on Mount Rainier in the United States in June and in the Caucasus Mountains in the Soviet Union in September. Mount Rainier is less than half as high as Mount Everest, at 14,410 feet. After the first joint climb, the Chinese changed their team, however, and it is now made up mostly of Tibetans.
