Most of the more than $1 million cost of the expedition is being paid by U.S. corporate sponsors and individual donations.

DOC.HEAD: Political Status of Soviet Republics
With AM-Soviet-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Voters in the Soviet Union's 15 republics began electing new local Supreme Soviet legislatures in a six-month period that began Jan. 7. Here is a look at the republics and their problems:

ARMENIA _ Armenians elect a new Supreme Soviet on May 20. The current legislature passed a resolution Dec. 1 that called for reuniting the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh to the republic. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev branded the resolution unconstitutional. The disputed territory is being directly controlled by a special Kremlin commission.

AZERBAIJAN _ Beset by ethnic unrest in the capital of Baku, a state of emergency and curfew are in effect in this southern republic and a date for Supreme Soviet elections has yet to be announced. The republic is locked in a bitter dispute with Armenia over control of Nagorno-Karabakh, the mainly Armenian Christian enclave inside predominantly Moslem Azerbaijan. The dispute has led to hundreds of deaths in the two republics in the past two years.

BYELORUSSIA _ The Byelorussian Popular Front is organizing a challenge to the Communist Party in elections scheduled for March 4. The Popular Front has accused the republic's authorities of refusing to register pro-democracy candidates for the election.

ESTONIA _ As in Latvia and Lithuania, the People's Front in the Baltic republic of Estonia demands independence from the Soviet Union. In local elections Dec. 10, non-Communists won about half the ballots. Estonians will elect a new Supreme Soviet on March 18.

GEORGIA _ Militant nationalists are demanding independence. At a pro-independence rally in April 1989, 19 people were killed in clashes with Soviet soldiers. Georgians vote for a new Supreme Soviet on June 17, and independence will be a key campaign issue. The region is also beset by disputes in which the Abkhazian and Ossetian minorities are demanding more autonomy from the republic's ethnic Georgian majority.

KAZAKHSTAN _ Ethnic problems have been simmering in this central Asian republic since December 1986, when residents rioted over the replacement of Communist Party chief Dinmukhamed Kunaev, a Kazakh, by a Russian, Gennady Kolbin. Voters go to the polls March 25 to elect a new Supreme Soviet.

KIRGIZIA _ In Supreme Soviet elections Feb. 25, voters failed to elect candidates in more than half the constituencies. A runoff election has been scheduled for early March. Kirgizian nationalists are demanding official status for their own language. Better food supplies and housing also are among activists' demands.

LATVIA _ The People's Front, in elections in December, garnered more than half the vote, signaling it will do well when a new legislature is elected March 18. Like other People's Fronts in the Baltics, it wants complete independence from the Soviet Union. Latvia in December became the second Baltic republic to abolish the Communist Party's constitutional monopoly on power. About 50 percent of the population is Russian, compared with much lower ratios in other Baltic states.

LITHUANIA _ Sajudis, the secessionist Lithuanian popular front movement, won 72 out of 90 parliamentary seats in the first round of multiparty voting Feb. 24, according to unofficial results. The remaining 51 seats will be contested in runoff elections March 10 and April 7. The Lithuanian Communist Party broke with the Kremlin in December and came out in favor of indepedence. A smaller group of Soviet loyalists formed their own Communist Party.

MOLDAVIA _ Moldavians had their first free elections Feb. 25 with the Moldavian Popular Front, an independent political movement, challenging the Communist Party. Official results are expected Thursday, and the Moldavian People's Front is expected to win about half the 380 seats in parliament. Moldavia has a common heritage with Romania and many ethnic Moldavias would like to be reunified. But, the Popular Front says reunification should be put on hold in favor of rebuilding the economy and restoring Moldavian culture.

RUSSIAN FEDERATION _ Political activists in the Russian Federation, the largest of the 15 republics, have formed a People's Front and similar organizations demanding basic reforms in the rule of the Communist Party, including direct popular vote of a president. Voters elect a new Supreme Soviet on March 4. Supporters of political maverick Boris Yeltsin are urging him to run for its presidency, but he has not announced his candidacy.

TADZHIKSTAN _ Elections were held Feb. 25, with runoff elections scheduled for March after candidates failed to gain a majority in more than half the constituencies. Clashes between Tadzhiks and Soviet soldiers sent to stop attacks on Armenians in the capital of Dushanbe in early February left 22 people dead. Tadzhiks demand that government provide more housing and food and not provide any accommodations for Armenian refugees.

TURKMENIA _ A high voter turnout Jan. 7 cost as many as one third of the Communist Party candidates their majorities. Several first secretaries of districts and regions are among those facing runoff elections in March.

UKRAINE _ A nascent nationalist movement is emerging in the Ukraine, the Soviet Union's second largest republic. Rukh, the organization of progressive nationalists, wants an independent Ukraine. But, unlike populist movements in the Baltics, Rukh does not have widespread support of the people. The Ukraine will elect a new Supreme Soviet on March 4.

UZBEKISTAN _ Voters in elections Feb. 18 complained that ballots did not have alternative candidates and independent groups boycotted the election. Many other voters crossed out the candidates' names, rendering the ballots invalid. Ethnic tensions run high with minority Meskhetian Turks, forcibly resettled from Georgia in the 1940s, demanding a homeland of their own. Many say overcrowding and lack of jobs have created an explosive situation.

DOC.HEAD: Hunt For Art `Loaned' to Communist Party
DOC.TEXT: The chroniclers of Communist abuses are amassing a list of valuable works of art from Polish museums loaned to party and government ministries but never returned. ``Thanks to those loans, many very valuable objects were lost. But things are changing,'' a television commentator said in a recent report. The Polish opposition has taken power without the virulence seen in other East bloc nations where Communist leaders have been tried and imprisoned. But the public fascination has been caught by a series of exposes of long-suspected abuses from the four decades when the Communist Party had total control of the government. The press has reported in detail the party's amassing of vast property holdings through dubious leases from obliging city officials. Now it has turned to the works of art provided to the Communist Party Central Committee and government ministries when refusing was not a viable option for museum directors. The prosecutor's office has been called in. And the Social Democracy of the Polish Republic, the newly formed party that took over the assets and liabilities of the Communist Party dissolved in January, has tried to demonstrate its new thinking with a promise to help locate the lost national property. ``The obligation is to figure out all those secrets that now have been made public, for example the vanishing of those paintings, and we want to take an active part,'' Marek Siwiec, editor of the party's newspaper, Trybuna, said in an interview. But he said those individuals responsible should be prosecuted, not the party. ``If a crime occurred, and everything indicates that a crime was committed, ... one chases particular persons responsible, and does not stigmatize an institution in which those persons worked,'' Siwiec said. The Social Democracy party might make ``moral compensation,'' however, in money or other works of art, he said. According to a report in the government daily Rzeczpospolita, ``the list of missing objects is thick.'' Ten paintings and two sculptures are missing from among 96 objects borrowed from the National Museum by the Central Committee. Among the lost canvases are the 1915 ``Still Life with Two Jugs'' by Tadeusz Makowski, borrowed in 1975, and the 1909 ``Head of a Peasant Girl'' by Teodor Azentowicz, loaned in 1950. ``The Pond'' by J.M Ronowski hung in the Central Committee headquarters for a decade and only recently was noticed to be missing, the newspaper said. Missing since the 1970s from the Council of Ministers are seven valuable 19th century German pottery statuettes, borrowed in 1949 for then-Premier Jozef Cyrankiewicz, Rzeczpospolita said. By November, only a third of the approximately 100 paintings and decorative objects loaned to the Culture Ministry had been returned, the daily reported. Marian Soltysiak, director of the National Museum, told Polish TV this week that one lost object has been found in the Central Committee headquarters and three more in the National Defense Ministry. ``And now I can see the breakthrough in our relations with the central institutions that were borrowing objects,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Two Children Killed in Witchcraft Clash
DOC.TEXT: Two infants were burned to death after an angry crowd set fire to their parent's home because they believed the couple was involved in witchcraft, police said Tuesday. Police in the tribal homeland of Venda near Zimbabwe said a 2-year-old boy and his 7-month-old brother died in the incident Monday night. Police said the crowd attacked and burned the house Monday night, and the parents were unable to rescue the sleeping children from the flames. ``The parents, who are alleged to have been practitioners of witchcraft, could not rescue their children in the menacing fire,'' the South African Press Association said. Fighting between people allegedly involved in withcraft and their opponents left 19 people dead this month in Venda, police said. Venda is one of four nominally independent homelands set up by South Africa for blacks.

DOC.HEAD: Prison Authorities Get Power to Administer Anti-Psychotic Drugs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 3 grafs after 8th graf, Stevens, writing, with Washington reaction; Picks up 9th graf pvs: Ruling in...
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today gave prison officials sweeping power to force inmates to take anti-psychotic drugs. The 6-3 ruling in a Washington state case is a victory for prison officials and doctors who say they, and not judges, should decide when such powerful, behavior-modifying drugs are administered. The justices said prisoners are not entitled to court hearings or other due-process safeguards before they must take the medication. ``Given the requirements of the prison environment,'' Justice Anthony M. Kennedy wrote for the court, the state may ``treat a prison inmate who has a serious mental illness with anti-psychotic drugs against his will if the inmate is dangerous to himself or others and the treatment is in the inmate's medical interest.'' The decision as to whether to use the drugs in such circumstances is best left to prison officials and psychiatrists, not judges, Kennedy said. Kennedy was joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Byron R. White, Harry A. Blackmun, Sandra Day O'Connor and Antonin Scalia. Justices John Paul Stevens, William J. Brennan and Thurgood Marshall dissented. Stevens, writing for the dissenters, said the court mistakenly ``has concluded that a mock trial before an institutionally biased tribunal constitutes due process of law. A competent individual's right to refuse psychotropic medication is an aspect of liberty requiring the highest order of (constitutional) protection.'' Washington Corrections Secretary Chase Riveland said the decision was an important one but doesn't mean his department will go on a medication binge. ``I'm not suggesting that we should be willy nilly running around medicating people. We need to be sure that people have appropriate input into the medication that they're taking,'' he said. ``There have been abuses historically in the country, not necessarily in prison only, but in general. I think that ...if medically appropriate it's very helpful,'' Riveland said. Ruling in a separate case today, however, the Supreme Court said that people held against their will at state mental hospitals without receiving legally required hearings may sue state officials in federal court for monetary damages. The justices voted 5-4 to reverse lower-court decisions involving a Florida man who was held in a state hospital for five months without a hearing that state law requires within 48 hours. And in another case, the Supreme Court decided 9-0 that the Boeing Co. did not violate a federal conflict-of-interest law when the defense contractor paid $485,000 in severance to five employees who left to take government jobs. The justices overturned a ruling that the money must be turned over to the government. In the inmate case, the high court overturned a Washington State Supreme Court ruling in 1988 that convicted robber Walter Harper, diagnosed as schizophrenic, must be given a court hearing before anti-psychotic drugs are administered to him. The state court also said prison officials must show a compelling state interest to give him the medication and show that the drugs will be effective. The state's compelling interest can be demonstrated by a need to preserve life, to protect others who might be harmed by Harper, to prevent his suicide and to maintain ``the ethical integrity of the medical profession,'' the state court said. Harper was imprisoned in 1976, and for most part over the next four years was in a mental health unit where he agreed to take anti-psychotic drugs. He was paroled in 1980 on condition he continue receiving psychiatric care. His parole was revoked after he attacked two nurses at Saint Cabrini Hospital in Seattle. Back in prison, Harper at first agreed to take anti-psychotic drugs. But in November 1982 he refused to take the medication any longer, complaining it was poisoning his brain and causing other side effects. A committee of prison officials decided he should be given the drugs against his will for his own good and to control his violent behavior. Harper sued. The state Supreme Court, calling the drugs as intrusive as electro-shock therapy, ruled that an inmate who has not been found mentally incompetent has a right to determine what should be done to his own body. While the drugs are beneficial to seriously ill patients, they also can have serious side effects ranging from involuntary spasms to permanent brain damage. Those who support the rights of mental patients and prisoners say there has been widespread abuse in prescribing anti-psychotic drugs. They have called for tighter control of doctors and public health officials. They also argue that inmates like Harper, if need be, can be restrained physically or placed in isolation rather than forced to take drugs continually. But public health and law enforcement officials say it makes little sense to give an irrational or mentally disturbed person the right to veto sensible medical practices. The U.S. Supreme Court previously had given mental health authorities and prison officials wide latitude in treating and controlling patients and inmates. While Harper's appeal was pending before the U.S. Supreme Court, a law was enacted in Washington state that requires judicial hearings for involuntary medication of mental patients except in some emergencies. The new state law does not cover prison inmates. Courts in several states have ruled that mental patients who are not legally incompetent have a right to refuse anti-psychotic drugs. But, according to some studies, judges in those states almost always end up deciding that anti-psychotic drugs may be administered against the individual's will after holding hearings in individual cases. Kennedy noted today that the court was told Harper no longer is refusing the medication. But Kennedy said because there is no evidence Harper has recovered from his mental illness, treatment against his will may have to be resumed in the future. Therefore, he said, the legal controversy posed by the case is still alive. The case acted on today is Washington vs. Harper, 88-599.

DOC.HEAD: French Reporter, Translator Ordered to Leave China
DOC.TEXT: A French television reporter and her translator were ordered to leave China after conducting interviews without permission in a sensitive minority region, an official report said Tuesday. Daniele Loustallot of the French television network Antenne 2 is the first foreign correspondent ordered to leave China under a new press law that took effect last month. It requires visiting reporters to obtain temporary accreditation from the government and limits them to approved interviews. Ms. Loustallot and her translator, Fabienne Goldberg, were working for the network's human rights program, ``Resistances,'' according to program spokesman Noel Mamere in Paris. He did not give details of their planned report. The People's Daily newspaper said the two arrived Feb. 13 in the Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region, a vast, mostly Moslem area in China's far northwest. They traveled on tourist visas. ``They conducted a series of illegal interviews and other activities not compatible with their tourist status,'' the paper said, without giving details. It said they ``ignored a warning by the Public Security Bureau and had a rude and unreasonable attitude.'' It did not say what deadline was set for the women to leave China. The French Embassy said they were still in the country Tuesday, but refused to give other details. Xinjiang is sparsely populated by various minority groups, including the Uygurs, who have clashed from time to time with Chinese security forces over religious and cultural differences. Local authorities generally have treated foreign reporters with suspicion, and last year police beat up two Beijing-based foreign correspondents who believed they had permission to visit. Foreign journalists in Beijing have come under tighter surveillance in recent weeks. However, Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen, in Geneva for a disarmament conference, said journalists ``have great freedom, I think that perhaps the freedom has been too extensive.''

DOC.HEAD: Colombian Journalist, Three Peasants Killed
DOC.TEXT: BOGOTA, Colombia _ Two unidentified men shot and killed a Colombian journalist and the three peasant farmers she was interviewing at a restaurant in northern Cimitarra, an official said today. Police were searching for the gunmen, who fled after slaying Silvia Duzan and three members of a local agricultural cooperative late Monday, said Mayor Salvador Pardo of the town, 75 miles north of Bogota. He identified the three peasant farmers as Josue Vargas, Miguel Barajas, and Saul Castaneda, and said they were directors of the Carare Agricultural Workers Association. Duzan, a free-lance journalist, was working on a story on right-wing death squads active in the area, according to the Caracol national radio network. It was not immediately clear who she was working for. Peasants have said the death squads were responsible for massacres of peasants and leftist leaders in the region. Four years ago, 36 peasants were found slain in the region. Half of them had been decapitated. Duzan was the sister of Maria Jimena Duzan, a columnist for Bogota's El Espectador newspaper who writes about drug traffickers and the right-wing death squads they finance in areas they own land. She is the 49th journalist to be assassinated in Colombia since 1977. Since last August, when the government intensified a crackdown on drug traffickers, 14 media employees have been killed. Authorities have said that many of the assassinations were contracted by traffickers.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Double Agent Describes Escape Under KGB Surveillance
DOC.TEXT: A KGB agent who worked for the British for 13 years says he escaped his country by pretending to go on his daily jog in Moscow and catching a train to the Finnish border. Oleg Gordievsky, who described his flight to the West in a BBC-TV interview broadcast Monday, also said some of the British spy scandals that have made headlines were baseless and damaging. ``It was a waste of time, waste of resources, waste of paper _ all those articles were published,'' the former spy said. ``There was great damage and the public morale and the trust to the intelligence security services in Western countries was impaired. It was a pity. It was totally unnecessary.'' Gordievsky said Sir Roger Hollis, who headed Britain's MI5 counterespionage service from 1956 to 1965, was not a Soviet agent. Writer Chapman Pincher and former MI5 officer Peter Wright, whose book ``Spycatcher'' the British government failed to suppress after lengthy court battles, have alleged the late Hollis was almost certainly a Soviet spy. Pincher, responding to Gordievsky's remarks, said the KGB restricted information about high-level double agents and that Gordievsky would have been too junior to have known. Gordievsky said he was in a position to know if the KGB had recruited high-level agents like Hollis. ``It was inconceivable really not to know if there had been such an important agent of KGB. If a person like him had been KGB agent, the people would have gossiped,'' Gordievsky said. ``There would have been some indication in the files; there were no signs of it at all.'' Gordievsky began to work for the British in Copenhagen in the early 1970s after becoming disillusioned with the Soviets, particularly after the 1968 invasion of Czechoslovakia. He was transferred to London where he became one of the top KGB agents in Britain. He first learned that the Soviets were suspicious of his activities in 1979 when a senior agent confronted him and six other KGB members about intelligence leaks, he said. ``And of course I knew that I was the source of leaks,'' Gordievsky said. ``It demanded from me a tremendous self-control and concentration not to reveal myself by body language, by a gesture.'' He said he was called to Moscow in 1985 under false pretenses and then questioned about his activities. He revealed nothing despite being drugged during interrogations, but knew he had to escape. ``I was very worried two or three days later when I started to recollect the whole content of the interrogation I realized that I was under strong suspicion and my life was in great danger.'' He would not speak of the contacts that enabled him to escape, but described how he stuffed his sweatsuit with identification papers and money, then set off on his daily jog past KGB surveillance. Gordievsky ran to the Moscow-Leningrad rail station where he got a train west to the Finnish border and defected. He would not say how he achieved the crossing. He said his only regret was that he had to leave his wife, Leila, and two daughters. ``I didn't betray the country, I didn't betray the people of the Soviet Union. ... I think I betrayed the regime and the Soviet Communist system which was illegitimate, wrong, and in many periods of the Soviet history, even criminal,'' he said. Gordievsky, wearing a tweed jacket and smoking a pipe, smiled easily and spoke quietly in slightly accented but very good English. ``I feel myself quite well integrated into British society. In many aspects I am like a normal British citizen with similar habits and customs. For example the greatest Sunday pleasure is to spend the morning reading Sunday newspapers, sometimes in bed. ``And even, I never could have expected it from me, myself, but I have developed an interest for gardening,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Two Dead, One Critically Wounded in Missoula Restaurant Shootings
DOC.TEXT: A man shot and killed one person and critically wounded another in a downtown restaurant early this morning and was himself shot to death by police, authorities said. It happened shortly after 4 a.m. at the 4B's Restaurant in this west-central Montana town of 35,000, police said. ``Some kind of an argument started, we don't know what about,'' said Police Chief Don Millhouse said. ``Shortly thereafter he produced a weapon and fired at employees and patrons.'' The man was confronted by officers after he left the restaurant and was shot when he pointed his gun at the officers and refused orders to drop it, Millhouse said. Paul Richards, a Boulder resident staying overnight about half a block from the restaurant, was awakened by the commotion. ``The first thing I heard was the police yelling, `Freeze!'' Richards said. ``There was some type of guttural response ... then pop, pop, real quick shots.'' Richards said he quickly dressed and went out to see what was happening. ``I saw them loading one wounded (person) into an ambulance, and the guy was dead out there in the street,'' Richards said. ``There was a pistol near the dead person's body.'' The wounded person was taken to St. Patrick Hospital in Missoula and was in critical condition, Millhouse said. The police chief said that the names of those involved would not be released until after relatives were notified.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: Some American students hope they'll make the right moves during a trip to the Soviet Union next month. Ten students from Petal Middle School, ages 11 to 13, will participate in a special checkers tournament during the International Peace Conference. The trip is the idea of Charles Walker, founder and director of the International Checkers Hall of Fame in Petal, a small town near Hattiesburg. During their two-week trip, the students also will attend the Pioneer Palace school for the gifted in Moscow. The wife of the director of the Russian Draughts Association teaches at the Pioneer Palace school, which sponsors the annual Peace Conference. This is how the union of peace was born between checkers _ the American version of the British game of Draughts _ and the Russian version of Draughts, said Carolyn Lucas, secretary of the International Checkers Hall of Fame. While at Pioneer Palace, students will compose a peace book of essays, poems and drawings and put handprints in a cement memorial, Lucas said. Teacher Debra Herrin has been preparing her students during and after school. In addition to honing their checkers-playing skills, Herrin said, the students are learning Russian phrases such as ``hello, goodbye, where's the bathroom _ the things you really need.''

Who will speak for the purple loosestrife? Nobody in his right mind, one weed expert said Monday after the state Senate approved a legislation to kill the bushy garden flower with herbicides and ban its sale or use. The bill now goes to the House. ``It's a nightmare spreading across Washington,'' Rick Johnson said of the European weed, which is choking wetlands across the northern United States. Johnson is Thurston County's noxious-weed control coordinator Each stalk of the pesky plant contains maybe a million seeds, 800,000 of which are viable. The bill provides $1 million to eradicate purple loosestrife. Other states have banned or placed restrictions on its sale. State Rep. Marlin Appelwick said he had some concerns about the portion of the bill that would make it illegal to sell or use purple loosestrife plants or seeds. Violators could be fined $100, and that includes backyard gardeners, Senate staffers said. ``We'll probably do more for the underground purple loosestrife market than anything,'' Appelwick said, imagining basements crammed with grow lights and rows of purple plants.

DOC.HEAD: Election Violence Leaves 62 Dead, 250 Injured
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE figures; Pickup 14th, `The elections...'
DOC.TEXT: Indians voted in balloting for eight state legislatures today, and at least 62 people were killed in election day violence despite unprecedented security, news agencies reported. The dead included an independent candidate who was shot in eastern Bihar state, United News of India said. The elections were considered important for the governing National Front, the Congress Party of former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, and Hindu fundamentalists. In Bihar, notorious for organized criminal gangs that operate during elections, at least 60 people were killed, including the independent candidate shot by unidentified gunmen in Biharsharif, United News said. The election in that town was expected to be invalidated. Two people were killed in the western state of Gujarat, Press Trust of India said, but no details were immediately available. At least 250 people were injured in the eight states, police said. About 150 million of the 213 million eligible voters cast ballots in elections today for 1,610 members of the eight legislatures, all of which were controlled by Gandhi's Congress Party. First results were not expected until late Wednesday. Authorities deployed more than 45,000 federal troops to oversee the elections. Before today, campaign violence had claimed at least 13 lives in the eight states, 11 of them in Bihar. The New Delhi-based Hindustan Times newspaper said the elections were held under ``what is regarded as the tightest-ever security ever in view of the increasing incidence of poll violence and booth capturing.'' The term ``booth capturing'' covers an array of fraud ranging from stuffing the ballot boxes to intimidation. The Election Commission said police have been given shoot-on-sight orders in an effort to control vote fraud. Today, in Bihar's Bahadur village, police shot and killed three people when they opened fire to stop the stuffing of ballot boxes, United News said. Elsewhere in the state, 57 poeple were killed in bomb blasts and clashes, the news agency said. The elections are considered a test of the Congress Party's waning popularity and the rising voter appeal of the Indian People's Party. The People's Party, a right-wing Hindu fundamentalist group, registered massive gains in November's national election when it won 88 seats, compared with two in the 1984 polls. Prime Minister V.P. Singh's National Front, which ousted Gandhi's Congress Party, won 141 seats in the national election but formed the government only after the Indian People's Party extended its support. Gandhi's party won 193 seats. The policy-making lower house of the parliament has 544 seats. Today's elections were to decide which party, or coalition, will govern the states of Bihar, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Rajasthan, Gujarat, Orissa, Himachal Pradesh, Arunachal Pradesh and the federally adminstered territory of Pondicherry for five years. India has 25 states. There were 21,265 candidates vying for 1,611 seats in the states. The election was crucial for the Indian People's Party. Analysts have linked the party's showing in the last national election to the revival of Hindu fundamentalism. About 82 percent of India's 880 million people are Hindus, but they traditionally have voted for the Congress Party.

DOC.HEAD: Israel, Poland Resume Diplomatic Relations
DOC.TEXT: Israel and Poland resumed full diplomatic relations after a 23-year break Tuesday, the third Warsaw Pact country to renew relations with the Jewish state in the past six months. Poland ended relations in 1967 to support the Arab side in the Middle East War. Hungary restored relations in September and Czechoslovakia followed suit Feb. 9. Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki looked on as Israeli Foreign Minister Moshe Arens and Polish Foreign Minister Krzysztof Skubiszewski signed the protocal at a government palace, and the delegations sipped champagne to celebrate the long-awaited event. Poland has had low-level ties with Israel since 1987 and the new Solidarity-led government is hoping that the restoration of a formal embassy will lead to closer economic and cultural cooperation. ``We are today opening a new chapter in the long history, full of tragedies, of the Jewish people of Poland,'' Arens told Israel Army Radio. ``I hope for good and close relations between Israel and Poland.'' Speaking to reporters after the ceremony, Arens stressed that Israel also hopes for Polish support for Israeli positions in the Middle East peace process. He later told Israel Army Radio he found ``great understanding'' for Israel's problems among Poland's leaders. ``It seems even a greater and fuller understanding than we have found in Western Europe,'' he added. Poland has said resuming relations with Israel should not disturb its relations with Arab countries. Poland continues to endorse Palestinian rights to self-determination, and Skubiszewski held a January meeting with Arab diplomats to assure continued support. Nevertheless, state radio in Libya said it had ``deep regret'' over the resumption of relations. The Polish ambassador to Tripoli was summoned to the Libyan Foreign Ministry and told that the action would harm Libyan-Polish relations and Arab-Polish relations generally, the Libyan radio report said. Arens, in the radio interview, said he had invited Polish President Wojciech Jaruzelski to Israel. The invitation was accepted but no date was set, he said. Skubiszewski also said he, too, had accepted an invitation to Israel. Arens said he expected resuming diplomatic ties will lead to ``very extensive economic relations'' between Israel and Poland, as well as closer people-to-people links. ``There is no doubt in my mind that it will bring about a widening, a deepening and a strengthening of the relationship between the Polish people and the Jewish people in Poland and Israel,'' Arens said. He referred to the small community of about 10,000 Jews remaining in Poland after the Holocaust and massive postwar emigration of Polish Jews, mainly to Israel and the United States. On Monday, Arens went on emotional visits to memorials to Poland's once vibrant Jewish community, which numbered 3.5 million before World War II. He paid homage at the monument to the Warsaw Ghetto uprising of 1943, when Jews, held in a walled-in section of the city to face starvation or deportation, rose up against the Nazi occupiers. Arens stood in silence at the monument at Umschlagplatz, the depot where 300,000 Warsaw Jews were loaded on trains to the Nazi concentration camps. On Tuesday, Arens also discussed economic issues with Polish Finance Minister Leszek Balcerowicz, met with Mazowiecki and had a session scheduled with Jaruzelski, who was Communist Party leader when the then-Communist government initiated contacts with Israel. Arens commended Poland's leadership in the democratization of the East bloc during a Monday dinner toast and said there was a clear relationship with the readiness to improve ties with Israel. ``It is remembered in Israel that Poland was the first country in the Soviet bloc to start the process of improving relations with Israel. It took great courage,'' he said. Between 350,000 to 500,000 Israelis were born in Poland, including the first Israeli prime minister, David Ben Gurion, and the present one, Yitzhak Shamir.

DOC.HEAD: Embarrassed N.C. Officials Scrap Test That Tells It Like It Used To Be
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `The Charlotte...', to fix grammar. SUBS last graf to recast.
DOC.TEXT: State education officials hastily decided today to scrap questions about Eastern Europe on a sixth-grade social studies test instead of asking pupils to pretend the Cold War is still raging. The questions will ``be replaced as quickly as possible and we will send a new instructions to the teachers,'' said Glenn Keever, spokesman for the Department of Public Instruction. He said top officials in the department had been unaware of what the test administrators had done. ``We will have two other questions that will be drawn from another test that are current in terms of present conditions in eastern Europe,'' Keever said. The Charlotte Observer reported this morning that instead of rewriting the 3-year-old standardized tests, the state education department was instructing teachers to tell pupils to answer the questions as if Eastern Europe hadn't changed since 1987. ``It is a perfect illustration of the frailty of relying on standardized multiple-choice tests,'' said John Dornan, executive director of Public School Forum, a non-profit education think tank in Raleigh. ``For the teacher who's really passionate about teaching current events, this is really a disincentive, and that's tragic.'' About 80,000 sixth-graders will take the 60-question State Social Studies Test, used to rank and accredit schools, in March and April. Third- and eighth-graders take different versions _ which don't happen to contain any questions about Eastern Europe. The sixth-grade version developed three years ago has two such questions, officials said. The two old questions were: _ ``In an election, for which candidates are citizens of the Soviet Union expected to vote? A: Candidates of their choice, B: Only male candidates over 35 years of age, C: Candidates selected by the Communist Party, D: Candidates who have opposed the Communist Party.'' _ ``Which of these countries has a democratic government? A: Albania, B: Cuba, C: United States, D: Poland.'' Before the revolutionary changes started sweeping Eastern Europe, ``C'' would be the best choice for both questions. It's a little more complicated now. The Charlotte Observer reported that the state Department of Public Instruction had told teachers to instruct their sixth-graders: ``Do not think about or consider the recent governmental changes that have occurred in the last few months when you choose your answers for the questions about Eastern Europe. Think about how Eastern Europe was in 1987.'' Those words are taken from the written instructions sent to sixth-grade teachers to read to the pupils. The instructions were dated January 1990. Keever said the scrapping of the questions was ordered by Roger Jackson, deputy state school superintendent. State Superintendent of Public Instruction Bobby Etheridge and other top officials didn't know about the incorrect questions until today when they were reported in the newspaper, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Magazine Publishes Copies of Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact
DOC.TEXT: The Foreign Ministry has admitted it has found copies of the secret protocol of the 1939 Soviet-Nazi pact that allotted the three independent Baltic nations and part of Poland to the Soviet Union. Vestnik, a new Soviet magazine published by the Foreign Ministry, showed photographs in its premier edition that came out on Monday of a typewritten Russian-language copy of the ``Secret Additional Protocol.'' The Soviet Union has maintained it could not find any evidence of the protocols in its archives and still says it does not have the originals. Last summer, Soviet publications printed German-language copies of the protocols kept in the archives of the West German Foreign Ministry. Also last summer, Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev supported the creation of a commission to investigate claims there was such a protocol. He said at the time that no documents had been found to confirm the existence of the protocol. The protocol was signed by Stalin's foreign minister, Vyacheslav Molotov, and Hitler's top diplomat, Joachim von Ribbentrop on Aug. 23, 1939, a week before the outbreak of World War II. The document placed the independent countries of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania and parts of eastern Poland in the Soviet sphere of influence and was the basis of Stalin's decision later to annex that territory to the Soviet Union. The Baltic republics succeeded in winning Soviet government recognition of the existence of the protocols last year. The magazine also published a statement by one of Molotov's aides confirming the original had been handed over to another aide _ another confirmation of the existence of the originals. Vestnik, a joint venture between the Soviet Union and Austria, is edited in Moscow and printed in Vienna and costs $75 a year for the monthly publication.

DOC.HEAD: Profiles of Top Cabinet Ministers
With AM-Japan
DOC.TEXT: Profiles of the top Cabinet ministers named by Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu after his re-election Tuesday:

Finance Minister _ Ryutaro Hashimoto, 52, served as secretary-general of the governing Liberal Democratic Party during the tenure of Kaifu's predecessor, Sousuke Uno. This month, Hashimoto was elected to his 10th term as a member of the lower house of Parliament. A member of the intraparty faction led by former Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita, Hashimoto also has served as health and welfare minister and transport minister.

Foreign Minister _ Taro Nakayama, 66, a member of the faction headed by former Foreign Minister Shintaro Abe, also is being retained in the Cabinet position he received when Kaifu first assumed office in August. Nakayama has served one term in the upper house and was re-elected to his fourth term in the lower house. His only previous Cabinet post was as director-general of the Management and Coordination Agency. He was a physician before entering politics.

Chief Cabinet Secretary _ Misoji Sakamoto, 67, an eight-term member of the lower house, replaces Mayumi Moriyama, the first woman ever to hold this post. Sakamoto, like Ms. Moriyama, is a member of the same faction as Kaifu. He is a former labor minister and deputy secretary-general of the party.

International Trade and Industry Minister _ Kabun Muto, 63, a former agriculture minister, vice secretary general of the Liberal Democratic Party and deputy chairman of the party's Tax Research Council, Muto has been elected to the lower house nine times. He comes from the faction of former Finance Minister Michio Watanabe.

Defense Agency Director General _ Yozo Ishikawa, 64, former vice minister of foreign affairs and vice director general of the Environment Agency, is serving in his first Cabinet post. He has been elected to the lower house six times and is a member of the faction of former Finance Minister and Deputy Premier Kiichi Miyazawa.

DOC.HEAD: Rostenkowski Says No Way to Increase Revenues as Bush Asks
DOC.TEXT: The House's chief tax writer said Tuesday he sees ``absolutely no way'' to increase tax collections next year by the $13.9 billion President Bush is proposing. The remarks by Ways and Means Committee Chairman Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., further dimmed the prospects that Congress and the Bush administration will quickly forge a deficit-reduction plan for fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1. Meanwhile, Rostenkowski's panel voted to urge the Budget Committee to take the surpluses of the Social Security trust fund out of budget deficit calculations, a move that would greatly worsen the federal deficit problem on paper. As part of his plan to find $37.5 billion in deficit reductions next year, Bush last month proposed increasing tax receipts by $13.9 billion. The administration estimates that cutting the capital gains tax would increase revenue by $4.9 billion, with the rest coming from greater Internal Revenue Service efficiency and increases in several minor taxes. Democratic leaders of the House and Senate budget committees have said they oppose the ingredients of Bush's plan, especially the rate cut on capital gains taxes, which they say would mainly benefit the wealthy. They have said they might try to produce a budget of their own containing the same amount of new revenue _ $13.9 billion _ but with a different mix. But Rostenkowski told his panel such a tack would prove unworkable. ``I see absolutely no way we can raise $14 billion, and that's the direction the Budget Committee is taking us,'' he said. The Illinois Democrat said that if his committee is told to find $14 billion in new taxes, ``We're just not that good a magician, unless we become very serious about reaching out for revenues that are certainly going to be ducks.'' The word ``ducks'' was a reference to White House budget director Richard Darman's statement last year that Bush's pledge of ``no new taxes'' applies to any levies the public would perceive as taxes. He used the expression that if something walks and talks like a duck, it's a duck. Bush has repeatedly promised to veto increases in such taxes. Congress' Democratic leaders have said that, therefore, they will propose no tax increases that will provoke a veto and leave their party as the sole advocate of higher taxes. The Ways and Means panel voted Tuesday by voice, against Rostenkowski, to ask that Social Security trust fund surpluses be removed from deficit calculations. Supporters of the proposal, sponsored by Rep. Byron Dorgan, D-N.D., said the surpluses make the federal deficit appear smaller. The public thus feels less urgency to address the problem, they said. It was the first congressional vote of the year on the issue, which has been a focus of attention on Capitol Hill since Sen. Daniel Moynihan, D-N.Y., proposed cutting the Social Security payroll tax. Opponents _ mainly Republicans _ said Dorgan's plan would force Congress to find tens of billions of dollars in extra savings each year to meet the declining annual deficit targets of the Gramm-Rudman law. Rostenkowski said he might eventually support Dorgan's proposal. But he opposed it Tuesday, saying he first wanted to discuss the matter with the budget panel. The Social Security trust fund will have a surplus next year of $74 billion, the Congressional Budget Office estimates. Counting that infusion of money, the White House projects the 1991 deficit at $101 billion, not including the savings Bush has proposed.

DOC.HEAD: Dan Rather Still in Third
With AM-Nielsens
DOC.TEXT: The winning streak of Peter Jennings' ``World News Tonight'' continued Tuesday, as the ABC program won its seventh straight week in the ratings, averaging an 11.3 rating last week. Dan Rather's slumping ``CBS Evening News'' was third with a 9.9 ratings average. His broadcast has been third in ratings for five of the last six weeks. Tom Brokaw's ``NBC Nightly News'' was second with a 10.1 rating. Each ratings point represents 921,000, according to the A.C. Nielsen Co.

DOC.HEAD: East German Party Supported by Kohl Seeks Delay in Elections
DOC.TEXT: A small party backed by West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl said Tuesday the East German elections should be postponed because voting rules were not available in time to permit fair competition. The German Social Union told the Supreme Court its chances and those of other small parties were hurt because national newspapers did not publish procedures for the March 18 ballot, the first free election in East Germany's 40-year history. Parliament approved the regulations a week ago in the form of a lengthy voting law, which was printed and made available at bookstores Friday. It set Monday as the deadline for parties to notify the national election committee if they planned to run candidates. Representatives of the German Social Union, known as the DSU by its German initials, got a copy of the law from the election committee Friday and were able to register before the deadline. Its complaint to the court said newly formed parties had too little chance to prepare candidate lists for the 400 Parliament seats, which must be given to the committee by Wednesday, and asked that the vote be delayed at least until early May. Elections originally were scheduled for May 6, but the German Social Union and other parties pressed the Communist-led interim government to move the date up, partly from fear the economy would collapse before May. Some larger parties, including the Communists, have political networks with offices, telephones, vehicles and other advantages not available to new groups that have sprung up since the pro-democracy movement began last fall. Even so, the clear leader is the Social Democratic Party, founded less than five months ago and supported by the sister party that is West Germany's main opposition. Polls of East German voters predict the Social Democrats will get at least 50 percent of the vote March 18. Kohl's Christian Democratic Union supports the German Social Union, East German Christian Democratic Union and Democratic Awakening, which are joined in a conservative alliance. Thousands of East Germans cheered Kohl at a rally last week in Erfurt, but it was no match for the emotional welcome given former Chancellor Willy Brandt at a weekend rally of Social Democrats in Leipzig. Putting off the election would give the smaller parties a fairer chance, said Joachim Novak, deputy chairman of the German Social Union. ``We have argued from the beginning that it is unfair for the new parties to have to compete against organized forces so soon,'' he said. ``As a minimum, the regulations should have been published in the newspapers. Failure to distribute the procedural information broadly is clearly a violation of the constitution.'' East German newspapers remain technically under government control, although they have undergone great changes since the hard-line leadership of Erich Honecker was ousted in October. None published the text of the election law. Many government offices and enterprises have virtually halted operations until the elections allow plans for economic rescue and German reunification to proceed. West Germany has offered to make its Deutschmark the official currency of both Germanys, but only after a democratically elected government is in power and laws are rewritten to foster conversion to a free-market economy.

DOC.HEAD: Suspended HUD Landlord Renews Attack on Kemp, Agency
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 10 grafs new with subcommittee planning additional Rozet appearance, Gonzalez comments; picks up at pvs 7th graf, Most of
DOC.TEXT: The suspended landlord of nearly 350 federally subsidized housing projects told a congressional panel today that he tried repeatedly to improve conditions at problem developments but was denied help by government officials. ``HUD's administration and oversight of inner-city problem housing has been abysmal and verges on the criminal,'' said A. Bruce Rozet, who was recently suspended from any new Department of Housing and Urban Development work because of questions about past management of a handful of projects. ``They have condemned tenants to live in squalor while pleading the poverty of the government and trying to shift the blame,'' Rozet said, accusing HUD of trying to shift the blame for faulty housing programs. ``They have raised the hopes of poor inner-city residents with rhetoric and promises of action and then dashed their hopes on the anvil of purported reform and miserly budgets.'' Rozet is locked in a bitter battle with HUD and Secretary Jack Kemp, who last month suspended Rozet's Associated Financial Corp., or AFC, and a web of affiliates from any new department contracts. Several Kemp aides were on hand for the hearing by the House Banking subcommittee on housing, and on occasion scribbled questions on note paper and shuttled them to Republican lawmakers. Subcommittee mmbers had dozens of questions about the suspension and the condition of the nearly 45,000 units at developments owned or partly controlled by the California-based companies. The panel said it planned to call Rozet back after hearing from HUD officials and tenants of some AFC-related properties. The subcommittee's chairman, Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, said it was clear that inconsistent policies at HUD and high turnover had at least contributed to problems plaguing developments controlled by private groups such as Rozet's. He said he wanted to call HUD officials to see to what extent the agency's ``hands were dirtied,'' but then added to Rozet: ``I'm not too sure about yours.'' Rozet said he welcomed the review. He predicted the panel would agree with his contention that HUD should shoulder most of the blame for poor conditions, a position he supported by referring to several cases in which he said HUD had ignored or rejected renovation plans his company or affiliates presented. Most of those cases were before Kemp took office last year. Rozet, a prominent Democratic fund-raiser, said his company perhaps would have fared better had he hired Republican consultants _ a reference to past congressional testimony of rampant influence-peddling at HUD during the tenure of Kemp's predecessor, Samuel R. Pierce Jr. But Rozet also intensified his attacks on Kemp, saying that HUD has done nothing under his leadership to improve housing. HUD issued the suspension after alleging that AFC's management affiliate, Housing Resources Management, misused government and tenant funds at developments in Oklahoma and the District of Columbia. A HUD memo indicated the department's inspector general is working with the FBI to investigate whether the company overbilled for rent subsidies in Oklahoma. Kemp, in answer to earlier Rozet criticisms, has defended the suspension and denied Rozet's contention it was politically motivated. Rozet, in an interview earlier this month, said the company had ample evidence to refute the allegations but had been denied a HUD hearing. Because of the suspension, Rozet said AFC and its affiliates were seeking to relinquish control over most of the nearly 350 properties they manage in 40 states and Puerto Rico. In his statement today before the Banking Committee's housing subcommittee, Rozet said only a small number of AFC's properties are troubled and that most were acquired in late 1986 after HUD promised to help revitalize the developments. But HUD has reneged, he said. ``The one thing HUD cannot do _ and Congress cannot let them do _ is to make no decision and turn their back on the problem,'' Rozet said, accusing Kemp's HUD of ignoring provisions of federal housing law that require the agency to try to help troubled housing developments. He said a legislative package passed last year at Kemp's request gave the secretary new powers to penalize housing owners the department blames for poor conditions. ``Has HUD obtained the legal right to stab the owner in the back and then fine him for bleeding on the carpet?'' Rozet asked.

DOC.HEAD: Senate, White House Pushing Toward Agreement on Clean-Air Bill
DOC.TEXT: Senate and White House negotiators moved closer Tuesday to agreement on how to reduce smog-causing automobile emissions, sources said, as private talks resumed on a compromise clean-air bill. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell reiterated that he intends to bring the bill to a floor test on Thursday even if a compromise package is not reached with the Bush administration. Disagreements over pollution controls on automobiles, especially toughened tailpipe controls, have been a focus of much of the private discussions between key senators and senior administration officials over the last three weeks. A daylong round of closed-door negotiations that lasted well into the early hours of Tuesday produced tentative agreements on a number of areas, including increased pollution controls on toxic and smog-causing industrial emissions and on an alternative fuels program. At the same time, the negotiators agreed to jettison a proposal sought by environmentalists that would have required automakers to sharply increase their cars' fuel economy, according to sources close to the talks. The provision, aimed at concerns about global warming, would have required controls on carbon dioxide emissions from cars. Automakers had lobbied vigorously against it. At the same time, differences were narrowed on how to cut smog-causing pollutants from automobiles, including agreement for the first time by White House negotiators on conditions for imposing a second round of nationwide tailpipe emission controls, according to the sources, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. The sources emphasized that details remained to be worked out on when such toughened controls would kick in nationwide. President Bush has insisted that the tightened automobile pollution controls, a key element in the Senate bill to curb urban smog, were too expensive. Automakers have argued the new standards could not be met with current technology. The negotiators met past midnight Monday and resumed the talks Tuesday, focusing first on acid rain controls and then again on the automobile emissions questions. Mitchell began the talks with the administration Feb. 2 in an effort to enlist White House support for a compromise bill. He acknowledged that the tougher legislation approved by the Senate Environment and Pubilc Works Committee last November had encountered strong regional opposition and was sure to face a filibuster on the Senate floor. The legislation would be the first revision of the federal clean air law in 13 years. Senate leaders and the administration were generally in agreement over the acid rain provisions of the bill, which call for coal-burning electric utilities to reduce sulfur dioxide emissions by 10 million tons a year. But those acid rain controls have been opposed by a group of Midwest senators who seek a cost-sharing provision to help pay for installing expensive pollution controls at some of the dirtiest utility plants. At the same time, other senators from states where plants are relatively clean have opposed any such cost sharing and sought assurances instead that the controls will not hinder future growth. While both the White House and Mitchell are opposed to any national energy tax or fee to help pay for the pollution controls, the negotiations on acid rain have centered on trying to accommodate the various regional concerns, sources said.

DOC.HEAD: Toddler Dies After Head is Caught in Toy Box
DOC.TEXT: A 14-month-old boy whose head was trapped in a toy box died despite resuscitation efforts by his mother and a mailman. ``I heard her scream and saw the mother running across two lawns carrying the baby in her arms,'' mailman Ernest Wilkes said after Monday's accident that killed Seth Everett. ``She was screaming, `Help me! My baby is dead!''' Carol Everett had just extricated her son from a footlocker that served as a toy box, where the child had been playing with his 3-year-old brother. Wilkes carried the toddler into the house and placed him on a table, where first he and then the mother administered cardiopulmonary resuscitation to try to get him to breath. ``I never saw a bit of life in the child,'' said Wilkes. ``I wish I could have done something.'' A firefighter responding to a 911 call also failed to revive the boy. Police Lt. Dave Andrews said the lid apparently came down on the boy's head, trapping the child between the lid and the box.

DOC.HEAD: Actor Richard Widmark Gets Achievement Award
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 15th graf, `Documentary: Roger...', to correct `and' in movie title to an ampersand.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY5
DOC.TEXT: Richard Widmark, one of Hollywood's most durable stars, received the D.W. Griffith Career Achievement Award for his 40 years in films. The 75-year-old Widmark was presented the award at a ceremony Monday night from Sidney Poitier, who appeared with him in the 1952 movie, ``No Way Out.'' The award was given by the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures. Widmark got his start in radio in the 1940s in New York, then appeared in several Broadway plays. His screen debut in the 1947 thriller ``Kiss of Death'' is still considered his most famous role. He received an Oscar nomination for that role _ a psychopathic killer with a chilling laugh who pushed an old woman in a wheelchair down a flight of stairs. Some of his other films include ``Street with No Name,'' ``Panic in the Streets,'' ``Halls of Montezuma,'' ``The Cobweb,'' ``The Law and Jake Wade,'' ``Judgment at Nuremberg,'' ``How the West Was Won,'' ``Death of a Gunfighter,'' ``Coma'' and ``The Swarm.'' He starred in the television series ``Madigan.'' Other National Board of Review winners, announced in December, were: _ Best movie: ``Driving Miss Daisy.'' _ Best actor: Morgan Freeman, ``Driving Miss Daisy.'' _ Best actress: Michelle Pfeiffer, ``The Fabulous Baker Boys.'' _ Supporting actor: Alan Alda, ``Crimes and Misdemeanors.'' _ Supporting actress: Mary Stuart Masterson, ``Immediate Family.'' _ Director: Kenneth Branagh, ``Henry V.'' _ Foreign film: ``Story of Women.'' _ Documentary: ``Roger & Me.'' _ Made for television movie: ``Roe vs. Wade.'' _ Miniseries: ``Lonesome Dove.''

DOC.HEAD: Koop Says National AIDS Policy `Years Overdue'
DOC.TEXT: Former Surgeon General C. Everett Koop said Tuesday that a federal AIDS policy is ``almost 10 years overdue.'' Koop also told a House Energy and Commerce subcommittee that he was alarmed at a growing ``complacency about the AIDS epidemic,'' which he said is overburdening big-city hospitals while spreading to rural areas. Rep. Henry A. Waxman, D-Calif., chairman of the House health and environment subcommittee before which Koop testified, said President Bush has yet to act on groundwork laid when Koop was surgeon general under President Reagan. ``Having missed the opportunity to get the ounce of prevention, we now have to pay for the pounds and pounds of cure,'' said Waxman, who was hearing testimony on his proposed legislation to expand Medicaid coverage for people with AIDS or infected with the HIV virus believed to cause the disease. Although Koop didn't speak as sharply as Waxman, he repeatedly stated his disappointment with both Congress and the White House. ``There are ample opportunities'' for the White House and Congress to develop an AIDS policy, Koop said. ``I think it's almost 10 years overdue.'' ``My concerns this morning have yet to be addressed at a national level,'' said Koop. He said later, ``It seems incredible that the federal government has not had a dialogue'' with state and local governments and insurers. ``I also am disappointed to sense the amount of complacency about the AIDS epidemic,'' he said, adding that official government figures are probably underreported. Under Waxman's legislation, Medicaid coverage would include early intervention with drugs such as AZT and aerosol pentamidine. Those drugs are expensive _ $3,500 a year for AZT or $1,100 for pentamidine, according to Waxman's staff, but the cost of hospitalization is even higher _ $15,000 per admission. The bill would create a presumption of disability for people who have the virus but who may not have developed the symptoms, making it easier for them to qualify for the early intervention. Other provisions deal with reimbursements for care of people already sick, including babies and children with AIDS. Koop said the complacency is due to three mistaken beliefs: _That the leveled-off projections for new cases _ 40,000 this year as opposed to 35,000 recorded cases last year _ mean a shrinking epidemic. _That because the spread is confined to black and Hispanic drug users, the general population is less likely to be threatened. _That many believe the disease is not spread through heterosexual contact. Koop said the epidemic is having its most serious impact on big-city hospitals where more and more beds _ as many as 25 percent in New York _ are occupied by AIDS victims. As a result, patients with other ailments wait too long for beds to become available, medical and nursing students work elsewhere because of fear of contagion and a lack of variety in the types of patients, and budgets are drained because AIDS patients usually have already exhausted their funds by the time they reach the hospitsl, according to testimony.

DOC.HEAD: Just Over Half on Poll Respondents Back Bush Approach in Drug War
DOC.TEXT: Just over half the respondents in a new survey say they feel the Bush administration's law-enforcement approach to the war on illegal drugs will reduce the country's drug problem. At the same time, slightly more than one-third say they favor legalization for less serious drugs and an increase in drug treatment and education programs. National drug control policy director William J. Bennett, who has called legalization advocacy ``stupid and morally atrocious,'' dismissed the survey, saying some progress has been made in the war on drugs. ``Now that we're starting to see some encouraging signs, why put up the white flag?'' he rhetorically asked reporters at the White House. The telephone poll of 1,401 adult Americans was done Jan. 24-Feb. 4 by Targeting Systems Inc. of Arlington, Va., for the Drug Policy Foundation, which says it advocates treating drug abuse as a health problem, not a criminal justice issue. The survey has a margin of error of 3 percentage points. Richard J. Dennis of Chicago, chairman of the foundation's Advisory Board, paid for the survey. Among the poll's findings: _55 percent of the respondents said they believe the administration's primarily law enforcement approach to the war on drugs _ including more prison sentences for casual drug use, using the military to fight drug trafficking and more money for prisons _ is likely to reduce the drug problem. _36 percent favor legalization of less serious drugs along with an increase in drug treatment and education aid. _Asked if it was more important to take ``any step necessary'' in order to stop drug use than to protect civil liberties, 71 percent chose taking ``any step necessary.'' _Fewer than 2 percent said they might try cocaine if it were legalized, but 60 percent say they think cocaine use would go up if it were no longer a crime. Ten percent said cocaine use would decrease if it were legalized and 27 percent said it would stay the same. _9.6 percent said they might try marijuana if it were legalized, while 50 percent said marijuana use would increase if it were not a crime. Twelve percent said it would decrease and 37 percent said it would stay the same. _Given the choice between providing treatment and counseling for drug users or punishing them with fines and imprisonment, 68 percent favored treatment and 21 percent favored punishment. _61 percent said all drug use is immoral and should be illegal, while 35 percent disagreed with that view. _As for medical uses of some prohibited drugs, 76 percent said doctors should be allowed to prescribe heroin as a painkiller for terminally ill cancer patients, while 69 percent said physicians should be allowed to prescribe marijuana as a treatment for glaucoma.

DOC.HEAD: Nearly Everybody Guessed Wrong about Nicaragua
An AP News Analysis
With AM-US-Nicaragua Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Conventional wisdom took almost as bad a beating in Nicaragua as President Daniel Ortega. One of the most profoundly held views of the Reagan administration, for example, was that Ortega could never be counted on to hold a free and fair election. The perception of Ortega as an anti-democrat guided every policy decision concerning Nicaragua that the administration took. The notion that Ortega would hold a fair election and agree to turn over power if he lost was laughable, a tall tale belonging on the fiction shelf. Several years ago, one official who had the audacity to suggest that Ortega was a moderate in the Sandinista political context was looked on almost as a subversive by administration hardliners. He was banished to appen after a Sandinista victory, giving the alternative possibility short shrift. Their views, of course, were fed by the pollsters, who were predicting a Sandinista victory in excess of 15 percentage points. It is now obvious that a significant number of Nicaraguans gave the ``safe'' answer to the pollsters _ that they were pro-Sandinista. In the privacy of the voting booth, they abandoned Ortega. One of the few who was not taken in by the pollsters was the chief U.S. diplomat in Managua, Jack Leonard, who foresaw the Chamorro victory weeks ago. The pollsters were no less off base than former Assistant Secretary of State Elliott Abrams, who in an April 1987 speech predicted disaster for Central America if military aid to the Contras was cut off. Under Abrams' scenario, an aid suspension would enable the Sandinistas to devote their attention to subverting other Central American countries, leading to the eventual destruction of the fledgling democracies in the region. To abandon the Contras ``is to follow a recipe for certain disaster in the region within two years,'' he said. Abrams' grim scenario has not panned out. Military aid was indeed cut off by the Congress. The date was two years ago this week and instead of disaster befalling Nicaragua's neighbors, it befell the Sandinistas themselves.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: George Gedda has covered foreign affairs for the Associated Press since 1968.

DOC.HEAD: Irish Prime Minister Gets Camp David Invitation _ For Sure
DOC.TEXT: Whatever else Charles Haughey accomplished in his meeting with President Bush Tuesday, the Irish prime minister managed to wangle an invitation to Camp David. As the leaders posed for pictures in the Oval Office at the outset of their meeting, Haughey was overheard telling his host, ``You must bring me up to Camp David sometime.'' ``Absolutely,'' replied Bush. ``I think if you like the outdoors, you'd love it. In the spring and the fall it is wonderful.'' Bush, as is his usual practice, refused to answer reporters' questions during the photo opportunity. But when a reporter asked for Haughey's views on German unification, Bush said, ``This is a free country. You can ask him anything you want, but I don't know whether he'll answer.'' Haughey passed up the opportunity to explain his views, saying, ``I think the best thing I can do is take the good example of the president of the United States of America.'' But before the reporters and camera crews filed out, Haughey seized the opportunity to make sure the Camp David invitation was on the record. ``Are you really going to have me up to Camp David sometime soon?'' Haughey asked again. ``Yes, in front of everybody, I'm answering your question: You are welcome to come to Camp David sometime. We've got to do it when it's a little warmer.'' Camp David is the presidential retreat in the Catoctin Mountains of Maryland, 75 miles outside Washington. Bush spends nearly every weekend there and spent this past weekend there huddled with West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. Haughey became prime minister as head of a coalition government after Irish elections last June. He was prime minister in three earlier governments.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Seriously Hurt in Package Bomb Explosion
DOC.TEXT: A package bomb exploded in the home of judge whose court hears all terrorism cases, and he was seriously wounded, the Interior Ministry said. Fernando de Mateo Lage, 70, who was opening the package, underwent surgery at Gregorio Maranon hospital after the blast severed his hands and hurled shrapnel into his stomach, chest and face, doctors said. No group claimed responsibility for the bomb, which came less than a week after the government indicated it would respond favorably if armed Basque separatists would halt attacks for six months. Mateo Lage has been president since 1986 of the Audiencia Nacional, where all terrorism cases are tried. He worked at the same court as prosecutor Carmen Tagle, who was shot to death last year in an ambush claimed by the Basque separatist group ETA. ETA has killed more than 600 people in its violent, 21-year campaign for independence for the northern, three-province Spanish Basque region. ETA, whose initials stand for Homeland and Liberty in the Basque language, claimed responsibility for attacks that killed 17 people last year. ETA-claimed actions have caused one death so far this year.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Demands Suspension of Defense Minister
DOC.TEXT: Opposition leaders demanded Tuesday that Defense Minister Magnus Malan be suspended and directed to prove his allegation that an assassinated anti-apartheid activist was an army spy. ``You have besmirched a hero,'' Denis Worrall, co-leader of the Democratic Party, told Malan in Parliament. ``Not a single black person in South Africa or Namibia believes you.'' His party and the larger Conservative Party, which supports apartheid, want Malan suspended until pending a judicial inquiry into allegations that the Civil Cooperation Bureau, a secret military intelligence unit, killed opponents of South Africa's apartheid policy of race discrimination. Malan, defense minister since 1981, has denied ordering killings or other criminal activity. More than 60 unsolved killings of anti-apartheid activists have occurred in the past decade. South African and Namibian police are seeking three former police officers who allegedly were recruited into a unit of the military's Civil Cooperation Bureau. They have been missing since Namibian police issued warrants for their arrest in the assassination in September 1989 of Anton Lubowski, a lawyer who was the highest-ranking white member of the South-West Africa People's Organization. SWAPO guerrillas fought a bush war against South African forces in Namibia until April 1989. It won elections in November and will control the government when the territory becomes independent in March under U.N. supervision. On Monday, Malan declared in Parliament that Lubowski was ``a paid agent of Military Intelligence'' who had done good work for the army and there would have been no reason for the military intelligence chief to have ordered action against him. Malan said he would make further comments only to the judicial inquiry. Lubowski's family challenged him to repeat the allegation outside the protection of parliamentary privilege. ``One of the reasons for this allegation is to create suspicion of white SWAPO members,'' said Moses Garoeb, a SWAPO official. ``No matter the extent of the smear campaign, the name of Anton Lubowski will be remembered as a shining example of the struggle for independence.'' Worrall said in Parliament: ``Given the denial by the Lubowski family and SWAPO, and the improbability of the suggestion that he was a Military Intelligence agent, we are entitled to demand proof. ... If the man was paid, there must be bank acounts and evidence of payments.'' If Malan did not provide proof of his allegation, Worrall said, he would ``simply be seen to be trying to save his own political life.'' The Star newspaper in Johannesburg, which has published several articles showing the chain of command between Malan and the Civil Cooperation Bureau, said Tuesday legal experts were shocked that Malan had withheld evidence about Lubowski from police for five months. Col. Jumbo Smit, the Namibian officer investigating the case, said whether Lubowski worked for the South African army did not matter to him. ``This is a murder case,'' he said, and the victim's political affiliation or profession were not relevant. On Sunday, the Star said President F.W. de Klerk was ``expected to fire'' Malan, whom it described as ``the last remnant of ex-President P.W. Botha's securocrats.'' It noted de Klerk had said in a television interview that criminals, not the security forces, were under attack by those making allegations about death squads. The Star said de Klerk's comment appeared directed at statements by Malan that implied the allegations were an attack on the Defense Force. The president, however, was one of several National Party members of Parliament who shook Malan's hand after his statement Monday. De Klerk has drastically reduced the army's power since he replaced Botha in August. He has halved the period of compulsory military service, cut the defense budget and ended military management of black townships.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Leona Helmsley is abdicating her three-year reign in advertising as the picky-picky, tiara-wearing hotel queen. A new advertising campaign in April for the New York Helmsley hotels will no longer feature Mrs. Helmsley, recently convicted of federal tax fraud. The ad company that crowned her, Taylor-Gordon, Aarons & Co., quit in August after she demanded that it slash its commissions by 60 percent. Last week, Smith-Greenland Inc. won the $3 million to $5 million Helmsley account over 35 competing agencies. ``It was our point of view, and she agreed'' to stop using her picture in future print and TV ads, said Leo Greenland, chairman of Smith-Greenland. But though she'll no longer appear in the picture, ``she is president of the corporation and her presence is there _ definitely,'' Greenland said. ``We are going to sell the impeccable service that the hotel group delivers to each of its guests,'' he said. ``The emphasis will be on the theme that comes out of her business philosophy: fierce attention to details.'' Greenland said the new ads will boast guest room features such as magnifying mirrors and foil covers on complimentary bottles of hand cream so guests can be confident that ``no one else could have used the cream before.''

Pop singer Donny Osmond and Apollo astronaut Edwin E. ``Buzz'' Aldrin will have their autographs set in bronze on a sidewalk near Disneyland. They are being inducted into the Orange County ``Walk of Stars'' next month, joining Steve Martin, Gale Storm, Ruby Keeler, Buddy Ebsen, Tommy Lasorda and other celebrities. The walk was established three years ago at the entrance to the Anaheim Hilton and Towers, hotel General Manager Glenn Hale said Monday. ``Both of the inductees have been an integral part of American culture for over 25 years,'' Hale said. ``Music historians are already calling Osmond's 1989 success the comeback of the decade. And Aldrin, a moving force behind America's role in space exploration, now lectures throughout the world.'' Aldrin was the second man to step foot on the moon, after Neil A. Armstrong, during the July 1969 Apollo 11 mission. The plaques will be unveiled March 21.

The Soviet heavy metal band Gorky Park has been signed for Farm Aid IV at the Hoosier Dome on April 7, and has singer John Cougar Mellencamp to thank for its appearance. Mellencamp invited Gorky Park to play in what will be its biggest American gig yet. Lead guitarist Alexei Belov said the concert is ``the most exciting thing (that) ever happened for us in the United States.'' ``I think we live in a great time. We were first to come with rock 'n' roll to your country,'' he said during an appearance at an Indianapolis music store Monday. Belov lauded the loosening of borders in the Eastern bloc. ``We were locked for so many years,'' he said. ``And I always dreamed of a day when there would be no borders between countries. ``Maybe it will come in 100 years. Maybe I will still be alive. And I will know that a little piece of this work was done by our band by bringing people closer.''

Actor Richard Widmark, whose 40-year film career began in 1947 in the thriller ``Kiss of Death,'' received the D.W. Griffith Career Achievement Award. Widmark, 75, was given the award Monday night by Sidney Poitier, who appeared with him in the 1952 movie, ``No Way Out.'' The award was given by the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures. Widmark got his start in radio in the 1940s in New York, then appeared in several Broadway plays. He received an Oscar nomination for his role in ``Kiss of Death'' as a psychopathic killer with a chilling laugh who pushed an old woman in a wheelchair down a flight of stairs. His other films include ``Street with No Name,'' ``Panic in the Streets,'' ``Halls of Montezuma,'' ``The Cobweb,'' ``The Law and Jake Wade,'' ``Judgment at Nuremberg,'' ``How the West Was Won,'' ``Death of a Gunfighter,'' ``Coma'' and ``The Swarm.''
