Other National Board of Review winners, announced in December, were: _ Best movie: ``Driving Miss Daisy.'' _ Best actor: Morgan Freeman, ``Driving Miss Daisy.'' _ Best actress: Michelle Pfeiffer, ``The Fabulous Baker Boys.'' _ Supporting actor: Alan Alda, ``Crimes and Misdemeanors.'' _ Supporting actress: Mary Stuart Masterson, ``Immediate Family.'' _ Director: Kenneth Branagh, ``Henry V.'' _ Foreign film: ``Story of Women.'' _ Documentary: ``Roger & d Me.'' _ Made for television movie: ``Roe vs. Wade.'' _ Miniseries: ``Lonesome Dove.''

DOC.HEAD: Nightmare Scenario Spelled Out for Exxon Valdez
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with morning testimony. Picks up 7th graf, Greiner, who...'.
DOC.TEXT: A retired tanker captain suggested today that Joseph Hazelwood could have removed the helmsman of the Exxon Valdez if he doubted the man's capability in steering. Under prosecution questioning, Robert Beevers, of Grand Falls, Wash., said a tanker captain rarely can remove a seaman from duty without good cause, but can shift his assignments on board. ``Is there a difference between someone qualified to steer and someone you would have confidence in in close waters?'' asked Assistant District Attorney Brent Cole. ``Oh, yes,'' said Beevers, noting that anyone licensed by the Coast Guard is considerd qualified to steer. But in a tricky area such as Prince William Sound, he said, ``you would need someone who throughout the trip had proved he was capable of steering. ... You have to watch closely and decide who is a good helmsman and who is not.'' Some witnesses at Hazelwood's trial have blamed the grounding of the Exxon Valdez last March 24 on a helmsman who failed to follow commands to turn the ship away from the reef. Beevers was offered as an expert witness on the operations of the large ships. He said that on any trip the union provides a crew, but it is up to the skipper to monitor their abilities. Testimony has been inconclusive on whether Hazelwood knew that the helmsman, Robert Kagan, had a history of problems with steering. Hazelwood, 43, a veteran seaman from Huntington, N.Y., is charged with second-degree criminal mischief, a felony, and three misdemeanors: reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated and negligent discharge of oil. If convicted on all counts he could face a maximim of 7\ years in prison and $61,000 in fines. The Exxon Valdez spewed nearly 11 million gallons of oil into pristine Prince William Sound, killing countless birds, fish and other wildlife and blackening hundreds of miles of shore. On Monday, another expert witness gave jurors a scenario of death and destruction that might have followed the skipper's efforts to free the Exxon Valdez from a jagged reef. No one died in the grounding of the 987-foot tanker, but George Greiner Jr., a retired Coast Guard captain, testified that the engine room could have been flooded, killing crew members below. He said that Hazelwood risked their lives by trying to drive the ship off Bligh Reef. Defense attorneys attacked Greiner's testimony as inaccurate and elicited his concession that the ship was incapable of moving anywhere after it struck the reef and unleashed the nation's worst oil spill. Greiner, who spent 33 years in the Coast Guard, is a marine safety consultant from Ridgefield, Wash. He said the state is paying him more than $20,000 for his work on the Hazelwood case. He analyzed shipboard recorders of course changes as the vessel entered Prince William Sound in the early morning hours of March 24 and said it was obvious that after the ship ran aground, Hazelwood tried to extricate it by putting the engines on full maneuvering speed. In records for the time between 12:38 a.m. and 1:41 a.m., he said, the vessel's heading swung back and forth. ``The movement of the rudder back and forth is consistent with trying to move the vessel off the rock or bottom. I can think of no other reason for it,'' Greiner said under questioning from Assistant District Attorney Brent Cole. Asked what risks were involved, Greiner said, ``The risk was additional damage to the vessel and possible death or injury to people in the engine room.'' He said the ship ``could be totally lost if it came off'' the reef. The defense, which had contended that Hazelwood was trying to stablize the ship, took a slightly different position Monday. Attorney Michael Chalos suggested that even if Hazelwood was trying to extricate the vessel it didn't matter because the engine was not powerful enough move it the 450 feet required to get off the reef. ``Do you know how much thrust would have to be generated by the engine to move this vessel one inch?'' asked Chalos. ``No,'' said Greiner. ``There's no way to calculate it.'' Chalos then asked whether after the accident the ship was capable of moving even one inch. ``Obviously, it wasn't,'' said Greiner. ``It didn't move.'' Chalos suggested that Hazelwood's efforts to extricate the tanker from the reef thus meant little in assessing the criminal charges against him. Greiner said there was no damage evident from Hazelwood's post-grounding actions but speculated there might be some damage not visible immediately. ``Would that damage have resulted in any more of a spill?'' asked Chalos. ``In actuality, no,'' said Greiner.

DOC.HEAD: Plunge in Big-Ticket Orders Raises Worry About U.S. Manufacturing
DOC.TEXT: Orders to U.S. factories for durable goods plunged 10.5 percent in January, the biggest drop in 32 years of recordkeeping, the government said Tuesday in a report raising new concerns about widespread weakness in American manufacturing. While most private analysts maintained the country will avoid a recession, some were not so sure, expressing fears that further weakness in manufacturing could lead to more job layoffs, sagging consumer confidence and cutbacks in consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of all economic activity. And with the fresh signs of slow growth in the first quarter, analysts were looking for Wednesday's Commerce Department report on the gross national product to show the extent of economic stagnation in the last three months of 1989. In its first estimate of the fourth quarter GNP last month, the department said economic activity slowed to a 0.5 percent growth rate from 3 percent in the third. Some economists believe the October-December growth will be revised downward based on information that has become available since the initial estimate was made. ``I wouldn't rule out a negative (growth), but I think it's doubtful,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist with the Boston Co. ``But even if it is a small negative or a small positive, it would be the same. The economy ground to a halt in the fourth quarter.'' Many analysts had been looking for a slight improvement in the first half of 1990, but some expressed reservations after Tuesday's durable goods report. ``Overall, it was an indication the manufacturing economy definitely is slowing down further,'' said economist Thomas Runiewicz of the WEFA Group in Bala Cynwyd, Pa. ``The sharp decline is another sign we'll see virtually no real economic growth in the first quarter,'' concluded Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers. Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan sought in congressional testimony Tuesday to play down the number, although he admitted it was ``lower than I would have expected.'' Greenspan said it was the central bank's judgment ``that orders basically are flat.'' But Paul Getman, an economist with Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa., contended: ``This is more evidence that the slowdown in growth has not passed and we may be just in the middle of it. The economy's growth rate may slow even further in the months ahead.'' Not all of Tuesday's economic reports were bad, however. The Commerce Department reported that the U.S. trade deficit had narrowed to $113.2 billion last year, the best showing since 1984 and an 11 percent improvement over 1988. The report on merchandise trade as calculated on a balance-of-payments basis showed a 13.4 percent gain in exports, to a record $361.9 billion. This offset a 6.4 percent increase in imports, which also hit an all-time high at $475.1 billion. But in its other report, the department said orders for durable goods _ items expected to last more than three years _ fell to $118.2 billion after having risen 1.4 percent in December and 4.8 percent a month earlier. It was the steepest decline since the government began keeping records of orders in 1958 and broke the previous record drop of 9.2 percent, set in February 1982, during the last recession. ``Most of the decline was in transportation,'' the Commerce Department said, with aircraft accounting for about half of the decrease in that sector. Analysts had noted an unusually large number of aircraft orders in the previous two months and said the January drop represented a return to normal. But motor vehicle orders also were down sharply as automakers laid off tens of thousands of workers in January to pare bloated inventories. The auto industry has been among the weakest in the manufacturing sector recently. Overall, transportation orders were down 27.6 percent, to $27.9 billion, after having gained 4.8 percent in December and 10.8 percent in November. Excluding transportation, orders would have been off 3.4 percent. Electrical machinery orders were off sharply, down 17.6 percent to $18.8 billion, after having risen 5.6 percent in Decmeber and 7.3 percent a month earlier. Defense capital goods orders were down 36 percent, to $6.3 billion, due to government cutbacks in military spending. Excluding defense, orders were down 8.4 percent. The closely watched non-defense capital goods sector, often a barometer of business investment plans, also fell, down 13.7 percent and reversing December's 14.2 percent gain. Non-electrical machinery and primary metals orders both rose slightly. Non-electrical machinery orders were up 2.6 percent, to $22.3 billion, while primary metals increased 1.5 percent, to $11.1 billion.

DOC.HEAD: White House Denies Hostage Talk Report
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with new and edited grafs 3-5, re source of report, picking up graf 4 pvs, ``Fitzwater talked''; DELETES pvs graf 10, ``CBS News.''
DOC.HEAD: Subs 3rd graf, He said, to insert dropped word ``not''
DOC.TEXT: The White House today denied a report that the United States and Iran held secret talks in Geneva aimed at securing the release of Americans held hostage in Lebanon. ``We are not aware of the source of these stories or any talks that fit this description,'' said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. The report was carried by a London-based Lebanese newspaper, Al-Hayat. An editor at the paper said the Arabic-language story reported that Sheik Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, a key Lebanese Shiite Moslem cleric, had said contacts took place between Iran and the United States, through third parties. Fadlallah, said to have spoken in Beirut after a trip to the Iranian capital, Tehran, is spiritual leader of the Iran-aligned Hezbollah group. Some Western hostages are believed held by factions linked to Hezbollah. Fitzwater said the administration continues to pursue leads and contacts that might glean information about potential release of the hostages, but he would not reveal what they were. Fitzwater talked around the question of whether President Bush had authorized any officials to conduct talks on the hostages, except to say there were no talks between the U.S. emissaries and Iran. ``There are no direct talks between the United States and Iran authorized by the president,'' he said. ``I don't know who's talking to who,'' the spokesman said.``But I guarantee you I'm never going to say that nobody's talking, because I know a lot of people are.'' ``There are a lot of people around the world talking about release of the hostages in Lebanon _ people from other countries, people from other embassies, people on all levels, people we don't even find out about until after the fact,'' Fitzwater said. ``I will never rule out meetings anywhere, anyplace, anytime by anybody on the hostage question. Because there are meetings happening. But high-level U.S. officials, direct secret talks, no. Do I expect a breakthrough or anything new happening? No.'' Fitzwater said the administration knows ``of no new evidence'' to support hopes that the hostages' release might be forthcoming.'' Last month, a Kuwaiti newspaper, Al-Qabas, said ``an American personality'' had met in Geneva with a representative of Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani to discuss the hostage issue. None of those supposedly involved was identified. Eight Americans are held hostage in Lebanon, including Terry Anderson, the Associated Press chief Middle East correspondent whose captivity is nearing the five-year mark, the longest period of any of those held. The others, kidnapped by Moslem extremists, are: Thomas Sutherland, Frank Herbert Reed, Joseph James Cicippio, Edward Austin Tracy, Jesse Turner, Alann Steen and Robert Polhill.

DOC.HEAD: Carnival Celebration Enters Fourth and Final Day
DOC.TEXT: Crowds watched the last of Rio's lavish Carnival parades Tuesday and revelers prepared to bring four days of riotous pre-Lenten festivities to a close at all-night balls. Brazilians return to the realities of 70 percent monthly inflation at midday Wednesday, when banks, stores, and government offices open for the first time since Friday. In Rio, the undisputed capital of Brazil's Carnival, the last of the glittering ``Samba School'' parades danced along the six-block ``Sambadrome'' early Tuesday. The stands were filled to capacity with 75,000 people who danced, sang and cheered as the parades passed. The parades, which slum neighborhood groups spend a whole year and millions of dollars preparing, are the highlight of Rio's festivities. The 16 top ``schools'' parade in two 15-hour marathon sessions, which begin Sunday and Monday nights and end the following days. Each ``school'' picks a theme for its parade. It then composes a samba, choreographs dance steps and designs costumes and floats around the idea. In the parades, about 5,000 costumed dancers and percussionists march beside massive multicolored floats. On Tuesday, the clear crowd favorite was Mocidade Independente, backed by more than 500 percussionists. When the school finished its performance, the crowd roared ``They've already won.'' Another contender for the championship, Mangueira, had perhaps the most beautiful costumes, with samba dancers clad in plush pink-and-green feather headresses. As in most years, many female samba dancers wore little more than skimpy, sequined bikini bottoms. The naming of the parade winner is scheduled for Wednesday. After the parade, celebrants rested for a few hours, but by early afternoon thousands were on the streets again dancing to samba bands mounted on trucks, which snaked through city neighborhoods. Several all-night balls late Tuesday were to bring Carnival celebrations to a close. The two biggest, expected to attract up to 10,000 revelers each, are the Grande Gala G for homosexuals and Monte Libano nightclub's particularly raunchy bash, part of which is broadcast live on a local TV network. Carnival celebrations also were held elsewhere in this nation of 150 million, particularly in northeastern coastal cities.

DOC.HEAD: Drug-Case Witness Slain by Hired Killer, Authorities Say
DOC.TEXT: A hired killer gunned down a murder trial witness to eliminate the man's testimony against four suspects charged with the drug-related slaying of the witness' girlfriend, authorities said Tuesday. John Shelton, 43, was killed Feb. 7 outside a dry cleaners in the Queens borough by a ski-masked man with an M-1 rifle, authorities said. Shelton had been at home with his longtime girlfriend, Maxine Peterson, when she died in a hail of 20 bullets on May 28, 1988. Ms. Peterson was standing in her kitchen holding her 6-week-old baby when she was shot; the baby was not harmed. Ms. Peterson's killers, believed to be drug dealers, allegedly were retaliating for a shooting committed by her son earlier that day. A spokesman for the Queens district attorney said it was not definite that Shelton would have testified against four young men charged with Ms. Peterson's killing. But police Lt. Eugene Dunbar said: ``The information we have is he was killed because he was going to testify.'' Opening statements began Monday in the trial of the four murder defendants, with no mention of Shelton's slaying. Reports in the Daily News and New York Newsday said Shelton's killer received between $3,000 and $10,000. An 18-year-old has been charged. The Shelton shooting was not the first violent incident involving witnesses in cases in Queens. In October 1987, taxi dispatcher Mildred Green was shot to death at her job after she appeared before a grand jury investigating a shootout outside her office. A month later, a drug-case witness who uses the single name Arjune was targeted by drug dealers who firebombed his home. Police assigned a round-the-clock guard to Arjune's home; one of his protectors, Officer Edward Byrne, was killed Feb. 22, 1988, on the order of local drug dealers. ``Certainly, it raises concerns among witnesses. It does have a chilling effect. People think twice about coming forward,'' said Dick Piperno, spokesman for District Attorney John J. Santucci. ``But they still do. People have the guts to come forward.'' Authorities say Michael Bethea, 18, already jailed on drug and weapon charges, has been charged with murdering Shelton. He is scheduled for arraignment March 15. Piperno, citing the ongoing trial, would not provide any details about why Shelton was targeted or who might have hired his killer. Bethea's lawyer, Michael A. Fishman, offered no comment on the charges. Opening statements in the Peterson murder trial began Monday in state court. The defendants charged with killing Ms. Peterson are Gary Steadman, 24; Raymond Blair, 21; Kevin Gaines, 27; and Keenan Wynn, 21, all from Queens.

DOC.HEAD: Boy Survives Night Lost in Snowy Woods Huddled with Dog for Warmth
LaserPhoto BX4
DOC.TEXT: A 12-year-old boy who got lost in the snowy woods was rescued nine hours later along with his Labrador retriever, who helped keep him alive by huddling against him and licking his face. The dog, Shadow, was lying across the lap of Greg Holzworth when rescuers reached them early Monday. Searchers found them by following the sound of the dog's barking. ``It was sort of like scary,'' the sixth-grader said in a telephone interview from school Tuesday. ``Everything looked the same. It was like we were walking around in circles. My pants got frozen because I had to walk through these puddles.'' Greg's adventure began a little before 4 p.m. Sunday when he and Shadow set off for a walk in the thick, swampy woods that line his family's home in Raynham, 30 miles south of Boston. Greg said he intended to take a short walk with Shadow, who joined the family nine years ago when he was a puppy. Greg was wearing a denim jacket missing buttons over a T-shirt and cotton pants, and gloves. But the two ventured farther in the woods than planned. Greg started building a fort of brush and tree limbs; heard Shadow barking; and followed the dog even farther into the woods. Greg realized he was in trouble when falling snow began covering his tracks. It had snowed most of the day, the end of a storm that dumped about 8 inches on the region. The temperature dropped to 10 degrees. ``Shadow lay down next to me and he kept his head on my legs and he'd lick me in the face,'' Greg said. ``He kept me warm.'' Raynham police Officer Thomas Smith said the dog's body heat helped keep the boy alive. Greg's father, Donald, started searching for his son around 6 p.m. When he hadn't returned an hour later, his wife, Donna, called police. Greg is the younger of their two sons. More than 100 people, including police and firefighters using megaphones and sirens, combed the woods. ``I can't tell you how thrilled I was to have so many people help us,'' Mrs. Holzworth said Tuesday. Greg's memories are a little hazy. For one, he thought it was only about dinnertime _ not 1 a.m. _ when he was actually found. ``I was laying down because I was cold and I could barely walk because my pants wouldn't bend,'' he recalled. ``After a while my legs started hurting and they got wicked sore. I could hear people yelling. I couldn't really yell back because my throat was sore and I had chapped lips.'' They were found just a half mile from home. Greg was treated at a hospital for exposure. Shadow was rewarded with a full day inside the house Monday, Mrs. Holzworth said. Normally he stays in the basement or outside. ``And my dad gave him a steak, too,'' Greg said.

DOC.HEAD: Excerpts from Newspaper Editorials on Nicaragua Election
With AM-Nicaragua Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a roundup of editorials on Violeta Chamorro's election victory over Marxist Sandinista leader Daniel Ortega in Nicaragua: ``Most of all (Mrs. Chamorro) has to rely on the understanding and generosity of a government in Washington that has all but sent Nicaragua to its deathbed to scourge it of Marxism. In the process 30,000 Nicaraguans have lost their lives and untold others have been maimed, fallen prey to disease or suffered privation. They have paid fearfully for U.S. insistence on ideological orthodoxy and now President Bush must move beyond the mere retraction of our sanctions and international-loan blackball to a trade and aid program that welcomes Nicaragua wholeheartedly back into the hemispheric fold.'' The Atlanta Constitution.

``In fairness, though, the defeated President Daniel Ortega and his Sandinista associates must be accorded a full measure of recognition for having held what was universally conceded to be a fair election, and for having committed themselves to abide by the results... Ortega's reaction to the voters' verdict reflected political and personal maturity. It may also have indicated a recognition that there just isn't much of a market these days for Marxist regimentation and inefficiency.'' Corpus Christi Caller-Times.

``Victory is always sweet, but it is not necessarily permanent. Violeta Chamorro, upset winner of Nicaragua's presidential contest, need only consider the troubles of Corazon Aquino in the Philippines to see what can happen following a triumph on election day. In Central America in particular, civilian presidents do not always control the military and, as a result, ruthless officers sometimes hold the real power. If Nicaragua is to recover from 10 years of the civil war that cost an estimated 30,000 lives, it is essential that Chamorro win not just a title but the authority that belongs to the head of government.'' San Francisco Chronicle.

``The United States, as principal bankroller of the anti-Sandinista forces, is deeply obligated to rebuild the devastated, poverty-stricken country. As starters, the U.S. trade embargo should be lifted, international loans should be arranged and economic assistance should be extended on a generous scale. For President Bush and Congress, this will require more changes in a foreign aid program already strained by the budget crunch and the needs of Panama and Eastern Europe.'' The Sun in Baltimore.

``All it took was one free election for the Nicaraguan people to reject 10 years of Sandinista rule and take back their revolution. Now comes the hard part: governing a nation whose economy has been all but ruined by inflation, bad management, war and a U.S. trade embargo .... If the transition goes peacefully ... there is one important certainty: When given a voice, the Nicaraguans decided their fate, not with a bullet but with a ballot. It's a shame they didn't get that chance years earlier.'' Beacon Journal in Akron, Ohio.

``As for what U.S. policy now will be, it appears, ironically, that things might have been easier for policy-makers if the Sandinistas had won; the administration then may have taken the option of quietly disengaging itself and walking away. Now, however, President Bush will have to demonstrate his commitment to the Chamorro government, which will be faced with enormous challenges upon taking power. The Nicaraguan heroine of the moment, Violeta Chamorro, may have more in common with Philippines President Corazon Aquino than she would have preferred.'' The Dallas Morning News.

``Election of opposition candidate Violeta Chamarro as Nicaragua's president offers hope for democracy at last in one of the last holdouts against the tide of freedom sweeping the world. ...Although it happened on President Bush's watch, her election is a vindication of the challenge to the Sandinista regime put forth by former President Reagan.'' The Daily Oklahoman, Oklahoma City.

``The U.S. also now has a solemn obligation to end its economic boycott of Nicaragua _ which has had devastating effects on the small country _ and to replace it with significant economic assistance. Nicaragua's desperate economic plight probably had more to do with the election result than any other single factor.'' Seattle Post-Intelligencer.

``Nothing less than the beginning of a political miracle appears to have occurred in Nicaragua. A Marxist government that came to power by revolution has not only permitted a fair election, it has lost the election resoundingly. (But) ...unless UNO has control of the army and Interior Ministry, the election's results, so heartening today, eventually will turn to ashes.'' The Miami Herald.

``The citizens of Nicaragua finally got a chance for an honest vote, and they did what abused and oppressed people generally do when they get the opportunity _ they threw the rascals out. ....Ortega, who has been trying in recent weeks to set the stage for improved relations with the United States, must be given credit for allowing a fair and free election. That the Sandinistas should allow such a remarkable event is vindication of the much-criticized U.S. policy of pressuring Ortega's government to allow dissent and democracy.'' Nashville Banner.

DOC.HEAD: Namibia Trip on Baker's Schedule, Officials Say
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III is expected to go to Namibia next month to attend ceremonies at which the territory formally achieves its independence from South Africa, U.S. officials said Tuesday. The ceremonies will be held March 21. Baker also is considering visits to several other countries, including South Africa, but has made no final decisions, said the officials, who asked that their names not be used.

DOC.HEAD: Stamp to Honor First Hispanic Senator
DOC.TEXT: The first Hispanic to serve in the U.S. Senate will be honored on a postage stamp next year, the U.S. Postal Service announced Tuesday. The stamp, in the Great Americans series, will honor Dennis Chavez, who served as a senator from New Mexico from 1935 to 1962. The value to be assigned the new stamp was not announced, pending a decision on new rates expected to take effect in 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Legislators Approve Powerful Presidency Under Gorbachev Pressure
DOC.TEXT: A determined and at times angry Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Tuesday rammed through the Soviet legislature his proposal for a more powerful presidency that progressive lawmakers warned could become a dictatorship. Gorbachev, his voice rising as his temper frayed, accused his critics of engaging in ``cheap demagoguery.'' The Soviet leader recognized lawmakers and revoked their right to speak apparently at whim during the often-stormy debate. He hailed the Supreme Soviet's final and overwhelming approval of his proposal as a ``a great political event.'' But lawmaker Leonid Sukhov, a Ukrainian taxi driver, warned: ``The way the voting went today is the same way presidential power will be.'' After only two days of discussion, spread over two weeks, the Supreme Soviet voted 347-24 with 43 abstentions to approve creation in principle of a national presidency with a five-year term, to replace the government post now held by Gorbachev, whose formal title is Supreme Soviet chairman. The bill was remanded to committees to consider the dozens of amendments offered by deputies during debate. Subject to final approval by the legislature's parent body, the Congress of People's Deputies, the president will be granted powers to veto laws, unilaterally declare states of emergency, and name the prime minister, according to a copy of the bill shown to Western reporters. Gorbachev, who chaired the legislature's proceedings, emphasized he has not yet been elected president and said he has even considered refusing the office, but few expect the 58-year-old Communist Party chief not to be chosen. The presidency would give Gorbachev a new and stable power base at a time when his 20 million-member party's popularity and prestige are waning and it pursues the declared aim of following East Europe's Communist parties in renouncing its legally guaranteed right to govern and compete in a multiparty system. Progressive lawmakers strongly objected to concentrating so much power in one leader's hands and what they called Gorbachev's undue haste in pressing the issue on the Supreme Soviet. But other legislators said mounting economic, social and ethnic woes prove the need for a strong leader. ``We are tired of social tension. When are you going to put the country in order?'' lawmaker Rano A. Ubaidullaeva of Uzbekistan said her constituents were demanding. ``We need a person who can have real power ... the quicker the better.'' But Anatoly A. Sobchak rejected the demand for ``a strong hand'' voiced by some. ``We are deciding the question of appointing a nationwide gendarme,'' the Leningrad jurist said. He told the 542-member legislature: ``All our decisions can be crossed out by the president.'' Sobchak and another member of the progressive Inter-Regional Group of parliamentarians, Sergei Stankevich of Moscow, said the new presidency would tilt the balance of power toward the head of state to the detriment of the new working legislature, which has functioned for less than a year. ``We know all too well from the history of our country how dangerous is the concentration and super-concentration of power and authority in one place,'' said Stankevich, who has studied the U.S. Constitution. Visibly stung by some lawmakers' insinuations that the new office was being tailor-made for him, Gorbachev exclaimed from the dais: ``This is not serious. This is cheap demagoguery!'' ``We're talking about the president's power, about constitutional changes,'' he said. ``What does Gorbachev have to do with this?'' He repeated previous assurances that there would be more than one candidate for the office, and added: ``Sometimes I have an outrageous thought, in order to prove that this (the political system) is not being adjusted for somebody ... to decline if my name is on the list of candidates.'' But he said such an act would be ``cowardice.'' The new presidency, he said, was vital for the success of his economic and social reform drive, known as ``perestroika.'' According to the draft bill on the presidency shown to reporters, the holder of the office must be a Soviet citizen at least 35 years old. The president will be directly elected by the voters, the bill stipulates, but the jurist who presented it to the Supreme Soviet said the procedure will be different the first time. Vladimir Kudryavtsev, a vice president of the Academy of Sciences, said the first president will be elected by the Congress to a four-year term, because it would take too long to prepare a nationwide election. The president's term would thus expire along with those of the 2,250 members of the Congress, who were elected last year. The bill shown to reporters empowers the president: _ To unilaterally declare a state of emergency anywhere in the country, and to declare war if the Soviet Union is invaded. _ To appoint the prime minister, subject to confirmation by the Supreme Soviet. _ To be commander-in-chief of the armed forces. _ To veto legislation. If the Supreme Soviet overrides the veto by a majority vote, the president can appeal to the Congress or go over the heads of the lawmakers by scheduling a nationwide referendum. On Gorbachev's recommendation, the Supreme Soviet voted to convene an extraordinary session of the Congress on March 12 to approve the constitutional changes creating the new office and elect the president. After the Supreme Soviet adjourned for the day, Inter-Regional Group members caucused in a Kremlin sideroom dominated by a painting of Soviet founder Vladimir Lenin haranguing a crowd on Red Square. ``It's awful,'' historian Yuri N. Afanasyev said of the legislature's proceedings. ``It shows there are around 300 people in the Supreme Soviet who simply do what Gorbachev wants.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Haughey Agree to Expand US-European Ties
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Irish Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey agreed Tuesday to expand U.S.-European Community ties, including formal semi-annual meetings between Bush and the president of the 12-nation council. Bush, hailing the peaceful revolutions that have changed the face of Eastern Europe, said, ``Transatlantic cooperation now is more important than ever.'' Haughey, the current president of the European Council, said the regular presidential meetings will provide ``a new framework for enhanced political and economic ties between the community and the United States. The U.S. secretary of state will also meet twice a year with his European counterparts. ``We are in fact building a broader bridge across the Atlantic,'' said Haughey, standing beside Bush outside the White House at a frigid departure ceremony following talks in the Oval Office and a private luncheon. Bush praised the Irish Republic's efforts to bring peace to Northern Ireland, torn by sectarian strife now entering its third decade. ``In a time when all things seem possible, all Americans hope for an end to the conflict that has brought such sadness to your beautiful land and your wonderful people,'' said Bush. Visibly touched, Haughey departed from his text to say, ``I greatly appreciate the president's deep personal concern for the situation in Northern Ireland and his constant wish to be of any possible assistance he can in bringing forward a solution to that intractable and difficult and tragic problem.'' Haughey, president of the European Council for the first half of 1990, has called a special summit of the 12 nations in Dublin April 28 to discuss German unification and the dramatic shifts toward democracy in once hard-line communist states. The Irish leader, serving as Eire's prime minister atop a coalition government for the fourth time in the past decade, called it a ``very exciting time for all humanity.'' ``The president and I agreed that the United States and the Community have a pivotal role to play in overcoming the divisions between East and West and in laying the foundations for a Europe united in its commitment to peace, prosperity, democracy and, above all, a respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms,'' said Haughey. Bush said, ``We both welcome the prospect of overcoming the artificial division of the continent.'' ``There is no question that Western solidarity protects stability in this time of change. ... The United States will remain a European power,'' Bush promised. He said they both also ``look to the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe to play a greater role in Europe's future.'' ``We believe the EC must play a vital role in the new Europe. A more united Europe, able to take its rightful place in world affairs, is good for the United States of America,'' said Bush. ``We'll look for ways to improve our ties to the community so a new Atlanticism will be teamed with a new Europe.'' The two leaders pledged to cooperate in the fight against drug trafficking, on global warming and other environmental issues. They also discussed bilateral issues including immigration, trade and foreign investment.

DOC.HEAD: Outlook for Wheat Farmers Brighter
DOC.TEXT: Widespread snow and rain over large areas of the Great Plains have brightened the outlook for wheat farmers, the government's Joint Agricultural Weather Facility said Tuesday. ``Moisture improved winter wheat growth in the central and southern Great Plains,'' the facility said in its report for Feb. 19-25. ``The northern Great Plains remained dry.'' The facility is operated by the Agriculture and Commerce departments. Weekly reports cover weather and crop conditions but do not include production forecasts. Looking at other crops, the report said rain again slowed field work in the Delta and the Southeast. Corn planting began in southwest Georgia and continued in Florida and Texas. Rain fell in all of Florida's citrus areas, and new growth was reported ``abundant and trees were blooming in all areas.'' ``Cold temperatures may have damaged peaches in northern Georgia and portions of Tennessee,'' the report said. ``Peaches were blooming in Texas (and) cold temperatures may have damaged peaches in the Cross Timbers area.'' In California, early varieties of apricots, plums, nectarines and peaches were blooming, but frost damage was reported to early peaches and table grapes in Riverside County.

DOC.HEAD: At Least 48 Killed on Election Day for 8 State Legislatures
DOC.TEXT: At least 47 people were killed and 200 wounded by bombs, factional battles or police during voting Tuesday for legislatures in eight Indian states, news agencies reported. Press Trust of India said 45 people were killed in Bihar, an eastern state that is among India's poorest, and two in the western state of Gujarat. It said an election officer died of a heart attack in mountainous Himachal Pradesh state. Bihar is notorious for organized gangs that operate during elections. One of the victims there was an independent candidate shot and killed by unidentified gunmen. Three of the 45 victims in Bihar were killed by police who opened fire near Patna, the state capital, to stop stuffing of ballot boxes, United News of India reported. It said the others were killed by bombs or in fights between members of rival political parties. About 150 million voters cast ballots for 1,610 members of the eight legislatures, all of which have been controlled by the Congress Party of former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi. The elections were seen as a test of the Congress Party's waning popularity and the rising voter appeal of the right-wing Bharatia Janata, or Indian People's Party. More than 45,000 members of federal security forces were deployed for the elections, 18,000 of them in Bihar. Thirteen people were killed during election campaigning in the eight states, including 11 in Bihar. About 70 percent of the 213 million registered voters turned out in Arunachal Pradesh, Bihar, Gujarat, Himachal Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Orissa and Rajasthan states. Results are not expected until Wednesday. Elections also were held in Pondicherry, a federally administered territory in the south, and in five national parliamentary constituencies and 17 state legislative districts where by-elections were due or elections had been canceled because candidates died. In November's national elections, Indians voted the Congress Party out of power, replacing it with the National Front coalition of Prime Minister V.P. Singh. The alliance of Singh's Janata Dal, or People's Party, and three minor factions is supported by the the Bharatia Janata and Communists. Gandhi's Congress Party entered candidates for all but 30 of the state legislative seats. The Janata Dal and Bharatia Janata were in about 1,000 contests each. More than half the 21,200 candidates were independents. The Hindustan Times of New Delhi said the elections were being conducted under ``what is regarded as the tightest-ever security arrangements, in view of the increasing incidence of poll violence and booth capturing.'' ``Booth capturing'' covers a variety of activity from stuffing of ballot boxes to intimidation that sometimes ends in murder.

DOC.HEAD: Coasters Lead Singer Cornelius Gunter Slain Inside Car
LaserPhoto VG1
DOC.TEXT: Police interviewed witnesses Tuesday to track down the man who shot to death Cornelius Gunter, lead vocalist for The Coasters. The '50s group's hits included ``Charlie Brown'' and ``Love Potion No.9.'' Gunter, inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1987, was the second member of the '50s group to die in a shooting in the Las Vegas area. Witnesses told police that Gunter's car was parked at an intersection in a residential area of the adjoining city of North Las Vegas on Monday and a thin black man was standing on the driver's side, talking to Gunter. ``They apparently got into a loud argument,'' said North Las Vegas Police Lt. Gary Rainey. ``People heard a couple of shots. Then the car took off, went about a block, then hit a block wall.'' Gunter, who was scheduled to perform this weekend, was found slumped over the steering wheel, with two gunshot wounds in his chest. ``It appears he was shot through the windshield and he was dead on the scene. We don't have a motive at this time,'' said Rainey. The suspect was seen running from the intersection with a gun in his hand, Rainey said. Rainey said Gunter, a Las Vegas resident, had no police record other than some traffic citations in North Las Vegas. Gunter, a tenor, joined The Coasters in 1957, two years after the group was formed in Los Angeles. Their comic vocals resulted in a string of wise-cracking do-wop hits in the late 1950s. With a flurry of hits that included ``Yakety Yak'' in 1957 and ``Charlie Brown,'' ``Along Came Jones'' and ``Poison Ivy'' in 1959, The Coasters were the country's most popular black rock 'n' roll group at the end of the decade. Among their other hits were ``Framed,'' ``Idol with the Golden Head,'' and ``Shoppin' for Clothes.'' Their last chart appearance was in 1971 with ``Love Potion No. 9.'' With varying personnel, Gunter kept the group on the concert circuit in the 1980s, including the current ensemble known as Cornell Gunter and His Coasters. Various band members headed separate groups billed as The Coasters in recent years. Gunter and The Coasters were scheduled to perform at the Lady Luck Hotel this weekend, said Janice Mazuroski, a hotel spokeswoman. ``It's a sad situation. He was so well liked in the industry,'' she said. The other Coaster slain, Nathaniel ``Buster'' Wilson was shot in the head in April 1980. His dismembered body was dumped near Hoover Dam and in a canyon near Modesto, Calif. Patrick Cavanaugh was convicted in the slaying and is now on Nevada's death row. Prosecutors speculated that Wilson was shot because he was going to tell police about a fraud scheme in which Cavanaugh was allegedly involved.

DOC.HEAD: John Lawn Retiring as DEA Chief
DOC.TEXT: John C. Lawn will retire as head of the Drug Enforcement Administration next month after five tumultuous years when drugs and related violence commanded the attention of the American people. Lawn, whose retirement was announced Tuesday, took over the agency in 1985 just as Mexican authorities were discovering the bodies of slain DEA agent Enrique ``Kiki'' Camarena and his Mexican pilot, Alfredo Zavala Avelar. Lawn's role in pressuring Mexican officials to pursue those behind the kidnap-torture-slaying of the two was portrayed last month in a television miniseries called, ``Drug Wars: The Camarena Story.'' In an interview in December, Lawn gave no hint that he might be retiring this year as head of the lead federal agency for drug law enforcement. When asked how long he would like to keep his job, Lawn said, ``Until I become tired of it.'' He acknowledged that the job was ``frustrating and challenging,'' and added, ``Some point in time will come that I'll have to turn over the reins, but I don't know when that'll be.'' One reason behind the decision to retire after 27 years of government service is that he will turn 55 in a few months, said DEA spokesman Frank Shults. While Lawn, as a presidential appointee, is exempt from the mandatory retirement age of 55 imposed on other federal law enforcement officers, ``he would not be able to maintain his position as a law enforcement officer, just an administrator,'' Shults said. ``It's extremely important to him ... that he is a special agent. That's his motivation. ``There's no suggestion that he's giving up the war on drugs,'' Shults said. ``He's very torn. ... It was an extremely difficult decision for him to make.'' In a letter to President Bush announcing his intention to retire March 23, Lawn said, ``My service as administrator of DEA over the past five years has been most rewarding and most satisfying. The ratification of the United Nations Convention, the National Drug Control Strategy and the Cartagena Summit have established the foundations upon which we can project with confidence our ultimate success in this battle.'' Lawn also thanked Bush for ``your personal involvement in honoring those DEA special agents who have paid the ultimate price in this battle,'' saying that action, combined with support for the agents' families ``have special significance for the men and women of the Drug Enforcement Administration and for me.'' In the December interview, Lawn said the toughest part of his job was the loss of personnel such as Camarena. He also expressed disappointment with the size of the drug war budget, contrasting the $9.5 billion budget for 1990 to the ``excess of $30 billion a year'' the United States spent for the Vietnam War. ``To have fewer agents than there are musicians in the United States Army, or to have fewer agents than there are New York City Transit Police ... you get a sense of too few people being asked to face a Herculean challenge,'' Lawn said. Just as Lawn is leaving, the Bush administration has requested a budget of $10.6 billion for the war on drugs in 1991, a sum that would boost DEA's share from $616.9 million this year to $791.3 million next year, enough to add several hundred new agents to the current complement of 3,191. When Lawn took over the job in 1985, the DEA budget was $353.8 million. Lawn, who was born in Brooklyn, N.Y., plans to return to New York City for a job in the private sector, said Shults, who did not give details of Lawn's new job. ``Jack Lawn has provided extraordinary leadership to the Drug Enforcement Administration during an extremely challenging time,'' Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said in a statement. ``He has been a catalyst for leadership in the international law enforcement community, helping to unite the drug-fighting efforts of many countries. ... His contributions to the international war on drugs will be missed.'' Lawn, a former Marine Corps officer, joined the FBI in 1967 and served in Savannah, Ga.; Monterey, Calif.; Kansas City, Mo.; San Antonio, Texas, and at FBI headquarters before he became acting deputy administrator of DEA in 1982. President Reagan nominated Lawn to the top DEA job in 1985 to replace Francis M. Mullen, who had retired.

DOC.HEAD: Legislation on Right of Republics to Secede Introduced in Parliament
DOC.TEXT: A draft law setting out a daunting procedure for a republic to secede from the Soviet Union has been submitted to the national legislature, a news service of Radio Moscow reported on Tuesday. Calls for secession from the Soviet Union are strongest in the Baltic republics of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, which were absorbed by the Soviet Union during World War II. The Soviet Communist Party recently pledged to support legislation establishing a procedure by which republics could legally secede from the union. But the law appeared certain to displease independent political leaders in the Baltics who argue that Soviet political control of their nations is not legitimate. According to the report published by Interfax, a recently introduced news service of Radio Moscow, the question of secession can be decided only after a referendum in the republic that wishes to secede. The parliament of the republic or at least one-third of the adult population of the republic can call for a referendum in which three-fourths of the adult must vote for the results to be valid, the report said. According to the draft, the results of the referendum will then be submitted to the Supreme Soviet and the Congress of People's Deputies, the two-tiered legislative system that will make a preliminary decision on the basis of domestic and foreign consequences of secession. Any secession would take place over a minimum of five years until the final decision on separation is taken. That power rests in the hands of the 2,250-member Congress. Two-thirds of the deputies must approve the secession. During the transition phase, defense and security issues as well as the establishment of a new border would be settled after which the governments of the republic that has decided to secede and other Soviet republics would settle financial and property issues. The seceding republic has the right to lease or buy any property belonging to the Soviet Union as a whole or the property can be returned. A spokeswoman for Sajudis, the Lithuanian Popular Front, said the movement's leaders were meeting Tuesday night and could not be reached for comment. Sajudis claimed a landslide victory in elections to the Lithuanian parliament held Saturday and is determined to press forward with its primary demand for the republic's independence and sovereignty. Secessionist sentiment is strongest in Lithuania where native Lithuanians make up 80 percent of the population, while in neighboring Latvia, for example, the policy of Russification has reduced the native population to about 50 percent. Even some Russians living in Latvia say secession and an independent Latvia would be desirable because of the expected economic benefits. Labor productivity and quality of goods is higher in the Baltics than in other republics.

DOC.HEAD: Embattled HUD Landlord Blames Agency; Congress To Take A Look
DOC.TEXT: A major low-income housing landlord suspended by the Department of Housing and Urban Development told Congress on Tuesday that HUD footdragging and negligence greatly contributed to poor conditions at properties cited in the sanctions. ``HUD's administration and oversight of inner-city problem housing has been abysmal and verges on the criminal,'' A. Bruce Rozet told a House Banking subcommittee, which in turn told Rozet it planned to call HUD officials and tenants to discuss conditions and management of the properties. Rozet, whose California-based companies control to varying degrees some 45,000 subsidized housing units in 40 states and Puerto Rico, accused HUD of reneging on several promises to help his company revitalize troubled properties it acquired three years ago. While most of his allegations dealt with HUD actions taken during the Reagan administration, Rozet said current HUD Secretary Jack Kemp, who suspended the Rozet companies last month, has added only rhetoric to the nation's housing woes. ``They have condemned tenants to live in squalor while pleading the poverty of the government and trying to shift the blame,'' Rozet said. ``They have raised the hopes of poor, inner-city residents with rhetoric and promises of action and then dashed their hopes on the anvil of purported reform and miserly budgets.'' HUD General Counsel Francis Keating termed Rozet's accusations ``silly, irrational and untrue.'' He said the Rozet-led investors had realized ``handsome returns'' and should put more of their money into the projects before seeking additional government funds. ``His view was always, `Write me another check,''' Keating said. ``It should be the responsibility of the owner to keep up the property, not the responsibility of the taxpayer.'' The subcommittee chairman, Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, told Rozet he would be called to testify again, after the panel hears from HUD officials about properties managed by Rozet's Associated Financial Corp. and its web of 40 affiliates. While placing no blame on Rozet, Gonzalez said he disagreed with government policies that allow private investors such as Rozet's groups to reap lucrative tax benefits from comparatively small investments in low-income housing. Kemp has attacked Rozet's and other groups, saying they often allow properties to decay and refuse to put money back into them. Rozet in turn has argued that his groups have a strong record of re-investing but often have been turned away by HUD when they propose renovation plans. Gonzalez said he wanted to hear from HUD officials to determine to what extent the agency's ``hands were dirtied.'' He told Rozet: ``I'm not too sure about yours.'' Rozet has said the suspension, which prohibits his companies from new HUD-related work, has forced him to seek to transfer most of the 350 properties in his portfolio. He has vowed to fight HUD in court and for the last month has been engaged in essentially a battle of accusations with the agency. Kemp had four aides at Tuesday's hearing. Several times, one scribbled down questions and had them delivered to Republican subcommittee members. Rozet said he would gladly testify again and predicted the subcommittee's review would support his contention that the poor conditions at the properties cited in the suspension were aggravated by HUD denials or delays when acting on renovation proposals. ``The one thing HUD cannot do _ and Congress cannot let them do _ is to make no decision and turn their back on the problem,'' Rozet said. The suspension alleges an AFC management affiliate misused government and tenants' money at developments in Oklahoma and the District of Columbia. Rozet submitted reams of documents to the panel that he said proved his companies had done nothing wrong and said they would prove that if HUD would grant them a hearing. At one point in his attempt to turn the tables on HUD, Rozet, a Democratic Party fund-raiser, said perhaps none of his properties would be troubled had he hired a Republican consultant to lobby HUD for the proposals that were rejected. That was a reference to influence-peddling at HUD during the Reagan years, the subject of extensive congressional hearings last year and a Senate hearing even as Rozet spoke to the House subcommittee.

DOC.HEAD: Democratic Governors Criticize Bush on Eduation Spending
DOC.TEXT: Democrats accused President Bush on Tuesday of being unwilling to provide the resources to upgrade the nation's schools in line with the ambitious goals outlined by the president and endorsed by the nation's governors. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., told the closing session of the annual midwinter meeting of the National Governors' Association that Bush had proposed ``a meager 2 percent increase in the federal spending on education.'' Democratic Gov. Cecil Andrus of Idaho characterized as ``malarky'' the president's pledge of support during a White House meeting with the governors on Monday. Andrus said that when Bush was asked what support he could provide he said, ``we will come out and stand behind you and beside you as you tell your people they must increase the local property taxes.'' ``If he provides the rhetoric and we have to provide the resources ... there's no way that we can meet the goals that he's outlining,'' Andrus said. Gov. Terry Branstad of Iowa, a Republican who is chairman of the NGA, said the federal government has a ``relatively limited role'' in providing financial support for education. He said the government provides only about 7 percent of the money for public schools and that its principal responsibility was to help disadvantaged children with such programs as Head Start. ``Money isn't the total answer,'' said Branstad. He said the governors planned to issue an annual report card on the progress being made to achieve such goals as increasing the high school graduation rate to at least 90 percent and creating drug free schools. Foley addressed the governors at the closing session of the four-day midwinter meeting. ``While I commend the president for his desire to be known as `the education president,' I question whether he can achieve that goal by proposing a meager 2 percent increase in the federal spending on education,'' he told the governors. ``The simple fact is we don't have a 2 percent education problem in this country,'' he said. ``The education gap is much more daunting.'' He characterized the president's proposal for education as a ``tepid incrementalism'' and said, ``We need bolder action.'' Foley also told the governors they were living in ``astonishing times'' that were seeing an end to the Cold War and victories for freedom from Eastern Europe to Nicaragua. He said those changes would result in a peace dividend as the United States was able to cut defense spending in real terms, not just reduce the rate of growth as has been the pattern in recent years. Such a real cut ought to be possible within five years, he said. Foley endorsed the view expressed by the governors that whatever ``peace dividend'' is realized from the reduced spending, about half should go to reducing the federal budget deficit and half to social needs, including education. ``We will not want, however, for places to spend this money,'' said the speaker.

DOC.HEAD: Regional Bottler Out of Business Because of Contamination Reports
DOC.TEXT: Katell Roc, a regional mineral water bottled and sold in western France, went out of business Tuesday after reports that its water was contaminated with hydrocarbons. Water quality problems for the small bottler, which employed 35 people at its spring and plant at Lizio in Britanny, arose about the same time traces of benzene were found in Perrier sparkling water. The plant closure came as the government's consumer watchdog agency, the National Institute of Consumption, called for labels on all mineral water to bear the date it was bottled. ``The Perrier experience showed the negative effects and legitimate suspicion that can follow, in case of an accident, when there is no clear bottling date,'' the agency said. Katell Roc President Pierre Mignot suspended work at the plant Feb. 8, a day after Perrier issued its global recall. There were reports that contaminated Katell Roc water had ended up in a baby bottle. Katell Roc recalled 1 million bottles and ran tests on samples to check purity and restore consumer confidence, Mignot said. But traces of hydrocarbons were found in the bottles, spring and pipes. Chlorine also was found in the pipes. The widespread contamination meant the company could not return to production, said Mignot, without specifying the nature of the hydrocarbons or how much money the company had lost. ``Our financial situation is untenable. We are only a small company,'' Mignot said. ``The Katell Roc brand no longer exists.'' The discovery by a U.S. laboratory that forced Source Perrier SA to recall 160 million bottles of its popular brand from 120 countries on Feb. 7 has led to greater scrutiny of bottled water. Last week, the Vittel mineral water concern recalled 1 million to 2 million bottles of its domestic Hepar brand after reports that some had been contaminated with the hydrocarbon alkane. The company already had quietly withdrawn the contaminated water from the shelves, but issued a public general recall of new bottles to end confusion among consumers, executives said. The consumer agency said it had tested 27 mineral waters since the Perrier recall two weeks ago and said only Perrier showed traces of benzene or other chemicals above European standards. It said the results should restore public confidence in spring water and bottled mineral water. The withdrawal has been voluntary in France, with the decision left to distributors and shops whether to pull the pear-shaped green bottles off shelves.

DOC.HEAD: USDA, Interior Department Join Fight Against Marijuana
DOC.TEXT: Two federal agencies announced Tuesday they were joining forces in an effort to rid their lands of booby traps set by marijuana growers to protect their crops. ``We don't like people doing their dirty work on our public lands,'' Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan said Tuesday as he and Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter signed an agreement allowing law enforcement agents of each department to work on each other's lands. ``With this agreement, we're sending a stronger message that says to them, `Stay out of our lands,''' Lujan said during the signing ceremony. William J. Bennett, the national drug control policy director, joined the ceremony, saying he became personally interested in the problem of drugs grown on public lands when a book he was reading on Oregon hiking trails included the warning: ``Don't go off the trail because you might walk into traps, booby traps set by marijuana growers.'' The Interior Department controls about 500 million acres, while the Agriculture Department's Forest Service controls almost 200 million acres, about one-third of the land in the United States. Lujan said his department confiscated about 310,000 marijuana plants last year, while Yeutter said his department eradicated 350,000 to 400,000 plants. ``The thrust (of the agreement) is to do it better,'' Yeutter said. By working cooperatively, he said, the government will ``get more bang for the buck.'' Bennett said that at the Cartegena, Colombia, drug summit with the leaders of Colombia, Peru, Bolivia and the United States two weeks ago, ``We understood it was our responsibility to take care of our own domestic drug problem.'' The National Drug Control Strategy released Jan. 25 calls for almost doubling the funds for eradication of domestic marijuana production, to $35 million in 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Journalist, Three Peasants Killed in Wave of Violence
DOC.TEXT: Two gunmen shot and killed a Colombian journalist and three farmers she was interviewing, the latest victims in a wave of assassinations, officials said Tuesday. Silvia Duzan, a free-lance reporter, was killed Monday night in a cafe in Cimitarra, were she was working on a story on right-wing death squads, said Salvador Pardo, the town's mayor. The town, 75 miles north of Bogota, has been the scene of dozens of assassinations by right-wing death squads. Ms. Duzan was the sister of Maria Jimena Duzan, a newspaper columnist who often writes about drug traffickers and the death squads they finance. At the time of her sister's death, she was in New York City to appear in a panel discussion, ``Freedom of the Press Under Siege Overseas,'' at Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism. Pardo said the men slain with Ms. Duzan were directors of the Carare Agricultural Workers' Association. He identified the three as Jouse Vargas, Saul Castaneda, and Miguel Barajas, and said they were leading a campaign to reduce violence in the region. ``They had all been threatened with death,'' the mayor said. He did not say who was behind the threats. A friend of Ms. Duzan's said on condition of anonymity the reporter had been carrying out an independent investigation of violence in the region. It was not immediately clear who she was working for. In the past, reporters were told in Cimitarra that leftist guerrillas and right-wing death squads have been active in the region for years. The town is located in the heart of the central Magdalena River region, a base for paramilitary groups backed by drug traffickers. The groups have killed more than 1,000 people in the last four years, according to the attorney general's office. Drug traffickers who bought large stretches of land in the area have cooperated with other wealthy farmers in a campaign of violence against leftist guerrillas and peasant farmers suspected of supporting them. According to human rights investigators, members of the Colombian military also have perpetrated massacres, torture and other atrocities in a war against union and cooperative organizers, leftist leaders, judges and journalists. Four years ago, a death squad killed 36 peasants near Cimitarra. Ms. Duzan's death brought to 49 the number of journalists assassinated in Colombia since 1977. The killings in Cimitarra were the latest in a wave of political violence that included the slaying of three city councilmen and a mayor. Nine died in battles between the army and leftist guerrillas. Unidentified gunmen on Monday shot and killed Martinez Mendoza, a city councilmen in Murindo, 240 miles north of Bogota, the Antioquia state police said. Campos Pinilla, a councilman in northwestern Muzo, was killed Monday by gunmen in a bar he owned there, the Boyaca state government office said. The Cauca state police said Lasso Martinez, a councilman in El Bordo, 250 miles south of Bogota, was killed on Saturday by a gunman. Five men on Monday kidnapped and killed the 31-year-old leftist mayor of Apartado, Diana Cardona, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Salvadoran Guerrillas Deplore Sandinista Overthrow, Vow To Fight On
With AM-Nicaragua, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Leftist guerrilla leaders Tuesday deplored the electoral overthrow of their Sandinista allies in Nicaragua and vowed to fight on to achieve ``genuine democracy'' in El Salvador. The rebels also called for a renewal of talks to end El Salvador's decade-old civil war. ``We certainly deplore the adverse result obtained in these elections by the Sandinista National Liberation Front, which nevertheless has emerged as the single most important individual and influential force in Nicaragua,'' the guerrillas said in a communique broadcast by their clandestine Radio Venceremos. It said the Sandinistas were ``undoubtedly the principal guarantee for the development of democracy and greater social justice and popular participation'' in Nicaragua today. U.S. and Salvadoran officials long have accused Nicaragua's leftist Sandinistas of smuggling weapons to the Salvadoran guerrillas, fighting for power against a succession of U.S.-supported governments in the past decade. The Sandinistas repeatedly denied the accusations, claiming they provided only ``moral support'' to the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, as the coalition of five Salvadoran guerrillas groups is known. But two days before Sunday's election in Nicaragua, The New York Times quoted President Daniel Ortega as saying that if he was re-elected, his Sandinista government would not provide Salvadoran guerrillas with arms. In the interview, Ortega was quoted as saying there was no military solution to the civil war in El Salvador, and he promised to adhere to various agreements preventing the flow of illegal arms across borders in Central America. In their statement Tuesday, the guerrillas leaders vowed that despite the setback in Nicaragua, ``we will redouble our struggle to conquer an authentic democracy in El Salvador, for which so much blood has been shed by our people.'' An estimated 73,000 people have been killed since the civil war began in October 1979, according to human rights groups. The Salvadoran guerrilla leaders also called for a renewal of peace talks and urged both the United States and President Alfredo Cristiani's rightist government ``not to obstruct any further negotiations that can lead us to a regime of democracy, social justice and lasting peace.'' Repeated attempts to negotiate an end to the war since 1984 have failed. The last effort was called off in mid-November, after the rebels launched an month-long offensive in San Salvador that left an estimated 1,000 dead. The rebels said the Nicaraguan election was clean and honest, saying it reflected well on Ortega. ``As revolutionaries, we are proud of the honesty, the responsibility and the vision of the future our Sandinista brothers have,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: Teachers Avert Strike By Voting For Legislative Pay Package
DOC.TEXT: Utah teachers voted overwhelmingly to end a 10-day ``strike alert'' Tuesday and accept a $211 million education package, but union officials said they remained frustrated by low pay and crowded classrooms. Eighty-four percent of the 16,000 rank-and-file members of the Utah Education Association voted not to walk off the job at the state's 800 public and vocational schools in dissatisfaction with the legislative appropriation passed last Wednesday. But the association's president, Jim Campbell, under fire from some teachers for his handling of the negotiations, said it would be wrong to interpret the vote as an endorsement of the funding plan. ``The package was not everything we asked for and the frustration is still high'' among teachers more concerned about class sizes than salaries, Campbell said. Utah's 20,000 teachers rank 44th in the nation in pay with an annual average salary of $22,621, and the state's teacher-student ratio of 25.4 to 1 is the nation's highest. It spends an average of $2,026 per student each year, a nationwide low. The association's board of directors chided Republican Gov. Norm Bangerter and the Republican-dominated Legislature for having passed a $38 million tax cut last September instead of giving the money to public education. The appropriation package, which passed by one-vote majorities in both chambers last week, contains $1,000 pay raises for all teachers and a 4 percent boost in state subsidies to local school districts. It also authorizes local school boards to boost property taxes to reduce class sizes. The money could be used for other purposes, including teacher salaries, if a board certifies it is not needed for class-size reduction. The education association board endorsed the package last week at the end of the legislative session, but did not lift the ``strike alert'' order issued a week before. The teachers voted Feb. 16 to give authorize the board to call a strike. The next day, the board rejected the education package, although board members said they wanted to continue talking with political leaders. On Feb. 19, thousands of teachers staged a Capitol Hill rally reiterating their demands for additional education spending. The teachers union never made specific demands of the Legislature, but did suggest repealing the $38 million tax cut. Democrats in the Legislature also preferred repealing the tax cut to the optional property tax hike.

DOC.HEAD: Residents Evacuated from Homes Flooded by Raging Storm
DOC.TEXT: Raging seas, whipped up by a storm that has killed 51 people in Europe, surged through a shattered sea wall and swamped homes in this coastal village Tuesday. Rescue workers wearing rubber wet suits and traveling in flat-bottom boats helped evacuate 2,000 residents stranded by water five feet deep. Twenty-five people were hospitalized for treatment of hypothermia, and some people who ventured out to retrieve belongings from their homes had to be rescued by helicopter as the tide rose along the north coast of Wales. The storm knocked a hole 2,000 feet long in the century-old sea wall. ``We knew about the gale-force winds and high tides, and did what we could by way of sandbagging, but we could not have prepared for a breach of this magnitude,'' said Neville Gough, Colwyn Borough director of housing and technical services. Fifty-one deaths have been reported in Europe since the storm struck Monday: 16 in Britain, 12 in West Germany and three in East Germany, 10 in France, five in Belgium, two in Switzerland and one each in Ireland, Italy and the Netherlands. In the north of Britain, driving snow and 120 mph winds hampered efforts to reach an injured climber, later found dead in his survival bag. The weather forced the cancellation of the parade of decorative floats at the Mardi Gras celebration in Nice, France, and a fireworks show set for Tuesday night was canceled because of the fire danger from sparks born by the high winds. Residents of Towyn might have to stay out of their homes through the weekend, said Don Norris, the area's emergency planning officer. Throughout Britain, volunteers and rescuers faced similar perils, exacerbated by power outages affecting 40,000 homes, road and rail disruptions and fears of sewage contamination and gas leaks caused by damaged pipes. In Kent, southeastern England, houses facing the sea were battered by waves that slammed pebbles against windows. ``There was a lot of noise and thumping and that. We were already upstairs because the house was shaking from time to time with the stones,'' an unidentified man told BBC radio. ``We heard a lot of clatter and then there was an exceptionally great bang and all the lights went out.'' Rain brought by the storm prompted the French Secretary of State for the Environment to issue new flood warnings in already-soaked east and central France, where floods last week caused pollution in certain ground water supplies. Environment officials reported that the Seine was overflowing its banks near Rouen, but no damage was reported. In Corsica, 125 miles off France in the Mediterranean Sea, winds clocked at 100 mph caused several fires to spread, destroying at least 30 homes and threatening a primary school and a retirement village. The Association of British Insurers estimated weather damage the past five weeks, including a Jan. 25 storm, at $4.2 billion. The earlier storm was blamed for 95 deaths in Europe. French and British meteorologists predicted continued high winds gusting up to 75 mph and further high tides Wednesday. Hubert Lamb, a climate researcher at the University of East Anglia, said Britain's worst storms have come in the last years of each century. He said the present cycle could be comparable to the 1790s when one storm produced winds of up to 170 mph.

DOC.HEAD: World Bank Approves First of Suspended Loans to China
DOC.TEXT: The World Bank's board, including the United States, unanimously approved a $60 million loan to China on Tuesday, the first of seven loans that bank president Barber B. Conable held back after the crackdown on the pro-democracy movement last June. Conable said after the decision that the bank is now back to regular lending to China. The bank is the largest single source of aid to the Third World, lending over $21 billion a year, and China and India are its biggest borrowers. ``You know, China has slowed up its reform program for some very good reasons and the loans now have to be reviewed,'' Conable told reporters. He has taken the position that World Bank loans to China are based only on economic considerations. The suspension last June was to make sure that the Chinese government could fulfill its financial obligations, he said. He added that the bank will be taking up some new loans to China as well as the old ones, which were to have totaled $820 million. The one approved Tuesday will be repayable in 40 years with less than 1 percent annual interest. For 10 years, only the interest need be paid. The money will go to help farming in Jiangxi province, the northeastern part of the country. The bank made another loan to China earlier this month to help repair damage from an earthquake that occurred after the political crackdown. The United States is the biggest contributor but has no direct veto over loans by the bank, which gets most of its money by floating bonds on world markets. It announced a bond issue on Tuesday for 50 billion Japanese yen _ $335.7 million. After Conable held back the loans to China last June, President Bush asked that lending be suspended. Since then the United States has resumed its own loans to China, and has made a grant to help American firms meet competition for material to be used on the Shanghai subway.

DOC.HEAD: Hank Williams Jr. and Late Father Lead Academy of Country Music Nods
DOC.NOTE: Eds: k.d. lang is cq
DOC.TEXT: Rowdy country singer Hank Williams Jr. and his late father shared top Academy of Country Music Award nominations Tuesday with the 40-year-old weepy saloon duet ``There's a Tear in My Beer.'' Williams got six nominations, including entertainer of the year, and the Grammy-winning song collaboration led to five nominations for his father. ``The ones for daddy are particularly important. I want to see daddy shine after these 37 years,'' Williams said from Paris, Tenn. ``I just wish daddy could be there to enjoy it all,'' he added. ``But I feel deep in my heart that daddy's watching somewhere.'' Clint Black also got six nominations, including best album and song for ``Killin' Time,'' and five went to Grammy-winning singer Rodney Crowell for ``After All This Time.'' Crowell joins Hank Williams Jr., Randy Travis, George Strait, Dolly Parton and Alabama in the top entertainer category. Multiple nominees for ``Hat'' trophies included Alabama, Travis and Miss Parton with three apiece. Strait, Kathy Mattea, Reba McEntire, Garth Brooks and the group Shenandoah each had two. The 25th edition of the academy's two-hour awards show take place April 25 in Hollywood and will be televised by NBC-TV. Nominations in 12 categories were announced by members of the band Highway 101, nominated for top vocal group, and Buck Owens, nominated for the duet ``Act Naturally'' with Ringo Starr. ``I feel great. How else could a person feel? It's a sunny day, we find out we're nominated, it's wonderful,'' said Paulette Carlson of Highway 101. In addition to the top entertainer nomination, Williams was picked for the duet with his late father ``There's a Tear in My Beer,'' which also was nominated for top song, record and video. Trophies are given to the artist and composer in the song category and the artist and producer in the record, video and album categories. ``There's a Tear in my Beer'' was on a Hank Williams Sr. demo tape found in the attic of songwriter ``Big Bill'' Lister. The elder Williams died in 1953, but modern technology allowed the addition of his son to the song and video. Several nominees won big during last week's Grammy Awards show: ``There's a Tear in My Beer'' was best country vocal collaboration, Crowell's ``After All This Time'' was country song and k.d. lang was female country singer for ``Absolute Torch and Twang.'' The academy's 2,500 members vote for the winners except for the video award, which is decided by a vote of the academy's Board of Directors. Here is the complete list of Academy of Country Music Award nominees: Entertainer: Alabama, Miss Parton, Strait, Travis and Hank Williams Jr. Male singer: Black, Crowell, Strait, Travis and Ricky Van Shelton. Female singer: Miss lang, Miss Mattea, Miss McEntire, Miss Parton and Tanya Tucker. Duet: Baillie & The Boys, The Judds, Owens & Starr, Sweethearts of the Rodeo, Hank Williams Jr. & Hank Williams Sr. Group: Alabama, Highway 101, Restless Heart, Shenandoah and The Statlers. New male singer: Black, Brooks and Lionel Cartwright. New female singer: Daniele Alexander, Jann Browne and Mary Chapin Carpenter. New duet or group: Kentucky Headhunters, Shenandoah and Wild Rose. Single (artist and producer get awards): ``Better Man,'' Black (producers James Stroud, Mark Wright); ``If Tomorrow Never Comes,'' Brooks (producer Allen Reynolds); ``I'm No Stranger to the Rain,'' Keith Whitley (producers Garth Fundis, Keith Whitley); ``There's a Tear in My Beer,'' Hank Williams Jr. & Hank Williams Sr. (producer Barry Beckett, Hank Williams Jr., Jim Ed Norman); ``Timber I'm Falling in Love,'' Patty Loveless (producer Tony Brown). Song (artist and composer get awards): ``After All This Time,'' Crowell (composer Crowell); ``If Tomorrow Never Comes,'' Brooks (composers Kent Blazy, Brooks); ``Killin' Time,'' Black (composers Black, Hayden Nicholas); ``There's a Tear in My Beer,'' Hank Williams Jr. & Hank Williams Sr. (composer Hank Williams Sr.); ``Where've You Been,'' Miss Mattea (composer Jon Vezner, Don Henry).
