Album (artist and producer get awards): ``Diamonds and Dirt,'' Crowell (producers Tony Brown, Crowell); ``Killin' Time,'' Black (producers James Stroud, Mark Wright); ``Old 8 x 10,'' Travis (producer Kyle Lehning); ``Will the Circle Be Unbroken Volume II,'' Nitty Gritty Dirt Band (producers Randy Scruggs, Nitty Gritty Dirt Band); ``Willow in the Wind,'' Miss Mattea (producer Allen Reynolds). Video (artist and producer get awards): ``Cathy's Clown,'' Miss McEntire (producer Narvel Blackstock); ``High Cotton,'' Alabama (producer Tammara Wells); ``Planet Texas,'' Kenny Rogers (producer Amanda Temple); ``There's a Tear in My Beer,'' Hank Williams Jr. & Hank Williams Sr. (producer Joanne Gardner); ``Why'd You Come in Here Lookin' Like That,'' Miss Parton (producer Tammara Wells).

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Missing the Boat in Eastern Europe and Japan, Witnesses Say
DOC.TEXT: The United States is offering too little aid to Eastern Europe while U.S. businesses are losing out to Japan and Western Europe on the chance to cash in on a potentially lucrative new market, three experts on the region said Tuesday. ``We almost have a stealth policy toward the region,'' said Ed Hewett, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, comparing Bush administration activity to the bomber designed to elude detection. ``It's hard to find it some days.'' The United States has abdicated any leadership role in Eastern Europe by failing to put in the money needed to assure successful transition to free-market economies, said William E. Griffith, a political scientist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Until more is done, ``we cannot expect to be taken anywhere nearly as seriously as we once were, either in Eastern Europe or, more importantly, in Western Europe or Japan,'' Griffith told the House Appropriations subcommittee that handles foreign aid. It will be up to Congress to boost the U.S. share of aid to emerging democracies such as Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia, Griffith said, because the Bush administration has proven reluctant to provide adequate cash. Hewett agreed. ``If we nickel and dime the problem now ... we will live to regret it,'' he said. Harvard economist Jeffrey Sachs, who is working as an adviser to the Polish goverment, said while the Japanese and Europeans are swarming over the area to mine new business opportunities, the ``U.S. business presence is hardly to be seen.'' Japanese businesspeople are ``all over Europe, putting enormous resources into study, analysis, contacts ... they realize it could be an extraordinarily profitable export base,'' Sachs said. ``I've been told they are on a first-name basis with all of the chiefs of the largest enterprises in the GDR (East Germany). ... One does wonder where is the United States, and why are so many businesses ready to cede this very large market to other countries.'' Poland in particular is crucial, said Griffith. If the new Solidarity-led government fails in its effort to transform its economy, it will discredit the idea and discourage other reformers in the region, he said. ``It is in my judgment close to essential that it not fail.'' The United States has won the Cold War with the Soviets but cannot now give up the effort, he added. ``It would not only be ironic ... but potentially dangerous if the United States would once again have won a war and then gone home,'' Griffith said.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Calls For Practical Help For Media in Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: The director general of UNESCO urged the West on Tuesday to provide practical assistance to independent media in Eastern Europe as journalists there report about the emergence of new societies. Federico Mayor said the fast-changing Eastern European press needs help to overcome many obstacles, identified by visitng editors as outmoded equipment, shortages of cash and newsprint and the need to train a new generation of journalists. ``The media are the arteries through which democracy passes, the means by which people are informed, policies questioned, two-way communication assured, political abuses checked _ provided that the media are free, independent and diverse,'' Mayor said. The head of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization made his remarks at the opening of a two-day conference, initiated by Western press organizations to address media needs in Eastern Europe. Media leaders from 15 Western nations including the United States and Canada attended the UNESCO conference along with journalists from Bulgaria, Hungary, Poland, East Germany, Romania, Czechoslovakia and the Soviet Union. The problems in establishing free and independent media in these countries were considerable, Mayor said, ``particularly when there is no historical memory of freedom, when the political culture has to be acquired from the beginning.'' Mayor said the West could help in five areas: offering advice, pooling information to avoid duplication, providing access to new technologies, training journalists and establishing permanent institutional contacts. Several Eastern European speakers appealed for assistance. ``We do not have the most elementary practical skill,'' said Ernest Skalski, editor of the Polish newspaper Gazeta. ``We don't know how to sell newspapers, we don't know about advertising, we don't have computers. ... I came here to learn how to get help.'' Miroslav Philip, editor of the Czech weekly Reporter Magazine, spoke of the ``catastrophic backwardness of our equipment. We want to modernize with the help of our neighbors.'' Encho Gospodinov of the Bulgarian publication Pogled said many new papers in his country could be profitable if they had more newsprint. He also said they lack hard currency to purchase computers and other equipment. Other speakers advocated regional approaches. ``We have to come together and understand each other if we are not to lose the new freedoms we have. ... The time has come for joint publications and joint television programs,'' said Vitaly Korotich, editor of the Soviet weekly Ogonyok.

DOC.HEAD: Airport Foes Suspected as Construction Executive's Home Burns
DOC.TEXT: Fire destroyed the home of a construction company president early Tuesday, and police said they believed radicals opposing expansion of Tokyo's international airport may have set the blaze. Investigators found two timer devices, plastic vessels and electric wires in the wreckage of the two-story wooden house belonging to Teruzo Yoshino, president of Shimizu Corp., a leading construction firm. Yoshino and his wife were at home when the fire started at 3:20 a.m. but fled to safety, said a police official speaking on condition of anonymity. Shimizu Corp. is building a new airport terminal jointly with other Japanese firms in a project to expand the airport, which opened in 1978 at Narita, 40 miles northeast of Tokyo. The government plans to build the terminal and two additional runways by the end of March 1991 at an estimated cost of $4 billion to cope with existing overcrowding and demands for even more flights from the airport. But eight farmers still live on the planned expansion site and refuse to leave. Farmers and their supporters, including radicals seizing on the issue for their anti-government activities, have been resisting the government's plans to expropriate farmland to expand the airport.

DOC.HEAD: Kaifu Names Cabinet Without Scandal-tainted Politicians
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, newly re-elected by Parliament, formed a Cabinet Wednesday after fighting off attempts to include scandal-tainted politicians in his administration. Kaifu displayed uncharacteristic assertiveness by weathering intense intraparty haggling over appointments that delayed announcement of the Cabinet for several hours. He also dropped both women named to his first Cabinet, formed shortly after July's election in which female voters played a major role in ousting the ruling Liberal Democratic Party from control of the upper house. But he kept his foreign and finance ministers in what political analysts said was a move to preserve continuity in relations with the United States at a time of renewed trade friction, and maintain a steady policy in dealing with a widely unpopular new tax. The Cabinet was to present itself to Emperor Akihito later Wednesday before holding its first meeting. The reshuffling came two days before Kaifu was to leave for a hastily arranged summit with President Bush. The two-day meeting begins Friday and is expected to focus on U.S. calls for Japan to radically alter the structure of its economy and ease its $49 billion trade surplus with the United States. Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama and newly named International Trade and Industry Minister Keibun Muto held a news conference to address immediately the trade tensions Kaifu will face. Japan ``must maintain good relations with the United States,'' Nakayama said. ``At a time of Japan-U.S. economic friction, we will make strong efforts in the ... talks. We must promote discussions for Japan-U.S. global partnership in the 21st century.'' Aside from Nakayama, the only other Cabinet holdover was Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, an ambitious politician widely regarded as a future prime minister. The backstage wrangling followed Kaifu's re-election Tuesday as president of the ruling party, and thus prime minister. Parliament's lower house, which officially names the premier, voted to keep Kaifu 286-146 over Socialist Party Chairwoman Takako Doi. The upper house, controlled by the opposition since July, voted for Kaifu 111-91 over Ms. Doi with 44 blank ballots in a runoff. Voter outrage over the tax and the far-reaching Recruit scandal led to the Liberal Democrats' trouncing at the polls in July. In the scandal, stocks in a subsidiary of Recruit Co. _ a business information conglomerate _ were sold to politicians at artificially low prices. The scandal brought down the administration of former Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita and led to the resignation of his successor, Sousuke Uno, who stepped down to take responsibility for the July election outcome. But Kaifu led the Liberal Democrats to an unexpectedly wide majority in the Feb. 18 lower house election, giving him and his party renewed confidence in their leadership. Kaifu lacks a significant power base within the party, but nevertheless insisted on a ``clean'' Cabinet. He stubbornly resisted former Finance Minister Michio Watanabe's backing of Koko Sato, an ex-agriculture minister and member of Watanabe's intraparty faction. Sato had been given a suspended sentence in a 1970s scandal in which Lockheed Aircraft Corp. bribed politicians to influence sales of its aircraft in Japan. Watanabe relented, however, when Cabinet negotiations became stalemated. Kaifu also rebuffed attempts from another party faction to include a Recruit-linked member in the Cabinet. But Kaifu's insistence on a Recruit-free Cabinet could cost him heavily, said Takashi Inoguchi, a political scientist at Tokyo University. ``Kaifu's dilemma is that to gain public approval, he has to assert himself vis-a-vis other major bosses,'' Inoguchi told Kyodo News Service. ``But unless Kaifu incorporates Recruit-tainted politicians, major bosses may not cooperate with him.'' Kaifu, from a small party faction, depends on support from the big party bosses: Takeshita, ex-Foreign Minister Shintaro Abe and ex-Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa, all linked to Recruit and heads of the three largest factions. Other lawmakers appointed to the Cabinet included former Agriculture Minister Kabun Muto as minister of international trade and industry; Justice Minister Shin Hasegawa; Labor Minister Shunpei Tsukahara; Construction Minister Tamisuke Watanuki, and Defense Agency Director General Yozo Ishikawa.

DOC.HEAD: Morgan Goes to Court for Passport
DOC.TEXT: A judge said Tuesday he would rule within two days on a request to release the passport of Dr. Elizabeth Morgan to enable her to travel to New Zealand to fight a custody lawsuit filed by her ex-husband. Morgan was jailed in 1987 for more than two years for failing to reveal the whereabouts of her daughter, Hilary, now 7. Her passport request was taken under advisement by District of Columbia Superior Court Judge Herbert Dixon following a 90 minute hearing. ``Keeping Elizabeth Morgan a prisoner in her own country won't be any more effective than keeping her a prisoner in that little cell,'' said her attorney, Steven Sachs. Sachs argued that Morgan has fulfilled ``every obligation'' since her passport was turned over to court authorities in 1987. ``It is being unlawfully and illegally held,'' he said. However, John Lenahan, representing Morgan's former husband and the girl's father, Dr. Eric Foretich, argued that returning the passport would only give Morgan ``an opportunity to further defy'' the previous contempt of court order. ``She has done nothing to purge herself of the contempt charge,'' Lenahan said. Morgan was jailed in 1987 for 25 months for refusing to turn over the girl for supervised visits with Foretich. Morgan has contended the girl was sexually abused by Foretich. He has denied the charges and claimed that Morgan was mentally ill. Foretich and his wife separated before Hilary was born. The girl, who has been living with her maternal grandparents in Christchurch, New Zealand, had been the subject of a 2{-year search by her father. Officials found her there last week.

DOC.HEAD: `America's Funniest Home Videos' Beats `60 Minutes'
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: An hour-long version of ``America's Funniest Home Videos'' beat CBS' ``60 Minutes,'' the first time an ABC entertainment show has won the Sunday time slot in 12 years, according to figures released Tuesday. NBC won the week that ended Feb. 25 with an average prime-time rating of 15.1, followed by ABC's 13.7 and CBS' 13.4, according to the A.C. Nielsen Co. A ratings point represents the percentage of the nation's 92.1 million television homes tuned into a show. The Sunday night broadcast of ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' which repeated segments from earlier shows, finished eighth, while ``60 Minutes,'' without its usual Andy Rooney signoff, was 18th. The last time an ABC entertainment show won the 7 p.m. to 8 p.m. slot against ``60 Minutes'' was a 1978 special, ``ABC's Silver Anniversary Special.'' Here are last week's top 10 shows: NBC's ``The Cosby Show'' and ``Cheers'' (tied); ``Roseanne,'' ABC; ``A Different World,'' NBC; ``The Golden Girls,'' NBC; ``Empty Nest,'' NBC; ``The Wonder Years,'' ABC; ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' ABC; ``The 32nd Annual Grammy Awards,'' CBS; and ``L.A. Law,'' NBC. Peter Jenning's ``World News Tonight'' on ABC won its seventh straight week in the news ratings, earning an 11.3 rating. Dan Rather's slumping ``CBS Evening News'' was third with 9.9. Tom Brokaw's ``NBC Nightly News'' had a 10.1 rating. NBC's midseason prime time replacement ``Grand'' was 11th, while CBS' ``The Bradys'' fell to 69th. Fox's ``Married...With Children'' was No. 24 and the newtwork's highest ranked show last week. Fox's ``The Simpsons'' came in 26th. Fox said it beat NBC and ABC with ``The Simpsons'' and CBS and ABC with ``Married...With Children.'' Several specials did well during the week, with ``The 32nd Annual Grammy Awards'' capturing ninth place, and the middle and concluding chapter of ``The Kennedys of Massachusetts'' taking 13th and 19th places, respectively. The annual CBS broadcast of ``The Wizard of Oz,'' followed by a one-hour special on Tuesday night, was 27th. NBC's movie ``Nasty Boys'' ranked 37th, but the Friday night premiere of the ``Nasty Boys'' television series was No. 52. ``A Family For Joe,'' an NBC Sunday night movie starring Robert Mitchum, ranked 22nd, while another version of ``Super Bloopers & Practical Jokes'' which followed the Mitchum movie, was 21st. CBS' ``Sparks: The Price of Passion'' on Sunday night was 38th. Viewers agreed with critics and preferred to turn away from ABC's ``Challenger'' on Sunday night. The story about the shuttle tragedy was ranked 44th, with a 12.8 rating, a deep cut from ``America's Funniest Home Videos'' lead-in of 19.4. For the season to date, NBC leads the ratings averages with 14.9, followed by ABC's 13.0 and CBS' 12.3.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Salutes 49ers, Complains People Tuned Out Before His Spot
DOC.TEXT: President Bush congratulated the San Francisco 49ers Friday on their stunning 1990 Super Bowl victory but complained the score was so lopsided many viewers tuned out early and missed his own TV appearance. He suggested that a public service message he taped was seen only by ``five people'' when it aired in the fourth quarter of the 55-10 rout. ``All of them work for me,'' he joked. The message, in which he praised the National Football League for its charity programs, also aired in the first quarter. The president honored the team at a White House reception and called the 49ers' defeat of the Denver Broncos ``one of the greatest victories in American championship history.'' ``You clobbered them,'' the president said. Noting that the team also had won the 1989 Super Bowl, Bush said, ``your team is carrying into the '90s the title the (Pittsburgh) Steelers carried into the '70s _ Team of the Decade.'' To an East Room audience that included family members of the team and many politicians, Bush said, ``This last Super Bowl seemed to have been over some time around the end of the National Anthem.'' Bush lavished praise on the winner of the game's Most Valuable Player award, 49ers quarterback Joe Montana, calling him ``Joe Cool'' and saying: ``Fair to say, he's the most accurate passer in the NFL. Never thrown a Super Bowl interception.'' That, Bush teased, was a claim that former Buffalo Bills quarterback Jack Kemp _ now Bush's secretary of Housing and Urban Development and seated in the front row at the reception _ could never make. Team owner Eddie DeBartolo presented the president and his wife Barbara with a ``little present for the youngest member of your family to help her nights at Camp David to stay a little bit warmer.'' It was a jersey for presidential dog Millie. After the ceremony, running back Roger Craig told reporters outside the White House that the dark, threatening sky overhead was ``a good sign.'' He noted that it rained when the team visited the White House following their 1989 Super Bowl victory.

DOC.HEAD: Blacks Interrupt Council Meeting Over Refusal to Repave MLK Street
DOC.TEXT: The white-majority City Council refused to repave Martin Luther King Jr. Street for the 25th anniversary of the Selma-to-Montgomery voting rights march, setting off new racial tension here. Angry blacks responded by interrupting Monday night's council meeting, forcing a recess after the panel voted 5-4 along racial lines not to repave the street named for the leader of the 1965 march. A re-enactment of the 50-mile march begins Sunday in Selma and ends March 10 in Montgomery. At the council's previous meeting, black council members walked out after the panel voted down a proposal to alternate black and white majorities on the school board. The city has been the scene of racial turmoil since December when the school board, also in a racial split, voted against renewing the contract of Norward Roussell, the city's first black school superintendent. His contract expires in June. Blacks and city leaders exchanged words at Monday's the council meeting, with white Mayor Joe Smitherman telling the audience to ``shut up'' and ``sit down.'' Black council member Lorenzo Harrison proposed that the city spend $17,000 to resurface Martin Luther King Jr. Street in his district for the march re-enactment. Smitherman quoted the city engineer as saying the street ``didn't need it. It would just make it look very shiny.'' He said each council member had $30,000 for ward projects and Harrison ``had used it on other streets.'' Council President Carl Morgan ordered a recess, saying the crowd had become too unruly for the council to conduct business. About 50 to 60 blacks waited for the members to return and didn't leave until Morgan said the panel would not meet again until its next regular session, on March 5. ``A lot of it is being orchestrated to try to get emphasis placed on this 25th anniversary,'' Morgan said Tuesday of the disruption. ``Once that period is over the national media will be out of the picture. The thing is about to fall on its face.'' Morgan, who is white, predicted that fewer than 500 of the 13,000 blacks in Selma would take part in the march, and said black leaders have alienated whites. Morgan said the city's racial unrest in recent weeks has been ``bad for business. It's bad for industry. But I think it has done more to solidify the white community, which is a setback, I'm sorry to say, for the blacks.'' Perry Varner, one of three blacks on the Dallas County Commission, said the protesters would keep disrupting the council until it ``does the right thing.'' But Smitherman said he expects the council will return to a peaceful atmosphere ``as soon as the march gets over.'' ``The way these things go, some of these leaders are trying to recreate the '60s where you have mass arrests,'' he said. Three weeks ago, Selma civil rights activist Rose Sanders was dragged by police from City Hall when she was arrested after a confrontation with Smitherman in his office. The FBI has looked into her allegations of police brutality, but a federal prosecutor said Tuesday a review of the FBI report is not completed. After the arrest, blacks occupied the city's only public high school for five days and held numerous marches and rallies in protest of the school board decision and the incident involving Mrs. Sanders.

DOC.HEAD: White House Promises `Meaningful' Post-Ortega Nicaragua Aid
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration, savoring the defeat of leftist President Daniel Ortega, promised Tuesday to lift sanctions soon against Nicaragua and assemble ``significant and meaningful'' aid to rebuild its shattered economy. President Bush met at the White House with congressional leaders including Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., who said post-Ortega assistance probably would cost hundreds of millions of dollars over five years. Nunn suggested creating an ``emerging democracy account'' of foreign aid for countries such as Nicaragua, Panama and the fledgling democracies in Eastern Europe. The White House said it liked the idea if it meant the administration would have more flexibility in the way the United States dispenses foreign aid. To the surprise of the administration, Ortega was defeated in Sunday's presidential election by opposition newspaper publisher Violeta Chamorro, who was backed by the United States. The vote sets the stage for the first democratic transfer of power ever in Nicaragua, with Mrs. Chamorro taking office April 25 from Ortega's revolutionary government. Mrs. Chamorro's chief economic adviser, Francisco Mayorga, will arrive in Washington next Monday to discuss with U.S. officials American economic cooperation with Nicaragua, Assistant Secretary of State Bernard Aronson announced. Bush summoned congressional leaders to the White House to chart a new strategy for dealing with a country viewed for a decade as a U.S. adversary. ``The president indicated that there would be a dramatic and swift change in policy,'' said Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., the assistant Democratic leader, after meeting with Bush. ``What we can do in terms of aid depends upon what Congress can find, along with the administration, in a very tight budget situation.'' Without providing a figure, White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater promised that U.S. assistance would be substantial. ``The United States' commitment is strong and enduring,'' Fitzwater said. ``We will develop an aid package for Nicaragua that will be significant and meaningful. The democratic aspirations of the Nicaraguan people deserve our support and they will have it.'' Fitzwater said the United States was examining ``the full range of economic options aimed at reintegrating Nicaragua into the international economy.'' He said Bush would discuss Nicaragua's needs this weekend at a meeting with Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, whose country has become the world's largest donor of foreign aid. Nunn also said U.S. aid for emerging democracies should be sizable. ``After all, we spent trillions and trillions of dollars, hundreds of billions of dollars, defending the free world waiting for this day, and now that we've arrived at this day, I think we should not be shortsighted in our approach,'' Nunn said. However, Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., said he was ``frightened again that we're watching expectations exceed reality'' on the question of U.S. aid. ``I see no political will to enlarge'' the foreign aid budget, Dodd said. Rather than emphasizing direct cash aid, the United States should emphasize trade benefits it can provide by buying more coffee and sugar from Nicaragua, and the reduction of foreign debts, he said. And Congress may well pay for part of the new U.S. obligation to Nicaragua by diverting part of the $500 million in cash the Bush administration will be seeking to help rebuild Panama's economy, he said. In a message that seemed primarily aimed at the Contra rebels long supported by the Reagan and Bush administrations, Fitzwater urged restraint in the post-election period. He reiterated a U.S. call that there be an immediate cease-fire ``under U.N. supervision and that it be strictly respected by all sides.'' ``We have always anticipated that the resistance would demobilize and repatriate under conditions of political freedom and personal security,'' Fitzwater said. In contrast to the skepticism the White House has applied to statements by Ortega, the administration appeared eager to accept his promise of a smooth transition of power. ``We have the words of President Ortega about wanting a peaceful and effective transition, and we fully expect that to occur,'' Fitzwater said. At the State Department, spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said that prior suggestions of Sandinista unwillingness to turn over power were made in the heat of the campaign and that, so far as the administration knows, no such statements have been made since the elections. Fitzwater said the administration would respond to the changes in Nicaragua's government with a series of steps designed to normalize relations. ``We intend to lift economic sanctions soon,'' he said, referring to a series of economic and trade sanctions in place since 1985. Fitzwater also said that ``we would expect to return an ambassador there'' and that ``we are looking at U.S. economic assistance.'' Although the United States has continued to maintain formal diplomatic relations with Nicaragua, there has not been a U.S. ambassador in Managua since 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Veteran Newsman in Canada, U.S. Dead
DOC.TEXT: Jim Rennie, a former Toronto Star editor whose three decades in journalism took him to newspapers in Canada and the United States, died following a car accident. He was 49. Rennie was driving to his cottage northeast of Peterborough on Monday when his car went out of control near that city, flipped over a median and skidded into a guardrail. He died later at a hospital. ``Jim was a suberb newspaperman,'' said Star editor John Honderich. ``His drive, his instincts and his ability to go after the big story were absolutely first-rate. He knew how to get a newsroom going.'' Born James Samuel Rennie in Glasgow, Scotland, he came to Canada when he was 11 and grew up in Norwich, Ontario. After working for The Windsor Star and the Examiner in Barrie, he joined the Toronto Telegram in 1963 and later became assistant city editor. He then became executive editor of the Ottawa Journal and worked there until the paper ceased publication in August 1980. Rennie then became managing editor of the Seattle Post-Intelligencer before rejoining the Star in 1986. In two stints at the Star, he worked as assistant city editor, entertainment editor, national editor, news editor, city editor and assistant managing editor. He twice served as deputy managing editor of the Star, leaving the paper just last month. He is survived by his wife Sandra and son David of Seattle.

DOC.HEAD: Authority Of Nation's Pension Insurance Agency Is Tested In Court
DOC.TEXT: The nation's pension insurance agency urged the Supreme Court Tuesday to leave intact its ability to prevent companies from abandoning responsbility for worker benefits. The high court heard oral arguments in a case seen by the Bush administration as an important test of the authority of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, a government corporation that insures the pensions of 30 million Americans. At issue is whether LTV Steel Co. will succeed in dumping billions of dollars in pension costs onto PBGC, The court must decide whether PBGC acted properly in ordering LTV Steel, a subsidiary of Dallas-based LTV Corp., to reassume responsibility for three pension plans. The vastly underfunded plans were taken over by the pension agency after LTV Corp. sought protection from creditors under Chapter 11 bankruptcy laws in 1986. But PBGC attorney Carol Connor Flowe told the court Tuesday that the agency sought to turn the plans back to LTV because the company's financial conditions improved, and because the firm entered into a ``follow-on'' arrangement with workers. Under the arrangement, LTV and the United Steelworkers of America agreed that the firm would make up the difference of any benefits lost to employees because of the pension terminations. The idea was that the PBGC would pay basic pension benefits to the workers, while the ailing firm would kick in supplemental benefits _ $400 per month, in many cases _ not covered by the government plan. But Flowe said such a follow-on arrangement represented an ``abuse'' of the pension insurance program. Under questioning by Justice Sandra Day O'Connor about PBGC's authority, Flowe said LTV's follow-on deal and its improved economic state by August 1987 each were independent grounds for turning the pension plans back to the company. Congress, Flowe said, provided PBGC with broad powers to restore terminated plans in 1974 by passing the Employee Retirement Income Security Act, or ERISA. ``What Congress said was that PBGC should make this determination,'' Flowe said. At issue, she said, was PBGC's right to discourage ``unwarranted terminations'' of pension plans by firms eager to gain a competitive advantage. But LTV attorney Lewis B. Kaden argued that the agency's action was at odds with the 1974 federal law, which he said was designed to protect pensioners' rights. He said PBGC wrongly determined that LTV could afford the previously terminated plans. ``In order to return all these plans, you have to answer the fundamental question, which is, `Can the company afford it?' '' Kaden said. If the plans are turned back, at least one them would likely have to be terminated a second time because it has no assets, he said. ``That kind of ping-pong effect could not have been contemplated by the drafters of ERISA,'' he said. A federal judge threw out the PBGC's order for restoration of the plans, and the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld that ruling last May 12. The PBGC already has a more than $1 billion deficit and says the LTV claims would more than double that figure. Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole says the case ``will have far-reaching ramifications for the retirement security of workers and pensioners'' across the country. The court is expected to rule by July. The case is PBGC vs. LTV, 89-390.

DOC.HEAD: American in Solitary Confinement, Lawyer Says
DOC.TEXT: An American member of a mysterious Hindu cult has been held in virtual solitary confinement since her detainment last month by the Communist-governed West Bengal state, her lawyer said Tuesday. Patricia Munday, 38, of Vermont, is not receiving the necessary medical treatment, according to a petition filed in West Bengal Court by her attorney, Bholanath Sen. Her hometown was not immediately known. ``West Bengal government does not believe in individual liberty,'' the lawyer said. Munday was detained by the West Bengal police Jan. 27, apparently for her links with a cult called the Anand Marg, or the Path of Bliss. The governing Communist coalition is opposed to the cult. Munday is being held in a private hospital in Calcutta, the capital. She is guarded by police and journalists are not allowed to see her. The petition asks that she be moved to a hospital in New Delhi. The habeas corpus petition was filed after the Indian Supreme Court on Friday ordered the government not to deport her. She had appealed to the Supreme Court to secure her release. Habeas corpus requires a person in custody be brought before a court. It places the burden of proof on those detaining the person to justify the action. ``Ms. Munday has been kept in virtual solitary confinement. ... She needs better medical treatment, her injuries are yet to heal,'' Sen said. West Bengal's advocate general, Naranarayan Goopu, said there was no need for the court to act on the petition because a similar writ is pending before the Supreme Court and will be heard Friday. Gooptu denied Munday is being held in solitary confinement, telling the court that police ``have only restricted her movement.'' Munday, a member of the United Nations team that won the 1981 Nobel peace prize for its work with refugees in Somalia, arrived in India from Katmandu, Nepal, on a private visit. A mob attacked her and an associate on Jan. 26 when they were traveling on a motorcycle near the Anand Marg headquarters in West Bengal's Purulia district. Munday suffered head injuries. The Purulia police, instead of lodging her complaint, detained her the next day. She later was moved to the hospital in Calcutta. The Anand Marg says it aims to create a social, economic and spiritual order that will replace both capitalism and communism. It claims to have branches worldwide.

DOC.HEAD: District Of Columbia Decides To Have `Shadow' Congressional Delegation
DOC.TEXT: The District of Columbia Council on Tuesday decided to allow elections of a ``shadow'' congressional delegation to lobby Capitol Hill for district statehood but declined to provide money for the positions. The action came about one week after a committee voted to postpone the elections indefinitely, which are scheduled for the fall. The full council has voted three times previously to postpone the election of ``shadow'' senators and a ``shadow'' representative after the city's voters approved the lobbying effort in a 1980 referendum. The unofficial ``shadow'' delegation would have no voting rights. The concept was first used by officials from the Tennessee territory prior to its admission to the union in 1796. The group's only official duty would be to encourage Congress to adopt legislation making the nation's capital the 51st state. ``This is a major victory for us,'' said Dee Hunter, director of the Rainbow Coalition's D.C. Statehood office. ``Even without the funding right now, this will allow the education process _ of city voters and those around the country _ to begin.'' Council members said they did not want to include language providing public money for the positions out of concern for the city's budget problems and fears that Congress might block the funds when it acts on the D.C. appropriations bill later this year. The measure, however, left open the possibility that money could be provided later this month as the the council continues deliberations on Mayor Marion Barry's $4 billion budget plan. Barry's budget includes $400,000 for the posts. The council defeated an amendment that would have permanently barred the city from using city money to pay for them. Several members said use of private funds remained under consideration. Last fall, the Senate voted 98-2 to shift $150,000 from a city statehood lobbying commission to anti-drug programs after Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., criticized the statehood lobbying effort as wasteful and irrelevant.

DOC.HEAD: Estimates Up
DOC.TEXT: U.S. agricultural exports should total $38.5 billion this fiscal year, up $500 million from estimates made last fall, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. But the new forecast for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1 still represents a 3 percent decline from an eight-year high of $39.7 billion in the previous fiscal year. The record was $43.8 billion in 1981. ``The upward revision (from November) largely reflected a 3-million-ton increase in expected U.S. coarse grain exports,'' the report said. ``Prospects for foreign coarse grain imports have increased, and U.S. corn is expected to capture a larger share.'' Overall, exports this fiscal year were forecast at 148.5 million metric tons, up 3 million tons from November and nearly 2 million tons more than in 1989. The decline in value was blamed on ``lower prices for grains and oilseeds,'' which more than offset the larger export volume. Estimates of agricultural imports were raised $500 million to $21.5 billion, matching last year's record. ``December's severe freeze in Florida and Texas has increased prospects for fruit, juice and vegetable imports,'' the report said.

DOC.HEAD: `It's Garry Shandling's Show' to End Production
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting a0674 to CORRECT cycle designator.
DOC.TEXT: ``It's Garry Shandling's Show,'' the self-deprecating situation comedy seen on Showtime and the Fox network, will stop production this spring, the series' star announced Tuesday. ``This show has required a tremendous amount of time and creative energy from everyone associated with it,'' Shandling said in a statement. ``As a result, it's been very difficult to do anything else. ``I'm ready to explore new directions in my career and our writing staff, which is very talented, would like to do new projects as well.'' The show will tape a special final episode that will be shown later this spring. The program, featuring Shandling narrating fictional developments in his personal life, premiered in 1986. It has won a variety of awards, including a 1989 Ace award for cable's best comedy series. It finished in last place in the A.C. Nielsen Co.'s prime-time ratings for last week.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Clears State Child Care Worker
DOC.TEXT: A judge on Tuesday ordered the acquittal of a Florida social worker accused of failing to report suspected abuse in the weeks before a 2-year-old boy was fatally punished for soiling his pants. ``No reasonable jury could reach any other verdict than for acquittal,'' Polk County Judge Jesse Barber said in ordering charges dismissed against social worker Kenneth Houk. The child, Bradley McGee, died from head injuries last July 28 after being repeatedly thrust headfirst into a toilet for soiling his pants, authorities said. Houk, 39, was the first of three Florida Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services workers to be tried over the child's death. The misdemeanor charge carried a maximum penalty of 60 days in jail. ``It's over,'' Houk said as he left court. ``All I want to do now is get back to work and get back to my family.'' Prosecutors contended Houk twice failed to notify the state child abuse registry after receiving reports about McGee. The last call came only weeks before the child died. Bradley's mother, Sheryl McGee Coe, 21, and stepfather, Thomas Coe, 22, go on trial this summer in Fort Lauderdale on charges of first-degree murder and aggravated child abuse. The child was abandoned at a shopping mall when he was 3 months old and lived most of his short life in foster care until the state gave him back to his mother and stepfather two months before his death. The judge's ruling came two hours into the first day of trial, before the defense began presenting testimony. As soon as the state rested its case, defense attorney Jack Wilkins moved for a directed verdict. ``Hopefully this will lead to a different wording of the law,'' Wilkins said. `` ... People who work for HRS must be given the freedom to make judgment calls.'' Prosecutors maintained Houk got a call in December 1988 that Mrs. Coe was unfit because she was drinking and using cocaine. Then, a few weeks before Bradley's death, he received another call that Mrs. Coe had forced the child to eat feces as punishment for violating potty training, the state said. Theresa Jacobs, a key state witness who originally reported the feces complaint, told the jury Houk had urged her numerous times to telephone the child abuse registry when she had something to report. She said she didn't follow his advice. ``He had told me before to call the registry, but I never got any satisfaction from the registry,'' Ms. Jacobs testified. ``I didn't see him eat feces. I didn't see the bruises.'' Caseworker Judy Ross was called by the state to confirm reports that she relayed the feces complaint to Houk and that Houk failed to call the abuse registry as required. But on the stand, she waivered when asked if she even thought such a secondhand report warranted a call to the HRS hotline. ``I don't think I would know enough at that point to make a report,'' she said. Caseworkers Margaret Barber and Shirley Duboise also are charged with failing to report child abuse. Ms. Barber, who had been assigned the Bradley case, faces an additional charge of felony child abuse, which carries a maximum penalty of five years in prison.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Restates U.S. Opposition to Shifting German-Polish Border
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Tuesday reiterated U.S. opposition to any plan to shift the German-Polish border as the visiting mayor of West Berlin criticized West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl for not offering Poland a similar assurance. Bush told congressional leaders that ``we have an unequivocal position that the borders should remain as they are,'' said Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga. and one of those who met with the president. Bush's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said the president ``simply pointed out that our position is firm and that he made that known to Chancellor Kohl.'' Bush, who met with Kohl last weekend, told reporters at a joint news conference Sunday that the United States formally recognizes the German-Polish border and, under international accords, regards all European borders as inviolable. Kohl acknowledged Polish anxiety on the issue and said, ``Nobody has any intention of linking the question of national unity with changes of existing border.'' But he said he could not speak for a new, united Germany. ``The border question will be settled definitely by a freely-elected all-German government and ... parliament,'' Kohl told the reporters. On Tuesday, Bush met with West Berlin Mayor Walter Momper, who later said Kohl should have ``said that he and the Federal Republic wants to guarantee the western borders of Poland.'' ``Nobody in Germany ... (wants) to change the borders,'' and Kohl failed to make that clear, said Momper, a member of the liberal Social Democrat opposition to Kohl's ruling Christian Democratic Party. Nunn agreed. ``I am personally disappointed that the chancellor has not been clearer in this respect,'' said Nunn, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee. ``I know there are election considerations (in West Germany), but this is a matter of tremendous sensitivity not only to the Polish people but also to all of Europe.'' ``It just makes a lot of people more nervous than they would otherwise be,'' added Nunn. The current German-Polish border follows the Oder and Neisse rivers. After World War II, Poland's borders were shifted westward, with the Soviet Union incorporating eastern parts of Poland and the Poles taking eastern parts of what was then Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Pilot Killed in Ocean Crash
DOC.TEXT: The son of silent film star Wallace Reid was killed when his single-engine plane crashed into the Pacific Ocean a mile off the Santa Monica Pier. Bill Reid, 72, of Los Angeles, was killed Monday when the Long-EZ, a type of home-built aircraft designed by Burt Rutan, went down in heavy fog, authorities said. Reid's father made his film debut in 1910, quickly going on to become one of the silent movie era's biggest stars. His career was cut short in 1919 when he was injured in a train crash and became addicted to the morphine doctors administered as a pain killer. He died in 1923 at age 32. The plane crashed shortly after takeoff from Santa Monica Airport early Monday, and authorities said Reid was flying solo. The cause of the crash was under investigation by the Federal Aviation Administration. Lifeguard Capt. Don Rohrer said visibility in the area was about three-quarters of a mile. The Long-EZ craft Reid was flying is constructed mainly of Styrofoam, epoxy, B1 fiberglass and plastics and is tailless and has a rear-facing engine. Owners and flight instructors have described it as fuel-efficient and nearly stall-proof. Rutan also designed the Voyager plane that circumnavigated the Earth in 1986 on a single tank of fuel and a new low-cost attack plane called the Ares that he rolled out Monday. However, Rutan stopped selling Long-EZ kits in 1985, citing liability concerns. Planes have since been built from plans obtained from previous builders, but authorities said it wasn't immediately known if Reid's plane was an original or a later copy.

DOC.HEAD: Animal Rights Groups Criticize Investigators
DOC.TEXT: Animal rights organizations are criticizing authorities for issuing an alert that militant animal activists may have been involved in the slaying of a veterinary school dean. ``The whole thing is so preposterous,'' said Siriol Evans, spokeswoman for the 280,000-member People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals organization in Washington, D.C. ``Unfortunately, somebody is taking this tragic event and trying to turn it into a press opportunity against animal rights,'' she said Monday. The Knox County Sheriff's Department alerted law enforcement agencies across the country last week through the National Crime Information Center computer about rumors that militant animal rights activists might be planning to kill a veterinarian school dean each month for a year. The advisory followed the Feb. 8 slaying of Hyram Kitchen, dean of the University of Tennessee College of Veterinary Medicine. Kitchen, 57, was gunned down in the driveway of his home by an unknown assailant. Lt. Larry Johnson, a homicide detective investigating the slaying, said the alert was based on information that ``was third hand and was unconfirmed by our investigation.'' It was intended for law enforcement use only, and not aimed at frightening veterinary school deans elsewhere or accusing anyone unjustly, he said. ``We put it out for only one reason: we didn't want to sit on anything,'' Johnson said. The matter has been ``blown out of context,'' he said. ``The proverbial mole hill has turned into the mountain.'' But animal rights groups were not appeased. ``I think it's incredibly irresponsible to name a group of people whose philosophy is non-violent as suspects simply because the Knox County Sheriff's Department is stumped,'' said Helen Mitternight of the Washington-based Humane Society of the United States. ``The whole thing seems quite ridiculous because that type of action is completely against everything the animal rights movement stands for,'' echoed Ms. Evans. Johnson said he heard from some animal rights groups Monday. ``Just the peaceful ones, who aren't so peaceful right now,'' he said, adding that because of the flap he worried that ``my dog might bite me when I go home.'' Johnson said he also talked with law enforcement agencies from California to New York. ``I have not come up with any other incidents since Dr. Kitchen's death or even before Dr. Kitchen's death that was as violent as this,'' he said. Johnson would not say where the animal-rights threat started, but he mentioned three letters sent to people connected with the university since Kitchen's death. Authorities have dismissed those as the work of pranksters. Local news media also have recalled the controversy that Kitchen became involved in when the neighboring Loudon County Commission agreed in 1988 to sell pound animals to the university for experiments. Kitchen defended the practice as furthering the university's study of human diseases. Animal rights activists objected, saying the stray dogs and cats might have become family pets. Nancy Howell, a spokeswoman for the veterinary school, said the university stopped buying animals from Loudon County and never heard another word from animal rights activists. As far as finding a suspect, much less a motive, for Kitchen's killing, Johnson said: ``We have eliminated some possibilities, but by the same token we have uncovered other possibilities. Just things we are not at liberty to elaborate on.''

DOC.HEAD: Havel Suggests Dubcek be Invited to Visit the Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovakia's president suggested Tuesday a visit to Moscow by Alexander Dubcek, the Communist Party chief whose liberal ``Prague Spring'' was crushed by the Red Army a generation before Gorbachev's reforms. In a meeting with Soviet lawmakers, President Vaclav Havel said it could be part of an exchange of parliamentary delegations, with the Czechoslovak group led by Dubcek, who now is president of Parliament. As Communist Party chief in 1968, Dubcek introduced reforms offensive to the Kremlin, which opposed liberalization until Mikhail S. Gorbachev became its leader in 1985. Soviet tanks rolled into Prague in August. Earlier Tuesday, Havel paid homage to human rights activist Andrei Sakharov, whom the official news agency Tass described as one of the few Soviets to openly welcome the ``Prague Spring'' and denounce the invasion. Dubcek's last two official visits to Moscow were humiliating. The first time, he was a prisoner days after the invasion and on the second, two months later, he signed an agreement allowing Soviet troops to stay in his country indefinitely and providing for a return to hard-line rule. He was dismissed as party chief in 1969 and languished in obscurity until Czechoslovakia's peaceful revolution broke the Communist grip on power last fall. Havel met with President Gorbachev on Monday and said they had agreed all 73,500 Red Army soldiers would leave Czechoslovakia by July 1, 1991, and might be gone sooner. Tass said the first train carrying troops and armor out of Czechoslovakia crossed into the Soviet Union on Tuesday afternoon. Sakharov, a fearless campaigner for human rights and reform, did not live to see Havel, a playwright scorned and jailed by the Communists, become president of Czechoslovakia. Havel went to the grave with Sakharov's widow, Yelena Bonner, and added flowers to mounds of others left by ordinary Soviet citizens who visit the grave. After the visit with members of the Soviet parliament's Foreign Affairs Committee, Havel walked across Red Square, surrounded by security guards, to the spot where eight Soviet citizens were arrested while protesting the invasion Aug. 25, 1968. He arrived Monday, three days after returning from meetings in the United States with President Bush. Tass said Gorbachev had accepted an invitation to visit Czechoslovakia. His last visit was in April 1987, when dissidents like Havel were either constantly harassed or in jail. On Monday, Havel and Gorbachev signed a joint declaration the Czechoslovak leader said would open the way to a new kind of cooperation between the two nations. It calls for relations to be developed ``on the basis of equality and complete mutual respect for each other's state sovereignty,'' according to a text carried by Tass.

DOC.HEAD: Precede LOS ANGELES
Judge Fines Anti-Abortion Group $450,000 For Contempt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with contempt of court fines against Operation Rescue in New York, background on group's finances. No pick up.
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Tuesday fined the anti-abortion group Operation Rescue, its founder and 10 protesters $450,000 for violating court orders against blocking entrances to abortion clinics. The contempt fines from U.S. District Judge Robert Ward came in a lawsuit filed by pro-choice groups over anti-abortion demonstrations in New York in 1988 and 1989. In Los Angeles, 15 members of the group were convicted Monday after a week-long trial on misdemeanor charges stemming from a demonstration at a family planning clinic last March. They face up to one year in jail and a $1,000 fine. Ward said in his ruling that the defendants in New York, including Operation Rescue founder Randall Terry, knew what to expect when they violated court orders against blocking clinic doors. Wendy Wright, an Operation Rescue spokeswoman, said she had no immediate comment on the fines. A telephone call Tuesday to the group's lawyer, A. Lawrence Washburn, was not returned. Ward's ruling stemmed from a lawsuit brought by the National Organization for Women and other abortion-rights groups against Operation Rescue and Terry. Mary M. Gundrum, a lawyer with the Center for Constitutional Rights who worked with NOW on the lawsuit, said the contempt actions were pursued to ``give fair warning to those persons and groups that the court will proceed to fine them if they violate the constitutional rights of women.'' Ward fined Operation Rescue and Terry $100,000. The remaining $350,000 in fines were against a local chapter of the group and 10 leaders and participants in demonstrations. The judge also ordered the defendants pay the plaintiffs' attorney fees, which had not yet been calculated. Terry and four others were acquitted in Los Angeles last year of several misdemeanor charges stemming from a protest there. Terry and two other defendants face retrial on conspiracy charges on which jurors deadlocked. Legal challenges to Operation Rescue tactics of staging clinic demonstrations around the country have left the organization so far in debt that it announced Jan. 31 it would close its national headquarters in Binghamton.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats And Republicans Clash Over Campaign Finance Reform
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers fighting a perception they can be bought through campaign gifts clashed Tuesday over how to clean up election financing without yielding an advantage to their opponents. Testifying before the Senate Rules Committee on campaign finance reform legislation it will begin writing next week, Republicans continued to oppose spending ceilings wanted by Democrats to dilute the GOP's superiority in raising funds through direct mail solicitations. Democrats lashed out at President Bush's proposals to outlaw corporation, labor union and trade association political action committees or PACs and prevent lawmakers from using their campaign kitties to help defray office expenses. ``You are meddling a little bit in the way we run our offices,'' the panel's chairman, Sen. Wendell Ford, D-Ky., told Assistant Attorney General William Barr, the administration's chief witness. Ford complained Bush's proposal would allow lawmakers to augment their office expenses with money from Senate party campaign committee accounts where Republicans enjoyed a 5-1 fund-raising advantage in the 1988 election. ``And now you want to use that money to beat us over the head,'' he said. As an alternative to taxpayer financing of elections long sought by Democrats and opposed by Republicans, Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., suggested a public financing scheme using voluntary $1-a-month contributions through the payroll tax withholding system. ``So long as our elected representatives must depend on private contributions to be viable candidates, our political system will be suspect,'' Cranston said. Cranston is one of the ``Keating Five'' senators now under investigation by the Senate Ethics Committee for intervening with federal thrift regulators in 1987 on behalf of the now collapsed Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif., and its owner, Charles H. Keating Jr. A Phoenix millionaire, Keating had raised more than $1.3 million for the political campaigns and causes of the senators, including nearly $1 million funneled to groups associated with Cranston. Meanwhile, freshmen Sens. Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., and Harry Reid, D-Nev., found little support for their bipartisan compromise that avoids the spending ceiling issue, curbs but does not outlaw PACs and gives the Federal Election Commission more enforcement powers. ``This `all or nothing' attitude on both sides solves absolutely nothing,'' Reid said. ``If we can't agree on PACs and spending limits, lets us at least reach a bipartisan accord on these other issues.'' Other Democrats, however, said they are unwilling to curb the growing influence of PACs without restrictions on overall spending. ``Only in a coordinated package of general restraint on campaign expenditures do I think that it makes sense to have limits on PACs,'' House Speaker Thomas S. Foley told reporters. ``Without campaign spending limits, there can be no reform worthy of the name.'' Foley said he would meet later this week with House Republican Leader Robert H. Michel of Illinois, who in December said for the first time that he was willing to consider a spending cap. Since then, however, Michel has been silent on the issue while the administration and other Republican leaders have maintained their opposition to any ceiling. With or without an agreement, Foley said he will bring a bill to the House floor in April. Ford said the Senate Rules Committee would begin writing a bill next week using as a foundation a bill by Senate Democratic leader George Mitchell of Maine and Sens. David Boren, D-Okla., and Robert C. Byrd, D-W.Va. That bill would provide ``voluntary'' general election spending ceilings ranging from $950,000 to $5.5 million depending on a state's population. Various carrots and sticks to achieve compliance are still being negotiated behind the scenes. The most likely is a combination of discount mail and television advertising rates for candidates who spend under the limit.

DOC.HEAD: Chill Remains Over The Northeast
DOC.TEXT: A new winter storm developed Tuesday over the southern Rockies and snow was scattered over the Northeast, where lingering cold weather produced record low temperatures. Snow fell from southern Wyoming to western Nebraska, western Kansas and northern New Mexico. Winter storm watches were posted overnight for the northeastern quarter of New Mexico. Rain extended from the rest of eastern New Mexico to western Texas. In the Northeast, snow fell across sections of northern Maine, Vermont, eastern New York state, Pennsylvania, Maryland and Delaware. Snow also fell on eastern Upper Michigan. In western Pennsylvania, Johnstown received 2 inches of snow and the Laurel Ridges got 2 to 3 inches, the National Weather Service said. Syracuse, N.Y., received 2 inches of snow during the six hours up to 1 p.m. EST. Temperatures in the East were generally milder than Monday, but enough cold air remained to drop temperatures to a record low of 2 below zero in Hartford, Conn., and a record-tying 10 degrees in Atlantic City, N.J. Elsewhere, rain fell across northern Kentucky, southern Ohio and central West Virginia. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 13 degrees at Presque Isle, Maine, to 79 at Harlingen, Texas, and Yuma, Ariz. Tuesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 29 below zero at Milo, Maine.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Won't End Debate on Armenia Genocide Resolution
DOC.TEXT: The Senate on Tuesday refused to cut off debate on a resolution designating an Armenian genocide, leaving the future of the measure up in the air. It was the second time in two weeks that Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., has tried _ and failed _ to end a filibuster against the resolution. The vote was 51-48 against Dole, who needed 60 votes to invoke cloture. Dole has pledged to keep fighting for the measure, saying he might ask for another vote to end the filibuster or introduce the resolution in a different form. The measure, which designates April 24 as ``National Day of Remembrance of the 75th anniversary of the Armenian genocide of 1915-1923,'' has created a firestorm in Turkey, which strenously objects to the use of the word genocide. Dole, who became familiar with Armenian issues when a doctor of Armenian descent treated him for injuries he received in World War II, fought strenously for the measure. He said Americans of Armenian heritage deserved to be recognized for their suffering, and called the resolution a human rights issue. On Tuesday, Dole met with a group of elderly people from New Jersey and Pennsylvania who lived through the events of the Ottoman Empire in the early 20th century. The alleged genocide occurred before the birth of the current Republic of Turkey. The Armenians claim 1.5 million were killed because of their race. But Turkish officials say there was no genocide. They say some 600,000 people, including Muslims and Christians, were killed in the turbulent times because of civil strife and marauding bands. Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., led a filibuster against the Dole resolution. He began talking against the measure last week, arguing the resolution would poison relations between the United States and Turkey, a NATO ally. The Turkish government has threatened retaliatory action against the United States if the resolution passes. If the resolution passes the Senate it would go to the House, and eventually to President Bush if both chambers approved it. The Bush administration opposed the Dole resolution, but Dole said Tuesday that White House officials would not object to softening the language and making it a so-called concurrent resolution. Bush would not have to sign such a measure.

DOC.HEAD: Safety Board Rejects Move To Reopen Kentucky School Bus Inquiry
DOC.TEXT: The National Transportation Safety Board rejected an appeal Tuesday from a Los Angeles lawyer to reopen its investigation into the Kentucky church bus crash that killed 24 children and three adults. The four-member board voted unanimously to reject a petition on behalf of Lawrence and Janey Fair, who lost their 14-year-old daughter, Shannon, in the May 14, 1988, crash. Board members said lawyer John P. Coale failed to raise any new evidence related to the crash. The board, completing its investigation last March, said the crash clearly was caused by a drunken pickup truck driver, but also cited characteristics of the 11-year-old former school bus as contributing to its severity. The pickup driver, Larry Mahoney, was sentenced Friday to 16 years in prison after being convicted of 27 counts each of second-degree manslaughter and first-degree wonton endangerment and one count of drunken driving. Mahoney's truck, going the wrong way on Interstate 71 near Carrollton, Ky., slammed headon into the bus, which was quickly engulfed in flames. The board, in rejecting Coale's petition, noted that it had already recommended improved standards for protecting school bus fuel systems. Coale contended that the bus involved in the accident contained significant construction and design defects that may have contributed to the puncturing of its fuel tank and the entry of smoke and fire into the passenger area. The board, in its investigation, recommended that older school buses used by churches and other groups be retired, since they do not meet stricter safety standards that have applied to school buses since 1977.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Japanese Prime Minister Will Meet This Weekend
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will try to prod Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu this week to a more conciliatory posture in so-far sluggish talks over contentious trade issues, an administration official said Tuesday. With Kaifu's recent election to the post he held on an interim basis, the Bush administration hopes he will see fit to bend his government's trade positions more to the U.S. view, said the official, who briefed reporters on Bush's upcoming meeting with Kaifu. Kaifu is flying to California at Bush's invitation, for talks Friday and Saturday in Palm Springs. The official said the meeting was conceived to address a wide-ranging set of bilateral issues and the future ``global partnership'' of Japan and the United States. He said that the two heads of state will not conduct negotiations as such, but that part of the emphasis will be on achieving progress in the Structural Impediments Initiative Talks, which are aimed at addressing the underlying causes of Japan's persistently huge trade imbalance with the United States. The talks on reducing the $49 billion trade imbalance between the two countries ended Friday with few signs of progress and ample evidence of mutual frustration. U.S. officials conceded frustration and concern, while the Japanese said the administration had demands more severe than Tokyo had anticipated. The administration contends that because of Japan's focus on its recent election campaign, which returned the ruling Liberal Democratic Party to power, the political prodding needed to move the SII talks beyond such roadblocks was missing. ``The SII exchanges have been at the technical level,'' the official said Tuesday. The SII talks are to produce an interim report by April and a final report in July. The administration looked for bolder reform proposals from Japan after the most recent SII round was postponed for more than a month for Japan's national parliamentary election. Bush also will discuss with Kaifu the prospect of Japanese aid to help the beleaguered Nicaraguan economy now that its elections have concluded with the U.S.-backed Violeta Chamorro as the new president, said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Appointed to Investigate Explosion
DOC.TEXT: European space authorities named a seven-member panel Tuesday to investigate last week's explosion of an Ariane rocket carrying two Japanese telecommunications satellites. Preliminary results of the inquiry will be submitted to the European Space Agency (ESA) and Arianespace on March 20, the two organizations said in a joint press statement. Jacques Durand, the French director of the Ariane 5 program, will preside over the committee composed of West German, Belgian, Italian and French aerospace experts. The panel is also charged with recommending ways to prevent future accidents. Its findings will not be made public before the reports are handed to the ESA and Arianespace, the statement said. Frederic D'Allest, president of Arianespace, has said the findings of the panel should help reassure customers of Ariane's reliability despite Thursday's failure. The 44-L rocket experienced a loss in power in a booster just after lifting off from the Ariane launch pad in Kourou, French Guiana. Technicians were unable to control the rocket and were eventually forced to abandon the mission. The vehicle blew apart over the Atlantic Ocean 1 minute, 41 seconds into flight, the first failure in an Ariane flight since 1986 and the fifth in 36 missions. The two Japanese satellites were valued by one of the companies, the Mitsubishi subsidiary Space Communications Corp., at more than $600 million. Flights of the unmanned Ariane rockets had become almost routine, with the European consortium capturing more than 50 percent of the world's lucrative satellite launch business. Analysts have said Arianespace, the commercial operation that runs the program for the ESA, must solve the problem quickly to avoid a loss in customer confidence.

DOC.HEAD: Businessmen Ready to Change Economy, Hope for Better Times
With AM-Nicaragua, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Seven years ago, Ramiro Gurdian says, he was threatened with death for criticizing the Sandinista government. His ranch, Candelaria, the biggest banana plantation in Nicaragua, was summarily confiscated. Now that the Sandinistas and President Daniel Ortega have been thrashed at the polls, losing by a widespread margin in Sunday's general elections to opposition leader Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, Gurdian wants Candelaria back. But for now he's hoping for a peaceful transition of power to the United National Opposition alliance headed by Mrs. Chamorro. ``Our position is we have to have a society where all Nicaraguans have space to live,'' said Gurdian. ``We have to respect the loser and his rights.'' As president of the Nicaraguan Union of Agriculture and Cattle Producers and vice president of the Superior Council of Private Enterprise _ the two most important private business groups in Nicaragua _ Gurdian was among those who drafted UNO's economic program. It calls for reprivatizing scores of companies that were confiscated by the Sandinistas, and have become bloated with state workers and inefficient through government intervention. It also calls for returning confiscated lands without harming the thousands of peasant families that benefited from the Sandinista agrarian reform _ which may be a tricky process. Businessmen say they know that political stability is essential for renewed economic activity. The Sandinistas, who will form a strong and cohesive minority in the National Assembly, may fight many of the new government's moves, and government workers already fear losing their jobs. ``If UNO decides to privatize the banking system it could be an irresponsible act that starts a war,'' said Rafael Solis, a Sandinista military commander. Negotiations between Sandinistas and leaders of the 14-party UNO coalition have not started, said a highly placed UNO source, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``We can't push them (the Sandinistas) right now because this is a very dangerous time and they're very tense,'' said the source. ``We have to leave them alone and let them seek a path out on their own.'' UNO already has made some policy decisions. There will be no Sandinistas in the UNO cabinet, Alfredo Cesar, a top aide to president-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, told The Associated Press. Party cadres will find themselves out of work, but lower-ranking technocrats are needed for continuity, Cesar said. UNO is putting together a transition team that would include Cesar and hold conversations with the Sandinistas. Thousands of businessmen, technicians and professionals fled Nicaragua during the 10{ years of Sandinista rule. The exodus of expertise contributed to a dramatic drop in production levels; inflation also soared. But some Nicaraguans plan to return, Gurdian said. Agriculture is the backbone of Nicaragua's economy and the sowing season starts in April. ``Many coffee growers simply did not have the money to replace broken machinery or the incentives to expand production,'' said Edgar Arguello, who owns coffee plantations in central Matagalpa province. ``But now we will have more freedom to do, to plant, to expand. You'll see how production shoots up in just this first year,'' Arguello said. ``The goal is that year by year we raise production, depending on resources,'' Gurdian said. ``In three to four years, we can have production levels like those of 1978,'' the year before the Sandinistas took power. Negotiations for loans are already in the works; so are talks with U.S. agro-companies to invest in Nicaragua, Gurdian said. Construction also is expected to increase. The need for housing and for repairs to crumbling roads, communications and other infrastructure is pressing. With state controls over the marketplace loosened and with an expected lifting of the 1985 U.S. economic embargo, Nicaragua is poised to become a land of opportunity, Gurdian said. ``The people are ready,'' Gurdian said. ``All we're saying is: Well? When do we start?''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
WASHINGTON: last year.
DOC.TEXT: Thornburgh and deputies said that if Exxon is convicted on all counts, criminal fines could total as much as $1.6 million. However, the government could also seek as much as $700 million more under federal laws that allow recovery of twice the amount of the proven loss caused by the spill, U.S. Attorney Mark Davis of Alaska told a Justice Department news conference. Thornburgh said the indictment was presented to the grand jury after a proposed plea deal fell through. However, he did not rule out the possibility of a deal in the future. ``You'd have to ask the defendants,'' Thornburgh said. MORE

DOC.HEAD: White House Dismisses Report of Hostage Talks with Iranians
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New material from Arab newspaper, other material thruout
DOC.HEAD: Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: The White House on Tuesday dismissed a published report that U.S. officials had secretly discussed with Iranian representatives the release of Americans held hostage in Lebanon. ``High-level U.S. officials? Direct, secret talks? No,'' said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater when asked by reporters about the report in the London-based Arab newspaper Al-Hayat. ``Do I expect a breakthrough or anything new happening? No.'' The newspaper said that progress was being made in discussions among the United States, Iran and Syria aimed at gaining the release of foreign hostages in Lebanon. The newspaper quoted unidentified political, militia and religious sources in Beirut as saying that Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani had convinced the groups holding the 18 foreign hostages that they should be released now. At the White House, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said, ``We are not aware of the source of these stories or any talks that fit this description.'' He also said that he would not rule out ``meetings anywhere, any place, any time by anybody on the hostage question. Because there are meetings happening.'' By that, Fitzwater said he meant that the administration continues to follow leads and make contacts in its effort to secure the release of the eight American hostages. He would not be specific. Fitzwater also said that despite recent speculation on a number of fronts, the administration knows ``of no new evidence'' to support hopes that the hostages' release might be forthcoming. ``There are no direct talks between the United States and Iran authorized by the president,'' he said. ``I don't know who's talking to who. But I guarantee you I'm never going to say that nobody's talking, because I know a lot of people are.'' ``There are a lot of people around the world talking about release of the hostages in Lebanon _ people from other countries, people from other embassies, people on all levels, people we don't even find out about until after the fact,'' Fitzwater said. Al-Hayat quoted Algerian sources as saying that contacts were in place through non-diplomatic organizations and that Algeria was itself involved. Diplomatic sources in Damascus, Syria, this week confirmed that the United States had a number of channels for reaching Iranian leaders. Contacts through Geneva were one such conduit, but the United States most recently has used Syria and Japan to pass messages to Iran, said the sources, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. The sources said there was not one, specific set of negotiations under way between the United States and Iran. Al-Hayat quoted the leading Shiite Moslem cleric in Lebanon, Sheik Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, as saying that he supported ending the hostage crisis, ``and I bring it up in every possible occasion because I do not believe in it from the begining.'' An editor at the newspaper said Fadlallah, spiritual leader of the Iranian-financed Hezbollah, or Party of God, confirmed that the United States and Iran were in contact through third parties. Some Western hostages are believed held by factions linked to Hezbollah. The Lebanese hostages include eight Americans, four Britons, an Italian, an Irishman, two West Germans and two Swiss. The longest-held is 42-year-old Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press when kidnapped in March 1985. In London, Anderson's sister, Peggy Say, said of the latest reports, ``I think there have been many, many positive signals being sent and this is one of them.'' The other Americans are Thomas Sutherland, Frank Herbert Reed, Joseph James Cicippio, Edward Austin Tracy, Jesse Turner, Alann Steen and Robert Polhill. Al-Hayat said the discussions included the fate of four Iranians who disappeared in Lebanon in 1982 as well as the fate of hundreds of Lebanese and Palestinian prisoners held in Israel. The release of the hostages was believed hinged to a power struggle in Tehran between the pragmatists and radicals in the government. The pragmatists, seeking foreign investment to rebuild Iran's economy after eight years of war with Iraq, are viewed as trying to end the hostage issue to burnish Iran's image. Two Tehran newspapers said in editorials this week that the hostages in Lebanon should go free, and Chief Justice Ayatollah Mohammed Yazdi said that Iran opposed taking hostages.

DOC.HEAD: Court Hears Arguments on Doctor Who Refused to Treat AIDS Patient
DOC.TEXT: An appellate court considering a lawsuit against a doctor who refused to treat an AIDS patient heard arguments Tuesday centering on whether a private physician's office is a ``public accommodation'' subject to anti-discrimination laws. The state Division of Human Rights has accused orthopedic surgeon Daniel Elstein of Syracuse of violating state anti-discrimination laws by refusing to treat Ronald Derby four years ago. Derby, who had been Elstein's patient since 1982, died of acquired immune deficiency syndrome last summer at age 36. He had claimed that Elstein refused to treat a back ailment in 1986 after Derby revealed he had AIDS. The doctor claims he did not treat Derby because he was not specially trained to treat AIDS, and instead referred him to an AIDS clinic. A similar case against a dentist was argued before an appeals court in New York City two weeks ago. The central issue in the Elstein lawsuit is whether a doctor's office is a ``place of public accommodation'' as defined in New York state's anti-discrimination laws. The Division of Human Rights, backed by a coalition of state civil rights and AIDS rights groups, argued that a doctor's office meets the definition. The law was intended to prohibit discrimination by doctors and other medical professionals in providing medical services, said Albert J. Kostelny, an attorney for the human rights agency. Elstein ``did not restrict his practice in any way except to exclude those afflicted with AIDS,'' Kostelny said. Elstein, whose case is supported by the state medical and dental societies, argued that a doctor's office is private and not subject to the agency's rulings. A state judge agreed with Elstein in 1988, ruling that a physician's office is ``distinctly private.'' The Division of Human Rights appealed to the court's Appellate Division. The agency argued that allowing private physicians to refuse treatment to AIDS patients would force them to seek care at public hospitals and clinics and ``force a collapse of the entire public health system in New York State under the sheer weight of the numbers of actual and suspected AIDS patients.'' In New York, which has a high concentration of the nation's AIDS cases, it is especially urgent that physicians not be allowed to discriminate on the basis of whether a patient has the disease, Kostelny argued in his brief. But Elstein's attorney, Catherine A. Gale, said the case is not about whether doctors should treat AIDS patients. Elstein referred Derby to the AIDS clinic rather than treating him ``based on medical considerations,'' not because he didn't want to treat an AIDS patient, she said.
