Deciding whether to treat a patient or to refer him to a specialist is ``clearly a matter of professional judgment,'' Gale's brief said. ``A lay body, such as the state Human Rights division, is not competent to address issues involving the practice of medicine.'' In a friend-of-the-court brief, the state medical society said that while no patient should be refused treatment simply because of AIDS, an agency of non-medical professionals should not intrude on physicians' autonomy. Gale said a more appropriate forum for such cases would be the state Health Department's Office of Professional Medical Conduct, whose board includes medical professionals. A complaint about Elstein's refusal to treat Derby was lodged with the medical conduct board, but an investigation found insufficient evidence to take action or hold a formal hearing, a spokeswoman for the office said. The appeals court is not expected to issue a decision for at least six weeks, Gale said.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Thanks Zambia for Being Host to ANC Exile Headquarters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To ADD that Yasser Arafat and other world figures greeted Mandela, INSERT 2 grafs after 7th pvs bgng, `Zambia has...' Pickup 8th pvs, `After his...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LUS1
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela embraced exiled African National Congress leaders and seven African presidents Tuesday and thanked Zambia ``from the bottom of my heart'' for providing the ANC a headquarters in exile. Tens of thousands of Zambians thronged the streets to welcome the 71-year-old South African black leader, who was released Feb. 11 after 27 years in prison. At a state banquet given by President Kenneth Kaunda for 380 guests, Mandela praised black African leaders for supporting the ANC, and singled out Kaunda as ``one of the greatest heroes, not only of Africa, but of humankind.'' South Africa legalized the African National Congress, the main organization fighting white supremacy, and dozens of other anti-apartheid groups early in February, before Mandela was released. Mandela said Kaunda gave unreserved support to the struggle of South Africa's black majority for freedom and political rights. ``From the bottom of my heart, I say thank you for all you have done and are doing for us,'' he told the president. ``I doubt if I will ever forget my first day in Zambia.'' Zambia has provided an exile headquarters to the African National Congress, which Mandela led before his imprisonment, for nearly two decades. Mandela was met at the airport by Kaunda and other African leaders and world figures, including Yasser Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, and Canada's external affairs minister, Joe Clark. Mandela and Arafat embraced, and Mandela later compared the ANC to the PLO, saying both were fighting a special brand of colonialism. After his arrival, children of ANC exiles put garlands of red and white flowers on Mandela, to the beat of drums, as dozens of guerrillas in green military fatigues looked on. Kaunda, 64, current chairman of the six-member group of ``front-line'' African nations bordering South Africa, saw Mandela last at a meeting of black nationalists in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, in 1962. At the airport, Mandela said those who led the ANC in exile ``have ... directed our people to the point where we are on the verge of a breakthrough in our struggle for freedom.'' He asked that ``the international community ... provide us with capital and other resources'' to reorganize the ANC inside South Africa. Kaunda was a peacemaker who tried to persuade successive South African governments to talk with the ANC, Mandela said, and ``if we are compelled to resort to arms ... the responsibility for this lies firmly on the shoulders of the government.'' The Zambian president described Mandela as a freedom fighter and ``a truly great son of Africa.'' The crowd chanted ``One Africa, one revolution!'' Tens of thousands of people, urged to turn out by full-page ads in government-controlled newspapers, lined the 15-mile route from Lusaka airport to Kuanda's official residence. Many groups, including school children and church choirs, waited in sweltering tropical sunshine for several hours. They waved green branches, a traditional African symbol of rejoicing, in the biggest public turnout in Zambia since the visit of Pope John Paul II in May 1989. Kaunda made Tuesday a national holiday named Nelson Mandela Day and factories offices and shops were closed in Lusaka, a city of 1 million. With Mandela is a delegation of 20 African National Congress members from inside South Africa. Meetings scheduled during his six-day stay include a summit of the front-line states _ Angola, Botswana, Mozambique, Tanzania, Zambia and Zimbabwe _ and talks with several government leaders from the 49-nation Commonwealth of former British colonies.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon: Thousands of Pink Slips Could Be Coming
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lede with updated $850 million sted $700 million; SUBS 3rd graf: ``The subject,'' to conform. Though Aspin cited $700 million; Pentagon said later actual figure is $852 million
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon on Tuesday assailed a decision by House Democrats to force the military to accept more than $850 million in budget cuts that could mean the dismissal of tens of thousands of men and women by October. ``It would be devastating to our forces. It's a really terrible idea,'' complained Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams. The subject of the dispute is the Pentagon's request to Congress to avoid massive layoffs by shifting $852 million to personnel from other accounts, mostly for procurement of aircraft, vehicles and weapons. The cuts are required under the Gramm-Rudman budget cutting law. House Armed Services Committee Chairman Les Aspin, D-Wis., wrote Pentagon officials that he has reluctantly decided not to bring their request before his committee. His decision, which has the backing of House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., dooms the request, since his committee is one of four that must approve it. President Bush had the option of exempting military personnel from the Gramm-Rudman law, but he didn't. Aspin argued in a memo to committee members that while Bush's decision is painful for the military, the administration must realize that accepting the Gramm-Rudman cuts meant accepting their results. Conceding that his decision ``will cause real pain,'' Aspin wrote his colleagues, ``If we don't stand firm now, this administration will have us playing `chicken' with the budget every year, distorting the deficit reduction process and relying on us to save it from its more irresponsible excesses.'' If Congress does not allow the Pentagon to switch the money, Williams said, rough estimates show that 44,100 to 68,200 military personnel would have to be fired by Oct. 1; between 32,500 and 32,600 people would be frozen in their current jobs; 57,000 to 67,000 promotions would be delayed and 59,900 to 115,900 fewer men and women could be brought into the armed forces. Currently, there are about 2.1 million men and women in uniform. Some members of Congress argue the Bush administration brought the problem on itself. In last year's budget agreement, the administration got Congress to agree to four months' worth of automatic spending cuts under the Gramm-Rudman budget law. However, Williams argued, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney was directed by Congress in the defense spending bill to request approval of the transfer. Williams quoted the bill as saying the request should be made ``to prevent a return to the 1970s phenomenon of the `hollow' Army in which many units were substantially undermanned.'' Williams said the Pentagon has been preparing ``dramatic decreases'' in force size, but to be executed judiciously over a period of years. ``You don't simply reach in and yank out a certain number of people in the force. You have to look at the question of recruiting, people that graduate from military academies, promotions, people who rotate from one position to another, and the total size of the force. And you have to do that very carefully and deliberately,'' Williams said. ``This would have an absolutely devastating effect on our men and women in uniform, if Congress denies us the ability to reprogram money in the '90 budget in order to soften the blow of the (spending cuts) on our military personnel,'' Williams said. Aspin issued a statement saying the administration last year ``let personnel take cuts, and that made the cuts on favored weapon systems smaller. Putting weapons before people was their decision and now they're stuck with it.'' Christopher Jehn, assistant secretary of defense for force management and personnel, told the House Armed Services subcommittee on military personnel and compensation that failure of Congress to agree to shift funds would be ``a disaster.'' ``We get the hollowness and fall in readiness that the Congress itself urged us very strongly to avoid,'' Jehn said. ``This makes a pretty good case for the administration to work more closely with Congress,'' responded Rep. Marilyn Lloyd, D-Tenn. ``I suppose so,'' Jehn said. Rep. Arthur Ravenel, R-S.C., suggested that perhaps the Pentagon did not request the exemption back in August knowing that cuts in military personnel would be an emotional issue. ``There is some validity in the premise that some people have that you all sidestepped the request for exemption at that time safe in knowledge you'd be in pretty good shape politically this year with the reprogramming request,'' Ravenel said.

DOC.HEAD: Popular Front Claims Victory in Moldavian Elections
DOC.TEXT: The Popular Front of Moldavia claimed Tuesday it had won about half the settled legislative races, but runoffs will be required in nearly two-thirds of the contests. The official Tass agency quoted Vladimir Kiktenko, chairman of the Central Election Commission, as saying 139 of the 380 seats were decided in the first round of voting Sunday. Grigory Petrashko, an official of the Popular Front, said the movement won at least 65 of those and had called for recounts in some other races. He did not say how many. His organization advocates greater autonomy for Moldavia, a republic bordering Romania, with which it shares a common language and cultural heritage. Josef Stalin annexed Moldavia during World War II. Before the election, Popular Front leaders said they hoped to win about half the legislative seats. It entered candidates in about 200 of the races. Kiktenko said Sunday's vote was the first truly democratic election in the Moldavian republic's history and the turnout was about 83 percent. He said Pyotr Luchinsky, the Moldavian Communist Party chief, had 93 percent of the vote, but he did not give figures for other races. Weekend elections also were held in the Baltic republic of Lithuania, where both the Communist Party and the Sajudis popular front advocate secession from the Soviet Union, and in the Central Asian republics of Tadzhikistan and Kirghizia. Sajudis won a landslide victory in Lithuania, but most of the seats will be decided in runoffs.

DOC.HEAD: Civilians Flee Christian Enclave
DOC.TEXT: Civilians who had run out of food and water or feared new fighting between rival Christian armies fled into the Moslem part of the city Tuesday, police reported. Sniper fire at the Museum crossing, which links Christian east Beirut with the Moslem western sector, did not discourage small groups of civilians from scurrying across the no-man's land. Police said most evacuees left the 310-square mile enclave north and east of Beirut at crossings on the northern and eastern flanks, leading to the Akkar Plain and Bekaa Valley. Christian civilians also fled to the Metin Mountains northeast of Beirut, which are controlled by Gen. Michel Aoun's forces, for safer areas in the Druse-held Chouf Mountains and south Lebanon, police said. The battle between Aoun and Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia has killed at least 694 people and wounded 1,930 since it began Jan. 30. A tenuous cease-fire has been in effect since Feb. 17. In addition to the danger of war, the 1 million Christians in the enclave face chronic shortages of cash, food, water, fuel and cooking gas. ``All civil servants and most of the private sector's employees haven't been paid their salaries for January because of the clashes,'' a police spokesman sid. Most banks in Christian territory have been closed since the battle for Christian supremacy began. Police estimate, about 110,000 of the 1 million people have fled.

DOC.HEAD: Another OTS Official Leaves
With AM-S&L Bailout
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial circuits
DOC.TEXT: A senior official at the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision resigned Tuesday, leaving three of the agency's top eight spots vacant as the Bush administration searches for a new director. Karl T. Hoyle, the senior deputy director in charge of congressional and media relations, said he was leaving the thrift office to start his own lobbying business. Last Friday, Jordan Luke, chief counsel of the agency, said he was entering private law practice. The agency's chief economist, James R. Barth, resigned last fall to teach at Auburn University. The departures leave only four senior officials at the agency in addition to its director, M. Danny Wall, who resigned Dec. 4 as the top federal S&L regulator. Wall continues to serve in his post and has set no date for his departure. They are Jonathan Fiechter, policy director; Darrel Dochow, supervision director; Rosemary Stewart, enforcement director and Gregory Rothwell, director of administration. Pending the appointment of Wall's successor, the vacant posts are being filled on an acting basis by lower-level officials. The Treasury Department has so far been unable to find a replacement for Wall, who resigned under congressional criticism for his handling of the failure of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, Irvine, Calif. The leading candidate for the job, Frederick D. Wolf, the former No. 2 official at the General Accounting Office, withdrew his name last week, complaining of Treasury officials' slowness in acting. Wall had said he was resigning to spare the agency from turmoil which would hamper its work. However, the long delay of his departure is creating the problem he sought to avoid, according to an agency official. ``Things are slowing down,'' said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity _ precisely what Wall sought to avoid. Disarray at the agency comes as two members of the House Banking Committee, Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., and Jim Leach, R-Iowa, are preparing legislation that would abolish it and divide its duties among commercial bank regulators.

DOC.HEAD: Czech Parliament Approves Election Laws
DOC.TEXT: Parliament on Tuesday adopted a law that establishes ground rules for the country's first free elections after more than four decades of Communist rule. The law calls for elections based on proportional representation in 12 districts, identical with the administrative division of Czechoslovakia. A party will have to gather 10,000 signatures or prove it has that many members to be able to run. A party must get 5 percent of the vote nationally to gain seats. The elections are set for June and will be the first free, multiparty balloting since the Communists took power in 1948. They lost that monopoly late last year in a peaceful revolution. Despite objections by legislators fearful that smaller parties would be discriminated against by the 5 percent hurdle, the draft law was adopted on a vote of 286-6 with seven abstentions. Earlier, Premier Marian Calfa told the legislature that his country's economy lagged five to 15 years behind advanced nations in the West because of decades of monopolistic Communist rule that had stifled creativity. In a key report on the state of the country delivered to Parliament, Calfa called for energetic measures to stimulate the economy by introducing market policies, curbing inflation and privatizing state-owned property. ``We must stop the negative trends and take the first steps toward a better future,'' said Calfa, who renounced his Communist Party membership this year after being named to head the government _ the first since 1948 not dominated by Communists. ``The GNP growth is estimated at 1.7 percent in 1989, but considering the `hidden price increases' it is difficult to say whether there is any growth at all,'' Calfa said. Under the Communist leadership, it had become common practice to repackage a product while increasing its price in an attempt to hide the higher costs. With inflation running at 2.5 percent to 3.5 percent and a foreign debt of $7.9 billion at the end of 1989, the Czechoslovak economy is in far better shape than those of some of its neighbors, such as Poland and Hungary. Nevertheless, Calfa called for strict measures to turn the economy around. ``An inevitable condition ... of the entire reform process must be a highly restrictive fiscal and financial policy with anti-infaltionary effects,'' he said. To achieve this goal, the Czechoslovak government plans to cut subsidies, improve its tax system, introduce market policies into the pricing process and open the economy to the outside world. New laws allowing private enterprise and the ownership of land will be introduced before the elections. However, Calfa said privatization of property should be ``cautious and gradual.'' He also announced planned cuts in military spending of $600 million in the 1990 budget. Czechoslovakia's military budget currently stands at $5 billion, representing 8 percent of the country's GNP, Calfa said. ``We know today that integration in the European Community in the immediate future is improbable, but we want to show quite clearly that we are attempting that in the long run,'' he said. ``We do not want the world to envy us. But we have to do everything so that our people do not have to envy the world,'' Calfa concluded.

DOC.HEAD: House Committee Passes Bill To Help Rural Communities
DOC.TEXT: Rural communities suffering from lost jobs and declining population would have more flexibility to spend federal development money if a bill approved Tuesday by the House Agriculture Committee becomes law. Money now placed in three funds _ sewer and water improvements, business development, or community facilities _ could be shifted from one use to another depending on the needs of the community. Each community would name a local committee to decide priorities. Reps. Glenn English, D-Okla., and Tom Coleman, R-Mo., who drafted the measure, said it solves the problem of differing needs in declining rural economies around the country. English said his subcommittee on rural development interviewed 250 witnesses in Washington and local areas before designing the legislation. ``Each had a different idea on what rural development meant,'' said English. ``One thing they all agreed on was that they wanted more money.'' But because of the pressures the deficit puts on the budget, there is no more money, said English. He said his bill allows regional committees to decide how to use the money that is available instead of relying on Washington to make the decisions. ``Some are going to need more water and sewer work,'' said English. ``We say fine. Take the money from some other area and shift it to your needs.'' The Agriculture Department would still have authority over the funds, but priorities would be set locally. Rep. Charles Rose, D-N.C., opposed the plan, saying it put too much strain on the sewer and water fund, which is the largest of the three with about $400 million this year, compared to $100 million for business development and $100 million for community facilities. Rep. H. Martin Lancaster, D-N.C., said communities might divert money to business develpment and let infrastructure suffer. ``I'm afraid water and sewer will get resources only when there is an emergency,'' said Lancaster. Rose offered an amendment to the bill that would have removed water and sewer money from the pool of funds, but English fought off his effort by proposing an amendment that limited the amount of money that could be shifted. Coleman said the bill is compatible with a report recently released by President Bush's Economic Policy Council Working Group on Rural Development. He said those findings showed: _Rural America needs help. _Federal rural development programs must look beyond traditional farm programs. _Rural development is essentially an economic issue. _Economic stress hurting most rural communities is primarily non-agricultural. _Rapid change in rural American demands tighter coordination of federal rural development programs. _Local community leadership is at the heart of any successful rural development program. English and Coleman's bill creates a Rural Development Administration within the Agriculture Department to direct federal policies. It also sets up an information center to be a clearinghouse for ideas that have proven successful in some rural communities. ``This will help small town America become more competitive in today's global economy,'' said Coleman. Last summer, the Senate passed a rural development bill sponsored by Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, that differs greatly from the House measure. It has three basic provisions: _A $300 million revolving fund that would provide seed money for businesses. _Satellite educational and health communication systems. _Improved drinking water.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinians Kill Arab Who Reportedly Confessed to Collaborating
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with army extending closure of universities, INSERT new 9th graf; pickup 10th pvs, `On Monday...'
DOC.TEXT: Palestinians stoned and beat a fellow Arab to death on Tuesday after a trial at a village mosque in which he reportedly confessed to collaborating with Israeli authorities, Arab reports said. It was the second public trial and slaying this month in Beit Furik, a village of 4,000 near Nablus in the occupied West Bank. On Feb. 16, hundreds of villagers gathered and cheered as another accused collaborator was hacked to death with axes and knives. The army confirmed the latest death and said police were investigating. Also Tuesday, about 200 Palestinian youths were detained by Israeli troops in the West Bank town of Ramallah after a firebomb was thrown at a parked car, Arab reports said. The car, which had Israeli license plates, was not damaged, they said. Military officials who insisted on anonymity confirmed the incident but declined to say how many youths were taken into custody. Meanwhile, several hundred students staged sit-down demonstrations outside three offices of the International Committee of the Red Cross to protest continued Israeli closure of Palestinian universities. The protests in Arab east Jerusalem and Ramallah passed without incident, authorities said. The demonstration in Bethlehem was broken up by soldiers firing tear gas, and six students were arrested, Arab reports said. The six Palestinian universities have been closed by army orders for two years. Israeli official contend they are hotbeds of violence in the 26-month uprising against Israeli rule in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. The military commander of the West Bank issued an order Tuesday extending the closure of the universities until the end of May for ``preventive measures,'' the army said. On Monday, the army announced that 16 Palestinian community colleges would be allowed to resume classes after a two-year closure but warned they would be shut again if there were anti-Israeli incidents near the schools. The slaying in Beit Furik raised to 190 the number of Palestinians killed by fellow Arabs during the uprising, most on suspicion of collaboration. At least 659 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians, and 43 Israelis have died. The victim Tuesday was identified as Ali Nasasra, 45. Arab reports said Nasasra fled from Beit Furik in 1969 after he was accused of being an informer for Israel and returned for the first time Monday, reportedly to visit his aunt. They said he was abducted by 15 masked Palestinian activists wielding axes and swords and brought Tuesday morning to the village mosque. As hundreds watched, Nasasra was forced to confess through the mosque loudspeaker that he helped arrange Israeli ambushes of several Palestinian guerrillas. ``What should we do with him?'' activists were quoted as shouting to the crowd. In response, dozens of villagers pelted Nasasra with stones and then chased him back to his aunt's home, where they followed him inside and stoned and clubbed him to death, the reports said.

DOC.HEAD: Top Safety Officials Score FAA On DC-10 Brakes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS time element, Tuesday sted Monday
DOC.TEXT: Top federal safety officials urged tougher standards for DC-10 jetliner brakes Tuesday and blamed inadequate government requirements for a 1988 Texas runway crash that destroyed an airliner.
DOC.HEAD: The National, 2nd graf
Senior Official Says 230,000 Soviet immigrants Expected in 1990
DOC.TEXT: Nearly a quarter-million Soviet Jews are expected to immigrate to Israel in 1990, three times the previous estimate, a senior government official was quoted as saying Tuesday on Israel television. The sudden leap in the estimate, the source said, derives from the opening of new migration channels that would allow 230,000 Jews to come to Israel, the television reported. The television did not reveal the identity of the senior official but noted that its estimates on Soviet immigration had previously been accurate. So far this year, 9,441 Soviet Jews have arrived and earlier Israeli estimates put the number of expected Soviet immigrants in 1990 at 80,000 due to more liberated Soviet emigration policies, American visa restrictions and allegations of rising anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union. Last year, about 12,000 Soviet Jews settled in Israel. At present, most Soviet Jews leave for Hungary and Romania and are then flown on to Israel after the emigrants reach Budapest or Bucharest by airplane or train. The report comes immediately following the resumption of ties Tuesday between Israel and Poland. On Monday, Finance Minister Shimon Peres said that Israelis may have to lower their standards of living to absorb the growing number of Soviet Jewish immigrants. The Finance Ministry has set aside $503 million to absorb 40,000 Soviet Jews in the fiscal year starting in April. An equal amount has been earmarked by the quasi-governmental Jewish Agency for immigrant absorption. Israel television reported Tuesday that immigration officials have called for the scraping of the present budget saying that $10 billion is now needed for absorption in light of the new estimates.

DOC.HEAD: `You've Suffered Enough,' Scottish Judge Tells Double Slayer
DOC.TEXT: A Royal Marine commando who admitted killing his wife and baby boy was released Tuesday by a judge who told him, ``You have punished yourself enough.'' Graham Sherman, 21, had been found guilty of homicide for the shotgun slaying of his wife Michelle, 23, and month-old son Josh as they slept in their home last November. The motive for the killings has not been explained. ``It is a strange message to come from a courtroom that the crime of homicide can be purged by mental self-punishment. Is this to be universally applied in Scottish courts?'' Brian Wilson, Scottish spokesman for the opposition Labor Party, said in London. ``This is a terrible decision,'' said David Evans, a lawmaker from the governing Conservative Party. The judge, Lord Dunpark, told Sherman the sentence was something ``I don't anticipate I will ever do ... again. I am going to admonish you on both charges.'' The judge said the purpose of sentencing is to punish, and to deter others. ``In my opinion you have punished yourself more than enough by what you did,'' the judge said. ``You will have to live with this for the rest of your life. You don't know why you did it. No one has been able to offer an explanation as to why you did it.'' There was no deterrent value in a prison sentence, the judge said, ``for no one in their right mind would have killed without reason these two people who were dearest to them in the world. ``But that's what you did. There's no point in deferring sentence for good behavior. You have no previous convictions. Neither is this a case in which in my opinion a probation order would help you. It would just keep reminding you of what you have done. ``And the sooner you try to forget this the better. For all these reasons I admonish you on both these charges and you have my deep sympathy.'' A letter that Sherman wrote to his sister-in-law, but never mailed, was read in court. ``I don't expect forgiveness, nor do I expect anyone to understand why. I have gone over it time and time again in my mind, and I still can't find an answer,'' the letter said. ``If I could turn back time and get rid of this tragedy, then I would. ``You all know that I love Michelle and Josh with all my heart, and believe me I still do. I can't explain the way I feel now. ``It's all like a terrible nightmare, one which I know I will never wake up from,'' the letter said.

DOC.HEAD: Contras Say Sandinistas Must Turn Over Power Before They Disband
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with Nicaraguan rebels reject Sandinista demand for them to disband, details. Picks up 8th pvs, `We will...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Nicaragua, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Contra rebels Tuesday rejected a Sandinista demand that they disband immediately and said they will not leave their Honduran bases until the Sandinistas turn over power to the newly elected Nicaraguan government. ``We don't trust the Sandinistas,'' said Israel Galeano, the top leader of the U.S.-backed Contras. ``They are capable of relinquishing the government but not power or weapons to the winners of last Sunday's election.'' President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro of the 14-party United National Opposition handed President Daniel Ortega a stunning defeat. Latest returns showed her winning 55 percent to 40 percent. Ortega said Tuesday the Contras must disband for there to be a peaceful transition of power. ``We will not return to Nicaragua until the Sandinistas leave power in our country,'' Galeano said. Mrs. Chamorro is to be sworn in as president for a six-year term on April 25. Earlier Tuesday, President Rafael Leonardo Callejas said the thousands of Contras based near the Nicaraguan border must leave Honduras as soon as possible. ``I don't want to force circumstances in Nicaragua, which is now going through a period of political transition following a victory by the opposition at the polls, but these rebels should not continue to stay in our territory,'' he told a news conference. Callejas indicated there was no point in the Contras continuing as a fighting force against Nicaragua's leftist Sandinistas. ``Now, with the electoral defeat of the Sandinistas, there are better democratic guarantees in Nicaragua for the quick repatriation of those who have taken up arms,'' Callejas said. Honduran officials estimated there are about 10,000 Contra rebels and some 42,000 dependents living in makeshift base camps in southern Honduras, near the Nicaraguan border. Most of them had pulled back from Nicaragua after the United State cut off military aid in 1988, and limited assistance only to non-lethal items. Most of them have been staying in the area around Yamales, 120 miles southeast of Tegucigalpa. But Galeano said he and his people were in no great hurry to return to Nicaragua, preferring to wait until Mrs. Chamorro is sworn in as president. ``We will return to Nicaragua when the Sandinistas abandon power. I believe this will be very soon, once Mrs. Chamorro consolidates herself in the presidency of my country,'' Galeano said in an interview. ``We are a cancer that no one wants. That is why we should act with caution before those events taking place in Nicaragua,'' said Galeano, who also calls himself ``Commander Franklin.'' Many ordinary Nicaraguan refugees who have not been involved with the Contras were planning to return home as soon as possible, before Mrs. Chamorro takes office, a spokesman said. ``We all want to return,'' saod Ramon Rivera, a refugee leader in Los Guacimos, a refugee camp about 80 miles northeast of Tegucigalpa. ``Many of us refugees are packing our bags to return to Nicaragua before Chamorro takes over. The great majority of us will do so afterwards.'' ``We are very glad Mrs. Chamorro won. We never expected it,'' said Rivera, 56, a peasant farmer who sought refuge with his wife and three children in Honduras in 1982. He is coordinator of the camp, one of more than a dozen holding an estimated 40,000 Nicaraguan refugees nationwide. The refugees include 20,000 Miskito, Suma and Rama Indians from Nicaragua's Atlantic coast, as well as Contra rebels and their dependents.

DOC.HEAD: Bataan Death March Prosecutor Dead at Age 80
DOC.TEXT: Benjamin F. Schwartz, a U.S. Navy attorney who helped prosecute a Japanese general after World War II for organizing the Bataan Death March, has died. He was 80. Schwartz died Sunday of heart failure at his Los Angeles home, said his widow, Lois. Schwartz was a Navy prosecutor at the Manila, Philippines, trial of Gen. Masaharu Homma, who was convicted of organizing the 1942 death march on the Philippines' Bataan Peninsula. Homma was executed. American and Filipino soldiers defending Bataan and Corrgidor, a rocky fortress in Manila Bay, were defeated by Japanese forces in April and May of 1942. Under Homma, the Japanese forced an estimated 60,000 of the soldiers to march about 70 miles to prison camps. About 10,000 of the prisoners died of starvation and other mistreatment during the march. Schwartz joined the antitrust division of the Justice Department before the war. He later joined the Navy's Industrial Incentive Division, speaking to defense plant workers to encourage increased productivity, before he became a Navy prosecutor. After the Manila trial, Schwartz entered private law practice. He mounted an unsuccessful campaign for state Assembly in 1952 and later became a member of the Democratic Party's state central committee. In addition to his widow, Schwartz is survived by four children and four grandchildren. Services were scheduled for Wednesday at Mount Sinai Memorial Park in Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: Enrile Charged with Involvement in Coup Attempt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with quotes from Enrile's law partner, further from government spokesman. Picks up 10th pvs, `Agents of...' Minor editing thereafter
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Juan Ponce Enrile, who played a key role in bringing Corazon Aquino to power, was arrested Tuesday on charges of aiding coup plotters, and the opposition accused her of trying to eradicate dissent. Military dissidents said the arrest of Enrile was a prelude to martial law. He helped put Mrs. Aquino in power four years ago, but now is the only opposition member of the Senate. Enrile was among seven people indicted Tuesday for ``rebellion with murder'' in connection with the coup attempt Dec. 1-9 in which at least 113 people were killed and more than 600 wounded. Enrile's law partner, Renato Cayetano, said he would ask the Supreme Court on Wednesday to release the senator for his own safety and because the charges were false. Enrile is the most prominent figure charged in any of the six coup attempts since Mrs. Aquino was swept to power in February 1986 by the ``people power'' uprising that drove the late President Ferdinand E. Marcos into exile. He was defense minister under Marcos but turned against him and led the military mutiny that prompted the uprising. Enrile kept the post under Mrs. Aquino, but she fired him in November 1986 after a coup attempt by his followers. On Tuesday, presidential press secretary Tomas Gomez said: ``What we are witnessing today is the effective operation of our criminal justice system under a constitutional democracy.'' He said the 160,000 members of the military were put on alert to prevent ``reprisals'' for the action against Enrile. Vice President Salvador Laurel described the arrest as an attempt to stifle the political opposition. Laurel broke with Mrs. Aquino in 1987 and later joined Enrile in forming the opposition Nacionalista Party. ``The arrest of Sen. Juan Ponce Enrile ... is the height of intolerance of political dissent, which is the essence of a functioning democracy,'' Laurel said in a statement. ``The attempt to simulate compliance with legal processes merely heightens the hypocrisy of the act.'' Later Tuesday, a spokesman for soldiers involved in the December coup said the nation ``should brace itself for the imminent declaration of martial law.'' In a radio interview Wednesday, Gomez said that despite his position, Enrile led ``the numerous attempts at a coup d'etat to destroy this government of ours.'' ``When there are no arrests, people say the government is weak,'' Gomez said. ``Now that the criminals have been arrested, then we are called vindictive. ... How can we have compassion for an individual who has repeatedly, time and time again, molested the peace and stability of our country?'' Agents of the National Bureau of Investigation took Enrile into custody outside the Senate chamber after serving him with an arrest warrant that included the charge of harboring fugitives. Enrile, one of the nation's wealthiest businessmen, told reporters he would ask the Supreme Court for bail, which is not usually allowed for the charges he faces. Indicted with Enrile, 66, were former Lt. Col. Gregorio ``Gringo'' Honasan; Rodolfo Aguinaldo, former governor of Cagayan province; retired Brig. Gen. Felix Brawner; retired Lt. Col. Billy Bibit; and businessman Rebecco Panlilio and his wife. Three people claimed they saw Honasan and about 100 rebels at Enrile's home on the first day of the attempted coup. The senator claims not to have seen Honasan, his former protege, since 1987. In a Senate speech before his arrest, Enrile said: ``The regime of President Corazon C. Aquino has marshaled all its forces in fabricating charges against me in order to silence the voice of the opposition in this chamber.'' As Marcos' defense minister, Enrile ordered thousands of people arrested during martial law in 1972-81, including her husband, Benigno, who later was assassinated. Aguinaldo, a former army lieutenant colonel, was suspended as Cagayan's governor for 60 days after telling a Manila radio station he was sending tanks to the capital to support the coup. Honasan, who has been dropped from military rolls, led the August 1987 mutiny against Mrs. Aquino and played a leading role in December's attempt. He was arrested in December 1987, but escaped the next April. Brawner, former military commander of northern Luzon, served as a consultant to the Senate Defense Committee after retiring from the armed forces in 1989. He is accused of advising the rebels. Bibit, security chief of the customs bureau, is accused of giving the mutineers weapons and food. He was arrested last month. Panlilio and his wife were reported seen at Enrile's house with Honasan on the first day of the December coup.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Byelorussian Envoy Appeals for $17 Billion in Chernobyl Aid
DOC.TEXT: The ambassador of the Soviet Byelorussian republic appealed Tuesday for billions of dollars in foreign aid for the victims of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster. Lev Maksimov, permanent U.N. representative of the republic, told a news conference that the nuclear power plant accident on April 26, 1986, has caused ``untold misery and suffering'' among the republic's people. He said death, birth defects and illness related to radiation have increased, but he could not provide statistics. Medical equipment and assistance urgently are needed, Maksimov said. The explosion and fire at the Chernobyl plant sent a cloud of radiation around the world and was the worst commercial nuclear accident in history. So far, Maksimov said, foreign assistance in cash, food, medical supplies and other aid has amounted to only about $6 million, but little of the aid has come from foreign governments. Within the Soviet Union, Maksimov said, the central government and neighboring republics have contributed the equivalent of about $2 billion in disaster relief. But he said at least $17 billion more is needed in various types of aid. Maksimov said his government urgently needs radiation monitors, ultrasound diagnostic equipment, endoscopes for examining chest and digestive tracts and foodstuffs. Maksimov said thousands of people have been evacuated and resettled and another 188,000 should be resettled. About 20 percent of the farmland has been contaminated and tainted soil must be removed, he said. Also, animals contaminated by radiation must be replaced and more foodstuffs are needed, Maksimov said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Honor Americans Who Helped After Quake
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT that Armenia is a republic.
DOC.TEXT: Eight Americans who helped in the Armenian earthquake relief effort were honored by Soviet officials Monday for their actions following the disaster, which claimed 25,000 lives. Soviet Ambassador Yuri Dubinin told Americans they had put ``lofty human principles of charity and compassion'' over political differences when volunteering after the quake hit the Soviet mountain republic in December 1988. Julia Taft, former director of the Agency for International Development's foreign disaster assistance office, was one of the eight who received the Soviet order ``For Personal Courage,'' a prestigious award signed by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Ms. Taft, of Lorton, Va., said the Armenians were ``majestic people.'' ``I feel we have built a great tomorrow together,'' Ms. Taft said. The quake caused such devastation that the Soviet Unon opened its borders to foreign assistance for the first time, accepting the help of thousands of experts, including rescue teams, doctors and construction specialists. More than a half billion dollars in assistance poured into the disaster area from overseas, marking a change in East-West relations after years of Soviet propaganda that depicted Westerners as greedy. The other seven Americans who received the honor were: William Dotson, a quality control inspector for Merck and Co. in Ruckersville, Va.; Caroline Hebard of Bernardsville, N.J., who took a team of rescue dogs; Warren Isman, a fire chief in Burke, Va.; Joseph Johnson, an aerospace engineer from King George, Va.; Neil Kahanovitz, a surgeon from Arlington, Va.; Frederick Krimgold, an architect from Alexandria, Va.; and Merton Perry, fire chief in Miami. Aubrey Carlson of the U.S. Embassy in Moscow will also receive the award for personal courage, officials said. Another 109 Americans, including President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker III, received lesser honors.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rejects Argument for Overturning Morris Conviction
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge on Tuesday refused to overturn the conviction of a 24-year-old hacker who unleashed a ``worm'' program that paralyzed thousands of computers nationwide in 1988. U.S. District Judge Howard Munson set sentencing for Robert Morris for May 4 in Syracuse. The suspended Cornell University student faces up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine for unleashing a computer worm that immobilized an estimated 6,000 computers across the country, including ones at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, military installations and major universities. The Arnold, Md., man was the first person brought to trial under a section of a 1986 federal computer fraud and abuse law that makes it a felony to break into and use a federal computer network. His lawyer, Thomas Guidoboni, said prosecutors did not prove Morris had actually broken the law because he technically had access to the Cornell University computer system where the virus was introduced. But the judge said Morris had entered computer files he was not supposed to. U.S. Justice Department lawyer Mark Rasch said Morris had described his own conduct to investigators as a ``break-in.'' The federal judge also rejected Guidoboni's argument that a new trial be ordered because a remark by Justice Department lawyer Ellen Meltzer about terrorism ``inflamed'' a community sensitive about terrorist acts. Meltzer had told the jurors during closing arguments in the case that they shouldn't thank Morris for prompting an increase in computer security, just as they wouldn't thank a terrorist for increased airport security. This remark was particularly insensitive in Syracuse because 35 students in a Syracuse University program were killed in December 1988 when a terrorist bomb exploded on Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, the lawyer said. But Munson said the ``objectionable'' remark was an isolated event in an otherwise fair trial. Morris, dressed in a gray suit, sat quietly as the lawyers argued. Guidoboni said it has not been decided whether he will appeal the verdict. During his trial, witnesses testified that the worm did not permanently harm the computers or computer files, but in some cases people were unable to use their computers for several days while the virus was hunted down and removed. Morris testified during his trial that he had made a programming error that caused the worm to go berserk and cripple the Internet system on Nov. 2, 1988. He said he did not intend to cause permanent damage to computer files, only to infiltrate the network's security. Prosecutors contended that Morris may not have intended harm, but that he deliberately broke into Internet and took deliberate steps to make his worm difficult to detect and eradicate.

DOC.HEAD: Man Surrenders to Newspaper After Elderly Mother Slain
DOC.TEXT: A man who described himself as a former mental patient surrendered at a newspaper office in the shotgun slaying of his mother after telling a reporter she ridiculed him and withheld a $150,000 inheritance. Leslie S. Amison was taken away in handcuffs from The Globe-Times office about three hours after his 76-year-old mother was shot Monday night at the home they shared. ``My mother liked having power over me,'' the Bethlehem newspaper's Tuesday editions quoted Amison as saying. ``She wouldn't let me have my own place. ... She said I didn't deserve privacy.'' Amison, 44, who told the newspaper he had been in and out of mental hospitals for more than 15 years, was charged with criminal homicide, police said. He was ordered held without bail at the Lehigh County Prison. A preliminary hearing was scheduled for March 7 in county District Court. Amison, who said he was a writer and poet, wandered into the newspaper office behind a cleaning man. He identified himself to night editor Kevin Flynn, who recognized his name because authorities had been looking for him in the slaying of his mother, Catherine Amison Murray. ``I shot my mother,'' Amison was quoted by the newspaper as telling a reporter. ``She just laughed at me because I had no rights.'' The newspaper said Amison told reporter David Josar that his mother withheld a $150,000 inheritance after his father died in 1986 and that she laughed at him, rifled his computer files, and read his letters and poetry. Amison said he fired a shotgun at his mother, then fled the house, the newspaper said. Police were summoned to the home by a neighbor. Flynn said Amison told him he chose the newspaper for his surrender because police patronized him like his mother. At one point, Flynn left the newsroom, where Amison and Josar chatted, to make coffee. He telephoned the newspaper's city editor, who called police. The newspaper quoted Amison as saying his father had him committed to Allentown State Hospital near Bethlehem more than 15 years ago and he had been in and out of hospitals ever since. Hospital sources cited by The Globe-Times said Amison was an outpatient at the hospital. Bethlehem is a steel town of about 72,000 people about 10 miles east of Allentown. Amison had urged state legislators in letters to reform state laws on the mentally ill, the newspaper said. He also had written letters to the editors of The Globe-Times and The Allentown Morning Call. In a letter to the Bethlehem newspaper dated Jan. 7, Amison called for more democratic treatment of mental patients.

DOC.HEAD: Son of Martin Luther King Says Gays Have `Problem'
DOC.TEXT: A son of slain civil rights leader Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Tuesday told middle school students that gay people have ``a problem.'' ``Our population is really all kind of mixed up right now,'' Martin Luther King III said during a speech observing Black History Month at Poughkeepsie Middle School. ``I mean, we've got a straight community and a community we call the gay community. ... We laugh, but that's real.'' ``Now something may be wrong in the makeup of that individual if they happen to be that way. Any man that has a desire to be with another man has a problem, in my opinion,'' King said. ``And that applies to any woman who has a desire to be with another woman.'' King did not talk to reporters afterward. An official with a national gay rights group called King's remarks ``strange and upsetting'' considering the increased reports of violence against gays nationwide. ``The majority of cases are in fact perpetrated by young people who really don't see anything wrong with anti-gay bigotry,'' said Karin Schwartz, assistant director of the New York City-based Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation. ``His statements won't do anything to confront that belief that many students have and, if anything, will bolster it,'' she said. Poughkeepsie is about 75 miles north of New York City.

DOC.HEAD: Former Alabama House Speaker Dead at Age 86
DOC.TEXT: William M. Beck Sr., a former judge and speaker of the Alabama House and a longtime friend of former Gov. George C. Wallace, has died after an extended illness. He was 86. Beck died Monday of respiratory failure at Baptist Medical Center-DeKalb Hospital in Fort Payne, where he lived. Beck, a Democrat, was first elected to the Alabama House in 1939 and elected again after World War II. He served four years the first time and became a DeKalb County circuit judge in 1943. Beck gave up his judgeship after about a year to enlist in the Marine Corps during the war. When Beck returned from the war, he was elected again to the House. He served as speaker from 1947 to 1951, during the late James E. ``Big Jim'' Folsom's first term as governor. During that time, Beck helped push bills through the Legislature to improve state roads. He became friends with Wallace, then a freshman representative. As governor, Wallace appointed Beck to the state Board of Education in 1962. Beck served for 10 years on the board and helped organize the state's junior college system. ``In his passing we have lost one of those who contributed so much to Alabama and to his own area,'' Wallace said Tuesday in a statement. ``He will be sorely missed.'' Beck's funeral was scheduled for Wednesday at First Baptist Church in Fort Payne. Survivors include two sons and a daughter.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Again Finds USX Discriminated Against Blacks
DOC.TEXT: The USX Corp. discriminated against 8,000 black job applicants even under the Supreme Court's more stringent standards for proving bias, a federal appeals court has ruled. The 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld for the second time a 1983 U.S. District court ruling that the company discriminated in the hiring of production and maintenance employees at its Fairless, Pa., steel mill. The federal appeals court first upheld the ruling in 1988, but was ordered last year to restudy the case by the Supreme Court. ``This means that once again the court of appeals has determined that USX discriminated against a class of black people and those people are entitled to a significant monetary remedy,'' said attorney Richard Z. Freeman Jr., who represented the job applicants. He estimated the ruling could cost the steel manufacturer nearly $30 million. Attorneys for USX did not return telephone calls seeking comment on the Friday ruling by the appeals court. The Supreme Court last June ordered the appeals court circuit court to re-examine its ruling in light of the high court's June 5, 1989, decision in Wards Cove Packing Co. vs. Atonio. The Wards Cove decision said minorities could not rely solely on statistics to prove discrimination but must link the data to a specific corporate employment policy. The decision also allowed companies to justify practices that appear to have statistically discriminatory by showing the policy was a reasonable employment policy. In its recent ruling, the appeals court determined that even under the new, more restrictive guidelines, the blacks in the class-action suit had proved discrimination in hiring practices. The court found that because the positions at issue were for unskilled workers, ``any able-bodied person should be competent to perform the job.'' Since the hiring process was subjective, the interviews had a ``significantly disparate impact on blacks, as the percentage of successful black interviewees was significantly less than the overall percentage of successful interviewees,'' Chief Judge A. Leon Higginbotham Jr. wrote in the appeals court decision.

DOC.HEAD: Grand Jury Fails to Take Action in Sheriff's Moonshine Case
DOC.TEXT: A grand jury has failed to indict a sheriff who was arrested on charges of doling out confiscated moonshine to friends for medicinal use. ``I'm awful thankful this matter is over,'' Madison County Sheriff Dedrick Brown said after a country grand jury took no action against him Monday. ``The judicial process has come through again.'' Brown, a first-term sheriff who is up for re-election to another four-year term this year, was arrested Feb. 9 by State Bureau of Investigation agents on a charge of altering, destroying or stealing criminal evidence. Six half-gallon jugs of the illegal brew Brown seized in a raid two weeks before his arrest were given to several of his friends, investigators said. SBI Director Robert Morgan said one of his agents was present during one exchange at the sheriff's office. Brown said 25 or 30 people offered to testify on his behalf that it's a century-old tradition in the mountain county for sheriffs to hand out ``white lightning.'' But the tradition will have to do without Brown. ``I don't think it would be worth going through this again,'' he said. The sheriff and county residents said moonshine is used in the western North Carolina area for home remedies such as cough medicine. Brown, a Republican, blamed Democratic foes for the flap, an allegation denied by a chief criminal investigator for Democratic state Attorney General Lacy Thornburg, who oversees the SBI. District Attorney Tom Rusher, who is a Republican, said the SBI arrested Brown without Rusher's knowledge. Rusher said he was ``unable to muster much zeal'' for prosecuting Brown and did not expect to seek other charges.

DOC.HEAD: Landslide in Highland Jungle Town Leaves 21 Dead, 100 Missing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with three grafs to UPDATE with 21 dead, 34 injured, 100 missing. Picks up 4th, `San Miguel...'
DOC.TEXT: A wall of mud, water and debris swept through part of a jungle town before dawn Tuesday, leaving at least 21 people dead and about 100 missing, authorities said. Army Gen. Jorge Ferreyros, head of the Civil Defense Institute, said a natural dam formed on the Cachiyacu River broke and a torrent devastated a portion of San Miguel, a town 425 miles north of Lima. Civil defense officials in Tarapoto, the provincial capital 400 miles northeast of Lima, said a number of residents managed to swim to safety and 300 were left homeless. Rescue personnel evacuated 34 people to Tarapoto where they were hospitalized with injuries. San Miguel has about 4,000 residents, many of them farmers who raise corn and bananas in the highland jungle. Ferreyros said recent rains caused landslides that formed the natural dam. He blamed the landslides on farmers who expand their cropland by cutting down trees and jungle vegetation on the steep hillsides above the river.

DOC.HEAD: Man Holds Wife, Child Hostage in Kentucky for Three Hours
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout, clarifying that abducted son is 9 years, sted infant; ADDS byline. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LH1
DOC.TEXT: A man apparently despondent over a child-custody dispute took his wife and 9-year-old son hostage Tuesday at the downtown county office building before surrendering three hours later, police said. John Delay, 35, demanded that he be given custody of his four children after abducting his wife and his son at gunpoint during a consultation session with a state social worker, said state Trooper Lon Fields. Delay surrendered after asking to be taken to a hospital for psychiatric care, and his 32-year-old wife, Linda, and son Shawn were released unharmed, Fields said. The social worker was not abducted. ``We think he just got tired and toward the end he said he wanted to go to the hospital, that he had some problems he felt needed help with,'' Fields said. Delay was armed with a .357-caliber pistol but fired no shots during the abduction at the Montgomery County Health and Civic Center, which was quickly evacuated. He made several threats to take his own life but never threatened his family, Fields said. Delay had a history of psychological problems and was being taken to Eastern State Hospital, a psychiatric institution in Lexington, said Officer Mike Martin of the Mount Sterling police department. Delay also has a 13-year-old daughter, Shelly, and two sons, Jessie, 12, and Christopher, 2, police said. Shawn had been in foster care for some time and was placed in emergency custody by the state Cabinet for Human Resources on Friday. Brad Hughes, a spokesman for the state Cabinet for Human Resources, said the children were involved in a ``child protection case'' but he declined to comment further. Mount Sterling, a town of about 5,000 people, is 35 miles east of Lexington in eastern Kentucky.

DOC.HEAD: President Calls for Coalition Government
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with opposition comment, INSERT 6 after 5th pvs, `He said...' pickup 6th pvs, `Critics say...'
DOC.TEXT: No party can govern Romania alone and a coalition would be best no matter how the May elections come out, interim President Ion Iliescu was quoted as saying in an interview published Tuesday. Iliescu leads the National Salvation Front, which took over during the uprising against the 24-year reign of Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, who was overthrown Dec. 22 and executed Dec. 25. The Front has been accused of being undemocratic and was forced to share power after reneging on its pledge not to enter candidates in the May 20 elections. ``Regardless of the results'' of the elections, ``the most realistic thing is to establish a multiparty coalition to govern the country,'' Iliescu was quoted as saying in an interview with Romania Libera, the country's largest-selling newspaper. He said the ``majority of parties and political formations are too weak to govern'' and ``not even'' the Front is strong enough to do it alone. The coalition proposal met with mixed reaction from major political rivals. Radu Campeanu, president of the National Liberal Party, did not rule out a possible alliance with the Front. ``The situation in the country is, and will continue to be, so grave that such a coalition of different political forces may be helpful,'' he said. Campeanu said, however, that ``there is not a great deal of ideological common ground'' between the Front and his party, which favors speedier restructuring of the centralized ecomony into a free market one. The Front's main rival, the National Peasants Party, was less enthusiastic. ``It is impossible to pronounce ourselves in favor of or against such a coalition before we know what the election results are,'' said party spokesman Valentin Gabrielescu. ``In any case, we would much prefer a coalition with other parties and are working to establish an alliance with them before the elections.'' Critics say Iliescu and other former Communists who ran afoul of Ceausescu want to retain some aspects of totalitarian rule. They contend, among other things, that the Front controls television in a heavy-handed manner. Several important parties are working toward an alliance against the Front. Leaders of the Peasant, Liberal, Social Democratic and Labor parties say they expect an agreement within two weeks. Iliescu was quoted as saying the Communist Party, which dissolved after Ceausescu fell, was too unpopular to regain power. About general policy, he said the government would encourage private agriculture and business, but keep some large state farms and industries. He said ways would be sought to introduce more decentralization and free-market principles to state enterprises. Fourteen armored personnel carriers blocking off government headquarters in Victory Square were removed Tuesday. They were brought in Feb. 19, the day after protesters stormed and ransacked the headquarters. The Council of National Unity, an assembly of the Front and 40 other parties governing Romania until the elections, passed a decree Friday imposing stricter penalties on demonstrators who threaten government or party buildings. About 100 students demonstrated outside the Interior Ministry against the government's handling of the officially defunct Securitate, Ceausescu's hated secret police. Gheorghe Constantin, an organizer of the rally, said the students from Bucharest University and the Polytechnical Institute wanted ``to know exactly what has happened to the Securitate, how it was structured and where every one of its former operatives are now.'' ``We are convinced the Securitate still exists,'' he said. ``Some of us still have our phones bugged and have received threats.'' On Monday, military officers showed reporters how they had begun dismantling Securitate telephone-tapping centers and said their work was proof widespread eavesdropping would not recur. Securitate agents tapped tens of thousands of telephones as part of a vast domestic spying apparatus.

DOC.HEAD: Screenplay Writer Sues Eddie Murphy Over `Harlem Nights'
DOC.TEXT: An aspiring screenwriter filed a $35 million federal lawsuit Tuesday against Eddie Murphy, contending the actor-comedian stole material from him for the movie ``Harlem Nights.'' At a news conference, Michael Greene estimated that the movie has 100 similarities to an original screenplay he wrote for Murphy in 1988 called ``A Halloween to Remember.'' Paramount Pictures Corp. lawyer Les Fagen, whose company is named with Murphy as a defendant, denied the allegation. He said any similarities were common motifs found in hundreds of movies. Greene, 35, of Hempstead on Long Island said he submitted his copyright script to Murphy in January 1989 and was soon advised Murphy ``was not interested in it.'' Greene said the script was never returned to him. ``I used to consider Murphy a hero,'' Greene said. ``Now I think he is an egomaniac. He's out for himself.'' The lawsuit filed in U.S. District Court in Uniondale seeks at least $35 million in damages for copyright infringement. Both scripts were about 8-year-old orphan boys being raised by underworld figures, both took place in the 1930s and both included a corrupt Italian plainclothes police officer, Greene said. He said both stories revolved around a duffle bag of money and both had Murphy fighting with elderly characters. ``I'm not going to tell you that he took Michael's screenplay and put it up on the screen, but he clearly edited it, cut it and pasted it,'' said Greene's attorney, Steven Legum. Fagen said the lawsuit was groundless. ``We've reviewed Michael Greene's screenplay and the screenplay for the motion picture `Harlem Nights.' We find no similarity which could form the basis for a lawsuit,'' he said. In January, Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist Art Buchwald and producer Alain Bernheim won a lawsuit against Paramount that claimed the studio took the idea for the 1988 movie ``Coming to America'' from a screen treatment by Buchwald. Paramount was ordered by a judge to pay the two 19 percent of the movie's net profits. The amount owed has not yet been determined.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: Pageant Winner Allegedly Picked Before Final Competition
DOC.TEXT: Contestants in Israel's national beauty pageant were in tears after judges announced a winner allegedly picked ahead of the final event Tuesday. The Hadashot newspaper wrote that the 11-judge panel had chosen 18-year-old Ivonna Krugliak, a Soviet immigrant, as Israel's new beauty queen after interviewing the 20 candidates on Saturday. The pageant is sponsored by the mass circulation newspaper Yediot Ahronot, one of Hadashot's competitors. Pageant organizer Rachel Givon denied the Hadashot story. The green-eyed Krugliak was crowned winner following the final evening gown and bathing suit competitions Tuesday night in Tel Aviv. Mrs. Givon said the judges had not made their decision before then and blamed the rival newspaper for trying to create a sensation. Before the crowning, Mrs. Givon had said the Hadashot story caused an uproar among the contestants. ``The girls were very much upset,'' she said. ``Ivonna was crying more than anybody else. She is really a very beautiful girl. If she is chosen, people will say, `See, we told you so.''' Said contestant Sharon Seidnorg, 20: ``This put our morale right down on the floor. I wonder what I'm doing here.'' Krugliak will go on to represent Israel in the Miss Universe Contest and first runner-up Ariela Tessler will represent the country in the Miss World competion, Mrs. Givon said.

DOC.HEAD: Juice-Company Owners Sentenced in Adulteration Case
DOC.TEXT: A former owner of a local fruit-juice company was sentenced Tuesday to two years in prison for selling orange juice adulterated with ingredients not listed on container labels. ``White-collar crime is truly a violent crime because it tears at the fabric of society,'' U.S. District Judge Milton Shadur told Edward Boden Sr. in sentencing him to two years in prison, a $250,000 fine and 1,000 hours of community service. Boden, 67, former president and chairman of Bodine's Inc., pleaded guilty in December to three felony counts of selling adulterated food under a plea bargain with federal prosecutors. Boden's son, Edward Boden Jr., pleaded guilty to five misdemeanor counts. He was sentenced to two years probation, fined $200,000 and ordered to perform 200 hours of community service. Boden and his son were two of three former owners of Chicago-based Bodine's who were charged with selling adulterated food. Roger Walsh Jr., a Texas resident, was sentenced last week to two years probation and 200 hours of community service. Walsh had pleaded guilty to misdemeanor counts. All three were originally indicted last July on 19 felony counts. The guilty pleas were entered to charges that specified only five shipments of adulterated juice and named only grapefruit solids as adulterants. Federal prosecutors had accused Bodine's of selling more than 7 million cases of ``100 percent pure frozen concentrated orange juice'' which actually contained such ingredients as beet sugar, corn sugar and distilled water. Proseuctors said the juice was sold under about 50 brand names at supermarkets in 36 states from 1978 to 1985. Assistant U.S. Attorney Thomas Durkin said U.S. Food and Drug Administration inspectors on three occasions discovered Bodine's was doctoring the juice, but the company continued doing it. Prosecutors said that because Bodine's had been cutting the juice with cheaper ingredients, the company was able to undercut competitors and increase orange juice sales from $5 million to $100 million during the seven-year period.

DOC.HEAD: Expert Faults Hazelwood's Judgment
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 2nd graf to UPDATE with new quote; picks up 3rd graf, `Soon after ...' SUBS 13th graf, `Hazelwood's attorneys ...,' with 7 grafs to UPDATE with afternoon testimony; picks up 14th graf, `Beevers was ...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Exxon-Valdez
DOC.TEXT: Joseph Hazelwood exercised bad judgment in virtually every decision he made the night the Exxon Valdez ran aground, a veteran sea captain testified Tuesday at Hazelwood's trial. Robert Beevers, a consultant who spent 14 years as a tanker captain, said the worst move Hazelwood made on March 24 was leaving the ship's bridge in the hands of a third mate during a hazardous passage into Prince William Sound. ``He created the risk of grounding, of losing the vessel, of fire, explosion and death to his crew and of pollution that occurred,'' said Beevers, who testified as a prosecution expert. Soon after Hazelwood left the bridge, the Exxon Valdez impaled itself on Bligh Reef, causing the nation's worst oil spill. ``In my opinion, it was bad judgment to leave the bridge ... at that location, at that time,'' Beevers said. ``Whether it was one minute or 20 minutes, it was bad judgment.'' In another development Tuesday, a federal grand jury in Anchorage indicted Exxon Corp. and its shipping subsidiary on five counts in the spill. If convicted of the two felonies and three misdemeanors in the indictment, the company could be fined up to $1.6 million, U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh told a Washington news conference. The government could also seek as much as $700 million more under federal laws allowing recovery of twice the amount of the proven loss caused by the spill, U.S. Attorney Mark Davis of Alaska said at the news conference. Hazelwood attorney Michael Chalos criticized the timing of the indictment. ``It's interesting that it should be happening now just as we're finishing the Hazelwood trial,'' Chalos said. ``They waited this long, why couldn't they wait two weeks longer?'' The trial is expected to last about two more weeks. Nearly 11 million gallons of oil were dumped into the pristine sound, killing countless birds, fish and other wildlife and blackening hundreds of miles of rocky shore. Hazelwood, 43, of Huntington, N.Y., is charged with second-degree criminal mischief, a felony, and three misdemeanors: reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated and negligent discharge of oil. If convicted on all counts, he could be sentenced to up to 7\ years in prison and $61,000 in fines. In the trial's fourth week, Beevers offered the most direct criticism yet of Hazelwood, giving him bad marks on such actions as his last-minute arrival before sailing, a hasty decision to divert the tanker from shipping lanes to avoid ice and transferring control to the third mate shortly before the ship rammed the reef. Hazelwood's attorneys objected repeatedly to the testimony, saying he is not charged with exercising bad judgment and that Beevers' opinions were irrelevant. But Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone allowed the testimony to continue and reprimanded Hazelwood lawyer Dick Madson after a pointed exchange with Beevers. Madson rose from his chair to cross-examine Beevers and declared, ``Am I standing here before the eyes of God?'' ``Mr. Beevers, you're not perfect, are you?'' Madson asked Beevers. ``No, I'm not,'' Beevers responded. ``And have you ever had someone hired to say you exercised bad judgment?'' said Madson. ``No,'' said Beevers. Beevers, who spent four hours on the witness stand and was to continue Wednesday, said he is being paid $35,000 for helping in the case. He retired from the merchant marine in 1987. Beevers was especially critical of Hazelwood's decision to leave third mate Gregory Cousins alone on the bridge with a helmsman. The witness portrayed Cousins as a mate far too inexperienced to be left with such a task, noting that he had only 13 months of sea experience on his license. ``He was heading into a dangerous situation, a situation that needed someone with experience to maneuver it, a situation that was beyond what you would expect a relatively inexperienced third mate to do on his own,'' Beevers said. He also criticized Hazelwood for leaving at the wheel a helmsman who had problems with steering.

DOC.HEAD: Skin, Sin, Sun and Fun _ Mardi Gras Has Them Dancing in The Streets
LaserPhotos NU4,5,9, LaserColor NU1
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with evening activities; picks up 3rd graf, ```Batman. I'm ...' Note contents
DOC.TEXT: Revelers in well-worn costumes jammed shoulder to shoulder in the French Quarter as the raucous, hard-drinking pre-Lent party known as Mardi Gras blasted on into the night Tuesday. ``Our closing line would be, `Have a good time, but get out alive.' With these costumes, we'll be lucky to,'' said Chris Collins, who was costumed as Batman and was accompanied by a friend dressed as Superman. Collins, who said he was from Pennsylvania but didn't want to give his hometown, said he and his friend had gotten some razzing, but most of it was good-natured. People in costumes that were gaudy, skimpy or both had filled the Quarter earlier. But as the night wore on, maskers gave way to the unmasked: torn shirts, tattered grass skirts through which pants were clearly visible, and garish clothes that might have been part of a costume earlier in the day. Live or recorded music blasted out of every club and hotel on Bourbon Street and nearby streets, and most of the partiers carried drinks in plastic cups. Batman costumes could be seen all around the city, but most had more pieces than Eric Wright's. At 9 a.m., Wright stood outside a Bourbon Street bar wearing wearing only a big grin and a leather athletic supporter with a plastic bat attached while people around him filled frame after frame of videotape or film. ``Batman. I'm Batman get it?'' Wright said. Tracy Jones of Nashville, Tenn., was among those taking pictures. ``If I'd come here when I was 20, it would have ruined me for life,'' said Jones, 43. ``I can barely stand it now.'' The weather was glorious this year, with temperatures in the 70s. It brought out an estimated 1 million locals and tourists, police said. Mardi Gras, French for fat Tuesday, is the last day of the Carnival season, which ends with the start of Ash Wednesday at midnight. Celebrations in heavily Catholic Louisiana began Jan. 6 but reached a frenzy more than a week ago. ``Honey, even if you don't have it you flaunt it on Mardi Gras. What's that saying? Less is more. That's definitely true,'' said Jim Owen of Los Angeles, dressed in a tight black miniskirt, tennis ball-stuffed bra, and high heels. Along the balconies in the French Quarter revelers dropped beads to celebrants below and women bared their breasts to the delight of onlookers. ``Well, technically, dropping beads is illegal but showing their breasts isn't, or at least we don't arrest them for it. In fact we pretty much just let it all roll by unless someone gets too out of control,'' said police officer M.L. Sposito. David Donze of New Orleans, who dressed as St. Michael the Archangel, complete with handmade feather wings and golden sandals, said costuming for Mardi Gras made everyone a star. ``It's your turn to be seen by other people. Instead of watching the parade, you are the parade. You become the parade and the center of attention,'' he said. Dozens of parades draw the focus to the Carnival season, with 15 organizations on the streets all day uptown and downtown _ starting with the club called Zulu which tossed painted coconuts and beads to the crowds. Next came Rex, the king of Carnival, with his parades down St. Charles Avenue. ``It's New Orleans' mission to see to it that everyone in the world has plastic beads, plastic cups and rubber chickens. The stuff they throw from the parades is no good, but everyone wants it,'' said Rita Miller. Miller, from suburban Metairie, and 20 of her friends, all dressed as clowns, had a front-row seat for the parades. Spectators 15 deep lined the route behind them, clamoring for the trinkets thrown from the floats. In contrast, dozens of Christian evangelists carried signs and handed out religious leaflets as they worked the crowds. ``Our motto is save a soul, don't catch the beads,'' said Laura Patterson of New York.

DOC.HEAD: Fifteen Transit Officers Injured in Grand Central Fire
DOC.TEXT: A fire broke out Tuesday at Grand Central Terminal during the afternoon rush hour, sending 15 transit police officers to hospitals with smoke inhalation, authorities said. The fire began in rubbish in a subway section of the train station, said Fire Department spokesman John Mulligan. Firefighters had the fire under control within 45 minutes of the first alarm at 5:30 p.m., Mulligan said. The 15 officers suffered smoke inhalation as they tried to control crowds and evacuate commuters from the subway section, said Transit Authority police spokesman Al O'Leary. All 15 were taken to hospitals. The fire also forced the suspension of some subway service, but service was restored by 7:45 p.m.

DOC.HEAD: Priest Who Founded Covenant House Resigns
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 6th graf, `James J. ...,' to UPDATE with comments from Harnett; picks up 7th graf, `The charges ...' SUBS 9th graf, `Ritter, a man ...,' to ADD background. ADDS 2 grafs with further comment. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The priest who founded Covenant House, the nation's largest organization for runaway youths, resigned Tuesday after months of disputing allegations of sexual misconduct. ``The controversy that has surrounded me for the past three months has made it impossible for me to lead Covenant House effectively,'' the Rev. Bruce Ritter said in a statement. Frank Macchiarola, the former city schools chancellor who served as acting president while the allegations were investigated, also resigned. Macchiarola, who was named acting president Feb. 7, said in a statement he was resigning because the shelter's board of directors had voted against his proposals for the future of Covenant House. A spokeswoman for Macchiarola, Maureen Connelly, said he was not available for interviews but said Macchiarola had wanted to conduct reviews, investigations and audits of current practices and make changes. James J. Harnett, executive vice president and chief operating officer, will take over the shelter until a permanent successor to Ritter is found, the organization said in a statement. In an interview, Harnett said he expected that the international search for a successor to the Franciscan priest would probably take months and would be limited to Roman Catholic nuns, brothers and priests. ``The focus has got to be on the needs of the kids,'' he said. ``Covenant House is not one man. It's not me, it's not Father Ritter. He was not all of Covenant House.'' Harnett, 43, said the shelter board accepted Macchiarola's recommendations, and plans to bring in outside consultants to revamp operating procedures. The charges against Ritter first arose in December, when the New York Post quoted a onetime male prostitute as saying he had had an affair with Ritter over several months last year. The young man's father defended Ritter, calling his son an emotionally troubled liar. Covenant House later conceded that it had provided the young man, Kevin Kite, with a new identity, using a birth certificate of a 10-year-old boy who died in 1980 without permission from the child's parents. Earlier this year, three more young men were quoted in published reports as saying they had had affairs with Ritter. Ritter, a man who was once celebrated by President Reagan as a hero and who served on the Meese Commission on Pornography, has called the accusations against him ``garbage.''
