Covenant House began in 1968, when Ritter, now 62, put a few runaways up in his apartment. It now serves 25,000 youths annually at 17 shelters in the United States, Canada and Latin America. Nearly all of its $85 million-a-year budget is funded by private donations. In letters to potential donors, Ritter detailed the lives of youths who left abusive homes for a street life of drugs and prostitution, but finally found peace at Covenant House. Since the controversy about Ritter began, contributions were said to have fallen off. Harnett said the controversies of recent months have ``been very upsetting to the kids and the kids are going to be very upset by this decision'' of Ritter leaving. ``But his vision, his courage and determination remain,'' Harnett said.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Leader Calls for New General Election
DOC.TEXT: Opposition leader Kim Dae-jung called Tuesday for early general elections as a referendum on the controversial merger of President Roh Tae-woo's ruling Democratic Justice Party with two opposition groups. Speaking before the National Assembly as head of the Party for Peace and Democracy _ the sole opposition party remaining _ Kim said a general election for national legislators should be held with local elections, tentatively scheduled for June. The next scheduled general election is set for 1992. Roh's governing party disbanded earlier this month to form a new giant ruling party with the No. 2 opposition Reunification Democratic Party, led by Kim Young-sam, and the No. 3 opposition New Democratic Republican Party, headed by Kim Jong-pil. Kim Dae-jung called the merger a ``political coup d'etat'' and ``a breach of contract'' with voters who had voted for members of some political parties that no longer exist. Park Hee-tae, spokesman for the governing party, said Kim's proposal would create confusion. ``We are convinced that the merger is supported by the people and is the way to save the country,'' he said. Roh and the other opposition leaders have said the merger was necessary to end strife among the parties and achieve political, social and economic stability. The new ruling Democratic Liberal Party controls more than two-thirds of the 299-seat National Assembly, easily enough to pass government-backed legislation or change the constitution. Radical students, workers and dissidents have staged demonstrations, some of them violent, in Seoul and other cities to protest the party merger. About 900 people, some from the now defunct opposition parties, met Tuesday in Seoul to form a new opposition party tenatively named the Democratic Party.

The Bush administration, hoping to boost reconciliation in Nicaragua after opposition candidate Violeta Chamorro's election win, is telling the Contra rebels to ``cool it'' and avoid provoking a hostile Sandinista response, U.S. officials say. Shortly after Mrs. Chamorro's victory was confirmed Monday, the State Department asked Chris Arcos, the U.S. ambassador to Honduras, to go to the Contra camps in southern Honduras to make clear the U.S. view on the need for restraint, the officials said. An additional envoy was expected to be sent from Washington, according to the officials. The concern is that the bitterness generated by almost 10 years of warfare, leading to an estimated 30,000 dead, could lead to excesses by revenge-seeking Contras.

The government is refusing to send its AIDS researchers into court to shed light on allegations that drug companies failed to move swiftly enough to prevent their blood products from transmitting the virus to children with hemophilia. The Centers for Disease Control contends AIDS researchers' time is better spent in the laboratory. Lawyers for families of the AIDS victims say they believe both justice and science can be served by having the experts testify. ``Parents whose hemophiliac children have gotten AIDS from AIDS-contaminated blood are shocked that the federal government is refusing access to the truth about what information was given to people in the blood business in the early 1980s about the transmissibility of AIDS,'' said Laura Anderson, a Miami attorney for families who are suing Armour Pharmaceutical of Bradley, Ill., and Cutter Laboratories of Berkeley, Calif. The government has won the first legal skirmishes, most recently a ruling by a federal judge in Atlanta that CDC experts can't be forced to testify in AIDS-related lawsuits.

Gay rights activists say a Supreme Court rebuff will not deter their continuing fight to overturn a general ban on homosexuals in the armed forces. ``There are other remedies for us to take care of this deeply irrational policy,'' said Peri Jude Radecic of the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force. ``We've had a great deal of congressional interest in this. Within the next year, you'll see some good things coming from Congress.'' The court Monday refused to disturb Pentagon policy, which says ``homosexuality is incompatible with military service.'' The court rejected appeals by Miriam Ben-Shalom, denied re-enlistment in the Army Reserve in Wisconsin because she is a lesbian, and James M. Woodward of Spring Valley, Calif., released from active Navy duty because he is gay.

The ``get tough'' approach is failing to deter criminal activity by young black males, 23 percent of whom are behind bars or on probation or parole, a non-profit group says ``We now risk the possibility of writing off an entire generation of black men from leading productive lives,'' said Marc Mauer, assistant director of The Sentencing Project, which promotes alternative punishments and sentencing reform. In a report issued Monday, the group said 609,690 black men age 20 through 29 _ nearly one in every four _ were in prison or jail or on probation or parole in mid-1989. In contrast, only 436,000 black men in the same age group were enrolled in college in 1986, the latest year for which figures were available.

Jesse Jackson's political future is beginning to resemble his past. His announcement Monday that he will not run for mayor of the nation's capital revived the assumption that when the 1992 presidential campaign gets rolling, Jackson will make his third bid for the White House. ``I want to continue to serve, but not as mayor,'' Jackson told a news conference, ending speculation that he might run to succeed the troubled Marion Barry as mayor of the District of Columbia, a city without a state. Serve as what, was the next natural question. ``It is premature to talk about the next level of activity,'' he replied to such queries. ``The push is for statehood.''

DOC.NOTE: $adv02
For release Fri PMs March 2, or thereafter
DOC.TEXT: Church leaders are urging increased reading of the Bible in response to President Bush's proclaiming 1990 the International Year of Bible Reading. The Rev. Harold C. Bennett, head of the Southern Baptist executive committee, said: ``The Bible is God's word of love, hope, direction and fulfillment in a world of hate, despair, confusion and dissatisfaction. That message from the Lord is needed now, more than ever.'' Bush proclaimed the year after a joint Senate-House resolution declared the ``history of our nation clearly illustrates the value of voluntarily applying the teachings of the Bible in the lives of individuals and families.'' The resolution says: ``The Bible has made a unique contribution in shaping the United States as a distinctive and blessed nation and people. Deeply held convictions springing from the Bible led to the early settlement of our nation.''

DOC.HEAD: ``Jesus'' Appears On Television Commercial To Boost Church Attendance
DOC.TEXT: An actor portrays Jesus in an unusual paid television commercial here seeking to boost attendance at an inner-city United Methodist church. The pastor, the Rev. Craig A. Hunter, decided something more was needed than the typical ``come visit us'' appeals used by churches in such efforts. With the help of a local advertising firm, he put together two 30-second spots using an actor portraying Jesus Christ. In one spot, ``Jesus'' is sitting silently and alone in a pew. In the other, he is being led through a church door by a young girl. ``To our knowledge, this is the first church in the nation that has ever used an actor to portray Jesus in a television commercial,'' said Hunter, senior pastor of Richard Brown Memorial United Methodist Church. The commercials, which state, ``There's a very special spirit in this church,'' and that it has ``a few seats left, and one of them is for you,'' began airing in mid-February on TV stations in this city of about 110,000 people. Hunter said it's too soon to gauge the sentiments of the public and other churches. But he's braced for criticism. Armed with a $6,000 grant from the East Ohio Conference of the United Methodist Church, Hunter visited local market and media specialist Vic Rubenstein, who offered his services for free and persuaded an area production crew and Ohio actor John Galgosi to make the commercial at cost. One Sunday last month Hunter cut short the church service, and crews wheeled in a fog machine, lights, movie camera and other equipment. They filmed two commercials in about four hours. One begins with the sound of a heartbeat and features a young man nodding off in a pew. He is the only person in the church, which appears misty. As the camera closes in on the man, a voice-over says, ``Some churches are kind of empty. Others are kind of staid. Others are very sleepy.'' He awakes and his image fades, then becomes the likeness of Jesus, with a small halo around his head. The camera pulls back and he is surrounded by congregation members. In the other commercial, a narrator portrays a visitor, speaking to his wife as he walks around inside the church. ``This is some special church, Martha,'' the man says as the camera scans people in classes and other activities. The man notes the different races and backgrounds of members and says, ``There is something special going here.'' Just then, a little girl walks through the door holding the hand of Jesus, who scans the activities and smiles slightly and approvingly. The character of Jesus, played by Galgosi, 37, does not speak in either commercial. Galgosi, a dark-complexioned Caucasian with brown eyes and long, brown curly hair, wears a robe in the spots. The church bought some of the local commercial time; other spots are given free by stations as public service announcements, Rubenstein said. The church qualifies because it is non-profit, he said. ``The first rule of marketing is one of positioning, of separating your product and your service from the rest,'' said Rubenstein, who attends a synagogue across the street from Hunter's church. Rubenstein said the Richard Brown church seemed special to him because of its mix of people. ``You see the blacks and the whites, the wealthy, the poor, the very secure, ... intellectual, university group, ... the handicapped. Who else but a spirit could bring these kinds of people together?'' The church's stone structure, built in 1915, is near the Youngstown State University campus. Hunter said membership reached about 500 in the 1950s, but residents' migration to the suburbs has cut the congregation to about 200. Hunter and Rubenstein said most of the calls they have received since the ads ran have been positive. ``I warned Craig. I said, believe me, be prepared for the flak,'' Rubenstein said. ``I don't think we've really experienced that backlash yet.'' Richard L. Rustad, pastor of Boardman United Methodist Church, one of the city's larger Methodist churches, said he saw no problems with the commercials. ``We believe, speaking as a person in a mainline church, not only in historical Jesus but in the present Christ, and it seems like they're trying to indicate that the person and presence of Christ can be found within that congregation,'' Rustad said. ``In fact it's creative. It's good. ``It's a very interesting church over there because it's very heterogeneous,'' he said of the Richard Brown congregation. ``I think if Christ were to come back, that may be the very kind of place you'd find him.''

DOC.HEAD: Paying Taxes: A Matter of Records
DOC.NOTE: Eds: John Cunniff is on vacation
DOC.TEXT: If you harbor any doubts that life is a business, stop and consider the record-keeping work that the government requires of the 100 million-plus people who pay U.S. income taxes. The assignment starts with, but is by no means limited to, filing a tax return on time each year. The rules also require you to be ready to support that return with documents on just about any question that the Internal Revenue Service might raise. So even people who farm out their tax affairs to paid advisers often find themselves with boxes or file drawers full of records that threaten to overflow. At this time of year, especially, the issue tends to arise: How long must one hang onto all those canceled checks from some year in the administration of President Ford? Is there any simple system to use in determining when to throw old tax records away? The short answers to those questions, in order, are ``It depends'' and ``Probably not.'' But cumbersome as the process of tax record-keeping may be, experts on the subject say it need not be totally unmanageable. The basic rule of thumb is that all documents related to tax matters should be kept for a minimum of three years after the date on which a return is filed or due (whichever comes later). That is the standard period in which the government has a legal right to take action on your return. The limitation period stretches to six years in cases where it is determined that a taxpayer failed to report income amounting to 25 percent or more of the total listed on any year's return. ``As a matter of course we recommend that you keep all your canceled checks for six years,'' says the accounting firm of Ernst & Young in this year's edition of its Arthur Young Tax Guide. Before you toss your pile of 1979 records in the trash bin, furthermore, advisers suggest that you give some thought to a few other eventualities. For one thing, in cases of fraud or failure to file any return, the statute of limitations may extend indefinitely. Additionally, you might give the documents a quick review before pitching them to see if they contain any information of lasting relevance. That applies in particular to anything that might affect the cost basis of property you own that you might one day sell at a capital gain subject to tax. Suppose you installed new kitchen cabinets in your home in 1979. Proof of expenses for such lasting improvements can lower the tax you might owe when the time comes to sell the house. Or to put it the other way around, an absence of such proof might well mean that you have to pay far more in taxes when you sell than the law would otherwise have required. For a variety of purposes, tax specialists generally agree that you should keep copies of your yearly tax returns indefinitely. KMPG Peat Warwick, accountants, suggest another reason to curb any instinct you feel to get rid of tax records as soon as possible: ``Occasionally, new tax legislation that benefits the individual is made effective retroactively. This may provide the opportunity to file an amended tax return and collect a refund _ but only if you have the appropriate records.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Doctor Treating America's Down and Out
DOC.TEXT: There's no couch in psychiatrist Lia Dobraya's office at the Salvation Army Adult Rehabilitation Center, just a couple of straight-backed chairs, a metal desk and some file cabinets. But the doctor who spent the first 27 years of her career in the Soviet Union calls the office her palace, and to the downtrodden who come through the door to try to beat drug or alcohol addiction, it's a trip toward sobriety. ``The happiest moment, really, of my life in America was when the Salvation Army hired me,'' said Dobraya, a therapist at the 126-bed center the past year. Dobraya is one of 11 clinical staffers at the Salvation Army's largest drug and alcohol rehabilitation center in the country. ``This was something she wanted to do. She came to us,'' said the center's administrator, Maj. Robert Bodine. ``One of her first thoughts when she came to the United States was to somehow be involved with the Salvation Army in terms of reflecting her own values in wanting to be involved with people and to help them.'' The Christian-oriented charitable agency wraps the spiritual approach into the educational and clinical aspects of treating _ at no charge _ alcoholics and drug addicts. ``Dr. Dobraya had a great deal of experience in treating alcoholism and drug addiction in the Soviet Union,'' said Dr. Edward Lataille, the center's director of clinical services. ``A lot of that skill is transferrable here.'' With her background and experience of oppression, ``she's able to understand, perhaps, some of the pain and hardships'' that many of the center's patients have experienced, he said. Some 450 people a year go through the center's six-month residential treatment program, about 40 percent of whom overcome their addiction, Lataille said. The patients' average age is 34 and they cross the social spectrum. The one thing they have in common is that alcohol or drugs have shattered their lives, often to the point where they're living on the street. ``Many of our people have been so devastated by the disease of alcoholism or drug addiction that they've lost medical insurance, they've lost family and don't have money or insurance to pay for treatment. So, we're treating a population that would otherwise not be treated,'' Lataille said. A graduate of Odessa's Medical Institute, Dobraya went into psychiatry after an internship at a mental hospital exposed her to the sadness of mental disease and chemical dependency. ``I thought, `I must help them,''' she said. And though failures often outnumber successful treatments, the success stories make the job worthwhile. ``It's hard, but it's a big happiness when you can see you can help these people,'' said Dobraya. Like the United States, the Soviet Union has severe problems with substance abuse. She described alcoholism as the Soviet Union's No. 1 health problem and drug abuse, once dismissed as a capitalistic phenomenon, as an emerging social problem. Because religion was frowned upon in the Soviet Union, doctors were forbidden from introducing it as a theraputic tool for recovering susbstance abusers. Rather, Dobraya said, techniques including hypnosis, group and individual psychotherapy and medications were emphasized in the Soviet Union. But she estimated that more than 80 percent of the Soviets treated for alcoholism return to drinking. Now, Dobraya, 51, is free to ``appeal to the souls of our clients'' as a way to help them toward sobriety. ``The people in the program are happy and from a psychiatric point of view, I know it works for them more than any education or medication,'' she said. In the Soviet Union, before recent reforms allowing more religious freedom, ``there was no possibility to even think about a Christian approach or spiritual approach,'' she said. ``Even if I could have used that approach, many could not understand it because they grew up without religion. They believed in a false religion. This false religion was created on blood, the blood of millions of people.'' Philosophical differences with the Soviet state and the way its secret police manipulated psychiatry in the past to suppress dissent also motivated her November 1988 emigration to the United States. She was allowed to leave with her husband, Vladimir, a 48-year-old software engineer, when emigration policies were loosened. Their two adult sons, a daughter-in-law and a granddaughter stayed behind, although Dobraya hopes to one day be reunited with them in America. ``I like and appreciate this country and its people, who are very kind and good and calm,'' she said. ``There are not so many irritated people, even among our clients who have emotional problems. The Soviet people are kind of survivors. They are, it seems, almost in a permanent state of tension.''

DOC.HEAD: The 1990 Census: What Will it Find?
DOC.TEXT: ``So, tell me about yourself,'' the Census Bureau is about to ask Americans, a bit like an eager young man in a singles bar. Both suitor and statistician think they already know some of the answers. But, inevitably, both will hear things they didn't expect. ``There were some surprises in 1980 and we also expect some surprises in 1990,'' says William P. Butz, associate director of the Census Bureau. ``There are things we think are happening but, come the '90 census, we'll find that some of that is wrong,'' Butz acknowledges. What surprises are likely? With Census Day set for April 1, and months of effort to follow in compiling and analyzing the numbers, Butz says simply, ``I don't know yet.'' While the Census Bureau takes a national head count only once every 10 years, it is constantly taking sample surveys and has a pretty good idea of what's going on with the nation's quarter-billion people. The 1990 census will find not only a bigger population than in 1980, but one that is different in many ways. Americans are older, live in different places, have a larger ethnic component and have changed socially and economically in the last decade. Anticipating what the April count will find, here's a look at the Census Bureau's most recent estimates:

The U.S. population was estimated at 249.6 million as of Jan. 1 and should be close to 250 million by April 1, up from 226.5 million in 1980. The first census, in 1790, counted 3.9 million people. That's just slightly more than now live in the Dallas-Fort Worth area.

Hispanics now make a big dent in America's consciousness, having increased to more than 20 million people as they flooded into the country in recent years. Hispanics now account for 8.4 percent of the population, up from 6.4 percent in the 1980 census. That means Hispanics are growing faster than the general population. ``Immigration accounted for about half of the overall gain,'' said Carmen DeNavas of the Census Bureau. ``Since 1982 the Central and South American population here has grown 67 percent.'' The location and characteristics of immigrants will be of interest this time, Butz said. In 1980 the bureau was surprised at the lack of education among Haitian immigrants, for example, and it located some unexpected pockets of new arrivals. The nation's racial breakdown also is changing. In 1980, 85.9 percent of Americans were white, 11.7 percent were black and 2.3 percent were Asian or members of other races. Estimates for 1990 anticipate the white share will be down to 84.2 percent, with blacks up to 12.4 percent and Asians and others rising to 3.4 percent. The 1980s appear to be the first decade in at least 100 years when more blacks moved to the South than left it, and the census hopes to learn more about that trend, Butz said. Getting an accurate county of minorities is an important effort this time, since studies of the 1980 census concluded blacks were missed more often than whites.

Families including a married couple account for just 56 percent of all households, down from 61 percent in 1980 and 70 percent in 1970, reflecting the growth in single people and one-parent families. Family size also has been declining as people have fewer children. In 1980 there were 79 youths aged 18 and under for every 100 families. By 1989 that was down to 69. The 1990 count may find the decline in childbearing is easing, however, as women who put off having families to complete schooling and start careers decide to have children. ``We are seeing significant changes in the number of women in their 30s having children. Women are postponing their first births and opting for more education and more time in the labor force,'' says Amara Bachu, a Census Bureau statistician.

The growth of single-parent families stemming from divorce also has allowed for more remarriages. Hence, the number of stepchildren grew to 6.8 million by 1985, up 15 percent from 1980. It it expected to prove even higher in 1990. Historically there have been far fewer children in one-parent homes, with more of those children in homes headed by a widowed, rather than divorced, parent, says Arlene Saluter of the Census Bureau.

Wives' earnings were increasing at twice the rate of husbands' in the 1980s. But wives still earn half of what their husbands bring home. From 1980 to 1987, wives' earnings rose 23 percent, compared to a 12 percent growth for their husbands. But wives still averaged $13,250, compared to $29,150 for their husbands.

The nation's center of population is continuing it's trek south and west. The mythical point where the nation could balance if everyone weighed the same crossed the Mississippi River in 1980, winding up in Missouri. Since then the Sun Belt states have continued to lead the nation in growth. In the 1980s, California added 4 million people, the most of any state. Indeed, California, Texas and Florida accounted for half the national growth in the decade.

The nation continues to age as the giant post-World War II baby boom generation matures. The median age of the United States hit 30 in 1980, grew to 32.1 by 1987 and will be even higher when the 1990 count is complete. Median means that half of all Americans are older than that age and half younger.

In addition to moving to the South and the West, Americans have been concentrating growth in metropolitan areas in the 1980s, in contrast to the 1970s, when rural areas experienced a boom. The result has been city growth in the Sun Belt, with places such as San Diego, Jacksonville, Fla., and San Jose, Calif., moving up the list of biggest cities.

Americans are better educated than ever before, thanks largely to the educational efforts of the baby boom generation. The 1990 census is expected to show 77.7 percent of men and 76.9 percent of women aged 25 and over have completed high school and 21.9 percent of men and 15.6 percent of women are college graduates, American Demographics magazine says. By contrast, in 1980, 67.7 percent of men were high school grads and 20.3 percent had finished college. For women, the 66.2 percent had finished high school and 12.9 percent held college degrees. But those gains may not continue. ``Men aged 25 to 34 are now less likely to have completed college than were the baby boomers ten years ago. The high cost of education may be pushing young adults out of college and into the workforce,'' say researchers Judith Waldrop and Thomas Exter.

The 1990 census will count people ``in shelters, on the streets and in halfway houses,'' says the bureau's Peter Bounpane. With estimates of the number of homeless ranging from 300,000 to 2 million, the bureau hopes to prodice a reasonably accurate estimate of these people for the first time.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 33,897.95, up 576.08 points, or 1.73 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Tuesday.

Wall Street shrugged off the latest bad news from Japan, and the U.S. stock market closed higher despite the Tokyo market's second-worst drop ever. Markets in London and Frankfurt, West Germany, also showed strength Monday following the latest plunge in Tokyo, where stock prices have been on a sustained decline from record highs reached in late 1989. On Wall Street, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 38.29 points to 2,602.48, snapping a string of five straight declines. Broader market indicators also rose.

American Express Co. said it would inject $750 million into its troubled Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. brokerage subsidiary through the purchase of Shearson stock. At the same time, American Express said Monday it would abandon its previously announced plan to sell Shearson shares to American Express shareholders. Shearson, likewise, would withdraw its planned sale of $250 million worth of stock rights. The move by American Express represents the second major change in a month in its plan to bail out the nation's second-largest brokerage.

The nation's top business economists believe the U.S. economy will avoid a recession for the next three years and break the record expansion set in the 1960s, according to a new survey. But the poll released Monday by the National Association of Business Economists indicated the economy is in a danger zone and is likely to grow only a sluggish 1.7 percent this year before accelerating to a 2.5 percent rate next year. The 65 professional forecasters also saw little sign of significant progress over the next two years in achieving the zero inflation goal set by the Federal Reserve Board.

Texas billionaire Harold C. Simmons said he will solicit shareholder votes to oust Lockheed Corp.'s board of directors and accused the defense contractor of attempting to stymie the bid. In a filing Monday with federal regulators, Simmons disclosed that in addition to seeking a new board he wants to eliminate Lockheed's shareholders' rights plan, which would make it prohibitively expensive for anyone to buy more than 20 percent of the company's common stock. Simmons has an 18.9 percent stake in Lockheed.

Low-level talks resumed between Greyhound Lines Inc. and its drivers' union as a Friday strike deadline approached that could curtail operations at the only nationwide bus system. Meanwhile, the National Labor Relations Board said Monday it is investigating charges of unfair labor practices filed by both sides. The Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions said subcommittees of its full negotiating committee are meeting in Scottsdale, Ariz., with company representatives ``to explore options for resuming bargaining talks on a new labor contract.''

Pfizer Inc. shareholders filed a lawsuit accusing company executives of withholding information about the financial impact of defects in a mechanical heart valve made by its Shiley Inc. unit. Pfizer stock has been battered in recent days because of potential liabilities from defects in a heart valve product that was removed from the market after reports of malfunctions that killed patients. The class-action lawsuit, filed Monday in U.S. District Court, was brought on behalf of shareholders who purchased Pfizer stock between March 27, 1988, and last Thursday, when a House subcommittee announced it would hold hearings on the heart valve.

The importers of Evian bottled water are launching a new advertising campaign this week even as the importer of a rival water, Perrier, announced its drink may be back in circulation within two months. Evian importers point out that their new advertising has been in development since June and that plans to launch the effort in late February were made months before Source Perrier SA recalled bottles of its flagship brand worldwide erlier this month. The new Evian ads make no reference at all to the problems that led to the Perrier recall.

Several thousand East Germans applied for the first benefits their government has ever given the unemployed, whose ranks may swell dramatically as the nation moves toward capitalism. Labor officials said Monday the number of applicants was much smaller than anticipated, but noted that economic reforms expected to cost hundreds of thousands of jobs have yet to be made. At the moment, East Germany has a severe labor shortage because skilled workers continue leaving for West Germany.

Until recently, the Army has kept quiet about a scientist's success in engineering the gene for spider silk into a bacteria that produces a fiber stronger than a silkworm's silk _ indeed, far stronger than steel. Now the secret is out. The military hopes to use the new fabric for bulletproof vests, helmets, parachute cords and other strong, light equipment. And the people on New York's Seventh Avenue may want to take notice _ silk stockings may come back, too.

The stock market kept its composure Monday in the wake of a nasty tumble on Tokyo's exchange and managed a convincing advance. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials jumped 38.29 points to 2,602.48. The dollar climbed broadly, reaching its highest levels in eight months against the Japanese yen. Gold prices fell. Bond prices rose. Precious metals futures plunged; oil futures were sharply higher; grains and soybeans were lower; livestock and pork futures declined; and cocoa was sharply lower.

DOC.HEAD: Evian Breaks New Ad Campaign; Perrier Plans to Get Back on Shelves
DOC.TEXT: The importers of Evian bottled water are launching a new advertising campaign this week even as the importer of a rival bottled water, Perrier, announced its drink may be back in circulation within two months. Evian importers point out that their new advertising has been in development since June and that timing of the campaign was decided long before Source Perrier SA recalled bottles of its flagship brand earlier this month. The new Evian ads make no reference at all to the the Perrier recall, which followed the discovery that some Perrier bottles were contaminated with traces of a toxic chemical, benzene. ``We are not trying to capitalize on the Perrier recall,'' said Maryanne Farrell, senior marketing manager for Evian Waters of France Inc., based in Greenwich, Conn. ``It's unfortunate for Perrier that it happened.' But timing of the Evian campaign is opportune nonetheless. Grocers and restuarant owners have had to scramble to find replacements for Perrier, the third best-selling bottled water in the U.S., since its Feb. 9 recall here. Orders for LaCroix Sparkling Water have quadrupled, according to LaCroix Water Co., based in La Crosse, Wis. The company says it boosted production by 50 percent to 60 percent a day to meet demand. Saratoga Springs Mineral Water Co. in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., another Evian company, has noted a marked increase in sales of its Saratoga natural sparkling water since Perrier was recalled on Feb. 9 in the United States. ``They have sold in a week's time what they normally sell in a month,'' she said. The production day has been lengthened 50 percent to meet demand. And Canadian Shield Spring Water Co., based in Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario, Canada, said the recall has meant more demand for its Canadian Spring Premium Sparkling Water even as the company was expanding distribution nationally after test marketing it in the Upper Midwest and Northeast for the past 2{ years. ``We have had to put new distributors on hold'' while meeting increased demand from current distributors, said spokeswoman Helen Gillespie. Perrier, which insists it acted responsibly in ordering the worldwide recall, said Monday in Paris that its recall was nearly complete. Its U.S. arm, Perrier Group of America Inc., said new safeguards are being put in place and it was expected the Perrier brand ``will be on the shelves within six to eight weeks.'' Evian sales figures since the recall are not yet available, said Evian's Ms. Farrell. And she noted that non-carbonated Evian is not directly comparable to the bubbly Perrier, which is often used on social occasions. The company refused to comment on spending plans, but trade reports indicate Evian plans to spend about $6 million on its ad campaign in 1990, up about 50 percent from last year. The campaign includes commercials that debuted Monday on television stations in New York and Los Angeles and will be run next month in San Francisco, Washington, D.C., Miami, Philadelphia and San Diego. The ads, shot in Hawaii and Yosemite National Park in California, show mountains, lakes and trees and active people basking in the natural beauty and drinking Evian, which is described as ``nature's gift.'' In one commercial, the viewer sees the dawn breaking through a wooded area where a man runs, a woman stretches her leg muscles and a bicyclist rides. ``Morning ... 365 chances a year to do something healthy,'' a narrator says. Like morning, the narrator adds, Evian is ``always there for you to do something healthy.'' Evian also is running a print ad in eight major newspapers that runs an unusually long 2,500 words and is called ``Just a Drop of What You Should Know About Water'' in which it tells consumers why their bodies need water. Hellen Berry, market research director at Beverage Marketing Corp. in New York, said local or regional brands are benefitting from Perrier's absence. But Perrier Group is filling the void as well with its own domestic sparkling water brands. Spokeswoman Jane Lazgin said Perrier is able to offer store owners replacements such as Poland Spring in the Northeast, Calistoga and Arrowhead in California and Ozarka in Texas. ``We have had real sound business relationships with these retailers for 10-12 years and we are retaining much of our space,'' Ms. Lazgin said.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Shuttle Pilots Ratify New Contract
DOC.TEXT: Pilots at Trump Shuttle, the northeast airline service named after the billionaire developer who bought it last June, have ratified a new contract agreement. The four-year contract was approved by the pilots over the weekend and announced by the airline Monday. It provides for wage increases averaging 10 percent this year and a total 15 percent over the next three years. The contract also makes changes in work rules to allow greater scheduling flexibility and calls for the pilots to begin sharing increased costs of medical benefits in 1991. Nearly all the 227 pilots at Trump Shuttle, which links New York with Boston and Washington, formerly worked for Eastern Airlines. Real estate tycoon Donald Trump bought the shuttle service from Miami-based Eastern for $365 million. Ray Grebey, the shuttle's chief labor negotiator, said in a statement that the new agreement reflects ``the unique nature of hourly shuttle operations.'' The wage hike for this year, which depends on a pilot's rank and averages 10 percent, was effective Feb. 19, Trump Shuttle spokeswoman Joan Fudala said. She said the changes in work rules will allow standby shuttle crews, for example, to be assigned to fly charter flights when passenger traffic doesn't require additional shuttle flights. The new contract also replaces a two-tiered wage structure for pilots with a single tier, Ms. Fudala said. Starting pay for all new pilots will be $26,400 a year. The contract calls for a retroactive 8 percent wage increase for July 18, 1989, through Jan. 1, 1990, for all pilots who formerly worked for Eastern. The wage hike reflects the result of arbitration between Eastern management and the pilots. Trump Shuttle pilots belong to the Air Line Pilots Association, one of three unions that struck Eastern last March, pushing it into bankruptcy court reorganization. Eastern pilots and flight attendants halted their sympathy strikes last November, but the Machinists union is continuing its walkout. Contract negotiations covering the 280 flight attendants at Trump Shuttle are due to start around April 1, Ms. Fudala said. Talks with Machinists have been postponed pending a challenge from a rival group, the Aircraft Mechanics Fraternal Association, which is seeking to represent mechanics at Trump Shuttle.

DOC.HEAD: New Ford Boss Rolls Out New Escort
LaserPhoto DT2
DOC.TEXT: With a handshake and the passing of a set of keys, Ford Motor Co. marked a change of leadership and the introduction of a new Escort that the company says is a prototype of its global manufacturing strategy. Chairman Donald Petersen sat at the wheel and his designated successor, Vice Chairman Harold ``Red'' Poling, rode alongside as the nation's No. 2 automaker on Monday rolled the first production model of its 1991 Escort, a bright red two-door, off the line at its Wayne assembly plant. The car, Poling said, ``is a sign of Ford's commitment to building small cars here in the United States.'' With the closing earlier this month of No. 3 Chrysler Corp.'s Jefferson Avenue assembly plant in Detroit, Ford became the only one of the Big Three that makes subcompacts in the United States. Sales leader General Motors Corp. gets its small cars, mostly grouped under the Geo nameplate, from Japanese makers or joint ventures in the United States and Canada. Nevertheless, Ford's new subcompact relies heavily on Japanese know-how. Mazda Motor Corp., which is 25-percent owned by Ford, designed the car and has helped Ford gear up its Escort plant using Japanese production techniques and equipment. Monday's ceremony took place in the newly renovated Wayne Assembly Plant. It's loaded with Japanese influences ranging from the obvious _ huge Komatsu stamping presses _ to the not-so-obvious _ a method of manufacturing strikingly similar to that used at Mazda's assembly plant in Flat Rock, south of Detroit. Petersen and Poling, who will take over as chairman when Petersen retires Thursday after more than 40 years with the company, said the Escort project shows how Ford is integrating its worldwide manufacturing business in Asia, Europe and North America. Ford is investing $2 billion into the project, code-named CT-20, which also involves production of the Mercury Tracer at the company's plant in Hermosillo, Mexico. Part of the project involves the 900 or so Wayne stamping and body assembly employees who work under what's called a modern operating agreement _ a manufacturing method using small teams of workers with the ability to perform several tasks. It is Ford's only such agreement in operation. GM and Chrysler have similar programs at a variety of their operations. The Ford agreement was patterned after programs at Japanese plants, including Mazda's Flat Rock factory, which makes the Ford Probe. As at Mazda's only U.S. assembly plant, workers at Ford's Wayne stamping plant wear identical uniforms and coordinate their jobs through the use of teams. Automakers said the concept improves contact between management and employees and helps productivity by encouraging employees to suggest how a job can be performed better. ``Perhaps this will be a new way of doing business,'' said Kevin McGuinness, an industrial engineer who now works in the new stamping operation linked to the main assembly plant. The United Auto Workers union has said there is a danger in the team concept eroding the traditional labor-management relationship. Although Poling said the Escort itself would be unprofitable, Ford is pinning a lot on the subcompact. The company needs the vehicle to help it meet government fuel economy standards, which sets average mileage standards that each automaker's fleet must meet. The more Escorts it sells, the more low-mileage, high-profit mid-and full-size cars Ford can sell without incurring any government penalties.

DOC.HEAD: Simmons Begins Proxy Fight for Lockheed, Hires Salomon Bros., Jefferies
DOC.TEXT: Dallas billionaire Harold C. Simmons is soliciting shareholder votes to oust Lockheed Corp.'s board of directors and has hired consultants on both coasts to help. In a filing with federal regulators Monday, Simmons disclosed that he also wants to eliminate Lockheed's shareholders rights plan, also known as a poison pill defense. That rights plan would make it prohibitively expensive for anyone to buy more than 20 percent of the company's common stock. Simmons has an 18.9 percent stake. The filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission also disclosed that NL Industries has hired New York investment bankers Salomon Brothers Inc. as a proxy solicitor and Jefferies & Company Inc., a Los Angeles-based firm, as a consultant in the proxy battle. NL agreed to pay Salomon $150,000 per month and Jefferies $100,000 per month. In addition, the filing disclosed that it would retain Salomon as a financial adviser and investment banker for a year if the proxy fight succeeds. Toward that end, NL paid Salomon $750,000 up front and agreed to pay mutually agreed upon fees ``from time to time.'' A letter to Lockheed included in the SEC filing blasted the California-based defense contractor for reportedly announcing the date of its annual meeting at a time designed to hamper NL Industries Inc.'s bid to unseat the board. Under company by-laws, shareholders have 10 days from the public announcement of the meeting's date to submit proxy statements for consideration at the meeting. NL Industries, a Houston chemicals concern controlled by Simmons, said Lockheed announced the March 29 meeting shortly after 6 p.m. on Feb. 16. ``By announcing the shareholders meeting after the close of business on a Friday preceding a three-day holiday weekend, Lockheed's management effectively gave NL just five business days to prepare its nomination materials,'' NL Industries President J. Landis Martin wrote Lockheed. ``We hope that management's conduct in connection with the announcement of the annual meeting does not mean that we are in for five weeks of manipulation of Lockheed's corporate machinery,'' Martin added. A Lockheed spokesman, Ron Meder, said the company had no comment on Martin's allegations. Simmons, of Dallas, revealed his 15 board nominees last Thursday. They include himself, Martin, former Sen. John G. Tower, a Texas Republican, and Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., a retired admiral and former chief of naval operations. All the nominees on Simmons' slate _ with the exception of himself, Martin and Michael Snetzer, president of Valhi Inc., another Simmons controlled company _ will be paid $20,000 apiece if they are not elected, according to the filing. Simmons decided to launch a proxy fight after Lockheed Chairman Daniel M. Tellep rebuffed his request for board representation.

DOC.HEAD: Honda Won't Enter East Europe _ For Now
DOC.TEXT: Honda Motor Co.'s chief executive officer says the automaker has no immediate plans to make vehicles in the emerging Eastern European market, although it is preparing to sell a U.S.-made station wagon in Europe. ``We are fully aware that major changes are taking place. Unfortunately, however, we are not very well versed in situations in Eastern Europe,'' Tadashi Kume said Monday. He was in Detroit to accept an award from Automotive Industries magazine. Honda spokesman Shin Tanaka said, ``It's too early to make a judgment.'' Other automakers, including General Motors Corp. and Suzuki Motor Co., already have signed deals to bring manufacturing into Eastern Europe and other companies are considering moves into the region. Honda is preparing to begin exporting to Europe a U.S.-made Accord station wagon, Kume said. ``Perhaps in the not-too-distant future the Accord wagon would be produced at the Ohio plant and would be the first car we would be shipping from the United States to Europe,'' said Kume. There is debate about whether U.S.-made Hondas should be classified as Japanese or U.S. vehicles as five of the 12 European Community nations have stiff barriers on importing Japanese cars. France and Italy are pushing for EC-wide quotas to restrict all Japanese cars regardless of where the vehicles are built. But Kume said he doesn't expect Honda to run into problems. ``We would hope they end up with a very amicable conclusion,'' he said. Honda will begin making the Accord wagon at its assembly plant in Marysville, Ohio, later this year for the 1991 model year. Honda's Marysville plant now makes its Civic and Accord models. The Honda Accord was the best-selling car in the United States last year, the first time a car with a Japanese company's nameplate topped the best-seller list. Honda sold 362,707 of the cars in 1989, topping the Ford Taurus at 348,061. Late last year, Honda began Civic production at a new plant in East Liberty, Ohio, making Honda the only Japan-based company with two assembly plants in the United States. By 1992, Honda will more than double its production at the East Liberty plant to 150,000 cars a year, while production of about 360,000 cars a year will continue at Marysville, said Honda spokesman Aki Kato. Of those, about 50,000 cars will be shipped to Japan from the United States. Other cars, including the Accord wagon, will be shipped across the Atlantic.

DOC.HEAD: American Express To Inject $750 Million Into Shearson
DOC.TEXT: The stock market's increasingly bearish attitude toward securities brokers appears to have forced American Express Co. to drop plans to reduce its stake in Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., the nation's No. 2 brokerage. American Express said Monday it will inject $750 million into its Shearson and increase its ownership of the troubled Wall Street house by purchasing new Shearson stock. The move would appear to be a significant setback for American Express. The financial services company had been trying for months to reduce its stake in Shearson to below 50 percent so it could remove the troubled broker from its balance sheet and reduce its exposure to the sharp profits swings of Wall Street. ``It sounds like American Express is going to take over Shearson lock, stock and barrel,'' said Perrin Long, a brokerage industry analyst for Lipper Analytical Securities Corp. The new plan will boost American Express' stake in Shearson by an undetermined amount, said American Express spokesman Matt Stover. It replaces a previous plan to shore up Shearson's finances that would have reduced American Express' stake in the broker to about 45 percent from 61 percent currently. Under the abandoned plan, Shearson would have sold $250 million worth of stock to its existing shareholders. American Express had planned to distribute its quota of Shearson shares to American Express shareholders. The Shearson share offering was dropped ``in light of unsettled conditions affecting the securities industry,'' American Express said in a statement. In addition to the Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing by the parent of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., profits at many Wall Street firms have been pressured by a drop in merger activity and securities underwriting and sluggish stock and bond trading since the October 1987 crash. Just last week, First Boston Corp. issued statements denying that it was under pressure because of loans to troubled buyout companies. And last month, Merrill Lynch & Co. reported a $213 million loss for 1989 after taking a heft $470 million charge to cover layoffs and cost-cutting. Asked whether the new plan represented a change of heart, Stover said American Express always had a commitment to Shearson. ``What we are doing with our action today is making a very clear, unequivocal, strong statement of our support of Shearson for the long term,'' he said. ``This is an industry where client confidence is of utmost importance,'' he added. ``There are times that you need to send a stronger signal.'' Long said the brokerage's earnings volatility still makes it unattractive to American Express in the long run. ``The longer-term strategy at American Express is to get Shearson into much better operating condition and then one way or the other get themselves out of Shearson altogether,'' he said. The latest move by American Express represents the second major change in a month in its plan to bail out Shearson, which has been under pressure to raise its capital levels. Late last month, Shearson scrapped a plan to sell stock to the public to raise cash after its stock price declined sharply. That move came in the wake of the sudden resignation under pressure of Shearson's chairman, Peter A. Cohen. Shearson needs capital because of the threat of a ratings downgrade by credit-rating agencies. Last fall, Moody's Investors Service Inc. said it was considering downgrading Shearson's rating because of the firm's low capital level, weak profits and exposure to commercial real estate loans and investments, as well as the overall securities industry slump. Like other securities firms, Shearson finances much of its activity with borrowed money. A ratings downgrade would raise its costs by forcing it to pay greater interest on its borrowings. Under the new plan, American Express will buy a combination of common and preferred Shearson stock worth $750 million. The common stock will be bought at $11 a share. Shearson stock closed unchanged Monday at $10.87{ a share in New York Stock Exchange trading. American Express disclosed its plans after the stock market closed. Analysts say much of Shearson's trouble stems from overexpansion during Cohen's reign. Shearson grew from a medium-sized retail outfit to a diversified brokerage by acquiring investment banking firm Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb in 1984 and retail brokerage E.F. Hutton & Co. in 1988. Cohen was replaced by Howard L. Clark Jr., chief financial officer and executive vice president of American Express. Clark's father was American Express chairman before current Chairman James D. Robinson. Analysts interpreted Clark's appointment as a sign that American Express wanted to run the troubled brokerage directly. The new recapitalization plan appears to be another move in that direction.

DOC.HEAD: Traders Wait, Impatiently, for Government to Raise Interest Rate
With PM-Japan-Markets, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: While prices have plunged on the Tokyo Stock Exchange in recent days, traders and the government have been playing a waiting game on the key question of interest rates. Many analysts believe the government must raise rates to cool the inflationary fears that many believe are underlying the market's jitters. But a rate increase could unsettle the market further because higher rates make stocks less attractive. ``Uncertainty hurts the market. An interest rate increase will hurt the market. The question is which will hurt more,'' said Robert Alan Feldman, an economist for Salomon Brothers' Asian subsidiary. The Tokyo Stock Exchange suffered its second-worst daily drop ever on Monday, with the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average falling 4.5 percent. The key market index has dropped about 14 percent since reaching record highs at the end of 1989. The index rallied 1.7 percent today after swinging sharply during the session. Many analysts and dealers are convinced that the Bank of Japan's only option to help settle the market is to raise interest rates. For weeks, market speculation has been that Japan's central bank would raise its discount rate, the interest it charges for loans to commercial banks. Analysts say such a move is needed to curb inflation, which has been heralded by a rapidly increasing money supply and a severe labor shortage, and to cool high stock and land prices that many see as signs of economic overheating. Expectations were that the move would follow the Feb. 18 parliamentary elections. It didn't, and analysts attributed the major stock market slide that began the next day to uncertainties over interest rates. In an interview Monday, Bank of Japan Governor Yasushi Mieno reiterated the bank's cautious stance on another increase in the discount rate, which was raised three times last year. ``Now we have to see how these rising interest rates (from last year) will affect the economy. We hope for a favorable result, but if we find that the measures we have taken so far are not enough, then we will have to move into the next step,'' he said. ``We are also listening to the views, which we hear in the markets, that if we raised the rate again at a time when stock prices are declining so sharply, it would push the market further down,'' he said. Feldman and others who urge an interest rate hike acknowledge that such a move might not immediately stop the fall on Tokyo's stock market. Interest rate increases tend to lower demand for stock shares because of the prospect that higher borrowing costs will hamper corporate earnings. But, Feldman contended, an interest rate boost would stabilize the Japanese yen, and ``will be a basis for calming down.'' Many analysts believe a ``vicious cycle'' of ``cheap yen, cheap stocks and cheap bonds'' is behind the turmoil in the Tokyo markets. ``The decline of each one has accelerated the decline of the other two,'' said Johsen Takahashi, director of Mitsubishi Research Institute Inc. If an interest rate increase strengthens the yen, these analysts say, that ultimately will break the cycle. The weakening Japanese currency has declined by 4.13 yen against the U.S. dollar in the last five trading days. The dollar closed Monday at 148.65 yen. ``As long as they (Bank of Japan) are waiting to help maintain the pursestrings of the Ministry of Finance, they'll screw up the rest of us,'' said Doug Schumway, a trader for Jardine Fleming Securities.

DOC.HEAD: Tokyo Markets: Stocks Recoup Some Losses, Dollar Surges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with market, dollar closing up. Pickup 5th graf `On Monday, the index...'
DOC.TEXT: Share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange bounced back moderately Tuesday, one day after the market's main index suffered its second-worst plunge ever, while the dollar rose slightly. The dollar closed at 149.03 yen, up 0.38 yen. After opening at 148.30 yen, the currency ranged between 148.10-149.50 yen. The dollar has gained 4.56 yen in the last six trading days. The dollar remained relatively firm against the yen despite the Bank of Japan's intermittent dollar-selling intervention to prop up the declining yen by selling dollars, traders said. The intervention amounted to some $2 billion, the Japan Broadcasting Corp. said. The yen remained weak and the demand for dollars strong since Japan's economic fundamentals have remained constant, said Bank of Tokyo trader Masato Hayashi. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues recouped 576.08 points, or 1.73 percent, closing at 33,897.95. On Monday, the index fell 1,569.10 points, or 4.5 percent, to close at 33,321.87. The loss was second only to the 3,836.48 plunge of Oct. 20, 1987, after Wall Street's ``Black Monday.'' That fall of 14.9 percent, however, was less than New York's Black Monday plunge of 22.6 percent. While the yen remained weak, demand for dollars is strong, said Hayashi. On Monday, the dollar rose 2.18 yen, closing at 148.65 yen. The dollar has gained 4.13 yen the last five trading days. Dealers initially attributed the Nikkei's recovery to market players' optimistic prospects that the index had hit bottom, as well as an overnight rise of 38 points in New York's Dow Jones industrial average. ``Market players are still a little bit cautious, but they started picking up issues that had fallen, and I think the plunge more or less stopped, at least just for now,'' said Masahiro Umemori, an analyst with Nomura Securities, Co. He said the market's initial recovery was in part encouraged by investors expectations that the Bank of Japan would not raise its official discount rate. It is considered unwise for the central bank to raise its discount rate when the stock market has been deteriorating, analysts said. Higher interest rates discourage stock investment. On the currency market, the dollar was slightly lower following its slip on overseas markets, traders said. Meanwhile, the Tokyo Stock Exchange disclosed it had asked 10 securities firms, both Japanese and foreign, to limit orders for index-linked arbitrage selling prior to the beginning of the morning and afternoon sessions. But there will be no penalty for not following the request, said Tokyo Stock Exchange spokesman Hironobu Takahashi. ``It is all right to do arbitrage deals when the index is rising like today, but arbitrage selling will accelerate the market plunge when the market is weak,'' he said. ``The purpose was to ask our member companies to cooperate and save the market, and whether to take cooperative actions or not is all up to the companies,'' Takahashi said. Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto said he will watch if the stock exchange's measures are effective in stabilizing the market. The stock exchange also eased its restrictions on credited buying and reduced safety deposit money to 40 percent from 50 percent, he added. Such measures began with Tuesday's trading.

DOC.HEAD: Shellfish Expected To Reach Rivers
DOC.TEXT: A striped shellfish now clogging water system pipelines and threatening the ecological balance of the Great Lakes could make its way to rivers around the country in as little as five years, scientists say. The rapidly producing zebra mussels could pose a significant problem for manufacturing plants, many of which have miles of pipes that draw cooling water, the experts warn. The mussels eventually will attach themselves to the insides of pipes supplying factories and municipal water plants, in some cases restricting flow, in the Allegheny, Ohio and Monongahela rivers, said Thomas Nalepa, a biologist with the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The Mississippi River basin also is vulnerable because Lake Michigan, where the mussels are expected to arrive soon, is connected to the Mississippi by the Chicago Canal. However, there is no reliable way to determine exactly when the 1{-inch mollusk will arrive in these or other rivers around the country, scientists said. Zebra mussels, so named because of their brown and white zigzag stripes, have been found in Lake Erie, Lake Ontario and Lake St. Clair, near Detroit. They are growing on spawning reefs favored by walleye, smallmouth bass and other fish in western Lake Erie, raising concern about the future of a valuable fishery. Like barnacles, zebra mussels can travel by clinging to boat hulls. They can survive out of water for perhaps up to 14 days by living on internal moisture. ``Let's say someone from Pittsburgh were to trailer their boat up to fish on Lake Erie and ended up with zebra mussels that attached to their hull,'' said David Kelch, a specialist with Ohio State University's sea grant program. ``They take their boat back to Pittsburgh and in a day or two put the boat into a river or lake in that area. You've got them.'' What's more, the larvae, or young, which are microscopic in size, easily can attach themselves to an angler's minnow bucket, a water nook in a boat trailer or the feathers of a duck. The zebra mussel originated in the Black and Caspian seas between Europe and Asia. In 200 years, it has spread through much of Europe. Two years ago, it was discovered in Lake St. Clair and has infested water intakes for Erie, Toledo, Cleveland and Monroe, Mich. The mussel reproduces at an astonishing rate. A single female produces as many as 40,000 eggs each breeding season. The mollusk also has a voracious appetite for phytoplankton, which are microscopic floating plants that form the bottom of the food chain. Mussels could reduce the supply of phytoplankton for microscopic animals called zooplankton. The zooplankton, in turn, are eaten by smaller fish, which are eaten for food by larger fish. ``Anytime you impact the basic bottom building block of the food chain, you're going to see an impact on the top predators _ walleye, smallmouth bass, yellow perch,'' Kelch said.

DOC.HEAD: K mart to Charge $640 Million Against 1989 Earnings
DOC.TEXT: K mart Corp., apparently aiming to match its competitors' slicker, more contemporary stores, plans to take a $640 million pretax charge against fourth-quarter results to cover the cost of a huge modernization program. K mart officials said Monday the $2.3 billion program to open new stores and modernize existing ones will take about five years. Company spokesman Orren Knauer declined to estimate K mart's 1989 earnings, which are to be announced March 8. But analysts with Seidler-Amdec Securities Inc. of Los Angeles, Calif., predicted K mart earnings would be about $730 million for the year, below the $802.9 million it earned in 1988. The nation's second-largest retailer after Sears, Roebuck and Co. will open about 250 new stores during the five-year program, Knauer said. K mart plans to close 30 of its 2,194 U.S. stores, refurbish or expand 1,880 stores and relocate 280. The only three stores left out of the K mart plan already have the new look, Knauer said. Tom Tashjian, analyst with Seidler-Amdec said K mart was slipping behind competitors Wal-Mart and Target in the discount retail market. The latter two chains expanded more recently than K mart. ``All the companies are about 25 years old, but K mart's expansion was early on in that period,'' Tashjian said. ``The others have expanded during the latter part of the 25 years so they have younger, better-looking stores. Target is much more fun to shop in.'' K mart reported in November a 17.5-percent drop in third-quarter profits to $104.1 million from a year earlier. The drop was blamed on price cuts made to improve the company's market share. But Knauer denied that K mart decided to embark on the five-year, billion-dollar plan in response to its competition. ``We made the decision because of internal factors,'' he said, citing an 18-month pilot project during which several stores were renovated or moved. ``It was based on Christmas sales and the success of stores where we've already made changes. ``In the enlarged, relocated and prototyped stores, customer acceptance of the layouts, fixturing and new merchandise assortments has been very good, and sales results have exceeded expectations.'' K mart Chairman Joseph Antonini said the store enlargements and relocations should be completed by 1993, and other refurbishments will be done by 1994. ``K mart is taking a far more aggressive approach to modernize their stores than they were planning before,'' Tashjian said. ``The Wal-Mart and Target chains are clearly better at merchandise presentation than K mart at this time.'' K mart has 4,171 outlets in the U.S., Puerto Rico and Canada, including 2,288 K mart stores, 1,258 Waldenbooks, 141 Builders Square and 282 Pay Less Drug stores. The Troy-based company also purchased PACE Membership Warehouse Inc. for $322 million late last year.

DOC.HEAD: Cash-Hungry Chrysler Wants to Sell, Lease Back Unfinished Tech Center
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. is seeking federal government permission to sell and lease back its unfinished, $1 billion technical center, a move that would give the automaker a needed cash infusion. Chrysler Chairman Lee Iacocca has estimated the nation's No. 3 automaker invested about $1 billion in the research and engineering center north of Detroit in Auburn Hills. Company officials maintain the Chrysler Technology Center is crucial to the automaker's future. But some critics contend that Chrysler, which lost $664 million in the fourth quarter of 1989, can't afford the facility. The fourth-quarter loss, which included $577 million in write-offs for auto plants Chrysler is closing, was the company's first quarterly deficit since 1982. Chrysler in September sold half its 21.8-percent stake in Japanese automaker Mitsubishi Motors Corp. for an after-tax profit of $310 million. In November, Chrysler said it was considering a sale and lease back on the technical center to raise cash needed for other operations. Earlier this month, the company sold its Gulfstream Aerospace subsidiary for $825 million. According to the request filed Monday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Auburn Hills Trust, organized with the assistance of Manufacturers Hanover Bank, proposes a public offering of about $800 million in securities _ money that would be used to pay for Chrysler's interest in the technical center. Auburn Hills Trust then would assign the lease to a third company, Auburn Hills Trust Services, which in turn would rent the property back to Chrysler and provide maintenance and other services under a long-term contract. ``I know the papers were filed today, that's about all I know,'' company spokesman Steve Harris said from his home Monday night. Other Chrysler officials couldn't immediately be reached for comment. Chrysler employees are scheduled to start moving next month into a training unit on the 500-acre site, with technical and design staff slated to move to the 2.5 million-square-foot center in 1991 and 1992. Eventually, about 5,000 people will work at the center in the 1,100-acre Oakland Technology Park, a facility for high-tech research, development and engineering.

The stock market sported gains in the early going today as traders weighed the implications of the latest economic news. Blue chips, however, failed to continue their rally of the previous day. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks was unchanged from Monday's closing level of 2,602.48 at 10 a.m. on Wall Street. But in the broader market stocks headed higher. Gainers outpaced losers among issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange by about 13 to 9, with 528 up, 366 down and 522 unchanged. The NYSE composite index of all its listed common stocks edged up 0.10 to 181.36. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 20.85 million shares after the first 30 minutes of trading. At the Americansday February 27, 1990.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Trade Deficit Narrows to Lowest Level Since '84
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. trade deficit narrowed to $113.2 billion last year, its lowest level since 1984, as exports of manufactured products and farm goods posted sizable gains, the government reported today. The Commerce Department said that the increased exports helped overcome a continued increase in imports last year as the country improved its trading position with almost every nation. The $113.2 billion deficit was an 11 percent improvement from a $127.2 billion deficit in 1988. It stemmed from a 13.4 percent rise in exports, which climbed to a record $361.9 billion. This offset a 6.4 percent increase in imports, which also hit an all-time high of $475.1 billion. The trade deficit is the difference between imports and exports. Today's report on merchandise trade as calculated on a balance of payments basis confirmed an improvement already noted in the Commerce Department's monthly merchandise trade reports. The totals are slightly different because the new report excludes military sales by the U.S. government and makes other minor adjustments in the monthly figures. For the fourth quarter, the trade deficit posted an increase of 0.9 percent to $28.8 billion, following a deficirt of $28.6 billion in the third quarter. This marked the second consecutive quarter in which the U.S. trade deficit failed to improve, a trend analysts have termed worrisome given the fact that the annual deficit remains stuck above $100 billion. Economists have expressed fears that the deficit could begin deteriorating again in 1990, which would be a blow to President Bush's economic goals. The administration is hoping that further sizable gains in exports will spur a resurgence in the U.S. manufacturing sector, which has fallen on hard times in the past year, particularly in the key auto industry. In the fourth quarter, exports climbed 1.6 percent to $92.1 billion but this gain was offset by a 1.4 percent gain in imports which rose to $120.9 billion. Both imports and exports were at record levels in the final three months of the year, the sixth consecutive quarter they have set new highs. For the year, non-farm exports were up 14 percent to $320.4 billion, reflecting widespread increases, especially in capital goods. U.S. farm sales increased 9 percent to $41.4 billion. The volume of shipments of corn, wheat and sobybeans jumped 24 percent to record levels, with one-half of that increase coming in higher sales to the Soviet Union. The trade gains were held back, however, by a giant 28 percent jump in petroleum imports, which rose to $50.3 billion, the highest level since 1985. The average price per barrel increased to $17.08, up from $14.34. The number of barrels imported daily increased to 8.06 million, the highest level since 1979, a year in which shortages prompted long lines at gasoline pumps. Non-petroleum imports were also up last year, rising 4 percent to $424.9 billion with the largest increases coming in capital goods and consumer goods. However, imports of cars from Japan declined for the third consecutive year, reflecting in part the fact that more Japanese models are being manufactured in plants located in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Turner Broadcasting Sues Drexel Burnham Lambert
DOC.TEXT: Turner Broadcasting System Inc., which bought nearly $10 million worth of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. short-term debt shortly before the Wall Street firm filed for bankruptcy court protection, is suing the company for alleged fraud and violation of securities laws. Turner is asking for $7 million in compensatory and punitive damages, plus attorney fees, because the promissory notes ``have not and will not'' be paid. The cable programming company bought a $4.96 million Drexel promissory note, due Feb. 23, on Jan. 24, and another, at a cost of $4.99 million, on Feb. 11. Two days later, Drexel filed for federal bankruptcy protection from its creditors, including Turner Broadcasting. A promissory note is a written promise to pay a specific sum of money on a certain date. In its suit filed last week in federal court in Atlanta, Turner Broadcasting charged Drexel with fraud and violating state and federal securities laws for not disclosing the New York firm's deteriorating financial condition. Last October, Drexel underwrote $550 million worth of Turner Broadcasting high-risk debt, known as junk bonds, which the Atlanta firm used to refinance long-term obligations. Drexel also underwrote most of the $1.5 billion that Turner Broadcasting paid nearly four years ago for MGM-UA Entertainment Co. Turner Broadcasting said in the lawsuit it will not pay $3 million it owes Drexel on a note Turner Broadcasting issued on Feb. 12.

DOC.HEAD: Retailer Posts Record Quarterly, Annual Profits
DOC.TEXT: Woolworth Corp. on Tuesday reported a 22 percent increase in fourth-quarter net income and a 14 percent gain for all of last year. The growth lifted the quarterly and annual profits to record levels and came on revenue gains of 9.8 percent in the three months ended Jan. 27 and 9.1 percent in the entire year. Revenue from Woolworth's specialty operation, such as the Kinney shoe store chain, expanded 17 percent while general merchandise revenue rose 5.4 percent in the fourth quarter. Domestically, revenue grew 12 percent while foreign growth was 7.6 percent. During all of last year, specialty stores also had higher revenue growth than general merchandise stores. Revenue from specialty stores grew 19 percent in 1989 compared with a 3.1 percent rise for general merchandise revenue. Revenue was up 9.9 percent in 1989 in the United States vs. 8 percent abroad. The New York-based retailer said it earned $175 million, or $2.73 a share, on revenue of $2.79 billion in the fourth quarter. That was up from income of $144 milion, or $2.23 a share, and revenue of $2.55 billion a year earlier. For all of 1989, Woolworth earned $329 million, or $5.11 a share, up from $288 million, or $4.47 a share, in 1988. Revenue rose last year to $8.82 billion from $8.09 billion. Woolworth owns dozens of specialty chains including Foot Locker, the name brand athletic shoe retailer, Lady Foot Locker and Champs, a sporting goods chain. It also is the holding company for the Woolworth variety stores. Harold E. Sells, Woolworth's chairman and chief executive officer, said so far in 1990 sales have been strong both in the United States and abroad. However, he said interest expense in the current first quarter will be greater than in 1989's first quarter.
