DOC.HEAD: Federated, Allied Developing Retention Plan To Keep Executives
DOC.NOTE: EDS: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Federated Spokeswoman Saying Plan Will Not Include Raises; picks up 4th graf pvs, `The employee ...
DOC.TEXT: The holding company of Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. is working on an employee retention plan for executives who might be tempted to join a rival retailer. The plan being developed by Federated Stores Inc. must be approved by U.S. Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr. before it goes into effect. Federated and Allied, two U.S. retailing businesses owned by Canada's Campeau Corp., filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy law on Jan. 15 in the biggest retail bankruptcy filing in history. Carol Sanger, spokeswoman for the U.S. holding company, said today the plan will consist of ``various performance and retention incentives and a reaffirmation of contracts and other benefits.'' She declined to be more specific but said the plan would not include salary increases for executives or improvements in health coverage. The employee retention plan will be presented to Aug in early March, Ms. Sanger said. ``These are benefits which will keep us competitive with other executives in the retail industry,'' Ms. Sanger said. ``We do not want to lose anybody to another retailer.'' Analysts said employee retention plans are commonplace in the competitive retailing industry. They're aimed at preventing executives, from upper management to divisional officers, from jumping to rival stores. ``Those executives, usually at the middle-management level, who shine are always in demand,'' said Marc P. Schappell of Egon Zehnder International, a New York-based management recruitment firm. Ms. Sanger said the plan is a necessary step for Federated. ``We cannot operate at a severe disadvantage in this environment that we're dealing in. It would not be in the companies' best interest,'' she said. So far, Federated and Allied executives haven't left in large numbers, according to management recruitment firms. ``They see themselves as being on the first team,'' said Roger Kenny of Kenny, Kindler, Hunt & Howe, a New York recruiting firm. ``Why leave the Yankees to go to the farm team?'' The companies have taken several steps since filing the Chapter 11 petition five weeks ago. Aug has approved a special $700 million financial package that provided fresh lines of credit to the companies. Several ``business-as-usual'' motions _ from retention of employee benefits to allowing distributors to resume liquor shipments to a downtown Chicago Bloomingdale's store _ have been approved. And about 96 percent of the stores' top 117 merchandise suppliers have resumed shipments of apparel. ``We have moved so far beyond our difficult situation at the time of the filing that it has amazed even some of us,'' Ms. Sanger said. ``Nobody in the industry, no analysts or other retail executives expected us to accomplish as much as we have. Our mission now is to maintain this positive operational environment,'' she said.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 422.46 up 1.51 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Grain Futures Mixed In Early Trading
DOC.TEXT: Crop futures prices were narrowly mixed in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade with weather factors keeping a lid on the corn and soybean markets. The National Weather Service on Monday predicted above-normal precipitation early next week across a large portion of the nation's midsection, including areas of western Iowa, Minnesota and Nebraska that have remained quite dry since the 1988 drought. Soybean futures were struggling to rebound, though, after significant losses in the last three sessions. ``I think they're trying to have a little technical correction,'' said Victor Lespinasse, a trader with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago. Buying continued to lift the March wheat contract amid perceptions of tight deliverable supplies. Other wheat futures were lower despite news that the Agriculture Department had accepted bids from Morocco for more than 100,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat at subsidized prices. In early trading, wheat futures were 1 cent lower to 1\ cents higher with the contract for delivery in March at $3.97{ a bushel; corn futures were unchanged to 2 cents lower with March at $2.46 a bushel; oat futures were unchanged to { cent lower with March at $1.36{ a bushel; soybeans were { cent to 1{ cents higher with March at $5.62\ a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mostly lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle futures were .35 cent lower to .10 cent higher with April at 74.92 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent lower to .10 cent higher with March at 79.75 cents a pound; live hogs were .20 cent to .45 cent lower with April at 49.50 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .15 cent to .87 cent lower with March at 52.55 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures settled mixed on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Wal-Mart Reports Record Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. said Tuesday it had record sales and profits for the fourth quarter and for the year ended Jan. 31. Wal-Mart said its fourth-quarter net income increased 32 percent to $425.9 million, or 75 cents a share, from $323.2 million, or 57 cents a share, in the final quarter of 1988. Sales totaled $8.1 billion compared with $6.5 billion a year earlier, a gain of 24 percent. For the year, the nation's third-largest discount retailer said its earnings jumped 28.5 percent to $1.1 billion, or $1.90 a share, from $837 million, or $1.48 a share, the year before. Sales rose to $25 billion, up 25 percent from $20.6 billion. ``We are extremely pleased to report another record year of sales and earnings,'' David Glass, Wal-Mart president and chief executive officer, said in a written statement. ``We remain committed to our everyday low-pricing program on name-brand merchandise while working to exceed our customer's expectations of service.'' As of Jan. 31, the company operated 1,402 Wal-Mart stores, 123 Sam's Wholesale Clubs and three Hypermart-USA units compared with 1,259 Wal-Mart stores, 105 Sam's Wholesale Clubs, 14 dot Discount Drug stores and one Hypermart-USA unit at the same time last year. The sale of the dot Discount Drug stores was effective Feb. 1. Glass said the company's 1990 plans call for aggressive expansion. ``We believe the new year will be an intensively competitive environment but should provide a great opportunity for us to perform in a manner consistent with prior years,'' he said. Wal-Mart operates in 29 states.

DOC.HEAD: Crazy Eddie Founder Fails To Show In Court Again, Faces Criminal Contempt
DOC.TEXT: The founder of Crazy Eddie Inc. faces criminal contempt charges after he failed to appear today before a federal judge to answer demands he return $52 million to the United States. Judge Nicholas H. Politan ordered U.S. marshals to bring Eddie Antar before him and said a civil trial against Antar and two family members would proceed without the reclusive founder. Politan set a May 1 trial date for Antar, his brother, Mitchell, and his cousin, Sam E. Antar, all charged with securities violations. The Securities and Exchange Commission claims in a lawsuit the missing money may have been gained through insider trading. Jack Arseneault, Antar's attorney, told the judge he did not know Antar's whereabouts. The judge ordered a closed hearing today to question Arseneault further about Antar's whereabouts. Earlier this month, Politan ordered Antar to repatriate the money by Feb. 7, but Antar refused through his attorney, citing his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination. Antar allegedly transferred the $52 million in 1987 to bank accounts in Israel. Arseneault has argued that to return the money would be self-incriminating because it would be tantamount to an admission that the money is there. Politan has rejected that argument. Politan had ordered Antar on Feb. 7 to appear in person if he was going to use the Fifth Amendment. Two days later, Politan issued an arrest warrant on civil contempt charges after Antar failed to show. At the time, an angry Politan ordered marshals to ``spare no expense'' to capture Antar. Antar turned himself in to marshals on Feb. 13. He was released and was to appear today. The SEC said in its lawsuit Antar directed a financial fraud to falsify the company's income, and reaped illegal profits through the sale of his stock at artificially inflated prices. The 43-store empire collapsed last year.

DOC.HEAD: Court Clearing Contractor of Conflict of Interest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs pvs 11th graf, The five, with 5 grafs to update with Boeing reax
DOC.TEXT: The Boeing Co. did not violate a federal conflict-of-interest law when the defense contractor paid $485,000 in severance to five employees who left to take government jobs, the Supreme Court ruled today. By a 9-0 vote, the justices overturned a ruling, supported by the Bush administration, that the money must be turned over to the government. Justice John Paul Stevens, writing for the court, said the payments ``give rise to a possible appearance of impropriety.'' But he said the conflict-of-interest law also permits ``corporations to encourage qualified employees to make their special skills available to the government.'' As long as the employee has not begun working for the government, the law does not prohibit the payment, Stevens said. He said any ambiguity must be resolved in favor of government contractors and employees receiving severance pay ``until Congress plainly states that we have misconstrued'' the law. The law makes it a crime for any private party to pay, and a government employee to receive, supplemental compensation for the employee's government service. The statute is one of many federal laws aimed at prevent bribery, graft and conflicts of interest. Today's decision reversed a 1988 ruling by the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals that said Boeing paid the money illegally to the employees to compensate them for taking lower-paying jobs in the Reagan administration. The Bush administration urged the Supreme Court to uphold the appeals court ruling. Justice Department lawyers said the payments ``were classic violations'' of federal law because they were calculated to make up the difference between the employees' salaries at Boeing and their government pay. In Seattle, Boeing spokesman Paul Binder said the company was pleased by the decision and feels vindicated after almost eight years of legal questions surrounding the payments. The payments compensated employees for accrued sick leave, unused benefits and stock options and ``were always completely open and aboveboard and disclosed to the government,'' he said. ``It's not only a victory for Boeing but a victory for the government because it means that qualified people will not feel impeded in taking their industry-developed experience and expertise in to government positions,'' Binder added. Boeing stopped making such payments following the initial legal challenge. The company needs to study the high court's decision before deciding whether to resume them, Binder said. The five former employees are: Thomas K. Jones, who received $132,000 from Boeing before becoming deputy undersecretary of defense for strategic and theater nuclear forces in 1981; Herbert A. Reynolds, $80,000, deputy director of space and intelligence policy in 1981; Melvin R. Paisley, $183,000, assistant secretary of the Navy for research, engineering and systems in 1981. Also, Lawrence H. Crandon, $40,000, a computer scientist for the NATO air command and control systems in 1982; and Harold Kitson, $50,000, deputy assistant secretary of the Navy for command, communications and control intelligence in 1982. The former employees said in their appeal to the Supreme Court that they were not responsible for Pentagon contracting or procurement and that they had exemplary records with the government. They said there was no question of divided loyalties for any of them because each received ``an irrevocable severance payment'' before entering government service. Paisley became a defense consultant after leaving the Pentagon in 1987. His name arose in a Justice Department investigation of trafficking in confidential bid information on government contracts, but he was never charged criminally. His lawyers, in response to court documents, denied that Paisley violated the law. The cases are Crandon vs. U.S., 88-931, and Boeing vs. U.S., 88-938.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Secretary Looks Forward To East Bloc Membership in EC
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said Tuesday the European Community should offer the countries of Eastern Europe which have shed Communism an ``association agreement'' which would eventually lead to full membership. ``I do not know on what basis that (full membership) could be denied once they have achieved full democracy and market economies,'' Hurd told 3,000 members of the Institute of Directors, Britain's main employers' group, at their annual convention. The foreign secretary said the 12-nation European Community should offer each Eastern European country ``an association agreement which can gradually be increased and enriched as that country moves forward with its political and economic reforms.'' Hurd said the European Community needed to respond to the liberalized Eastern bloc by holding out a hand, not only of friendship, but of practical help and cooperation. He said the countries of Eastern Europe ``seem to have grasped'' the need to adopt policies which would lead to an enterprise culture and creation of wealth ``with remarkable speed.'' Answering questions, Hurd said countries such as Romania and Bulgaria had a long way to go before they could become full EC members. But he also noted that Greece, Spain and Portugal had all joined the European Community after getting rid of dictatorial governments. Hurd also urged British firms to get in ``on the ground floor'' as Eastern governments turned towards capitalism, citing ``an immense expansion of markets for goods and services.''

DOC.HEAD: Official Attempts to Steer Japanese Markets Seen as Muddled
DOC.TEXT: Actions by Japan's financial regulators and stock exchange officials to calm troubled markets in recent days appeared sometimes contradictory and in many cases ineffective, traders and analysts said Tuesday. Stock prices plunged on a day when officials asked stock market participants to limit program trading some have blamed for worsening recent price declines. The government also has intervened in the currency markets to support the value of the Japanese yen and in the bond market to push interest rates lower _ which tends to depress the yen. Regulators are trying to settle a Tokyo Stock Exchange whose key index has plunged by 14 percent this year, partly due to worries about rising inflation and higher interest rates. On Monday, the exchange asked securities houses to limit arbitrage dealings whe the stock market is declining. Arbitrage programs, involving rapid trading of huge numbers of shares to profit from price discrepancies between stocks and stock-index futures, has been blamed for worsening price declines. But with arbitragers inactive Monday, the stock market took its biggest plunge since the October 1987 crash. On Tuesday, despite some $201 million worth of arbitrage-selling and a temporary decline, the benchmark Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues closed 576.08 points higher. ``It is rather difficult to evaluate the market reaction from just one day of trading,'' stock exchange spokesman Hironobu Takahashi said Tuesday, ``but I believe our member firms understood our request and tried to cooperate.'' New York-based Salomon Brothers, one of the leading arbitrage firms in Tokyo, stated Tuesday that, ``The action taken yesterday may do more harm than good. It does not address the fundamental factors driving the market.'' ``All the finger-pointing at arbitrage is wrong,'' said Kevin Parker, director of futures and options at Morgan Stanley, another big American arbitrage player. ``Less than 5 percent of daily volume has been arbitrage-selling. It can't really explain the correction in the market.'' Parker said market fundamentals, such as rising interest rates and inflation, accounted for the downturn. These problems have been the target of divergent actions by the Finance Ministry and the Bank of Japan. The Finance Ministry primarily is interested with protecting government bond prices, thereby curbing interest rate rises and promoting economic expansion, said Jason James, a strategic analyst with James Capel Pacific. However, the central bank is concerned with battling inflation and supporting the value of the yen _ which are achieved by raising interest rates, James said. The ministry also reportedly was concerned that higher interest rates would cause Japanese investments to flow back from overseas, particularly from the United States. The Finance Ministry has intervened three times in the last week, its first bond market intervention since 1987, purchasing $604 million worth of 10-year government bonds on Monday in an attempt to raise their prices and reduce their yields. Monday's intervention reduced yields on the benchmark 10-year government bond to 6.875 percent from a high of 7.015 percent. However, the ministry stayed out of the market Tuesday and the yield climbed to 6.91 percent. Bond dealer Shinji Kokubun of Sanwa Bank suggested the ministry may have to spend a lot more to get the job done. ``The Finance Ministry's buying operation does not have an immediate effect. As far as I know, it works gradually,'' he said. The ministry's efforts may aid the stock and bond markets but they seemed to diverge from the central bank's moves to depress interest rates. Bank of Japan Governor Yasushi Mieno on Monday refused to rule out a widely anticipated increase in the bank's official discount rate to battle inflation. ``We don't change monetary policy only because stock prices ... or the yen move rapidly. ... We have to consider carefully what the interest rate increases will bring, how prices will change in the future,'' he said. The central bank regards the discount rate, the interest it charges commercial banks for loans, as a key weapon against inflation. It raised the rate three times in 1989, bringing it from 2.5 percent to the present 4.25 percent, but inflation continues to threaten due to rising oil and labor prices. The central bank's currency operations, its other weapon against inflation, also have been hindered by market forces. The bank reportedly spent $2 billion Tuesday to bolster the yen, but the dollar rose 0.38 yen and closed at 149.03 yen, its highest level since last June 15. The weaker yen makes imported items, such as oil, more expensive in Japan.

London investors were heartened by a gain in Tokyo after recent sharp plunges. The Nikkei average closed 576.08 points higher at 33,897.95 on Tuesday. ``There's a temptation to believe that the dramatic moves in Tokyo are of Japan's making and only their making,'' a dealing director at a London investment firm said. ``It's a consensus feeling that Tokyo was looking too expensive for too long and that some fundamental correction was long overdue.'' Wall Street's performance in the last 48 hours also has been encouraging, dealers said. The Dow Jones industrial average stood 23.42 points higher at 2,625.90 as the London session drew to a close Tuesday, following a 38-point advance Monday. However, if the Japanese market declines again, the other markets will be sorely tested, said the head of market making at another London firm. DOC.HEAD: Trade Deficit Falls to Lowest in Five Years
With AM-Economy Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. trade deficit narrowed to $113.2 billion last year, the smallest since 1984, despite the highest level of foreign oil imports in 10 years, the government reported Tuesday. The Commerce Department said the deficit shrank by 11 percent from an imbalance of $127.2 billion in 1988, reflecting continued growth in American exports, especially manufactured goods and agricultural products. The 13.4 percent increase in exports, which rose to a record $361.9 billion, more than offset a 6.4 percent gain in imports, which also hit an all-time high of $475.1 billion. Tuesday's report on merchandise trade as calculated on a balance of payments basis confirmed trends already noted in the department's monthly merchandise trade reports, which showed a deficit for all of 1989 of $108.6 billion. The new figure is higher because it excludes military sales by the U.S. government and makes other minor adjustments in the monthly figures. For the fourth quarter, the trade deficit posted an increase of 0.9 percent to $28.8 billion, following a deficit of $28.6 billion in the third quarter. It marked the second consecutive quarter in which the trade deficit failed to show improvement, and private economists expressed fears that the deficit could begin widening again in 1990. A higher trade deficit would spell trouble for the Bush administration, which is counting on further export growth to prop up the U.S. economy. One of the most ominous signs for the future is the surge in oil imports, which shot up 28 percent last year to $50.3 billion. The price per barrel rose to $17.08, up from $14.34 in 1988, while the number of barrels imported daily increased to 8.06 million, the highest level since 1979, a year in which Americans sat in gasoline lines because of shortages. Non-petroleum imports were also up last year, rising 4 percent to $424.9 billion. Car imports from Japan declined for the third consecutive year, reflecting the fact that more Japanese models are being manufactured in plants located in the United States. Non-farm exports were up 14 percent to $320.4 billion last year, reflecting increases in consumer goods and manufactured capital goods, especially commercial aircraft. U.S. farm sales increased 9 percent to $41.4 billion. The volume of shipments of corn, wheat and soybeans jumped 24 percent to record levels, with one-half of that increase coming in higher sales to the Soviet Union, the government reported. In the fourth quarter, exports climbed 1.6 percent to $92.1 billion but this was offset by a 1.4 percent increase in imports which rose to $120.9 billion. Both imports and exports were at record levels in the final three months of the year, the sixth consecutive quarter they have set new highs. But Paul Getman, an economist with Regional Financial Associates, said that U.S. export growth for manufactured goods is likely to slow in coming months, reflecting higher interest rates in such countries as Japan and West Germany. Higher interest rates dampen demand by raising the cost of borrowing for both businesses and consumers. The $113.2 billion trade deficit for 1989 was the smallest imbalance since a $112.5 billion deficit in 1984, the first year that the trade deficit climbed above the $100 billion mark.

DOC.HEAD: Lotus Unveils Version of Popular 1-2-3 Program For Mainframe Computers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `The move ...,' to CORRECT that the new program is Lotus' second move into software for other types of compters, sted first.
DOC.TEXT: Lotus Development Corp. on Tuesday unveiled a long-promised version of its popular 1-2-3 computer spreadsheet program for IBM mainframe computers. The program, 1-2-3-M, allows personal computer users to pull data from a mainframe computer file and transfer it directly into the 1-2-3 spreadsheet. Lotus and International Business Machines Corp. said the software could cut days off the the traditional procedure, in which data from a mainframe often must be altered so that it may be entered into a 1-2-3 spreadsheet on a personal computer. Spreadsheet programs allow the display of rows and columns of figures or bar graphs to represent such things as a company's sales or profits. They are among the most popular programs for personal computers and 1-2-3 is the leading personal computer spreadsheet. The move into mainframes represents the second foray by the Cambridge, Mass.-based company into software for other types of computers. Last month, Lotus introduced a spreadsheet program for workstations made by Sun Microsystems Inc. It also is believed to be developing a version of 1-2-3 for minicomputers made by Digital Equipment Corp. Lotus and IBM signed an agreement in April 1987 to jointly develop a spreadsheet program for IBM mainframes. The program originally was to be released in early 1988. Other versions of 1-2-3 also have suffered lengthy introduction delays due to programming bugs and other problems. At a news conference, Lotus Vice President Frank Moss said one possible use for 1-2-3-M would be for a retail-store chain to transfer sales data from spreadsheets on personal computers in its stores to a mainframe computer at company headquarters. IBM said Sears, Roebuck and Co. is one of about two dozen companies that have been using a preliminary version of 1-2-3-M since August. Users do not need to know the computer commands for the mainframe computer. The Lotus program automatically transfers data from personal computers to the mainframe, and vice versa. During the delay in introducing 1-2-3-M, a new type of computer setup may have reduced the need for the product, some industry analysts say. That setup involves a ``file server,'' a high-powered desktop computer that acts as a central repository for a network of personal computers. Existing versions of 1-2-3 can run on file servers. However, Rick Sherlund, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Co., said the new version of 1-2-3 should appeal to companies that have a mainframe computer in place and want to tie it to personal computers through the spreadsheet. Sherlund said 1-2-3-M should account for less than $5 million of Lotus' estimated 1990 revenue of $750 million. But, he said, ``It's more significant from a strategic vantage point'' since it should allow Lotus to maintain its foothold in major corporations. ``Their strategy, I think, is to basically cover all their bases and offer products that run across the broad spectrum of hardware installed in corporate America,'' he said. IBM will be the sole marketer of the program, which is designed for use on IBM's System-370 computer line. Sherlund said he believes Lotus will receive less than half the revenue. The software, which will be available next month, ranges in price from about $15,000 to $48,000, depending on the size of the computer system. In addition, monthly licensing charges of $583 to $1,800 are assessed, the companies said.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Changing Name to Disassociate From Bus Company Problems
DOC.TEXT: Dogged by an unclear corporate image, Greyhound Corp. announced Tuesday it is changing its name to Greyhound Dial Corp. to distinguish itself from the troubled nationwide Greyhound busline that it formerly owned. ``This name change will help clarify who we are and what we do,'' Greyhound Dial Chairman John W. Teets told a news conference in New York. The company, a diversified manufacturing and financial services concern based in Phoenix, sold the bus line in 1987 to Dallas investor Fred Currey, who later merged it with the Trailways bus system and renamed the operation Greyhound Lines Inc. Its drivers have threatened to strike on Friday in a wage dispute. Teets said the new name was chosen because of the importance of the company's Dial Corp. subsidiary, a consumer products maker with brands ranging from Dial soap to Purex detergents to Lunch Bucket microwave meals. He said the word Greyhound was retained as part of the name because it is an integral part of the name of several other subsidiaries, such as Greyhound Financial Corp. and Greyhound Food Management. ``For the corporation to abandon the Greyhound name would be a genuine blow to these companies,'' he said. The company's board of directors approved the name change on Feb. 15. Clive Chajet, an expert on corporate name changes, said the company is ``attempting to redefine the word Greyhound to be more than a bus service.'' Greyhound as a bus service is a ``well engrained symbol,'' he said. Name changes usually are an expression of a company's long-term strategy rather than a reaction to a specific event, said Chajet, the chairman of Lippincott & Margulies Inc., a corporate image consulting firm. Asked why the company had waited until now to make the name change, Teets said it had been studying such a move for a few years, but the threatened strike at Greyhound Lines ``was kind of the last grain of sand in the hourglass.'' He didn't rule out eliminating the word Greyhound from the company name in the future. As a reflection of the confusion caused by the Greyhound name, Teets said, the company's switchboard had been deluged with calls from the press seeking details about the possible bus strike. The company also was concerned that institutional investors might think it was involved in the strike. ``We're not involved in any way at all,'' Teets said. He declined to comment on the bus line's labor trouble. Greyhound was primarily known for its bus service until 1987, when it sold the line to Currey for $270 million. Its main businesses now are consumer products, financial services and catering. A strike by drivers at Greyhound Lines would disrupt the country's only nationwide bus system, serving 9,500 communities.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Close Mixed; March Wheat Slips
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed narrowly mixed Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade with the March wheat contract posting its first daily decline in a week. The contract for March delivery of wheat had risen a total of 14 cents a bushel during the four previous sessions amid perceptions of near-term supply tightness. Wednesday is the first day for traders to declare intentions to deliver wheat against the contract and Thursday is the first delivery day. March wheat began Tuesday's session slightly higher but fell late in the session on selling that began when one large independent speculator took profits, said Victor Lespinasse, a trader with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago. The price tumbled nearly 5 cents a bushel, then recovered to close with a loss of less than 2 cents after buying interest was stirred by indications that China had bid for 300,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat at subsidized prices. Corn futures slipped in reaction to forecasts for above-normal precipitation early next week in dry areas of the Corn Belt. Soybeans were narrowly mixed. At the close, wheat futures were 2} cents lower to 1 cent higher with March down 1} cents at $3.94{ a bushel; corn futures were 1\ cents to 1} cents lower with March at $2.44} a bushel; oats were unchanged to 1 cent lower with March at $1.36{ a bushel; soybeans were 1\ cents lower to } cent higher with March at $5.62 a bushel.

The stock market steadied at higher levels this afternoon amid improved investor confidence following Monday's moderate rally. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks rose 16.44 to 2,618.92 by 3 p.m. on Wall Street. Gainers outpaced losers among issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange by about 9upport Tuesday for a Caribbean-led effort to call attention to alleged human rights abuses in Haiti. Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler noted that the Organization of American States had unanimously approved a resolution Friday calling for a visit to Haiti by the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights. ``We believe the resolution signals to Haitian authorities that the international community expects it to honor its commitment to establish a democratic government and restore respect for human rights,'' she said. Last month, the government of Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril declared a state of siege and arrested a number of opposition political leaders. It also ordered strict censorship of the news media. The OAS resolution was introduced by Jamaica and other Caribbean countries. ``This resolution and the Caribbean Community's leadership in securing its approval sets the stage for renewed regional impetus for democracy in Haiti,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Ends Lower; Gold Finishes Flat To Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar finished lower against most major currencies in European trading Tuesday. Nonetheless, dealers said there was no rush to sell the U.S. currency. Instead, the dollar's retreat largely reflected the scale of selling in recent days by the Bank of Japan, which has intervened to prop up the yen, they said. Late in the day, dollar was quoted at 1.6836 Deutsche marks, down from 1.6903 marks late Monday in London. The dollar also ended the European day at 148.57 yen, down from 149.03 yen at the close in Tokyo earlier. Other dollar rates compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.4857 Swiss francs, down from 1.4865; 5.7010 French francs, down from 5.7205; 1.8985 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9023; 1,245.25 Italian lire, down from 1,250.25; and 1.1908 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1975. The British pound traded at $1.6915 late Tuesday, lower than $1.6927 late Monday. Gold traded in London at a late bid price of $407.25 a troy ounce, down from $411.75 bid late Monday. In Zurich, the bid price was $411.25, unchanged from late Monday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $4.30 to close at a bid $407.85. Silver closed in London at a bid price of $5.11 a troy ounce, from Monday's $5.23.

DOC.HEAD: Unilever Posts Profit Gains in Fourth Quarter, Year
DOC.TEXT: Unilever, the Anglo-Dutch food and consumer products giant, on Tuesday reported a 12 percent gain in net profit for 1989's fourth quarter, boosted by strong sales growth from its existing and newly acquired businesses. Unilever said its net profit for the three months ended Dec. 31 totaled the equivalent of $470 million, up from $419 million in the same period a year earlier. Sales rose 20 percent to $9.75 billion from $8.14 billion. For the year, net profit rose 12 percent to $1.69 billion from $1.51 billion in 1988. Sales jumped 11 percent to $34.4 billion, up from $30.9 billion. Chairman Michael Angus said the British pound's fall against most other currencies over the year aided the company's earnings. ``But even when taking out this effect, there was a good improvement,'' Angus said. Angus said profit margins were up an average 9 percent on the year, with the strongest gains coming in North American operations, where margins improved 10 percent. Unilever's 55 acquisitions during the year included the $1.55 billion purchase of the Faberge and Elizabeth Arden cosmetics lines from Faberge Inc., completed in July, and the purchase of the Calvin Klein fragrance business. The company has been particularly eager to boost its presence in the upscale end of the personal products area, in which it now claims a global market share of 10 percent. Among Unilever's well-known U.S. products are Dove soap, Wisk detergent, Ragu spaghetti sauce and Lipton tea.
The stock market was higher in late trading today. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 15.54 at 2,618.02 with five minutes left to go.

DOC.HEAD: `Crazy Eddie' Antar Found In Criminal Contempt
DOC.TEXT: Eddie Antar, the founder of Crazy Eddie Inc., faces criminal contempt charges after he failed to appear Tuesday before a federal judge to answer demands he return $52 million to the United States. U.S. District Judge Nicholas H. Politan, meanwhile, ordered a civil lawsuit to proceed against Antar while U.S. marshals hunt him down. Antar has repeatedly ignored warnings by Politan to appear in court or be jailed, but Tuesday's action marked the first criminal finding against him. The U.S. Attorney has been seeking a criminal indictment. The Securities and Exchange Commission is suing Antar, two family members and several associates, accusing them of reaping millions of dollars through fraudulent record keeping and insider trading. Politan ordered that trial to begin May 1. ``Mr. Antar will be found and he will appear,'' Politan said. Antar, through his attorney, refused a Feb. 7 order by Politan to return $52 million to the United States that the SEC said was in an Israeli bank account. Antar's attorney, Jack Arseneault, argued at the time that repatriating the money would violate Antar's Fifth Amendtment right against self-incrimination. Politan rejected that argument and said if Antar wanted to invoke the Fifth, he would have to do so in person. The judge then ordered him to appear the next day to explain why he should not be held in contempt for keeping the money in Israel. When Antar did not appear, Politan found Antar in civil contempt and ordered U.S. marshals to ``spare no expense'' in bringing the fugitive before him. Antar, 42, founder of the discount electronics chain, surrendered to marshals Feb. 13 but was released with the agreement that he return before the judge on Tuesday. When he did not, Politan found him in criminal contempt, which carries a penalty of up to six months in prison. Arseneault said in an interview that Antar has contacted him by phone, but he does not know his client's whereabouts. He would not comment on Antar's reasons for violating the court orders. Antar's 43-outlet store empire collapsed last year.

DOC.HEAD: Retailer Says FTC Closed Investigation
DOC.TEXT: Benetton Group SpA announced Tuesday that the Federal Trade Commission has closed an investigation into the fairness of certain U.S. business practices of the Italian apparel maker and retailer. The FTC informed Benetton in a letter Feb. 5 that the matter had been closed and that it wouldn't initiate any proceedings against the company, Benetton said. The investigation, which began in late 1988, first came to light last June. Benetton disclosed in a prospectus for a sale of securities in the United States that the regulatory agency had undertaken a preliminary probe. The government probe had been aimed at determining whether Benetton should be considered a franchiser and therefore subject to federal franchise rules. It focused on the company's relationships with owners of Benetton boutiques in the United States. Benetton said in a news release it was gratified that the FTC has decided not to take action against the company. Benetton consistently maintained throughout the investigation that it wasn't a franchiser, under the FTC definition, and that it had not engaged in unfair or deceptive business practices. A violation of franchise rules can result in civil penalties of up to $10,000 a day. The FTC also has the power to seek civil remedies in court on behalf of owners, investors or others. A number of U.S. store owners previously alleged in bankruptcy court proceedings that Benetton had acted unfairly and violated franchise rules and other statutes. One store owner had threatened to file a class action lawsuit on behalf of all owners that have challenged the way Benetton does business. Federal law requires franchisers to make detailed disclosures before selling a franchise. Franchisers must obey various federal laws intended to protect business owners from abusive practices. Some states also have statutes that apply specifically to franchisors. Benetton markets its colorful clothing for women, men and children through independently owned Benetton retail stores. There are more than 700 Benetton stores in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: United Brands Getting a Name Change
DOC.TEXT: United Brands Co. announced Tuesday it is changing its name to Chiquita Brands International Inc., effective March 20. The change is intended to increase the Cincinnati-based company's recognition, but will not alter its business strategy, said Keith Lindner, president and chief operating officer. The company is a major marketer of fresh fruit and vegetables, including Chiquita bananas, along with prepared foods. American Financial Corp., a Cincinnati-based holding company which holds 82 percent of United Brands' common stock, has approved the name change and no further shareholder action is required, company spokeswoman Sandra Heimann said. Cincinnati financier Carl Lindner controls American Financial.

DOC.HEAD: Group Says Ad Bans Would Impede Access to Information, Cost Jobs
DOC.TEXT: Placing further limits on tobacco and alcohol advertising could push more sports programming from broadcast television to pay-TV outlets, drive some magazines out of business and eliminate thousands of jobs in the media industry, a new report said Tuesday. Critics said the report failed to reflect the possibility that other advertisers likely would fill any void left by a decline in tobacco and alcohol products advertising. The report was released by a group of advertisers, media companies and ad agencies called The Leadership Council on Advertising Issues, whose stated goal is to ``preserve and enhance the freedom to advertise.'' ``Our study shows that reduced advertising exacts social and economic penalties from the public,'' said Reginald Brack, the Time Warner Inc. executive who is co-chairman of the group. He said the study was not prompted by any specific legislation, although there have been periodic calls for new limits on tobacco and liquor ads. An author of the report said he hoped the findings would inject some discussion of social and economic costs into the debate over whether to further limit advertising of tobacco, beer, wine and liquor. DOC.TEXT: The stock market chalked up additional gains today amid improved investor confidence following Monday's moderate rally. A partial recovery earlier in Tokyo after a key measure of the world's biggest equities market took its second-steepest one-day plunge ever on Monday reassured U.S. investors, analysts said. Spirits were lifted on Wall Street Monday when the market managed to overcome its uneasiness about Tokyo's troubles. Hildegarde Zagorski, a market analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said stocks were ripe for a rebound, having been sold heavily before this week. ``I think what we're seeing here is a technical rebound,'' she said, noting that investors still are nervous about the consequences sluggish economic growth could have on corporate profits. Investors, meanwhile, were reluctant to read too much significance into a tumble in orders to U.S. factories for durable goods. Stocks barely budged in response to the news, market watchers said. The January drop of 10.5 percent, the biggest decline since the government began keeping track of the figures, was seen as further evidence of a slumping manufacturing sector. However, analysts noted the orders are volatile and often subject to large revisions.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Still Talking With Drivers; News Blackout Extended
With AM-Greyhound-Name Change
DOC.TEXT: Negotiations between Greyhound Lines Inc. and its bus drivers union continued Tuesday, with a news blackout extended until midday Wednesday. Dallas-based Greyhound, which operates the nation's only intercity bus system, faces a 12:01 a.m. Friday strike deadline set by the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions, which represents 6,300 drivers and 3,075 of the company's office and maintenance workers. Full scale negotiations over wage issues ceased last week, but low-level talks resumed in Scottsdale, Ariz., Sunday, and a news blackout was imposed until noon local time Tuesday. That deadline was extended until noon Wednesday, company spokesman Liz Hale said. Citing the blackout, Ms. Hale refused to say if progress had been made in the talks. The two sides went into negotiations far apart on wage issues, with the company saying it could not afford more than its initial $63 million offer. The company estimates the union's three-year proposal would cost $406 million. Greyhound has said it will operate on a limited schedule if the drivers go on strike, with plans to be back to full operations by the end of March.

DOC.HEAD: Ford's Petersen: Japanese May Move Too Fast on New Cars
DOC.TEXT: Japanese automakers, praised for quickly developing new cars, are so fast in bringing out some new products that they blur distinctions between two models of the same car, outgoing Ford Motor Co. Chairman Donald Petersen said Tuesday. Petersen steps down Thursday as leader of the world's second-largest automaker, at a time that Ford and other U.S. companies retrench operations as their market shrinks and as they struggle to curb costs. One cost-saving area for U.S. automakers is to cut the time for developing a new car and bring it to dealers. The Big Three have been taking leads from their associations with Japanese companies to reduce that time. Petersen, whose company is in ventures with Mazda Motor Corp. and Nissan Motor Co. Ltd. of Japan, said there's risk in being too fast. ``The Japanese are changing their rate that isn't necessarily doing them a lot of good. I don't think I'm abnormal in my inability to identify one car from another,'' said Petersen, who has worked in the industry for nearly 41 years. One company considered to have an exceptionally quick product cycle time is Honda Motor Co. Ltd. Yet its 1990 Accord, which Honda advertises as an entirely new vehicle, has been criticized for not being distinctive enough from earlier models. Petersen became Ford president in 1980 at the nadir of the company's fiscal troubles and took over as chairman and chief executive officer on Feb. 1, 1985. In 1980, Ford lost $1.5 billion. Petersen led Ford out of its slump, aided by the marketing of such popular vehicles as the Taurus, and the company posted an industry-record $5.3 billion profit in 1988. Petersen is departing as the U.S. auto industry struggles to hold down costs in a diminishing market that is threatened more than ever by cars made by Japanese companies overseas and in the United States. Petersen said he wanted to be remembered at Ford for his work in developing a ``no-star system.'' ``I wanted people to have a sense of teamwork,'' he said. Since Petersen has been chairman, and with influence from Mazda, Ford has begun adapting a Japanese team-oriented manufacturing method. Ford owns 25 percent of Mazda and gets its Probe cars from Mazda's plant in Flat Rock, Mich. Later this year, Ford will make the Mazda Navajo sport-utility vehicles at its plant in Louisville, Ky. But when asked outside of Ford which automaker he most admired, Petersen said Toyota Motor Corp. ``They have a very complex product line,'' he said. ``They are a very big company and sell in very high volume. There are others (companies) but they are more limited in their product line. ``I'm extraordinarily impressed with (the West German) BMW,'' Petersen said. ``And the other company that impresses me is (France's) Peugeot. I think their cars are beautifully designed.'' Taking over for Petersen is Vice Chairman Harold Poling, who will be chairman for three years. Speculation is that Executive Vice President Alan Gilmour, who becomes president of the Ford Automotive Group on Thursday, will succeed Poling. During the next 18 months, General Motors Corp. Chairman Roger B. Smith and Chrysler Corp. Chairman Lee Iacocca also will step aside.

DOC.TEXT: A federal grand jury in Alaska is considering a five-count criminal indictment against Exxon Corp. stemming from last spring's oil spill in Prince William Sound, a government official said today. The information could not be confirmed. The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, had said at one point that an indictment had already been handed down. Later he explained that he had spoken prematurely after reading a draft Justice Department news release. David Runkel, spokesman for Atty. Gen. Richard Thornburgh, said no indictment had been returned. Thornburgh scheduled a late-afternoon news conference and aides said he was expected to discuss the Exxon case. Exxon officials said they would have no immediate comment. It was March 24, 1989 that the Exxon Valdez released 11 million gallons of oil in Prince William Sound, causing widespread environmental damage in the nation's worst oil spill.

DOC.HEAD: Delaware Supreme Court Affirms Directors Rights in Time-Warner-Paramount Case
DOC.TEXT: The Delaware Supreme Court, in a written decision resulting from last year's Time-Warner-Paramount takeover battle, on Tuesday affirmed the right of a board of directors to determine the future course of a company. The ruling came seven months after the state's highest court upheld a Chancery Court decision allowing Time Inc. to proceed with its $14 billion takeover of Warner Communications Inc. and barring Paramount Communications Inc. and Time stockholders from interfering with the deal. The case was heard in Delaware because all three companies _ like many of the biggest U.S. corporations _ are incorporated there, and is seen as likely to affect other future merger proposals. The plaintiffs had sought to force the Time board to consider Paramount's $12.2 billion bid, which would have given Time stockholders $200 a share in cash. But, Delaware's highest court said, ``A board of directors, while always required to act in an informed manner, is not under any per se duty to maximize shareholder value in the short-term even in the context of a takeover.'' In March 1989, Time and Warner announced plans to merge in a friendly exchange of stock. But in June, less than three weeks before shareholders were to vote on the deal, Paramount launched a hostile $10.7 billion bid that it later sweetened to $12.2 billion. Time and Warner countered by amending their plans to provide for Time's $14 billion tender offer for Warner. In Chancery Court in Delaware, Chancellor William T. Allen decided in favor of Time and Warner. The Supreme Court sustained Allen's ruling in an oral decision in late July, saying it would issue a written opinion in the future. Time and Warner completed their merger on Jan. 10. In his ruling, Allen gave corporate directors wider latitude in defending against unwanted takeover bids. While affirming his decision, the Supreme Court disagreed with his concern about Paramount's attempt to disrupt Time's long-range plans. ``We think it unwise to place undue emphasis upon long-term vs. short-term corporate strategy ... '' Justice Henry R. Horsey wrote in an 82-page decision. ``Directors generally are obliged to charter a course for a corporation which is in its best interest without regard to a fixed investment horizon,'' Horsey said. Paramount and Time shareholders contended that Time essentially put itself up for sale with its initial Warner merger agreement, partly on grounds that Warner shareholders at that time would have ended up holding more than 60 percent of the stock in Time Warner Inc. They argued that control of Time effectively would be transferred to the Warner shareholders and, under a 1986 Delaware Supreme Court ruling resulting from the takeover of Revlon Inc., the Time board should have considered the Paramount bid. But the Supreme Court agreed with Allen that the Time case did not meet the requirements of the Revlon case. Horsey cited ``the absence of any substantial evidence to conclude that Time's board, in negotiating with Warner, made the dissolution or breakup of the corporate entity inevitable, as was the case in Revlon.'' Revlon applies when a ``corporation initiates an active bidding process, seeking to sell itself or to effect a business reorganization involving a clear breakup of the company,'' Horsey wrote. The Revlon standards also apply when, ``in response to a bidder's offer, a target company abandons its long-term strategy and seeks an alternative stratey also involving the breakup of the company,'' he wrote, adding that neither of these scenarios applied to the Time case. The plaintiffs also contended that Time's tender offer for Warner put the company up for sale. But, Horsey wrote, the tender offer was a reasonable defensive response and not an abandonment of Time's continued existence. Paramount had sought to portray Time's tender offer as an unreasonable defense aimed at forcing the Time-Warner merger onto shareholders. The Supreme Court responded by giving directors more leeway in deciding whether an offer poses a threat to a company, its shareholders, workers or surrounding community. Horsey told the plaintiffs that a court cannot be involved in ``substituting its judgment for what is a `better' deal or that of a corporation's board of directors.'' He also said there was nothing to stop Paramount from pursuing the combined Time Warner Inc. The case also was heard by Justices Randy J. Holland and Andrew G.T. Moore II.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Extend Advance
With AM-Japan Markets Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices chalked up additional gains Tuesday amid improved investor confidence due to the market's strong performance in the aftermath of a rout in Tokyo. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which jumped 38.29 points on Monday, added another 14.64 to close at 2,617.12. Advancing issues outnumbered declining ones by about 5 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 927 up, 558 down and 496 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 152.59 million shares, up slightly from 148.91 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 181.33 million shares. Spirits on Wall Street had gotten a lift from the market's ability on Monday to cope calmly with Tokyo's troubles. Confidence was bolstered again Tuesday as the market managed to maintain its upward momentum. Hildegarde Zagorski, a market analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said stocks were ripe for a rebound, having been sold heavily before this week. ``I think what we're seeing here is a technical rebound,'' she said, noting that investors still are nervous about the consequences sluggish economic growth could have on corporate profits. A partial recovery earlier Tuesday in Tokyo after a key measure of the world's biggest equities market took its second-steepest one-day plunge ever on Monday also reassured U.S. investors. Investors, meanwhile, were reluctant to read too much significance into a tumble in orders to U.S. factories for durable goods. Stocks barely budged in response to the government report, market watchers said. The January drop of 10.5 percent, the biggest decline in 32 years of recordkeeping, was seen as further evidence of a weak manufacturing sector. However, analysts noted the orders are volatile and often subject to large revisions. American Express led the Big Board's list of actively traded stocks, slumping | to 28[ as more than 3.4 million shares changed hands. The selloff came after news that American Express will pump an additional $750 million into its Shearson Lehman Hutton Holdings unit after making a $250 million infusion in December. Pfizer regained 3[ to 59[ after running up losses Monday as a Congressional subcommittee began hearings on defective heart valves formerly manufactured by the company's Shiley unit. Securites analysts noted the panel didn't recommend a criminal investigation into Shiley. Among the active blue chips, International Business Machines lost \ to 103}, General Motors moved ahead by { to 45, American Telephone & Telegraph added { to 39|, General Electic was up } at 62 and Philip Morris fell [ to 37|. AMR, parent of American Airlines, gained altitude due to a favorable assessment by a Wall Street analyst. It rose 1 to 59{. Among other airline stocks, UAL, owner of United, jumped 2 to 128{. Several retail stocks had a strong day. Wal-Mart, which reported a 32 percent surge in fourth-quarter income, jumped 1] to 43\. Woolworth, which posted a 22 percent pickup in its fourth-quarter profit, rose } to 59]. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market gained $15.61 billion, or 0.49 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks ended 0.90 higher at 182.16. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 1.91 to 380.42, and S&P's 500-stock composite index went up 1.59 to 330.26. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 1.66 to 422.61. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 351.40, up 1.04.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures Prices Slip
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices fell Tuesday as a bid to extend the previous session's rally faltered late in the day. Analysts attributed the pullback to expectations that oil and unleaded gasoline inventories are growing, a recognition that prices of the benchmark grade of U.S. crude are high relative to those available on comparable grades overseas and to profit-taking following Monday's rally. The April contract for West Texas Intermediate, the key grade of U.S. crude oil, lost 21 cents to close at $21.58 a 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange after rising 37 cents a barrel on Monday. Later contracts also finished lower on Tuesday. Refined products traded on the New York Merc also fell. Unleaded regular gasoline for delivery in March, which slipped 0.02 cent a gallon Monday, dropped 2.27 cents to 57.56 cents a gallon. Later contracts had smaller losses. No. 2 heating oil for March delivery fell 0.89 cent a gallon, after rising 0.75 cent on Monday. Later contracts were down by smaller amounts. Tom Bentz, director of futures trading at United Energy Inc., said prices moved higher early in the session in an extension of Monday's move. But he said prices headed lower late in the session, led by unleaded gasoline prices. He said gasoline prices have been under pressure for several weeks because refiners have been building stocks at a time when demand is seasonally sluggish. He said stocks of unleaded gasoline are about 20 million gallons higher than they were a year ago. James Steel, energy analyst at the brokerage company Refco Inc., said gasoline stocks are ``more than adequate for this time of year.'' Steel said Tuesday's decline also reflected traders' realization that ``there was no firm fundamental reason for the market rising on Monday.'' He said West Texas Intermediate crude is also being viewed as overvalued relative to comparable grades of crude oil from the North Sea.

DOC.HEAD: Gasoline Futures Plunge On Supply Perceptions, Technical Weakness
DOC.TEXT: Gasoline futures prices were pummeled Tuesday on the New York Mercantile Exchange in a sell-off linked to perceptions of ample near-term supplies and strongly bearish chart signals. Other petroleum futures also retreated. On other commodity markets, silver futures led the precious metals lower; pork bellies were down the daily limit while cattle futures advanced; and grains and soybeans were mixed. Unleaded gasoline futures settled .80 cent to 2.27 cents lower with the contract for delivery in March down 2.27 cents at 57.56 cents a gallon. West Texas Intermediate crude oil finished 18 cents to 41 cents lower with April at $21.58 a barrel; heating oil was .06 cent to .89 cent lower with March at 58.16 cents a gallon. Energy futures were weak for much of the session amid perceptions of ample supplies of gasoline along the Gulf Coast and in the New York harbor, analysts said. Further selling stemmed from expectations the American Petroleum Institute would show a substantial increase in U.S. inventories of gasoline for the seventh week in a row, and from position-evening ahead of the expiration Wednesday of the March petroleum contracts. But the heaviest selling occurred late in the session after the March gasoline contract dropped below 59 cents a gallon, triggering waves of sell orders based purely on chart signals. ``When it got pushed down to the point where the technicals kicked in, then it was just a bloodbath,'' said Jerry Samuels, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. in New York. The weekly API inventory report, released after the close of trading, showed a 2.5-million-barrel rise in gasoline stocks last week, which was within market expectations. Crude oil inventories fell by a moderately surprising 2.9 million barrels, and U.S. supplies of petroleum distillates, including heating oil, fell 2.3 million barrels, a larger-than-expected drop. Silver futures fell to a 4{-month low on New York's Commodity Exchange but other precious metals posted only slight declines after steep losses Monday. Silver's weakness stemmed in part from the government's report of a record-large, 10.5 percent drop last month in orders to U.S. factories for durable goods, ``indicating again that the economy is not as strong as I think the Fed would like us to believe,'' said Anne Orton, a vice president of precious-metals dealer Deak International Inc. Silver, as an industrial metal, would suffer a greater drop in demand than gold or platinum in an economic slowdown, she said. Silver futures finished 7 cents to 7.3 cents lower with March at $5.075 a troy ounce, the lowest settlement of a silver futures contract in New York since Oct. 9. Gold futures finished 80 cents to $1.10 lower on the Comex with March at $408 a troy ounce. Platinum futures finished $1.30 to $1.80 lower on the New York Merc with April at $509.80 a troy ounce., Most frozen pork belly futures plunged the permitted 2-cents-a-pound daily limit on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in a technically inspired sell-off that erased nearly half of last week's gains. Hog futures weakened on spillover selling from the belly pit while cattle futures ended mostly higher on expectations for firmer cash markets. Live cattle futures settled .10 cent lower to .40 cent higher with April at 75.37 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .12 cent lower to .25 cent higher with March at 80 cents a pound; live hogs were .27 cent lower to .10 cent higher with April at 49.82 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.9 cents to 2 cents lower with March at 51.27 cents a pound. Grain and soybean futures prices closed narrowly mixed on the Chicago Board of Trade with the March wheat contract posting its first daily decline in a week. Wheat futures settled 2{ cents lower to 1 cent higher with March down 2 cents at $3.94\ a bushel; corn was 1 cent to 1{ cents lower with March at $2.45 a bushel; oats were unchanged to 1 cent lower with March at $1.36{ a bushel; soybeans were 1\ cents lower to 1 cent higher with March at $5.61{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Creditors Still Waiting to See New Proposal
DOC.TEXT: The holding company seeing Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. through Chapter 11 reorganizations wants to seek U.S. Bankruptcy Court approval for a plan to retain executives. Carol Sanger, a spokeswoman for Federated Stores Inc., holding company for the U.S. retailing operations of Toronto-based Campeau Corp., said Tuesday the proposal _ designed to keep executives from leaving to join rival retailers _ is still being developed. It would apply to ranks from senior management all the way down to middle-level executives in merchandising and similar jobs within the Federated and Allied store groups, Ms. Sanger said. She said the proposal may not be ready to be submitted at the next hearing scheduled March 15 before Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr., who is overseeing the Federated and Allied bankruptcy cases and must approve expenditures. But the proposal could be added to the agenda if it is completed. ``There's still plenty of time to add things to the calendar,'' Ms. Sanger said. She said the plan will consist of ``various performance and retention incentives and a reaffirmation of contracts and other benefits.'' She declined to be specific about whether salary increases or improved benefits might be offered. Lewis Rosenbloom, a lawyer for Federated's unsecured creditors, including major merchandise suppliers and factoring companies that serve as middlemen between suppliers and stores, said Federated has not made any details of its proposal available to the creditors. He said he did not know enough about the proposal to say whether the creditors would support it. ``We are told that the plan will be disclosed March 1 at a meeting in New York. It'll be the first opportunity we have to look at it,'' Rosenbloom said. ``I am aware of it. We have no details whatsoever.'' Rosenbloom said the creditors recognize the need to provide incentives designed to retain key managers from leaving to join other firms during the Chapter 11 reorganization. But he said the creditors would want part of the managers' compensation and benefits tied to emergence of Federated and Allied from Chapter 11 and to the ultimate dividend payable to unsecured creditors. Federated and Allied, both based in Cincinnati, filed their Chapter 11 petitions Jan. 15, listing a total of $7.7 billion in debts. The companies were saddled with the debt when Campeau purchased them in 1986 and 1988. The companies are developing reorganization plans while under Bankruptcy Court protection from creditors.

DOC.HEAD: B. Dalton Announces Chainwide Discount Program
DOC.TEXT: B. Dalton Bookseller on Tuesday said it plans a chainwide launch of a discount program aimed at regular book buyers. The announcement came a day after one of B. Dalton's major competitors, Waldenbooks, unveiled a new ``Preferred Reader'' program, which rewards frequent buyers with discounts and extra services. The B. Dalton ``Booksavers Club,'' which begins March 5, is similar to the Waldenbooks program. The company said in a news release it had launched the Booksavers Club in Dallas in 1988 and now would be offering it at all of its 800 stores around the country. Members in the B. Dalton club will be able to purchase membership cards for $10 entitling them to receive 10 percent discounts on all books bought for a year. A special $5 introductory price will be available during March. ``The `Booksavers Club' program will be supported by a mailing of specially produced custom catalogs to participating members,'' said Leonard Riggio, president and chief executive officer of the B. Dalton division of B.D.B. Inc. Riggio said in a news release the chain will be offering other in-store programs in the spring. Waldenbooks, owned by K mart Corp., said its program will start Friday. Among other elements, Waldenbooks also will offer 10 percent discounts to participants enrolling for $10 a year into the ``Preferred Reader'' program.

DOC.HEAD: Levi Strauss Income Jumps
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS lede CORRECT that $3.6 billion figure is full-year sales sted profit and be more specific on 4th-Qtr profit rise. Picks up 2nd graf, The parent ... INSERTS 2 grafs after 11th graf pvs, ``The year's ... to include details on Dockers sales and debt repayment. Picks up 12th graf pvs, ``We feel ...
DOC.TEXT: Levi Strauss Associates Inc., reporting results for the first time since going private in 1985, said Tuesday its profits rose nearly fivefold in its fourth quarter and more than doubled for its latest fiscal year as annual sales climbed to $3.6 billion. The parent company of Levi Strauss & Co., the world's largest brand-name clothing manufacturer, disclosed its results as it began issuing stock to employees. Levi Strauss said it earned $49.8 million in the fourth quarter on sales of $960 million for 1989, vs. $10.3 million on sales of $821.9 million for 1988. For the fiscal year ended last Nov. 26, the company's net income rose to $272.3 million from $111.9 million the year before. The 1989 income exceeds the record earnings of $223.7 million reported by the company's publicly held predecessor in 1980. Sales of $3.6 billion, which increased for the third straight year, rose 16 percent over $3.1 billion in 1988. Ninety percent of the company's stock is owned by about 100 shareholders, mostly from the Haas family, who took the company private. The company is beginning a stock savings plan in which it will match 50 percent of employees' savings. Levi Strauss said it expects employees to own up to 10 percent of the stock within five years. The company employs 31,000 worldwide. The company attributed its strong performance to higher margins on increased sales, the sale of a minority interest in the company's Japanese subsidiary and a lower effective tax rate. The pre-tax gain on the sale of the Japanese subsidiary's stock was $71.8 million. International sales increased 22 percent to $1.2 billion in 1989 and accounted for one-third of Levi's business. Domestic sales increased 14 percent to $2.4 billion. ``The year's results were achieved during a time of significant changes in the retail industry,'' said Robert D. Haas, chairman and chief executive officer. ``They reflect our success in focusing on our core jeans, jeans-related products and casual wear.'' A big reason for the booming sales was the success of the Dockers line of casual clothes, introduced in late 1986 and designed for aging baby boomers who have outgrown jeans. The total Dockers wear _ for men, women and, now, children _ accounted for nearly $400 million in sales in 1989, more than triple the $118 million of the year before. The company also said it had repaid most of the $1.6 billion debt from its leveraged buyout five years ago. It said it reduced its debt to $475 million. ``We feel we've been one of the most successful (leveraged buyouts),'' said George B. James, senior vice president and chief financial officer, who noted the company is seven years ahead of schedule on repayment of its buyout debt. ``Last year all our businesses were setting records. It was one of those years when nothing dragged us down, a satisfying, vintage year,'' he said. ``It was a good year to start our public reporting.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against the Japanese yen Tuesday, reaching an eight-month high despite intervention by central banks, while closing mixed against other currencies. Gold prices fell. Republic National Bank of New York quoted a bid for gold at $408.25 a troy ounce as of 4 p.m. EST, down 25 cents from late Monday. Thomas Palladino, a trader with Amsterdam Rotterdam Bank in New York, said the Federal Reserve sold dollars in New York an attempt to drive down the currency's value against the yen when the dollar reached the 148.80 to 148.85 yen level. He said the intervention appeared to have little effect. Earlier, the Bank of Japan tried to stem the dollar's rise against the yen in the Tokyo market. On Monday, both central banks likewise sold dollars, but the currency reached an eight-month high against the yen despite the intervention. The dollar rose Tuesday to 148.73 yen in late trading in New York. The dollar has not closed that high against the yen since June 15, when it reached 151.30 yen. Traders said U.S. currency softened a bit in the morning after the Commerce Department reported that orders to U.S. factories for durable goods plunged 10.5 percent in January, the biggest decline since orders first were tracked 32 years ago. But the dollar soon regained its strength, Palladino said. ``It really was a nothing trading day,'' said Bob Morrissey, a trader for Bank of Boston. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 149.03 yen from 148.65 yen at Monday's close. Later, in London, it slipped to 148.57 yen. The dollar was mixed against the British pound. In London, the pound traded at $1.6915 late Tuesday, cheaper than $1.6927 late Monday. In New York, the pound cost $1.6908, more than the $1.6903 of late Monday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Monday, included: 1.6880 West German marks, down marginally from 1.6882; 1.4840 Swiss francs, down from 1.4860; 5.7150 French francs, up from 5.7140; 1,248.75 Italian lire, up from 1,248.50; and 1.1938 Canadian dollars, down from 1.19405. Late rates in Europe, compared with late Monday's prices, included: 1.4857 Swiss francs, down from 1.4865; 5.7010 French francs, down from 5.7205; 1.8985 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9023; 1,245.25 Italian lire, down from 1,250.25; and 1.1908 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1975. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold for curent delivery dropped 70 cents an ounce to $408. Earlier, Gold traded in London at a late bid price of $407.25 a troy ounce, down from $411.75 bid late Monday. In Zurich, the bid price was $411.25, unchanged from late Monday. In Hong Kong, gold fell $4.30 to close at a bid $407.85. Silver bullion closed in London at a bid price of $5.11 a troy ounce, down from Monday's $5.23. In New York, silver for current delivery fell to $5.075 an ounce from $5.147 Monday on the Commodity Exchange.
